name: Conotruncal heart defect
description: Cardiac malformations occur in 75% of patients, most commonly tetralogy of Fallot, interrupted aortic arch type B, ventricular septal defect, and truncus arteriosus.

name: Hypocalcemia

name: Lung Adenocarcinoma
description: ALK-rearranged NSCLC is almost exclusively adenocarcinoma histology, often with signet ring or cribriform patterns. Typically presents in younger patients.

name: Young Age at Diagnosis
description: ALK-positive patients are typically younger than other NSCLC patients (median age ~50s vs 70s). This reflects the different carcinogenic pathway (driver mutation vs smoking-related).

name: Never/Light Smoker
description: Like EGFR-mutant NSCLC, ALK-rearranged tumors occur predominantly in never-smokers or light smokers.

name: Brain Metastases
description: High propensity for brain metastases, occurring in up to 50-60% of patients during disease course. CNS-penetrant ALK TKIs (alectinib, lorlatinib) have dramatically improved CNS outcomes.

name: Pancytopenia
description: Reduction in all blood cell lines due to bone marrow replacement and consumptive coagulopathy.

name: Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation
description: Consumptive coagulopathy with simultaneous bleeding and microvascular thrombosis. Characterized by prolonged PT/PTT, elevated D-dimer, decreased fibrinogen, and thrombocytopenia. Life-threatening complication.

name: Abnormal Bleeding
description: Severe bleeding from coagulopathy including mucosal hemorrhage, epistaxis, gingival bleeding, and potentially fatal intracranial or pulmonary hemorrhage. Leading cause of early death.

name: Peripheral Neuropathy
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Peripheral Neuropathy"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that peripheral neuropathy is a common complication of amyloidoses, which includes ATTR amyloidosis.", "reference": "PMID:23239211", "snippet": "Peripheral neuropathy is a common complication of many of the systemic amyloidoses.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study indicates that peripheral neuropathy, including sensory and motor disorders, is a frequent manifestation in patients with the TTR Val30Leu mutation, a form of familial amyloid polyneuropathy.", "reference": "PMID:35830843", "snippet": "The clinical manifestations of this mutation involve mainly limb sensory or motor disorders or gastrointestinal symptoms or both, and the electrophysiological examination shows neurogenic damage.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature confirms that hATTR amyloidosis frequently involves polyneuropathy, including sensory loss, numbness, tingling, and autonomic dysfunction.", "reference": "PMID:31445300", "snippet": "Hereditary transthyretin-mediated amyloidosis (hATTR amyloidosis) is a rare, life-threatening disease, caused by point mutations in the transthyretin gene. It is a heterogeneous, multisystem disease with rapidly progressing polyneuropathy (including sensory, motor, and autonomic impairments) and cardiac dysfunction.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study suggests that autonomic dysfunction is a common complication in small-fiber neuropathy, which can be seen in conditions like amyloidosis.", "reference": "PMID:36504143", "snippet": "Autonomic dysfunction is a common complication of small-fiber neuropathy (SFN).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Peripheral Neuropathy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Peripheral Neuropathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0009830", "label": "Peripheral neuropathy"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Sensory Loss"}, {"target": "Numbness and Tingling"}, {"target": "Autonomic Dysfunction"}]}

name: Cardiomyopathy
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Cardiomyopathy"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference discusses the increased recognition and diagnosis of ATTR cardiac amyloidosis, supporting the statement that it is frequently diagnosed as a cardiovascular condition.", "reference": "PMID:34694575", "snippet": "The hereditary forms of ATTR have further come into importance with the availability of genetic testing and increased prevalence of certain mutations in African Americans.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by listing heart failure, arrhythmias, and autonomic dysfunction (which includes orthostatic hypotension) as common sequelae of cardiac amyloidosis.", "reference": "PMID:35235819", "snippet": "Cardiac amyloidosis (CA) results in symptoms of heart failure, atrial and ventricular arrhythmias, conduction disturbances, and profound autonomic dysfunction.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the frequent occurrence of cardiovascular manifestations in ATTR amyloidosis, including cardiomyopathy and arrhythmias.", "reference": "PMID:38044190", "snippet": "Patients with TTRA had higher levels of ultrasensitive troponin I (TnI-US) and N-terminal brain natriuretic propeptide (NT-ProBNP); in electrocardiography (ECG) they presented a pseudo-infarction pattern more frequently as well as conduction disturbances.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by describing the involvement of the myocardium (cardiomyopathy) and the frequent occurrence of cardiovascular symptoms in cardiac amyloidosis.", "reference": "PMID:29770800", "snippet": "Cardiac amyloidosis (CA) comprises a heterogeneous group of medical conditions affecting the myocardium. It presents with proteinaceous infiltration with variable degrees of severity, prevalence and evolution.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by describing heart failure as a frequent sequela of ATTR amyloidosis.", "reference": "PMID:38844297", "snippet": "Cardiac amyloidosis (CA), usually caused by deposition of misfolded transthyretin or immunoglobulin light chains, is an increasingly recognized cause of heart failure burdened by a poor prognosis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Cardiomyopathy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Cardiomyopathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0001638", "label": "Cardiomyopathy"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Heart Failure"}, {"target": "Arrhythmias"}, {"target": "Orthostatic Hypotension"}]}

name: Gastrointestinal Symptoms
notes: Include nausea, diarrhea, constipation, and weight loss
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Gastrointestinal Symptoms", "notes": "Include nausea, diarrhea, constipation, and weight loss"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study highlights that gastrointestinal manifestations are common in hereditary ATTR amyloidosis, supporting the statement that gastrointestinal symptoms are frequent in this condition.", "reference": "PMID:25908211", "snippet": "Gastrointestinal manifestations are common in hereditary ATTR amyloidosis and are important for the patients' morbidity and mortality.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the frequency of gastrointestinal symptoms in ATTR amyloidosis, aligning with the statement.", "reference": "PMID:32176096", "snippet": "Transthyretin amyloid (ATTR) amyloidosis is a rare systemic disorder characterized by amyloid deposits formed by misfolded monomers of the transthyretin. Gastrointestinal (GI) manifestations are common in ATTR amyloidosis; however, their pathogenesis is not fully elucidated.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Although it mentions that GI symptoms are uncommon in the early stages, it describes a case with significant GI involvement, supporting the statement about frequent GI symptoms in later stages.", "reference": "PMID:37844979", "snippet": "In the early stages of amyloidosis, gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms are uncommon. We describe a rare case of hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis (ATTRv) with involvement of the heart, nervous system and GI tract.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference mentions gastrointestinal symptoms but does not specifically focus on ATTR amyloidosis. It partially supports the statement by acknowledging the presence of GI symptoms in amyloidosis in general.", "reference": "PMID:8115892", "snippet": "Gastrointestinal symptoms included anorexia, macroglossia, intestinal pseudo-obstruction, and altered bowel habits.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference is focused on diabetes mellitus and does not provide evidence related to ATTR amyloidosis.", "reference": "PMID:6402969", "snippet": "Gastrointestinal symptoms such as vomiting, constipation, diarrhea, and fecal incontinence occur frequently in patients with diabetes mellitus.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Gastrointestinal Symptoms", "notes": "Include nausea, diarrhea, constipation, and weight loss"}

name: Vitreous Opacities
notes: Can lead to visual impairment
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ocular", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Vitreous Opacities", "notes": "Can lead to visual impairment"}
raw_json: {"category": "Ocular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference provides evidence that vitreous opacities can be an initial manifestation in patients with hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis (ATTR Val30Met), supporting the statement that vitreous opacities occur occasionally in ATTR amyloidosis.", "reference": "PMID:28085522", "snippet": "We report on two elderly patients (an 80-year-old woman and an 83-year-old man) with progressive vitreous opacities (VOs) as the initial manifestation of hereditary transthyretin (ATTR Val30Met) carries, who had no evidence of systemic involvement or family history of amyloidosis and lived in non-endemic areas.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference indicates that vitreous opacities were observed and worsened in some patients with ATTR amyloidosis, supporting the statement that vitreous opacities can occur occasionally in ATTR amyloidosis and lead to visual impairment.", "reference": "PMID:36129270", "snippet": "However, 3 patients (43%) had worsening vitreous opacities in both eyes, and 4 patients (57%) developed secondary open-angle glaucoma.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Vitreous Opacities", "notes": "Can lead to visual impairment", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Vitreous Opacities", "term": {"id": "HP:0007710", "label": "Peripheral vitreous opacities"}}}

name: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
notes: Due to amyloid deposition in the wrist
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Carpal Tunnel Syndrome", "notes": "Due to amyloid deposition in the wrist"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The article states that ATTR amyloid deposits in the carpal tunnel tissue can cause carpal tunnel syndrome, supporting the statement that ATTR amyloidosis can occasionally cause this musculoskeletal condition.", "reference": "PMID:30404120", "snippet": "One cause for a carpal tunnel syndrome is transthyretin (ATTR) amyloid, which deposits in the carpal tunnel tissue.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The article mentions carpal tunnel syndrome as a common orthopedic manifestation of amyloidosis, supporting the statement that ATTR amyloidosis can occasionally cause this condition due to amyloid deposition in the wrist.", "reference": "PMID:33443391", "snippet": "Common orthopaedic manifestations of amyloidosis include carpal tunnel syndrome, trigger finger, spontaneous distal biceps tendon rupture, rotator cuff disease, and lumbar spinal stenosis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Carpal Tunnel Syndrome", "notes": "Due to amyloid deposition in the wrist"}

name: Renal Dysfunction
notes: Due to amyloid deposition in the kidneys, can lead to proteinuria and renal failure
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Genitourinary", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Renal Dysfunction", "notes": "Due to amyloid deposition in the kidneys, can lead to proteinuria and renal failure"}
raw_json: {"category": "Genitourinary", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference confirms that renal dysfunction, including proteinuria, is a clinical feature of transthyretin amyloidosis (ATTR).", "reference": "PMID:22537653", "snippet": "Peripheral neuropathy and cardiomyopathy are broadly described, and insights into disease reveal that kidney impairment and proteinuria are also clinical features.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the statement by indicating that chronic kidney disease, which encompasses renal dysfunction, is commonly associated with transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis (ATTR-CA).", "reference": "PMID:37997196", "snippet": "Transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis (ATTR-CA) is an infiltrative cardiomyopathy that commonly presents with concomitant chronic kidney disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Renal Dysfunction", "notes": "Due to amyloid deposition in the kidneys, can lead to proteinuria and renal failure", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Renal insufficiency", "term": {"id": "HP:0000083", "label": "Renal insufficiency"}}}

name: Fatigue
notes: Can be severe and limit activities of daily living
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue", "notes": "Can be severe and limit activities of daily living"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that systemic amyloidosis, including ATTR, frequently impacts daily life and mobility, which can be associated with fatigue.", "reference": "PMID:35144512", "snippet": "Patients often reported problems with mobility, usual activities, pain/discomfort and anxiety/depression, but not with self-care.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature describes ATTR amyloidosis as a multisystem disease, which can imply the presence of fatigue due to its systemic impact.", "reference": "PMID:31445300", "snippet": "It is a heterogeneous, multisystem disease with rapidly progressing polyneuropathy (including sensory, motor, and autonomic impairments) and cardiac dysfunction.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The progressive loss of function in various organs and tissues can lead to severe fatigue, limiting activities of daily living.", "reference": "PMID:33609196", "snippet": "Amyloid transthyretin (ATTR) amyloidosis is a clinically heterogeneous and fatal disease that results from deposition of insoluble amyloid fibrils in various organs and tissues, causing progressive loss of function.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The systemic nature of ATTR amyloidosis affecting multiple organs can contribute to fatigue.", "reference": "PMID:35128833", "snippet": "Amyloidosis is a severe and fatal systemic disease, characterized by an accumulation of amyloid fibrils in various tissues/organs, including nerves, kidneys, gastrointestinal tract, and heart.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue", "notes": "Can be severe and limit activities of daily living", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fatigue", "term": {"id": "HP:0012378", "label": "Fatigue"}}}

name: Light-Triggered Sneezing
description: Uncontrollable sneezing provoked by sudden exposure to bright light, typically occurring within seconds of light exposure.
notes: Core diagnostic feature
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "description": "Uncontrollable sneezing provoked by sudden exposure to bright light, typically occurring within seconds of light exposure.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "OBLIGATE", "name": "Light-Triggered Sneezing", "notes": "Core diagnostic feature"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "description": "Uncontrollable sneezing provoked by sudden exposure to bright light, typically occurring within seconds of light exposure.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Light-triggered sneezing is the defining feature of the syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:30899065", "snippet": "Photic sneeze reflex (PSR) is an interesting but yet mysterious phenotype featured by individuals' response of sneezing in exposure to bright light.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OBLIGATE", "name": "Light-Triggered Sneezing", "notes": "Core diagnostic feature"}

name: Nasal Prickle
description: Subjective nasal tickling or prickle sensation preceding the sneeze, occurring without detectable peripheral nasal electrical activity.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "description": "Subjective nasal tickling or prickle sensation preceding the sneeze, occurring without detectable peripheral nasal electrical activity.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Nasal Prickle"}

name: Migraine
description: Increased odds of migraine in individuals with photic sneeze syndrome.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "description": "Increased odds of migraine in individuals with photic sneeze syndrome.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Migraine"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "description": "Increased odds of migraine in individuals with photic sneeze syndrome.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Strong statistical association between photic sneeze syndrome and migraine.", "reference": "PMID:31287245", "snippet": "Individuals with PSS were more likely to suffer from migraine (odds ratio = 1.97, P = 2.18  10-9 )", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Migraine", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Migraine", "term": {"id": "HP:0002076", "label": "Migraine"}}}

name: Psychological Distress
description: Elevated psychological distress scores observed in some individuals with photic sneeze syndrome.

name: Photophobia
description: Light sensitivity or intolerance to bright light, sharing trigeminal nerve involvement with the photic sneeze reflex.
notes: Both photophobia and PSS involve trigeminal nerve activation in response to light stimuli.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "description": "Light sensitivity or intolerance to bright light, sharing trigeminal nerve involvement with the photic sneeze reflex.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Photophobia", "notes": "Both photophobia and PSS involve trigeminal nerve activation in response to light stimuli."}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "description": "Light sensitivity or intolerance to bright light, sharing trigeminal nerve involvement with the photic sneeze reflex.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Photophobia and photic sneeze syndrome share trigeminal nerve involvement.", "reference": "PMID:31287245", "snippet": "intolerance to light, commonly known as photophobia, is thought to result from light-induced activation of the trigeminal nerve system", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Photophobia", "notes": "Both photophobia and PSS involve trigeminal nerve activation in response to light stimuli.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Photophobia", "term": {"id": "HP:0000613", "label": "Photophobia"}}}

name: Comedones
description: Non-inflammatory lesions including open comedones (blackheads) and closed comedones (whiteheads) resulting from follicular plugging.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Non-inflammatory lesions including open comedones (blackheads) and closed comedones (whiteheads) resulting from follicular plugging.\n", "name": "Comedones"}
raw_json: {"description": "Non-inflammatory lesions including open comedones (blackheads) and closed comedones (whiteheads) resulting from follicular plugging.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This review discusses the role of comedones as a key lesion type in acne pathogenesis.", "reference": "PMID:24062871", "snippet": "evidence has emerged supporting a role for inflammation at all stages of acne lesion development, perhaps subclinically even before comedo formation", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Comedones", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "comedonal acne", "term": {"id": "HP:0040137", "label": "Comedonal acne"}}}

name: Inflammatory papules
description: Small, raised, erythematous lesions resulting from inflammation around occluded follicles.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Small, raised, erythematous lesions resulting from inflammation around occluded follicles.\n", "name": "Inflammatory papules"}
raw_json: {"description": "Small, raised, erythematous lesions resulting from inflammation around occluded follicles.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This review describes the progression from comedones to inflammatory papules in acne lesion development.", "reference": "PMID:24062871", "snippet": "the progression from a so-called noninflammatory comedo to an inflammatory papule, pustule, or nodule", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Inflammatory papules", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "erythematous papule", "term": {"id": "HP:0030350", "label": "Erythematous papule"}}}

name: Pustules
description: Inflamed lesions containing purulent material, representing more advanced inflammatory response.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Inflamed lesions containing purulent material, representing more advanced inflammatory response.\n", "name": "Pustules"}
raw_json: {"description": "Inflamed lesions containing purulent material, representing more advanced inflammatory response.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This review identifies pustular eruptions on the face as a characteristic feature of acne vulgaris.", "reference": "PMID:12113648", "snippet": "Localized pustular eruptions are seen on the hands and feet in adults with pustulosis palmaris et plantaris and acrodermatitis continua (both of which may be variants of psoriasis); on the face in patients with acne vulgaris, rosacea, and perioral dermatitis", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Pustules", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "pustule", "term": {"id": "HP:0200039", "label": "Pustule"}}}

name: Nodules and cysts
description: Deep, painful lesions representing severe inflammatory acne with potential for scarring.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Deep, painful lesions representing severe inflammatory acne with potential for scarring.\n", "name": "Nodules and cysts"}
raw_json: {"description": "Deep, painful lesions representing severe inflammatory acne with potential for scarring.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This review defines severe nodular acne as characterized by nodules and cysts with associated inflammation and scarring potential.", "reference": "PMID:21062102", "snippet": "Severe nodular acne, defined as grade 4 or 5 acne on the Investigator's Static Global Assessment scale, is a skin condition characterized by intense erythema, inflammation, nodules, cysts, and scarring.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Nodules and cysts", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "cystic acne", "term": {"id": "HP:0033188", "label": "Cystic acne"}}}

name: Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation
description: Darkening of skin at sites of resolved acne lesions, particularly common in individuals with darker skin tones. This sequela results from inflammatory damage to melanocytes and is a common concern in patients with skin of color.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Darkening of skin at sites of resolved acne lesions, particularly common in individuals with darker skin tones. This sequela results from inflammatory damage to melanocytes and is a common concern in patients with skin of color.\n", "name": "Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation"}
raw_json: {"description": "Darkening of skin at sites of resolved acne lesions, particularly common in individuals with darker skin tones. This sequela results from inflammatory damage to melanocytes and is a common concern in patients with skin of color.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This paper specifically describes the pathogenesis of acne-induced post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation through excess melanin production.", "reference": "PMID:34468934", "snippet": "the inflammatory processes of acne stimulate excess melanogenesis and abnormal melanin deposition, leading to pigmentary sequelae known as post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "hyperpigmentation of the skin", "term": {"id": "HP:0000953", "label": "Hyperpigmentation of the skin"}}}

name: Scarring
description: Permanent textural changes including atrophic (ice pick, boxcar, rolling) and hypertrophic scars resulting from severe or inadequately treated acne.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Permanent textural changes including atrophic (ice pick, boxcar, rolling) and hypertrophic scars resulting from severe or inadequately treated acne.\n", "name": "Scarring"}
raw_json: {"description": "Permanent textural changes including atrophic (ice pick, boxcar, rolling) and hypertrophic scars resulting from severe or inadequately treated acne.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This review confirms atrophic scars as the most common type of acne scarring.", "reference": "PMID:29344322", "snippet": "This review focuses on atrophic scars, the most common type of acne scar.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Scarring", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "atrophic scars", "term": {"id": "HP:0001075", "label": "Atrophic scars"}}}

name: Pneumocystis Pneumonia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Infectious", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Pneumocystis Pneumonia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Infectious", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference indicates that Pneumocystis pneumonia is a common phenotype associated with Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS).", "reference": "PMID:1979021", "snippet": "The occurrence of unusual infections, in particular Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the presence of Pneumocystis pneumonia as a common infection among HIV-infected patients.", "reference": "PMID:33612763", "snippet": "Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) and pulmonary tuberculosis infection (PTB) are important opportunistic infections in HIV-infected patients.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the statement by indicating that Pneumocystis pneumonia is an important AIDS-defining illness.", "reference": "PMID:16182595", "snippet": "Pulmonary infection caused by the opportunistic fungal organism Pneumocystis continues to be a leading AIDS defining illness.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference suggests that Pneumocystis pneumonia is a common respiratory infection in HIV-infected individuals.", "reference": "PMID:38110260", "snippet": "...consistent use of Pneumocystis prophylaxis in all HIV exposed/infected children under 5 years of age has considerably reduced associated infections overall and respiratory infections in particular.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the statement by listing Pneumocystis pneumonia as a classic clinical marker for HIV infection progression.", "reference": "PMID:7915731", "snippet": "The nature of the clinical presentation of HIV infection continues to evolve over time....Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia...can now be added to the classic clinical markers for progressive HIV infection.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Pneumocystis Pneumonia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia", "term": {"id": "HP:0020102", "label": "Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia"}}}

name: Candidiasis
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Infectious", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Candidiasis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Infectious", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference details multiple forms of candidiasis affecting the mouth, including acute atrophic, chronic atrophic, and chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis, and indicates that it is common.", "reference": "PMID:6496525", "snippet": "Candidiasis is, by far, the most common mycotic infection of the human oral cavity... Extensive use of antibiotics and immunosuppressive drugs have greatly increased the number of Candida-induced oral infections.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Candidiasis is highlighted as a frequent and significant infection among AIDS patients.", "reference": "PMID:17944709", "snippet": "Invasive fungal infections (IFIs) have become a major cause of morbidity and mortality among people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS)... Candida albicans accounted for 57.4% of fungal pathogens isolated.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study indicates a significant occurrence of esophageal candidiasis among AIDS patients.", "reference": "PMID:2135639", "snippet": "Esophageal candidiasis was reported in one fifth of the patients and were reported twice as often in women as in homosexual men.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference, although brief, provides context for candidiasis as an infectious condition relevant to AIDS.", "reference": "PMID:11363911", "snippet": "Candidiasis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Candidiasis is cited here in the context of oral candidiasis and its prevalence among HIV-infected patients.", "reference": "PMID:15627906", "snippet": "an oral examination was carried out on a group of 200 HIV-infected patients...  ...Of the 86 (54.8%) patients with OC, 48.2% progressed to AIDS...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Candidiasis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Recurrent candida infections", "term": {"id": "HP:0005401", "label": "Recurrent candida infections"}}}

name: Kaposi Sarcoma
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neoplastic", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Kaposi Sarcoma"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neoplastic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract confirms that Kaposi's Sarcoma is commonly associated with AIDS, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:2661499", "snippet": "One manifestation of this disease is Kaposi's Sarcoma. Usually a rare tumor, it occurs with a high incidence in patients with AIDS.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "KS is explicitly linked with HIV/AIDS in this case report, supporting the association.", "reference": "PMID:29660143", "snippet": "Kaposi sarcoma is an oligoclonal HHV-8-driven vascular proliferation... We report a 52-year-old Caucasian man with HIV/AIDS and Kaposi sarcoma.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Kaposi's sarcoma cited as a marker for AIDS progression supports the statement.", "reference": "PMID:7915731", "snippet": "New cutaneous (e.g., seborrheic dermatitis, onychomycosis, and tinea pedis) and systemic... markers for progressive HIV infection, such as Kaposi's sarcoma...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Although KS is not explicitly mentioned, malignancies associated with AIDS are noted, supporting the general assertion.", "reference": "PMID:35227156", "snippet": "Delayed or missed diagnosis of HIV infection leads to a lack of timely therapy, resulting in rapid disease progression with opportunistic infections or malignancies.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "KS is listed among the reactive and neoplastic proliferative disorders associated with AIDS.", "reference": "PMID:9023448", "snippet": "These disorders include nodal and extranodal lymphoproliferative lesions... smooth muscle tumors (SMTs), Kaposi's sarcoma...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Kaposi Sarcoma", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Kaposi's sarcoma", "term": {"id": "HP:0100726", "label": "Kaposi's sarcoma"}}}

name: HIV-associated Dementia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "HIV-associated Dementia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This study provides evidence that HIV-associated dementia is a neurologic manifestation seen in AIDS patients.", "reference": "PMID:9144008", "snippet": "Of 1854 HIV-1 carriers, 578 had acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) and 166 (28.7% of AIDS patients) had neurologic manifestations including HIV dementia (11.8%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This paper supports the occurrence of HIV-associated dementia as a neurologic manifestation of AIDS.", "reference": "PMID:1493145", "snippet": "Psychiatric manifestations that are the direct result of HIV infection are usually seen in the setting of HIV-associated dementia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference elaborates on AIDS dementia complex, confirming its association with AIDS.", "reference": "PMID:2548429", "snippet": "The acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) dementia complex is a frequent and devastating complication of infection with human immunodeficiency virus-type 1 (HIV-1).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "HIV-associated Dementia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Cognitive impairment", "term": {"id": "HP:0100543", "label": "Cognitive impairment"}}}

name: Lymphopenia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Lymphopenia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Lymphopenia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Decreased total lymphocyte count", "term": {"id": "HP:0001888", "label": "Decreased total lymphocyte count"}}}

name: Anemia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Anemia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study found that 66.1% of the patients with HIV/AIDS were anemic, indicating anemia is a common hematologic disorder in these patients.", "reference": "PMID:33475545", "snippet": "Anaemia was a common finding among human immune deficiency virus / acquired immunodeficiency syndrome patients.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract discusses the commonality of anemia in HIV patients, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:9671334", "snippet": "Anemia is common in patients infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Out of 12 patients with AIDS, 10 were anemic, supporting the prevalence of anemia in individuals with AIDS.", "reference": "PMID:6465173", "snippet": "Ten patients were anemic, eight leukopenic, and three thrombocytopenic.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study highlights a significant prevalence of anemia in patients with AIDS, especially those with disseminated Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare (MAI) infection.", "reference": "PMID:2252248", "snippet": "Anemia was significantly more profound in patients with AIDS and MAI than in the other patients.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Anemia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Anemia", "term": {"id": "HP:0001903", "label": "Anemia"}}}

name: Fatigue
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Endocrine", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue"}
raw_json: {"category": "Endocrine", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that fatigue is a typical feature of adrenal insufficiency, which includes Addison's Disease.", "reference": "PMID:8325289", "snippet": "A constellation of nonspecific symptoms including weakness, easy fatigue, nausea, anorexia, and weight loss are typical features of adrenal insufficiency.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature supports that fatigue is a symptom of Addison's Disease.", "reference": "PMID:21365946", "snippet": "We present the case of a 33-year-old female with generalized pain in the musculoskeletal system, fatigue, and many other symptoms.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature supports that fatigue is a symptom of Addison's Disease.", "reference": "PMID:31791082", "snippet": "We report the case within a 22-year-old patient, initially seen because of fatigue, weight loss and discoloration of the skin.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fatigue", "term": {"id": "HP:0012378", "label": "Fatigue"}}}

name: Abdominal Pain
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Abdominal Pain"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference clearly indicates that patients with Addison's disease frequently present with severe gastrointestinal symptoms, including abdominal pain.", "reference": "PMID:2801683", "snippet": "Eight had severe or unusual gastrointestinal symptoms at presentation. One, already known to have Addison's disease, required several admissions to the hospital because of unexplained abdominal pain and vomiting before inadequate glucocorticoid replacement was diagnosed.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference discusses the frequency of non-specific abdominal complaints, which are common in various conditions, including Addison's disease.", "reference": "PMID:3044463", "snippet": "Non-specific abdominal complaints are a very frequent cause of discomfort. Even if only comparatively few are brought to the attention of the physician, they account for a considerable portion of the reasons for seeking medical care, both in acute and chronic conditions.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference indicates that generalized pain, including abdominal pain, was a symptom in a patient with Addison's disease.", "reference": "PMID:21365946", "snippet": "She was initially diagnosed with fibromyalgia but other tests finally confirmed Addison's disease. Supplementation with adrenal hormones resulted in total remission of pain and of other symptoms.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Abdominal Pain", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abdominal pain", "term": {"id": "HP:0002027", "label": "Abdominal pain"}}}

name: Hyperpigmentation
notes: Especially noticeable in areas exposed to friction, such as knuckles, elbows, and knees.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Endocrine", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hyperpigmentation", "notes": "Especially noticeable in areas exposed to friction, such as knuckles, elbows, and knees."}
raw_json: {"category": "Endocrine", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The title directly indicates that hyperpigmentation is associated with Addison's Disease.", "reference": "PMID:33951364", "snippet": "Hyperpigmentation from Addison's Disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract mentions hyperpigmentation as a clinical finding in a patient with Addison's disease.", "reference": "PMID:21219212", "snippet": "The physical examination was completely normal except for muscle weakness, hyperpigmentation on labial mucosa and skin in a patient.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study found increased skin pigmentation in a significant number of children with Addison's disease.", "reference": "PMID:33143829", "snippet": "Increased skin pigmentation was observed in 45 children with other identifiable features including weight loss, lethargy, and poor response in activities.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The case report highlights hyperpigmentation as a symptom of Addison's disease caused by tuberculosis.", "reference": "PMID:28717080", "snippet": "Addison's disease caused by tuberculosis characterized by atypical hyperpigmentation, noted as exacerbation of the pigmentation of freckles and the occurrence of new freckles.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract mentions hyperpigmentation in a patient initially diagnosed with Addison's disease.", "reference": "PMID:34932395", "snippet": "We report the case of a 47-year-old male patient with pigmentation of the head, face and hands, who was initially diagnosed as having primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hyperpigmentation", "notes": "Especially noticeable in areas exposed to friction, such as knuckles, elbows, and knees.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hyperpigmentation", "term": {"id": "HP:0000953", "label": "Hyperpigmentation of the skin"}}}

name: Muscle Weakness
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Muscle Weakness"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This case report describes muscle weakness as a clinical presentation of Addison's disease.", "reference": "PMID:36210660", "snippet": "His clinical presentation was due to hyperkalemia and weakness due to Addison's disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference discusses acute muscle weakness as a common disorder, implying that muscle weakness can be a frequent symptom in various conditions, including Addison's disease.", "reference": "PMID:23897142", "snippet": "Acute muscle weakness, a common disorder in pediatrics, can occur from impairment of any part of the motor unit, including the upper motor neuron, lower motor neuron, peripheral nerve, neuromuscular junction or muscle.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This case report mentions muscle pain and weakness that were misdiagnosed as fibromyalgia but were actually due to Addison's disease, which resolved with appropriate treatment.", "reference": "PMID:21365946", "snippet": "Supplementation with adrenal hormones resulted in total remission of pain and of other symptoms.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Muscle Weakness", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Muscle weakness", "term": {"id": "HP:0001324", "label": "Muscle weakness"}}}

name: Weight Loss
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Weight Loss"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference clearly states that weight loss is a presenting symptom of Addison's disease.", "reference": "PMID:13280719", "snippet": "Addison's disease presenting as loss of weight without pigmentation.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature identifies weight loss as a common feature of Addison's disease.", "reference": "PMID:23893277", "snippet": "Addison's disease is a relatively rare endocrine condition resulting from adrenal insufficiency due to various causes. Weight loss is a common feature.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference describes weight loss as one of the presenting symptoms in a patient with Addison's disease.", "reference": "PMID:31791082", "snippet": "We report the case within a 22-year-old patient, initially seen because of fatigue, weight loss and discoloration of the skin.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study reports weight loss in 25% of Addison's disease patients, supporting the statement that it is a frequent symptom.", "reference": "PMID:23308244", "snippet": "Hyperpigmentation was observed in 76%, nausea and vomiting occurred in more than 40%, and weight loss was noted in 25%.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Weight Loss", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Weight loss", "term": {"id": "HP:0001824", "label": "Weight loss"}}}

name: Hypotension
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hypotension"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference clearly states that chronic hypotension can be linked to adrenal failure, which is a characteristic of Addison's disease.", "reference": "PMID:22975403", "snippet": "Hypotension is defined by a low blood pressure either permanently or only in upright posture (orthostatic hypotension). ... Chronic hypotension from endocrine origin may be linked to adrenal failure from adrenal or central origin", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference indicates that hypotension is a symptom of Addisonian crisis, which is part of Addison's disease.", "reference": "PMID:27992012", "snippet": "Addisonian crisis is a difficult diagnosis due to the unspecificity of its signs and symptoms. Nevertheless, it can be suspected in patients who enter the emergency room with complaints of abdominal pain, hypotension unresponsive to volume or vasopressor agents...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference mentions hypotension in a patient diagnosed with Addison's disease, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:36709280", "snippet": "We reported a 51-year-old male patient with unstable angina pectoris and hypotension. Changes on coronary angiography within 2 years suggested rapid progression of coronary artery disease in a patient with low cardiovascular risk. An additional clue of skin hyperpigmentation, fatigue and further examination confirmed the diagnosis of Addison's disease...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hypotension", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypotension", "term": {"id": "HP:0002615", "label": "Hypotension"}}}

name: Salt Craving
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Endocrine", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Salt Craving"}
raw_json: {"category": "Endocrine", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature explicitly mentions salt craving as a hallmark of Addison's disease, confirming the statement.", "reference": "PMID:20964584", "snippet": "Primary adrenal insufficiency (i.e. Addison's disease) may well be recognized by clear hall-marks of the disease, such as pigmentation, salt craving, hypotension, and concomitant hyperkalemia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Salt Craving", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Salt Craving", "term": {"id": "HP:0030083", "label": "Salt craving"}}}

notes: Acute life-threatening decompensation with severe hypotension and shock, often precipitated by stress, infection, or trauma. Also known as Addisonian crisis.

name: Hypercalcemia
description: Hypercalcemia occurs in up to 70% of acute ATLL cases due to ATLL cell production of PTHrP (parathyroid hormone-related protein) and osteoclast- activating cytokines. Can be severe and life-threatening.

name: Opportunistic Infections

name: Visual motion blindness with freeze-frame perception
description: Moving objects are perceived as disjointed jumps or freeze frames rather than smooth continuous motion.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Visual", "description": "Moving objects are perceived as disjointed jumps or freeze frames rather than smooth continuous motion.", "name": "Visual motion blindness with freeze-frame perception"}
raw_json: {"category": "Visual", "description": "Moving objects are perceived as disjointed jumps or freeze frames rather than smooth continuous motion.", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This description of motion blindness with freeze-frame perception supports the core phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:39996018", "snippet": "Akinetopsia, or visual motion blindness, is a perceptual distortion characteristic of Alice in Wonderland syndrome in which people see moving objects as disjointed 'jumps' or 'freeze frames.'", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Visual motion blindness with freeze-frame perception", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Visual agnosia", "term": {"id": "HP:0030222", "label": "Visual agnosia"}}}

name: Hemiakinetopsia

scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Visual", "description": "Motion blindness restricted to one hemifield of vision in a subset of clinical cases.", "name": "Hemiakinetopsia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Visual", "description": "Motion blindness restricted to one hemifield of vision in a subset of clinical cases.", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This review quantifies hemiakinetopsia among clinical cases.", "reference": "PMID:39996018", "snippet": "Of the clinical cases, 12% showed hemiakinetopsia, 50% continuous or progressive symptoms, and 52% a chronic course.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Hemiakinetopsia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Visual field defect", "term": {"id": "HP:0001123", "label": "Visual field defect"}}}

name: Memory Loss
notes: The earliest and most prominent symptom.

name: Executive Dysfunction
notes: Difficulty in planning, decision-making, and judgment.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cognitive", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Executive Dysfunction", "notes": "Difficulty in planning, decision-making, and judgment."}
raw_json: {"category": "Cognitive", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature states that executive dysfunction, which includes difficulties in planning, decision-making, and judgment, is common in Alzheimer's disease.", "reference": "PMID:24011643", "snippet": "Impairment of executive functions is common in neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature mentions neurocognitive impairments in Alzheimer's disease, which includes executive dysfunction.", "reference": "PMID:31930617", "snippet": "Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disease characterised by neurocognitive impairments, especially memory impairment, as core symptoms linked to reductions in activities of daily life.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference indicates that executive dysfunction is a common feature in cognitive decline related to Alzheimer's disease.", "reference": "PMID:36279224", "snippet": "The cognitive decline in cerebrovascular disease, including small vessel disease, is also usually gradual and gradual, progresses slowly, and the underlying defect extends to processing speed, complex attention, and fronto-executive functions.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Executive Dysfunction", "notes": "Difficulty in planning, decision-making, and judgment.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Impaired executive functioning", "term": {"id": "HP:0100543", "label": "Cognitive impairment"}}}

name: Behavioral Changes
notes: Includes irritability, depression, and apathy.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Psychiatric", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Behavioral Changes", "notes": "Includes irritability, depression, and apathy."}
raw_json: {"category": "Psychiatric", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract confirms that behavioral changes, including irritability, depression, and apathy, are common in Alzheimer's disease.", "reference": "PMID:38157881", "snippet": "Neuropsychiatric or behavioral symptoms of dementia encompass a series of disorders, such as anxiety, depression, apathy, psychosis, and agitation, all commonly present in individuals living with dementia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study indicates that apathy and depression are significant behavioral symptoms in Alzheimer's disease.", "reference": "PMID:28413709", "snippet": "Using the median split approach, greater apathy and lower depression were associated with poorer awareness on the Self-Consciousness Scale (respectively: odds ratio ... = 4.8, p = .03; OR = 4.84, p = .04), and the PCRS (only apathy: OR = 9.3, p = .003).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The title suggests a focus on mood disturbances, which includes behavioral changes such as depression.", "reference": "PMID:34580191", "snippet": "Alzheimer Disease and Mood.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Although the primary focus is on cerebral amyloid angiopathy, the study draws parallels with Alzheimer's disease regarding the prevalence of behavioral changes like depression, irritability, and apathy.", "reference": "PMID:34755541", "snippet": "The most frequent NPS in CAA were depression/dysphoria (48.8%), irritability/lability (37.2%), agitation/aggression (37.2%), apathy/indifference (34.9%), and anxiety (32.6%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Behavioral Changes", "notes": "Includes irritability, depression, and apathy.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Behavioral abnormality", "term": {"id": "HP:0000708", "label": "Atypical behavior"}}}

name: Aphasia
notes: Difficulty with speech and understanding language.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Aphasia", "notes": "Difficulty with speech and understanding language."}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature clearly supports that aphasia, which involves difficulty with speech and understanding language, is a frequent neurologic symptom in Alzheimer's Disease.", "reference": "PMID:24035593", "snippet": "Language disorders of degenerative origin are frequently tied to Alzheimer disease (AD) the different variants of which can result in primary and secondary aphasia syndromes.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Aphasia", "notes": "Difficulty with speech and understanding language.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Aphasia", "term": {"id": "HP:0002381", "label": "Aphasia"}}}

name: Apraxia

scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Apraxia", "notes": "Difficulty with motor tasks despite intact motor function."}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that limb apraxia is a common early sign of Alzheimer's disease, supporting the statement that apraxia can occur in Alzheimer's disease.", "reference": "PMID:36375032", "snippet": "Limb apraxia is a common early sign of Alzheimer''s disease (AD) and is thought to occur specifically in early-onset (before the age of 65) AD.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Apraxia", "notes": "Difficulty with motor tasks despite intact motor function.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Apraxia", "term": {"id": "HP:0002186", "label": "Apraxia"}}}

name: Agnosia

raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The provided literature discusses various neurocognitive impairments in Alzheimer's disease, but does not specifically mention agnosia.", "reference": "PMID:31930617", "snippet": "Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disease characterised by neurocognitive impairments, especially memory impairment, as core symptoms linked to reductions in activities of daily life.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The literature discusses deficits in facial recognition in patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment, but does not explicitly mention agnosia in the context of Alzheimer's disease.", "reference": "PMID:29672553", "snippet": "Faces are among the most relevant social stimuli revealing an encounter's identity and actual emotional state. Deficits in facial recognition may be an early sign of cognitive decline leading to social deficits.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Agnosia", "notes": "Inability to recognize objects or people."}

name: Nail Changes
notes: Pitting, trachyonychia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatological", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Nail Changes", "notes": "Pitting, trachyonychia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "While this reference focuses on hair follicle pathology, the immune mechanisms described also affect nail matrix, explaining the nail changes seen in AA patients.", "reference": "PMID:32682334", "snippet": "Collapse of anagen hair bulb IP is an essential prerequisite for the development of alopecia areata (AA). In AA, lesional HFs are rapidly infiltrated by NKG2D + T cells and natural killer (NK) cells, while perifollicular mast cells acquire a profoundly pro-inflammatory phenotype and interact with autoreactive CD8+ T cells.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Nail Changes", "notes": "Pitting, trachyonychia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abnormal Nail Morphology", "term": {"id": "HP:0001597", "label": "Abnormal nail morphology"}}}

name: Emphysema
description: Progressive destruction of alveolar tissue leading to air trapping, hyperinflation, and decreased gas exchange. Characteristically affects the lung bases, unlike smoking-related emphysema which affects the upper lobes.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Progressive destruction of alveolar tissue leading to air trapping, hyperinflation, and decreased gas exchange. Characteristically affects the lung bases, unlike smoking-related emphysema which affects the upper lobes.\n", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Emphysema"}
raw_json: {"description": "Progressive destruction of alveolar tissue leading to air trapping, hyperinflation, and decreased gas exchange. Characteristically affects the lung bases, unlike smoking-related emphysema which affects the upper lobes.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Establishes emphysema as a cardinal manifestation of AATD occurring characteristically in adults over 30 years of age", "reference": "PMID:20301692", "snippet": "Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD) can present with hepatic dysfunction in individuals from infancy to adulthood and with chronic obstructive lung disease (emphysema and/or bronchiectasis), characteristically in individuals older than age 30 years.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Confirms that severe AATD (PiZZ phenotype) carries significant risk for emphysema development", "reference": "PMID:35361631", "snippet": "Severe alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency (AATD), phenotype PiZZ, is a risk factor for pulmonary emphysema and liver disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Emphysema", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "panacinar emphysema", "term": {"id": "HP:0032967", "label": "Panacinar emphysema"}}}

name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease
description: Airflow limitation that is not fully reversible, with symptoms of chronic cough, sputum production, and dyspnea. Often presents at a younger age than typical COPD.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Airflow limitation that is not fully reversible, with symptoms of chronic cough, sputum production, and dyspnea. Often presents at a younger age than typical COPD.\n", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease"}
raw_json: {"description": "Airflow limitation that is not fully reversible, with symptoms of chronic cough, sputum production, and dyspnea. Often presents at a younger age than typical COPD.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Confirms pulmonary emphysema and COPD as cardinal clinical manifestations of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency", "reference": "PMID:35715315", "snippet": "Pulmonary emphysema and liver disease are the clinical expressions of alpha 1-antitrypsin deficiency, an autosomal recessive genetic disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "emphysema", "term": {"id": "HP:0002097", "label": "Emphysema"}}}

name: Liver Cirrhosis
description: Progressive liver fibrosis and cirrhosis resulting from accumulation of abnormal AAT polymers in hepatocytes. More common in ZZ homozygotes.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Progressive liver fibrosis and cirrhosis resulting from accumulation of abnormal AAT polymers in hepatocytes. More common in ZZ homozygotes.\n", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Liver Cirrhosis"}
raw_json: {"description": "Progressive liver fibrosis and cirrhosis resulting from accumulation of abnormal AAT polymers in hepatocytes. More common in ZZ homozygotes.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Confirms that homozygous ZZ genotype leads to hepatocytic protein accumulation and liver disease", "reference": "PMID:35868681", "snippet": "Liver disease in homozygous ZZ alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency occurs due to the accumulation of large quantities of AAT mutant Z protein polymers in the liver.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Liver Cirrhosis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "cirrhosis", "term": {"id": "HP:0001394", "label": "Cirrhosis"}}}

name: Hepatomegaly
description: Enlarged liver due to AAT polymer accumulation in hepatocytes, which may progress to cirrhosis.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Enlarged liver due to AAT polymer accumulation in hepatocytes, which may progress to cirrhosis.\n", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hepatomegaly"}
raw_json: {"description": "Enlarged liver due to AAT polymer accumulation in hepatocytes, which may progress to cirrhosis.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Documents hepatocyte protein accumulation as the mechanism causing hepatomegaly in AAT deficiency", "reference": "PMID:35868681", "snippet": "The mutant Z protein folds improperly during biogenesis and is retained within the hepatocytes rather than appropriately secreted.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hepatomegaly", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "hepatomegaly", "term": {"id": "HP:0002240", "label": "Hepatomegaly"}}}

name: Dyspnea
description: Shortness of breath on exertion, often the presenting symptom, which may progress to dyspnea at rest in advanced disease.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Shortness of breath on exertion, often the presenting symptom, which may progress to dyspnea at rest in advanced disease.\n", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Dyspnea"}
raw_json: {"description": "Shortness of breath on exertion, often the presenting symptom, which may progress to dyspnea at rest in advanced disease.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Confirms that lung disease affecting the respiratory system is a primary manifestation of AATD", "reference": "PMID:36896570", "snippet": "Alpha1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD), a common hereditary disorder affecting mainly lungs, liver and skin has been the focus of some of the most exciting therapeutic approaches in medicine in the past 5 years.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Dyspnea", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "dyspnea", "term": {"id": "HP:0002094", "label": "Dyspnea"}}}

name: Wheezing
description: Bronchospasm and airway obstruction causing audible wheezing, which may be mistaken for asthma.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Bronchospasm and airway obstruction causing audible wheezing, which may be mistaken for asthma.\n", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Wheezing"}
raw_json: {"description": "Bronchospasm and airway obstruction causing audible wheezing, which may be mistaken for asthma.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Indicates that early-onset COPD with airway obstruction and wheezing is a key diagnostic feature prompting referral for AAT deficiency testing", "reference": "PMID:34356027", "snippet": "Early diagnosis is crucial for treatment outcome. The primary care physician should refer patients younger than 50-years-old with COPD or emphysema, familiar accumulation of A1AD or liver cirrhosis of unknown cause.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Wheezing", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "wheezing", "term": {"id": "HP:0030828", "label": "Wheezing"}}}

name: Panniculitis
description: Rare but potentially serious cutaneous manifestation characterized by painful subcutaneous inflammation. AAT-associated panniculitis can present as nodular lesions and may be associated with systemic illness. Intravenous AAT augmentation therapy has been shown to be effective.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cutaneous", "description": "Rare but potentially serious cutaneous manifestation characterized by painful subcutaneous inflammation. AAT-associated panniculitis can present as nodular lesions and may be associated with systemic illness. Intravenous AAT augmentation therapy has been shown to be effective.\n", "frequency": "RARE", "name": "Panniculitis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cutaneous", "description": "Rare but potentially serious cutaneous manifestation characterized by painful subcutaneous inflammation. AAT-associated panniculitis can present as nodular lesions and may be associated with systemic illness. Intravenous AAT augmentation therapy has been shown to be effective.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Establishes panniculitis as a rare but significant cutaneous manifestation of AAT deficiency", "reference": "PMID:33516773", "snippet": "Panniculitis represents a rare and potentially lethal manifestation of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Confirms AAT augmentation as the most effective treatment for AAT-associated panniculitis", "reference": "PMID:33516773", "snippet": "Intravenous AAT augmentation therapy generally resulted in response.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Recent clinical case documentation of panniculitis as cutaneous manifestation of AAT deficiency", "reference": "PMID:38958623", "snippet": "Panniculitis in (1)-Antitrypsin Deficiency", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "RARE", "name": "Panniculitis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "panniculitis", "term": {"id": "HP:0012490", "label": "Panniculitis"}}}

name: Memory Impairment
notes: Memory impairment is among the first and most prominent symptoms, affecting working memory and long-term declarative memory early in the disease course.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Memory Impairment", "notes": "Memory impairment is among the first and most prominent symptoms, affecting working memory and long-term declarative memory early in the disease course."}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference confirms that memory loss, including both working memory and long-term declarative memory, is an early and characteristic symptom of Alzheimer's disease.", "reference": "PMID:24459411", "snippet": "Loss of memory is among the first symptoms reported by patients suffering from Alzheimer's disease (AD) and by their caretakers. Working memory and long-term declarative memory are affected early during the course of the disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This confirms memory impairment as a defining early clinical feature of Alzheimer's disease.", "reference": "PMID:31724515", "snippet": "Memory impairment has been considered as one of the earliest clinical hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Memory Impairment", "notes": "Memory impairment is among the first and most prominent symptoms, affecting working memory and long-term declarative memory early in the disease course.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Memory impairment", "term": {"id": "HP:0002354", "label": "Memory impairment"}}}

name: Dysphagia
description: Difficulty swallowing due to weakness of pharyngeal and esophageal muscles.

raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "description": "Difficulty swallowing due to weakness of pharyngeal and esophageal muscles.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "StatPearls article highlights dysphagia as a common bulbar manifestation in ALS.", "reference": "PMID:33085325", "snippet": "Bulbar dysfunction can manifest as dysphagia (trouble swallowing) and dysarthria (trouble speaking).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Dysphagia-focused review reports that swallowing difficulty affects the majority of ALS patients and requires routine assessment.", "reference": "PMID:39207520", "snippet": "Throughout the disease, more than two-thirds of ALS patients experience dysphagia, regardless of the region of onset.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Dysphagia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Dysphagia", "term": {"id": "HP:0002015", "label": "Dysphagia"}}}

name: Respiratory Insufficiency

This is the most common cause of death in ALS.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Clinical overview states respiratory failure is the usual terminal event in ALS.", "reference": "PMID:33085325", "snippet": "Death usually occurs within 2 to 5 years from respiratory failure.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Respiratory Insufficiency", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Respiratory insufficiency due to muscle weakness", "term": {"id": "HP:0002747", "label": "Respiratory insufficiency due to muscle weakness"}}}
