name: Deep Vein Thrombosis
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Thrombosis", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Deep Vein Thrombosis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Thrombosis", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference mentions that venous thromboembolism, which includes deep vein thrombosis, is a frequent manifestation in Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS).", "reference": "PMID:36575066", "snippet": "Venous thromboembolism belongs to the most frequent clinical manifestation of this syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While it confirms the presence of venous thrombosis, including potential complications like stroke, it does not definitively confirm deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism as common sequelae in all cases.", "reference": "PMID:10961585", "snippet": "In its classic presentation, the antiphospholipid syndrome manifests a combination of venous or arterial thrombosis... The manifestations often include a moderate thrombocytopenia and, less commonly, hemolysis.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "Venous thrombosis, including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, is frequently observed in APS.", "reference": "PMID:12627666", "snippet": "The relative frequency of ACLAs in association with arterial and venous thrombosis strongly suggests that they should be looked for in any individual with unexplained thrombosis; all three idiotypes (IgG, IgA, and IgM) should be assessed.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Deep Vein Thrombosis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Deep Vein Thrombosis", "term": {"id": "HP:0004850", "label": "Recurrent deep vein thrombosis"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Pulmonary Embolism"}, {"target": "Stroke"}]}

name: Preterm Birth
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Pregnancy-Related", "context": "Pregnancy", "name": "Preterm Birth"}
raw_json: {"category": "Pregnancy-Related", "context": "Pregnancy", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference lists premature birth (preterm birth) as a form of obstetric morbidity associated with APS, supporting its categorization as a pregnancy-related phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:26815583", "snippet": "Obstetric morbidity includes recurrent first trimester loss, stillbirth, intrauterine death, preeclam-psia, premature birth and fetal growth restriction", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The evidence suggests that patients with APS (OAPS) can experience similar pregnancy outcomes to those without the specific criteria of classical APS, which includes preterm birth.", "reference": "PMID:36756665", "snippet": "The pregnancy outcomes were not significantly different between NC-OAPS and OAPS groups.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The meta-analysis found that APS patients, especially those with lupus anticoagulant positivity, have an increased risk of preterm birth, supporting the statement that APS phenotypes include pregnancy-related complications such as preterm birth.", "reference": "PMID:34280554", "snippet": "Patients with lupus anticoagulant positivity had an increased risk of preeclampsia (OR 2.10, p = 0.02, I2 = 48%), SGA (OR 1.78, p < 0.01, I2 = 0%) and preterm birth (OR 3.56, p = 0.01, I2 = 48%)", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Preterm Birth", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Preterm Birth", "term": {"id": "HP:0001622", "label": "Premature birth"}}}

name: Thrombocytopenia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "name": "Thrombocytopenia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Thrombocytopenia is a hematologic phenotype observed in APS patients.", "reference": "PMID:8952756", "snippet": "a variable degree of thrombocytopenia occurs in approximately 20-40% of the patients with APS", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Thrombocytopenia is mentioned as a manifestation studied in APS.", "reference": "PMID:21303834", "snippet": "This article summarizes the studies analyzed on thrombocytopenia and skin manifestations", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Thrombocytopenia is a significant hematologic feature observed in APS.", "reference": "PMID:29316193", "snippet": "Thrombocytopenia is the most common non-criteria hematological feature in patients with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Thrombocytopenia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Thrombocytopenia", "term": {"id": "HP:0001873", "label": "Thrombocytopenia"}}}

name: Cardiac Valve Disease
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "name": "Cardiac Valve Disease"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference indicates that cardiac valve disease, specifically valvular involvement, is a common manifestation in patients with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS).", "reference": "PMID:17916990", "snippet": "Valvular involvement is the most common manifestation with a prevalence of 82% detected by transesophageal echocardiography. Symmetrical, nodular thickening of the mitral and/or aortic valves is characteristic.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The title of this reference directly connects cardiac valve diseases with APS, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:10852159", "snippet": "Cardiac valve diseases and antiphospholipid syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study shows a significant prevalence of cardiac valvular involvement in patients with primary APS.", "reference": "PMID:1733383", "snippet": "Valvular involvement is frequently found in patients with the primary antiphospholipid syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This report confirms that cardiac valve disease is a manifestation of APS, most commonly affecting the mitral valve.", "reference": "PMID:30614053", "snippet": "Most commonly mitral valve is affected followed by aortic and then tricuspid valve.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This review discusses various cardiac abnormalities associated with APS, including valvular disease.", "reference": "PMID:1442504", "snippet": "The earliest reports were of valvular disease, including verrucous endocarditis, as well as valvular thickening and insufficiency.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Cardiac Valve Disease"}

name: Preeclampsia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Pregnancy-Related", "context": "Pregnancy", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Preeclampsia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Pregnancy-Related", "context": "Pregnancy", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature supports the association of antiphospholipid syndrome with preeclampsia, but it does not specify that the frequency is 'occasional'.", "reference": "PMID:26815583", "snippet": "Obstetric morbidity includes recurrent first trimester loss, stillbirth, intrauterine death, preeclam-psia, premature birth and fetal growth restriction", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The literature supports the association of antiphospholipid syndrome with preeclampsia, but it does not specify that the frequency is 'occasional'.", "reference": "PMID:32413497", "snippet": "Its major presentations are thrombotic (arterial, venous, or microvascular) and pregnancy morbidity (miscarriages, late intrauterine fetal demise, and severe pre-eclampsia).", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Preeclampsia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Preeclampsia", "term": {"id": "MONDO:0005081", "label": "preeclampsia"}}}

name: Thrombocytopenia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Thrombocytopenia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates thrombocytopenia is a frequent clinical manifestation in patients with primary APS.", "reference": "PMID:35536236", "snippet": "Thrombocytopenia, a frequent clinical manifestation in patients with APS, could be an independent predictor of recurrent thrombotic, obstetric and severe extracriteria events.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Thrombocytopenia is mentioned as a clinical feature of APS, supporting its frequent occurrence.", "reference": "PMID:17426356", "snippet": "Other features include recurrent miscarriage, thrombocytopenia, and livedo reticularis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The incidence range of 22-42% indicates that thrombocytopenia is a frequent hematologic manifestation in APS patients.", "reference": "PMID:18417261", "snippet": "Thrombocytopenia is frequently found in APS patients, its incidence has ranged from 22-42% in different series.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Thrombocytopenia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Thrombocytopenia", "term": {"id": "HP:0001873", "label": "Thrombocytopenia"}}}

name: Cardiac Valve Disease
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Cardiac Valve Disease"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature states that heart valve disease is the most frequent cardiac manifestation in APS, not an occasional occurrence.", "reference": "PMID:23456852", "snippet": "Heart valve disease (HVD) is the most frequent cardiac manifestation in patients with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS), with prevalence of 30 %.", "supports": "REFUTE"}, {"explanation": "The literature indicates that valvular involvement is frequently found, contradicting the statement that it is occasional.", "reference": "PMID:1733383", "snippet": "Valvular involvement is frequently found in patients with the primary antiphospholipid syndrome.", "supports": "REFUTE"}, {"explanation": "The literature describes valvulopathy in APS as quite common, not occasional.", "reference": "PMID:12402416", "snippet": "The valvulopathy in APS is quite common and may lead to valve replacement.", "supports": "REFUTE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Cardiac Valve Disease"}

name: Livedo Reticularis
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Livedo Reticularis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference states that livedo reticularis is a common cutaneous manifestation of APS, supporting its categorization as a dermatologic manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:26223086", "snippet": "Livedo reticularis is a common cutaneous manifestation of APS and may be a prognostic marker of more severe disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference confirms that livedo reticularis is one of the cutaneous manifestations of APS.", "reference": "PMID:9204065", "snippet": "Cutaneous manifestations may occur as the first sign of antiphospholipid syndrome. These include livedo reticularis...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the association of livedo reticularis with APS, indicating its presence in patients with the syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:35697016", "snippet": "This cross-sectional analysis of a large cohort of Serbian PAPS patients confirmed a strong relationship between livedo reticularis and arterial thrombosis...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference discusses the prevalence of livedo in patients with SLE and APS, supporting its categorization as a dermatologic manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:36112747", "snippet": "Livedo is a well-known skin condition in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) which correspond to small vessels involvement.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Livedo Reticularis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Livedo Reticularis", "term": {"id": "HP:0033505", "label": "Livedo reticularis"}}}

name: Migraine Headaches
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Migraine Headaches"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that migraine headaches are frequently reported in patients with Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS), supporting the statement that they are an occasional neurological manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:27423434", "snippet": "Migraine is the most commonly reported type of headache in APS/aPL-positive patients.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study supports the association between APS and neurological manifestations, including migraines, although it does not provide specific frequency data for migraines.", "reference": "PMID:29756580", "snippet": "Cerebral vascular accident (33%), retinal artery/vein occlusion (21%), and seizure (20%) were the most frequent presentations among the patients.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the occurrence of migraines as a neurological manifestation in APS patients, even though it is not part of the official classification criteria.", "reference": "PMID:27658514", "snippet": "Although in the most recently updated (2006) APS classification criteria, the neurological manifestations encompass only transient ischemic attack and stroke, diverse 'non-criteria' neurological disorders or manifestations (i.e., headache, migraine...) have been observed in APS patients.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Migraine Headaches"}

name: Coronal Craniosynostosis
description: Bilateral coronal suture fusion causing brachycephaly with turricephaly (tower-shaped skull) and flat occiput.

name: Syndactyly of Hands
description: Symmetric complex syndactyly of digits 2-4 (type I) or 2-5 (type II/III), creating the characteristic "mitten hand" appearance. Both osseous and cutaneous syndactyly are present.

raw_json: {"description": "Symmetric complex syndactyly of digits 2-4 (type I) or 2-5 (type II/III), creating the characteristic \"mitten hand\" appearance. Both osseous and cutaneous syndactyly are present.\n", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "Defines syndactyly of hands and feet as a core diagnostic feature of Apert syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:7719344", "snippet": "Apert syndrome is a distinctive human malformation comprising craniosynostosis and severe syndactyly of the hands and feet.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Syndactyly of Hands", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Finger syndactyly", "term": {"id": "HP:0006101", "label": "Finger syndactyly"}}}

name: Ambiguous Genitalia
description: External genitalia that do not have typical male or female appearance due to prenatal androgen excess in 46,XX individuals.
notes: In 46,XX individuals
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Reproductive", "description": "External genitalia that do not have typical male or female appearance due to prenatal androgen excess in 46,XX individuals.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Ambiguous Genitalia", "notes": "In 46,XX individuals"}
raw_json: {"category": "Reproductive", "description": "External genitalia that do not have typical male or female appearance due to prenatal androgen excess in 46,XX individuals.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature discusses varied presentations including ambiguous genitalia (Prader III/IV), but 'frequency: VERY_FREQUENT' is not clearly established.", "reference": "PMID:37348676", "snippet": "In the seven patients from our center, presentation was frequent in childhood or adolescence (4/7: delayed puberty or hyperandrogenism), with maternal virilization (4/7), predominance of Prader III/IV (5/7), and initial rearing as females (6/7).", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference focuses on DSD in general and not specifically on aromatase deficiency, discussing other common diagnoses like congenital adrenal hyperplasia.", "reference": "PMID:36686446", "snippet": "Among the 46XY DSD patients, the most common cause was partial androgen insensitivity. In contrast, congenital adrenal hyperplasia constituted the most common diagnosis in 46,XX DSD cases.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Ambiguous Genitalia", "notes": "In 46,XX individuals"}

name: Delayed Puberty
description: Failure to develop secondary sexual characteristics at the expected age due to estrogen deficiency.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Reproductive", "description": "Failure to develop secondary sexual characteristics at the expected age due to estrogen deficiency.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Delayed Puberty"}
raw_json: {"category": "Reproductive", "description": "Failure to develop secondary sexual characteristics at the expected age due to estrogen deficiency.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference discusses aromatase deficiency and mentions pubertal development but does not provide specific evidence supporting delayed puberty as a phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:30173221", "snippet": "BACKGROUND: Aromatase deficiency is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. 46,XY-affected patients often remain undiagnosed until late puberty. Only 2 pediatric cases have been reported. Data on pubertal development in affected males are scarce.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference is about IHH, not aromatase deficiency, and does not provide direct evidence for delayed puberty in aromatase deficiency.", "reference": "PMID:36268624", "snippet": "Isolated hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (IHH) is phenotypically and genetically heterogeneous.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference provides an overview of genetic testing of disorders of sexual development but does not provide strong evidence supporting delayed puberty due to aromatase deficiency.", "reference": "PMID:30550360", "snippet": "Despite the advances in translational medicine, hospitals are yet to adopt genetic testing and counseling facilities in India that shall have potential impact on clinical diagnosis.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "While the reference discusses reproductive implications of aromatase deficiency, it does not directly address delayed puberty as a high-frequency diagnostic phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:17581673", "snippet": "Alterations of spermatogenesis in terms of number and motility of spermatozoa have been described in men genetically deficient in aromatase. These last observations... suggest that aromatase could be involved in the acquisition of sperm motility.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference discusses the role of estrogen in puberty but does not specifically mention delayed puberty as a phenotype of aromatase deficiency.", "reference": "PMID:24612204", "snippet": "Oestrogen is the final key factor to start the onset of puberty.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference discusses congenital adrenal hyperplasia but does not provide evidence on delayed puberty linked to aromatase deficiency.", "reference": "PMID:10418977", "snippet": "The diagnostic term congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) applies to a family of inherited disorders of steroidogenesis.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Delayed Puberty", "phenotype_term": {"description": "Lack of pubertal development by age 13 in girls or 14 in boys.", "preferred_term": "Delayed Puberty", "term": {"id": "HP:0000823", "label": "Delayed puberty"}}}

name: Osteoporosis
description: Reduced bone mineral density and increased fracture risk resulting from inadequate estrogen-mediated bone remodeling.
notes: Due to estrogen deficiency
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "description": "Reduced bone mineral density and increased fracture risk resulting from inadequate estrogen-mediated bone remodeling.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Osteoporosis", "notes": "Due to estrogen deficiency"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "description": "Reduced bone mineral density and increased fracture risk resulting from inadequate estrogen-mediated bone remodeling.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract mentions osteoporosis as one of the phenotypes observed in males with aromatase deficiency due to estrogen deficiency.", "reference": "PMID:18448329", "snippet": "The clinical phenotype in the male affected subjects comprises tall stature, persistent linear growth and delayed bone age, osteopenia/osteoporosis, eunuchoid body proportion, different degrees of glucose-insulin and of fertility impairment.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the role of estrogen in bone health, noting its wide biological effects including skeletal outcomes.", "reference": "PMID:18448329", "snippet": "Estrogens exert a wide range of biological effects in both sexes also on non-reproductive systems and organs.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Osteoporosis", "notes": "Due to estrogen deficiency", "phenotype_term": {"description": "Decreased bone mass and structural deterioration leading to increased fracture risk.", "preferred_term": "Osteoporosis", "term": {"id": "HP:0000939", "label": "Osteoporosis"}}}

name: Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism
description: Elevated gonadotropin levels (FSH, LH) with inadequate gonadal function due to lack of estrogen negative feedback.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "Elevated gonadotropin levels (FSH, LH) with inadequate gonadal function due to lack of estrogen negative feedback.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism"}

name: Primary Amenorrhea
description: Absence of menstruation by age 15 due to estrogen deficiency preventing endometrial development.
notes: In 46,XX individuals
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Reproductive", "description": "Absence of menstruation by age 15 due to estrogen deficiency preventing endometrial development.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Primary Amenorrhea", "notes": "In 46,XX individuals"}
raw_json: {"category": "Reproductive", "description": "Absence of menstruation by age 15 due to estrogen deficiency preventing endometrial development.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature mentions that affected girls with aromatase deficiency fail to develop secondary sexual characteristics and exhibit progressive virilization, which can be associated with primary amenorrhea, but it does not explicitly state that primary amenorrhea is a frequent occurrence.", "reference": "PMID:11305285", "snippet": "Aromatase deficiency results from autosomal recessive inheritance of mutations in the CYP19 gene. It gives rise to ambiguous genitalia in 46,XX individuals. At puberty, affected girls have hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, fail to develop secondary sexual characteristics, and exhibit progressive virilization.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference discusses primary amenorrhea in the context of LHCGR gene mutations, not aromatase deficiency.", "reference": "PMID:35366614", "snippet": "In this study, LHCGR gene mutations were detected in a total of nine patients as a result of the analysis of the index patients presenting with primary amenorrhea from four different families and the examination of the families.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This reference discusses hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and its association with amenorrhea, not aromatase deficiency.", "reference": "PMID:34494333", "snippet": "AIM: The aim of this study was to evaluate the general characteristics, menstruation status, and fertility outcomes of patients with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (HH).", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Primary Amenorrhea", "notes": "In 46,XX individuals", "phenotype_term": {"description": "Absence of menarche by age 15 in females with otherwise normal development.", "preferred_term": "Primary Amenorrhea", "term": {"id": "HP:0000786", "label": "Primary amenorrhea"}}}

name: Tall Stature
description: Continued linear growth beyond normal age due to delayed epiphyseal closure from estrogen deficiency.
notes: In both 46,XX and 46,XY individuals

Thus, estrogen is the hormone necessary for normal skeletal growth and maturity.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference indicates an association between 46,XX gonadal dysgenesis and tall stature, which is relevant to the statement about aromatase deficiency in 46,XX individuals.", "reference": "PMID:27824615", "snippet": "Tall stature is not a widely recognized association. CASE REPORT: A 15-year-old girl presented with primary amenorrhoea... Initially, a 364055-bp deletion on Xp21.2 was reported on array CGH. However, repeat analysis using BlueGnome CytoChip ISCA 4x180k v2.0 array was normal... the patient was remarkably tall with height SDS +2.88.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While the reference discusses hormonal parameters in 46,XX aromatase deficiency, it does not directly address tall stature.", "reference": "PMID:37348676", "snippet": "Serum FSH levels were elevated except in preterms, and can be used as a diagnostic marker.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Tall Stature", "notes": "In both 46,XX and 46,XY individuals", "phenotype_term": {"description": "Height significantly above the population mean for age and sex.", "preferred_term": "Tall Stature", "term": {"id": "HP:0000098", "label": "Tall stature"}}}

Here, we review the research relating to these phenotypes, with a focus on the methods used to define and validate them.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference describes wheezing as a common symptom associated with asthma, supporting the statement's claim that wheezing is a common phenotype and respiratory diagnostic of asthma.", "reference": "PMID:8620967", "snippet": "Wheezes are usual clinical signs in patients with obstructive airway diseases and particularly during acute episodes of asthma.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference mentions exercise-induced asthma and details its symptoms, including wheezing, though noting that wheezing may not always be present.", "reference": "PMID:1788358", "snippet": "Exercise-induced asthma is a common but frequently undiagnosed problem. The patient may not wheeze, but rather have shortness of breath, chest tightening, and coughing.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Confirms the existence of multiple phenotypes within asthma, including wheezing, supporting the statement's categorization of wheezing as a phenotype of asthma.", "reference": "PMID:26606077", "snippet": "The syndrome of asthma contains a number of different phenotypes that offer the possibility of personalized medicine based on the respective asthma phenotype.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Supports the statement indirectly by acknowledging variations in asthma phenotypes, which includes wheezing as a common symptom.", "reference": "PMID:21722845", "snippet": "Oral corticosteroids are the cornerstone of management of acute moderate or severe asthma whilst preventive inhaled corticosteroids are the mainstay of the preventive management of children with asthma. Yet, variation in the magnitude of response to corticosteroids has been observed.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Although the snippet discusses a different case, it implies that wheezing is commonly associated with asthma management.", "reference": "PMID:38716537", "snippet": "We want to highlight the presentation of a 75-year-old female who was initially managed as asthma and subsequently diagnosed with concurrent excessive dynamic airway collapse (EDAC).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Wheezing", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Wheezing", "term": {"id": "HP:0030828", "label": "Wheezing"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Respiratory Distress"}, {"target": "Reduced Exercise Tolerance"}]}

However, dyspnea and airway obstruction could potentially lead to cyanosis in severe cases.", "reference": "PMID:29601558", "snippet": "Dyspnea as a subjective feeling of lack of air is the patients with the pathology of the respiratory system. Objectivization of this phenomenon is difficult, despite the introduction of questionnaires about the degree of dyspnoea. The results of these assessments do not always correlate with the results of spirometric tests. In patients with asthma, dyspnoea is caused by airway obstruction.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Cyanosis", "notes": "Bluish discoloration of skin and mucous membranes due to low oxygen", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Cyanosis", "term": {"id": "HP:0000961", "label": "Cyanosis"}}}

name: Fatigue
notes: Due to increased work of breathing and sleep disturbance
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue", "notes": "Due to increased work of breathing and sleep disturbance"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates that fatigue is a common symptom in asthmatic patients and is associated with various aspects of asthma, supporting the statement that fatigue is frequent in asthma.", "reference": "PMID:33783133", "snippet": "Fatigue as a symptom is common in asthmatic patients and correlates with asthma-related quality of life, asthma control, dyspnea, depression and anxiety.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While the study supports the association of fatigue with asthma, it does not explicitly confirm that the increased work of breathing and sleep disturbance are the causes of fatigue, hence the partial support.", "reference": "PMID:33783133", "snippet": "Future studies are needed to better understand the physical, psychological, behavioural and systemic factors that precipitate or perpetuate fatigue in asthma.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue", "notes": "Due to increased work of breathing and sleep disturbance", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fatigue", "term": {"id": "HP:0012378", "label": "Fatigue"}}}

name: Exercise Intolerance
notes: Worsening of asthma symptoms with physical activity
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Activity", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Exercise Intolerance", "notes": "Worsening of asthma symptoms with physical activity"}
raw_json: {"category": "Activity", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that exercise can trigger asthma symptoms in individuals with asthma, supporting the statement that exercise intolerance is frequent in asthma patients.", "reference": "PMID:8088098", "snippet": "Given sufficient exercise intensity, exercise can trigger acute exacerbations in virtually all individuals with asthma.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study highlights that physical activity can exacerbate asthma symptoms such as wheezing and breathlessness, indicating exercise intolerance.", "reference": "PMID:31662445", "snippet": "Asthma severity was dependent on variety of symptoms, consisting mostly of wheezing, breathlessness, chest tightness, and cough.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature confirms that physical activity can trigger asthma symptoms, supporting the statement about exercise intolerance.", "reference": "PMID:34536613", "snippet": "PA can trigger asthma symptoms.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature indicates that exercise can lead to bronchoconstriction, which supports the statement about exercise intolerance in asthma patients.", "reference": "PMID:20472861", "snippet": "Exercise can trigger later bronchoconstriction in many patients.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature confirms that exertion can trigger or magnify asthma symptoms, supporting the statement about exercise intolerance.", "reference": "PMID:32280032", "snippet": "Asthma symptoms can be triggered or magnified during exertion.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Exercise Intolerance", "notes": "Worsening of asthma symptoms with physical activity", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Exercise Intolerance", "term": {"id": "HP:0003546", "label": "Exercise intolerance"}}}

name: Sleep Disturbance

maintaining sleep.", "reference": "PMID:11990234", "snippet": "Nocturnal airway narrowing in asthma is often associated with sleep disorders, such as episodes of nocturnal and early morning awakening, difficulty in maintaining sleep, and day time sleepiness.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by showing that nighttime cough frequency is higher in asthmatic patients, which implies sleep disturbances.", "reference": "PMID:31541769", "snippet": "CoFr during nighttime (asleep) was significantly higher in asthmatic patients than in nonasthmatic patients.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by indicating that sleep disruption is common in patients with chronic cough, which includes those with asthma.", "reference": "PMID:19823913", "snippet": "Sleep disruption is common in patients with cough and is often the reason why they seek medical attention.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by indicating an association between worsening asthma-related lung function and poor sleep quality.", "reference": "PMID:28526251", "snippet": "Results from analyses using structural equation modeling revealed an association between worsening asthma-related lung function and poor sleep quality in the full sample, as well as better asthma-related lung function at night and more optimal sleep efficiency that night.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by indicating that nocturnal symptoms of asthma are prevalent and regularly affect sleep in children.", "reference": "PMID:26774954", "snippet": "The prevalence of nocturnal symptoms of asthma is high, and most children regularly experience nighttime symptoms.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Sleep Disturbance", "notes": "Nocturnal asthma can cause nighttime coughing and difficulty sleeping", "phenotype_term": name: Glaucoma
notes: Early onset, often leading to vision loss if untreated. Abnormal development of the anterior segment due to defective PITX2 function leads to poor aqueous humor drainage, resulting in elevated intraocular pressure and glaucoma.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Glaucoma", "notes": "Early onset, often leading to vision loss if untreated. Abnormal development of the anterior segment due to defective PITX2 function leads to poor aqueous humor drainage, resulting in elevated intraocular pressure and glaucoma.", "severity": "Severe"}
raw_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature states that Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome carries a high risk of glaucoma, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:22199394", "snippet": "In the eye, this condition manifests with varying degrees of anterior segment dysgenesis and carries a high risk of glaucoma.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature confirms that malformations of the anterior segment, which are characteristic of Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome, frequently lead to glaucoma.", "reference": "PMID:12015278", "snippet": "Individuals with malformations of structures of the anterior segment of the eye frequently develop elevated intraocular pressure and glaucoma.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study specifically investigates early-onset glaucoma associated with Axenfeld-Rieger anomaly, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:27055677", "snippet": "To determine the long-term surgical and visual outcomes in Indian children with early-onset glaucoma associated with Axenfeld-Rieger anomaly (ARA).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature describes glaucoma phenotypes in individuals with Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:32905845", "snippet": "Our study describes the glaucoma phenotype in a family with Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome (ARS) and a FOXC1 variant.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature states that glaucoma is a major cause of visual morbidity in Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:33367186", "snippet": "Glaucoma is the main cause of visual morbidity in patients with ARS, therefore a complete periodic ophthalmological exam is a priority.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature describes ocular abnormalities consistent with glaucoma in Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:21666320", "snippet": "The patient had megalocornea with Haab's striae in the right eye and posterior embryotoxon in both the eyes. In the left eye, there was a white cord-like structure traversing the anterior chamber with adhesions to iris tissue along its course.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature explicitly states that glaucoma is a manifestation of Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:15509533", "snippet": "The eye manifests with iris ruptures, irido-corneal adhesions, cloudy corneas, and glaucoma.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Glaucoma", "notes": "Early onset, often leading to vision loss if untreated. Abnormal development of the anterior segment due to defective PITX2 function leads to poor aqueous humor drainage, resulting in elevated intraocular pressure and glaucoma.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Glaucoma", "term": {"id": "HP:0000501", "label": "Glaucoma"}}, "severity": "Severe"}

name: Posterior Embryotoxon
notes: A prominent, anteriorly displaced Schwalbe's line seen on eye examination.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Posterior Embryotoxon", "notes": "A prominent, anteriorly displaced Schwalbe's line seen on eye examination.", "severity": "Mild"}
raw_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature supports that posterior embryotoxon is a common feature of Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome but does not confirm it as 'VERY_FREQUENT'. Additionally, it may be present without clinical significance.", "reference": "PMID:15492748", "snippet": "One of the main ocular features associated with Axenfeld-Rieger is posterior embryotoxon, which is a prominent anteriorly displaced Schwalbe's line. This can be found in up to 15% of normal eyes, without any clinical significance or may represent a forme fruste of an anterior segment dysgenesis.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The case report supports the presence of posterior embryotoxon in Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:21666320", "snippet": "The patient had megalocornea with Haab's striae in the right eye and posterior embryotoxon in both the eyes.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference confirms that posterior embryotoxon is a common feature of Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:34937757", "snippet": "Posterior embryotoxon, an anteriorly displaced Schwalbe's line, is the most common feature of Axenfeld Rieger syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement that posterior embryotoxon is a diagnostic feature of Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:38006999", "snippet": "Posterior embryotoxon as the initial ophthalmological sign of Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Posterior Embryotoxon", "notes": "A prominent, anteriorly displaced Schwalbe's line seen on eye examination.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Posterior Embryotoxon", "term": {"id": "HP:0000627", "label": "Posterior embryotoxon"}}, "severity": "Mild"}

name: Iris Hypoplasia
notes: Underdevelopment of the iris, may include corectopia (displacement of the pupil). Mutations like the V45L variant cause reduced DNA-binding with increased transactivation, disrupting iris development due to unregulated gene expression during embryogenesis.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Iris Hypoplasia", "notes": "Underdevelopment of the iris, may include corectopia (displacement of the pupil). Mutations like the V45L variant cause reduced DNA-binding with increased transactivation, disrupting iris development due to unregulated gene expression during embryogenesis."}
raw_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature clearly states that iris hypoplasia is a component of the Rieger anomaly, which is part of Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:30860739", "snippet": "This anomaly encompasses posterior embryotoxon, iris hypoplasia, polycoria, and corectopia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature confirms that iris hypoplasia is a frequent feature of anterior segment dysgenesis, which includes Axenfeld-Rieger anomalies.", "reference": "PMID:35327965", "snippet": "Anterior segment dysgenesis (ASD) encompasses a wide spectrum of developmental abnormalities of the anterior ocular segment, including congenital cataract, iris hypoplasia, aniridia, iridocorneal synechiae, as well as Peters, Axenfeld, and Rieger anomalies.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature identifies iris hypoplasia as a clinical feature in multiple pedigrees with Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:11740218", "snippet": "In pedigrees 1,2, and 4, younger generations had iris hypoplasia with severe early-onset glaucoma, whereas their parents had posterior embryotoxon without glaucoma.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Iris Hypoplasia", "notes": "Underdevelopment of the iris, may include corectopia (displacement of the pupil). Mutations like the V45L variant cause reduced DNA-binding with increased transactivation, disrupting iris development due to unregulated gene expression during embryogenesis."}

name: Corectopia
notes: Displacement of the pupil from its normal central position, often observed alongside iris hypoplasia and other anterior segment abnormalities.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Corectopia", "notes": "Displacement of the pupil from its normal central position, often observed alongside iris hypoplasia and other anterior segment abnormalities."}
raw_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature explicitly lists corectopia as a component of Rieger anomaly in Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:30860739", "snippet": "This anomaly encompasses posterior embryotoxon, iris hypoplasia, polycoria, and corectopia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Corectopia", "notes": "Displacement of the pupil from its normal central position, often observed alongside iris hypoplasia and other anterior segment abnormalities."}

name: Dental Anomalies
notes: Includes missing teeth (hypodontia), small teeth (microdontia), and enamel hypoplasia. Highly penetrant in PITX2-related cases.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Dental Anomalies", "notes": "Includes missing teeth (hypodontia), small teeth (microdontia), and enamel hypoplasia. Highly penetrant in PITX2-related cases."}
raw_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract confirms dental abnormalities are definitive features of Rieger syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:16302606", "snippet": "Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by various ocular and extraocular malformations. Dental abnormalities are considered as definitive features for the diagnosis and differentiation of Rieger syndrome from other anterior chamber of the eye malformations.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study provides evidence for enamel hypoplasia in some patients with Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome but does not provide information on the frequency or other dental anomalies such as hypodontia or microdontia.", "reference": "PMID:35836351", "snippet": "Enamel formation is disturbed in some patients with ARS. Pitx2 knockdown can influence the proliferation and ameloblast differentiation of inner enamel epithelial cells, and PITX2 may regulate cell proliferation via Wnt/beta-catenin signaling pathway.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Dental Anomalies", "notes": "Includes missing teeth (hypodontia), small teeth (microdontia), and enamel hypoplasia. Highly penetrant in PITX2-related cases.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abnormal dental morphology", "term": {"id": "HP:0006482", "label": "Abnormal dental morphology"}}}

name: Craniofacial Dysmorphism
notes: Includes features such as an underdeveloped maxilla, broad nasal bridge, and hypertelorism (increased distance between the eyes). Hypertelorism is significantly more prevalent in FOXC1 variants (81.8%) compared to PITX2 variants (25.0%).
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Craniofacial Dysmorphism", "notes": "Includes features such as an underdeveloped maxilla, broad nasal bridge, and hypertelorism (increased distance between the eyes). Hypertelorism is significantly more prevalent in FOXC1 variants (81.8%) compared to PITX2 variants (25.0%)."}
raw_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature confirms that craniofacial dysmorphism, including an underdeveloped maxilla, is a feature of Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:16302606", "snippet": "Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by various ocular and extraocular malformations. ... Significant cranio-dento-facial findings that have been observed are, teeth with short and dilacerated roots, hyperplastic frenums and underdeveloped maxilla.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature indicates that hypertelorism, a craniofacial feature, is frequently observed in individuals with Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:33231930", "snippet": "Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by ocular and systemic features. ... A thin upper lip (55.9%) and a prominent forehead (41.2%) were common facial features shared between both genes. Hypertelorism/telecanthus (81.8% vs 25.0%, p = 0.002) and low-set ears (31.8% vs 0.0%, p = 0.036) were significantly more prevalent in individuals with FOXC1 variants compared with PITX2 variants.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Craniofacial Dysmorphism", "notes": "Includes features such as an underdeveloped maxilla, broad nasal bridge, and hypertelorism (increased distance between the eyes). Hypertelorism is significantly more prevalent in FOXC1 variants (81.8%) compared to PITX2 variants (25.0%).", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypertelorism", "term": {"id": "HP:0000316", "label": "Hypertelorism"}}}

name: Headache

raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference indicates that headaches are frequently associated with meningitis, supporting the statement that headache is a very frequent symptom in bacterial meningitis.", "reference": "PMID:34749918", "snippet": "secondary headaches related to life threatening infections are most frequently associated with meningitis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference lists headache as one of the most common symptoms in adults with bacterial meningitis, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:36720125", "snippet": "The most common symptoms in adults are fever, headache, positive meningeal symptoms and impaired consciousness.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference describes headache as a cardinal symptom of acute meningitis, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:11301494", "snippet": "Headache as a cardinal symptom of acute meningitis reflects activation of trigeminal afferents from the meninges.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference provides statistical evidence of the prevalence of headaches in bacterial meningitis patients, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:37867184", "snippet": "Among the 277 alive patients at M12 87/274 (31.8%), 213/271 (78.6%) and 86/277 (31.0%) reported headaches before, at the onset, and at M12, respectively.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Although this reference emphasizes the non-specific nature of initial symptoms, it underscores the importance of headache as a diagnostic clue, indirectly supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:18528447", "snippet": "Initial symptoms can be non-specific, which can complicate and delay diagnosis, hence the extreme importance of all the information that can be obtained through anamnesis and physical exploration, with frequent complementary explorations.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Headache", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Headache", "term": {"id": "HP:0002315", "label": "Headache"}}}

name: Neck Stiffness
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Neck Stiffness"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature states that neck stiffness occurs in less than half of the patients, which does not support the claim that it is 'VERY_FREQUENT'.", "reference": "PMID:22667193", "snippet": "Bacterial meningitis is often difficult to recognize since the classical presentation with neck stiffness, reduced awareness and fever occurs in less than half of the patients.", "supports": "REFUTE"}, {"explanation": "The study shows that neck stiffness was present in 36% of late diagnosis cases and 78% of early diagnosis cases, indicating it is not 'VERY_FREQUENT' across all cases.", "reference": "PMID:28652113", "snippet": "We observed several statistically significant baseline differences (p <0.05) in patients with late versus early diagnosis including age >65 years (56/113, 50% versus 67/245, 27%), neck stiffness (35/97, 36% versus 183/234, 78%)...", "supports": "REFUTE"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Neck Stiffness"}

name: Altered Mental Status
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Altered Mental Status"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that altered mental status is a common symptom of CNS infections, including bacterial meningitis.", "reference": "PMID:27741995", "snippet": "Patients with CNS infection can present to the ED with nonspecific signs and symptoms, including headache, fever, altered mental status, and behavioral changes.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Altered mental status is part of the classic triad of symptoms for bacterial meningitis, indicating it is a frequent occurrence.", "reference": "PMID:23981452", "snippet": "The classic triad of bacterial meningitis consists of fever, neck stiffness, and altered mental status; headache is also another common symptom.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The mention of febrile encephalopathy, which includes altered mental status, as a leading symptom of bacterial meningitis supports the statement.", "reference": "PMID:29206991", "snippet": "BACKGROUND: Malaria and acute bacterial meningitis (ABM) are the leading infectious causes of febrile encephalopathy in malaria endemic settings. The clinical distinction of the two conditions is complicated by overlap in clinical features.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While the main focus is on CSF findings, the background suggests that altered mental status is a common indicator for diagnosis.", "reference": "PMID:25442861", "snippet": "BACKGROUND: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cell count and biochemical examinations and cultures form the basis for the diagnosis of bacterial meningitis. However, some patients do not have typical findings and are at a higher risk of being missed or having delayed treatment.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Cognitive impairments, which encompass altered mental status, are noted as common initial symptoms in bacterial meningitis.", "reference": "PMID:27056850", "snippet": "Cognitive impairments, including dementia, can present as first symptoms at the acute stage, and/or as sequelae in the chronic stages, in some patients with bacterial meningitis (BM) or encephalitides.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Altered Mental Status"}

name: Fever
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Fever"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The statement is supported as fever is reported as a very frequent symptom in both pediatric and adult patients with bacterial meningitis.", "reference": "PMID:36720125", "snippet": "Fever is the most commonly reported symptom in paediatric patients, occurring in up to 93% of cases. Further, it is possible to observe headache, vomiting and positive meningeal phenomena. The most common symptoms in adults are fever, headache, positive meningeal symptoms and impaired consciousness.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by indicating that fever is a common symptom during the treatment of bacterial meningitis, with various durations and patterns observed.", "reference": "PMID:6473134", "snippet": "The rates of prolonged fever for 10 days or more, persistent fever for 5 to 9 days and secondary fever were 13, 13 and 16%, respectively.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The case study of a 33-day-old infant with bacterial meningitis presenting with fever supports the statement that fever is a very frequent symptom.", "reference": "PMID:35436245", "snippet": "A 33-day-old previously healthy term female is admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit with fever, lethargy and bulging fontanel.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by indicating that high fever is a common symptom in severe cases of meningococcal sepsis, a form of bacterial meningitis.", "reference": "PMID:37466696", "snippet": "Meningococcal sepsis is a severe clinical feature comprising high fever, chills and disorders of consciousness.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Fever", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fever", "term": {"id": "HP:0001945", "label": "Fever"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Notes hearing loss as a measured sequela in H. influenzae meningitis and shows adjunctive steroids reduce its incidence, supporting inclusion of hearing loss.", "reference": "PMID:33330135", "snippet": "More recent data from a meta analysis of corticosteroid use for the treatment of bacterial meningitis found no significant reductions in mortality across 25 studies in H. influenzae meningitis cases treated with adjunctive steroid therapy, but similarly did observe a significant reduction in the rate of hearing loss overall in children with H. influenzae meningitis from 12% to 4% after adjunctive corticosteroid therapy.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Hearing Loss", "notes": "Cochlear inflammation and toxin exposure can lead to sensorineural hearing loss as a sequelae", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hearing impairment", "term": {"id": "HP:0000365", "label": "Hearing impairment"}}}

name: Petechial Rash
notes: Particularly with meningococcal meningitis
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Integumentary", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Petechial Rash", "notes": "Particularly with meningococcal meningitis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Integumentary", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference indicates that meningococcal meningitis is often accompanied by a petechial rash, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:23830646", "snippet": "Meningococcus should be considered and investigated promptly as a potentially etiologic pathogen in any patient with meningitis, or sepsis accompanied by a petechial rash.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference mentions that petechial rash is a common symptom in meningococcal infections, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:1994692", "snippet": "A rash with petechiae or purpura, the presence of shock, and a normal or low peripheral leukocyte count continue to be predictors of poor outcome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Petechial Rash", "notes": "Particularly with meningococcal meningitis"}

name: Seizures
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Seizures"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Identifies seizures as a complication to monitor and prevent during acute bacterial meningitis management, supporting their clinical relevance.", "reference": "PMID:29889417", "snippet": "Seizures should be avoided, the sedation-pain control optimized and ventilation adapted to assure normal oxygenation and normal CO levels.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Notes that bacterial CNS infections can present with new-onset seizures, reinforcing seizures as a frequent neurological manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:31378869", "snippet": "Brain abscess may initially present only with headache, or as a new-onset seizure or with a focal neurological deficit.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Seizures", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Seizures", "term": {"id": "HP:0001250", "label": "Seizure"}}}

name: Focal Neurological Deficits
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Focal Neurological Deficits"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Reports focal neurological deficits as a common chronic sequela in bacterial meningitis survivors.", "reference": "PMID:36472590", "snippet": "Up to 24% of those who survive develop chronic neurological sequelae, such as hearing loss or focal neurological deficits.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Highlights focal neurological deficits as a key presenting sign that guides urgent imaging in suspected bacterial meningitis.", "reference": "PMID:36472590", "snippet": "Brain imaging should be performed before lumbar puncture if patients present with altered mental status, focal neurological deficits, papilledema, or history of immunocompromising conditions or central nervous system disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Focal Neurological Deficits", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Focal Neurological Deficits", "term": {"id": "HP:0001268", "label": "Mental deterioration"}}}

name: Retinitis Pigmentosa
description: Progressive rod-cone dystrophy leading to night blindness in childhood and progressive vision loss, often resulting in legal blindness by early adulthood.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "description": "Progressive rod-cone dystrophy leading to night blindness in childhood and progressive vision loss, often resulting in legal blindness by early adulthood.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Retinitis Pigmentosa"}
raw_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "description": "Progressive rod-cone dystrophy leading to night blindness in childhood and progressive vision loss, often resulting in legal blindness by early adulthood.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature confirms that RP is a high-frequency ophthalmologic phenotype in Bardet-Biedl syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:15690372", "snippet": "Bardet-Biedl syndrome is a genetically heterogeneous multisystem disorder that causes severe visual impairment. Retinitis pigmentosa (RP), hypogonadism, digit and renal anomalies, obesity, and a variable degree of mental retardation characterize the disorder.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study acknowledges that RP includes night blindness and progressive vision loss, supporting the sequelae mentioned in the statement.", "reference": "PMID:36481880", "snippet": "Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a set of symptoms including tunnel vision, night blindness, and progressive vision loss...as part of a larger syndrome (syndromic)...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "RP is reported as a predominant feature in patients with Bardet-Biedl syndrome, confirming the high frequency of this phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:35791150", "snippet": "Patients with RP in LMBB syndrome present mainly in the first to second decade of life with severe visual acuity impairment to blindness early in life.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Retinal dystrophies, including RP, are significant causes of progressive vision loss, congruent with the statement's listed sequelae.", "reference": "PMID:31864384", "snippet": "Inherited retinal dystrophies are major cause of severe progressive vision loss in children.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Retinitis Pigmentosa", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Retinitis Pigmentosa", "term": {"id": "HP:0000510", "label": "Rod-cone dystrophy"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Night Blindness"}, {"target": "Progressive Vision Loss"}]}

name: Polydactyly
description: Postaxial polydactyly, typically presenting as extra digits on the ulnar side of the hands and/or fibular side of the feet.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Skeletal", "description": "Postaxial polydactyly, typically presenting as extra digits on the ulnar side of the hands and/or fibular side of the feet.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Polydactyly"}
raw_json: {"category": "Skeletal", "description": "Postaxial polydactyly, typically presenting as extra digits on the ulnar side of the hands and/or fibular side of the feet.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The statement is partially supported because renal abnormalities are common in Bardet-Biedl Syndrome, but the frequency and diagnosis related to polydactyly is not addressed.", "reference": "PMID:20876674", "snippet": "Renal abnormalities, including impairment of renal function and signs of chronic interstitial nephropathy of dysplastic nature, were documented in 82% of the patients.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference confirms that both polydactyly and renal disease are features of Bardet-Biedl Syndrome, but it does not specify the diagnostic frequency relationship of polydactyly within renal phenotypes.", "reference": "PMID:6487184", "snippet": "The Bardet-Biedl syndrome is characterized by five main features: obesity, polydactyly, pigmentary retinopathy, mental deficiency and hypogonadism; recently a sixth feature, renal disease, has been described.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Polydactyly", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Polydactyly", "term": {"id": "HP:0010442", "label": "Polydactyly"}}}

name: Truncal Obesity
description: Early-onset obesity beginning in childhood with predominantly central distribution, often associated with hyperphagia.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Obesity", "description": "Early-onset obesity beginning in childhood with predominantly central distribution, often associated with hyperphagia.", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Truncal Obesity"}
raw_json: {"category": "Obesity", "description": "Early-onset obesity beginning in childhood with predominantly central distribution, often associated with hyperphagia.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature mentions high rates of obesity in individuals with Bardet-Biedl Syndrome but does not specifically categorize it as truncal obesity.", "reference": "PMID:32700463", "snippet": "Despite normal birth weight, most individuals with BBS experience rapid weight gain in early childhood, with high rates of overweight/obesity sustained through adolescence.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "While obesity is mentioned as a prevalent phenotype, there is no specific mention of truncal obesity.", "reference": "PMID:6487184", "snippet": "All had subnormal intelligence, twelve were obese, ten had polydactyly, eight hypogonadism, and two had renal disease.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference mentions severe obesity related to BBS genes but not truncal obesity specifically.", "reference": "PMID:29127258", "snippet": "CONCLUSION: CEP19 encodes a centrosomal and ciliary protein, as all BBS genes do. Another truncating mutation p.Arg82* has been reported as responsible for morbid obesity in a family; however, in the family we present, not all homozygotes are obese, although some are severely obese.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "Obesity is noted as a common phenotype, but truncal obesity is not specifically mentioned.", "reference": "PMID:12365916", "snippet": "RESULTS: All patients had an increased body mass index. The obesity varied between families from moderate to severe.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Truncal Obesity", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Truncal Obesity", "term": {"id": "HP:0001956", "label": "Truncal obesity"}}}

It mentions intellectual disability related to ciliopathies in general but does not directly correlate it with Bardet-Biedl Syndrome's frequency.", "reference": "PMID:19778711", "snippet": "Joubert syndrome (JS) is a primarily autosomal recessive condition characterized by... intellectual disability... Variable features include... polydactyly... disorders called ciliopathies.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Intellectual Disability", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Intellectual Disability", "term": {"id": "HP:0001249", "label": "Intellectual disability"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract mentions that Bardet-Biedl syndrome can affect the neurological system, which can include developmental delay.", "reference": "PMID:33040131", "snippet": "Clinical presentation of this rare condition may affect locomotive, neurological, cardio-vascular, endocrine and metabolic systems.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract provides evidence of reduced cognitive functions in patients with Bardet-Biedl syndrome, indicating developmental delays.", "reference": "PMID:24194441", "snippet": "On the age appropriate Wechsler scale, the mean Verbal Comprehension was 81 (n = 36), Working Memory was 81 (n = 36), Perceptual Reasoning was 78 (n = 24) and Full Scale IQ was 75 (n = 26).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Developmental Delay", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Developmental Delay", "term": {"id": "HP:0001263", "label": "Global developmental delay"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Genitourinary", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature mentions hypogenitalism mainly in males but does not provide evidence for its frequency or occurrence in females.", "reference": "PMID:7726222", "snippet": "The major manifestations of the Bardet-Biedl syndrome are digital anomalies, tapetoretinal degeneration, obesity, renal abnormalities, and hypogenitalism (described mainly in males).", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This study reports hypogonadism in a male patient but does not discuss its frequency or occurrence in females.", "reference": "PMID:19327768", "snippet": "To report a patient with Bardet-Biedl syndrome (BBS) with known hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism who developed spontaneous reversal of hypogonadism in adulthood.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The literature mentions hypogonadism in males but does not provide information about its occurrence in females or its frequency.", "reference": "PMID:31696011", "snippet": "The major features of this syndrome are cone-rod dystrophy, polydactyly, obesity, learning disabilities, hypogonadism in males, renal anomalies, nystagmus, speech disorders, developmental delay, polyuria/polydipsia, ataxia, and poor coordination/clumsiness.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The literature discusses genitourinary malformations and hypogonadism in male patients but does not mention its frequency or occurrence in females.", "reference": "PMID:32835378", "snippet": "BBS patients frequently presented with genitourinary malformations, such as cryptorchidism (5/11), short scrotum (5/8), and micropenis (5/8), but unexpectedly, with normal testis size (7/8).", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Hypogonadism", "notes": "In both males and females", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypogonadism", "term": {"id": "HP:0000135", "label": "Hypogonadism"}}}

Most had social skill deficits but no pattern of either externalizing or internalizing problems.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This study focuses on hyperphagia and appetite dysregulation, not on behavioral abnormalities such as impulsivity, emotional lability, or disinhibition.", "reference": "PMID:23776152", "snippet": "CONCLUSION: Appetite dysregulation may contribute to obesity in BBS.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This study does not address behavioral abnormalities in Bardet-Biedl Syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:7726222", "snippet": "The major manifestations of the Bardet-Biedl syndrome are digital anomalies, tapetoretinal degeneration, obesity, renal abnormalities, and hypogenitalism.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This study focuses on physical and cognitive characteristics, not on behavioral abnormalities.", "reference": "PMID:6487184", "snippet": "The Bardet-Biedl syndrome is characterized by five main features: obesity, polydactyly, pigmentary retinopathy, mental deficiency and hypogonadism.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This study focuses on renal failure in a specific type of Bardet-Biedl Syndrome and does not address behavioral abnormalities.", "reference": "PMID:32165602", "snippet": "This type can cause severe and delayed onset renal failure.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This study focuses on behavioral disinhibition in frontotemporal dementia, not Bardet-Biedl Syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:36658040", "snippet": "Disinhibition is a core symptom in behavioural variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD) particularly affecting the daily lives of both patients and caregivers.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Behavioral Abnormalities", "notes": "Includes impulsivity, emotional lability, disinhibition"}

raw_json: {"category": "Ophthalmological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This review confirms that uveitis occurs in over two-thirds of Behcet's disease patients and describes its bilateral, recurrent nature and sight-threatening complications including potential blindness.", "reference": "PMID:38778397", "snippet": "Behcet's uveitis (BU) is a common manifestation of BD, occurring in over two-thirds of the patients. name: Pulmonary Fibrosis
description: Fibrotic remodeling in chronic or progressive disease.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "description": "Fibrotic remodeling in chronic or progressive disease.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Pulmonary Fibrosis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "description": "Fibrotic remodeling in chronic or progressive disease.", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "The trial focuses on fibrotic hypersensitivity pneumonitis, supporting pulmonary fibrosis as a clinical phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:37028940", "snippet": "Fibrotic hypersensitivity pneumonitis (FHP) is an irreversible lung disease with high morbidity and mortality.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "The INBUILD subgroup analysis includes hypersensitivity pneumonitis within progressive fibrosing ILD populations, supporting a fibrotic phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:32145830", "snippet": "the rate of decline in FVC (mL/year) over 52 weeks in patients who received at least one dose of nintedanib or placebo in five prespecified subgroups based on the ILD diagnoses documented by the investigators: hypersensitivity pneumonitis", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "Chronic HP is discussed alongside fibrotic scoring on HRCT, reinforcing pulmonary fibrosis as a key disease feature.", "reference": "PMID:24480143", "snippet": "In the 3 diseases, most important prognosis-predicting factor is the extent of fibrotic score (the extent of honeycombing and reticulation) calculated on high-resolution computed tomography scans or fibrosis estimated on chest radiographs.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "MODEL_ORGANISM", "explanation": "In a hypersensitivity pneumonitis model, fibrosis is a documented outcome, supporting pulmonary fibrosis as a disease phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:38218353", "snippet": "Importantly, it was observed that the transfer of MMP14-overexpressing macrophages into mice promoted lung inflammation and fibrosis induced by SR-Ag.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Pulmonary Fibrosis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Pulmonary fibrosis", "term": {"id": "HP:0002206", "label": "Pulmonary fibrosis"}}}
