name: Profuse Watery Diarrhea
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Profuse Watery Diarrhea"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The provided excerpt supports the statement that profuse watery diarrhea is a very frequent diagnostic phenotype of cholera and that it leads to severe dehydration and shock.", "reference": "PMID:14738797", "snippet": "Intestinal infection with Vibrio cholerae results in the loss of large volumes of watery stool, leading to severe and rapidly progressing dehydration and shock.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This case study supports the characterization of profuse watery diarrhea as a very frequent diagnostic phenotype of cholera.", "reference": "PMID:34523840", "snippet": "Her stool was watery, with flecks of mucous, also referred to as 'rice-water' stool, which is typical for cholera and can amount to 1000 cc/hour.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study supports that rice-water stools (a form of profuse watery diarrhea) are indicative of cholera and frequently used in its diagnosis.", "reference": "PMID:29488455", "snippet": "Adding dehydration, vomiting, or rice water stools to the case definition could increase the specificity without a substantial decrease in sensitivity.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study supports that profuse watery diarrhea is a very frequent diagnostic phenotype of cholera.", "reference": "PMID:820813", "snippet": "The severity of diarrhea and nutritional status were measured in a prospective study of 97 patients hospitalized with cholera in Dacca, Bangladesh... The increased stool loss was unrelated to antibiotic usage, to presence of intestinal parasites, or to the refeeding diet given.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study supports that profuse watery diarrhea (choleriform diarrhea) is a very frequent diagnostic phenotype of cholera.", "reference": "PMID:27412979", "snippet": "Choleriform diarrhea and vomiting were the main signs, found respectively in 100% and 95% of the women; dehydration was mild for 16%, moderate for 45%, and severe for 39%.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study supports that watery diarrhea leading to severe dehydration is a frequent phenotype of cholera.", "reference": "PMID:38702080", "snippet": "The most common complications reported at admission and during hospitalisation included electrolyte imbalance (28.2%), followed by severe dehydration (16.3%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Profuse Watery Diarrhea", "sequelae": [{"target": "Severe Dehydration"}, {"target": "Shock"}]}

name: Dehydration
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Dehydration"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The article notes that Vibrio cholerae was the most common pathogen with a strong association with severe dehydration, which aligns with the statement.", "reference": "PMID:28448489", "snippet": "Vibrio cholerae was the most common pathogen isolated (12,405 patients; 22%), and had the strongest association with SD (AOR 4.77; 95% CI: 4.41-5.51).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study discusses severe dehydration, but also mentions metabolic and respiratory complications without specifically noting frequency.", "reference": "PMID:15367740", "snippet": "A patient presented with cholera and a severe degree of ECF volume contraction. Despite large losses of bicarbonate (HCO3-)-containing diarrhoeal fluid, laboratory acid-base values were remarkably close to normal.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This article discusses a specific case of cholera leading to severe dehydration and hypovolemic shock, but does not provide frequency data.", "reference": "PMID:33252133", "snippet": "It was later confirmed that he was suffering from cholera. On presentation, he was hyperkalemic with ECG changes and soon went into a hypovolemic shock.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Dehydration", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Dehydration", "term": {"id": "HP:0001944", "label": "Dehydration"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Sunken Eyes"}, {"target": "Low Blood Pressure"}, {"target": "Tachycardia"}]}

name: Hypovolemic Shock
notes: Caused by severe dehydration due to fluid loss
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Hypovolemic Shock", "notes": "Caused by severe dehydration due to fluid loss"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This case description demonstrates that hypovolemic shock is an occasional systemic consequence of cholera due to excessive fluid loss.", "reference": "PMID:33252133", "snippet": "The morbidity and mortality of cholera is resultant from large-volume diarrhea, hypovolemia, and electrolyte derangement. In the following case... he was suffering from cholera. On presentation, he was hyperkalemic with ECG changes and soon went into a hypovolemic shock.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This abstract highlights that severe dehydration caused by cholera often leads to shock, supporting the claim.", "reference": "PMID:14738797", "snippet": "Intestinal infection with Vibrio cholerae results in the loss of large volumes of watery stool, leading to severe and rapidly progressing dehydration and shock.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Hypovolemic Shock", "notes": "Caused by severe dehydration due to fluid loss", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypovolemic Shock", "term": {"id": "HP:0031274", "label": "Hypovolemic shock"}}}

name: Dehydration
notes: Can lead to death within hours if untreated
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Dehydration", "notes": "Can lead to death within hours if untreated"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by describing a case of severe dehydration due to cholera, highlighting its systemic nature and the rapid onset of severe symptoms.", "reference": "PMID:34523840", "snippet": "A 28-year-old female presented with severe dehydration due to acute diarrhea and vomiting, which she developed after returning from a vacation in Togo", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by noting that severe dehydration is a common and critical condition in cholera patients, which can lead to death if untreated.", "reference": "PMID:31668817", "snippet": "Cholera still affects about three million people a year and kills approximately 100,000. Cholera can be effectively managed in the majority of cases with oral rehydration solution alone. Up to one third of patients present with severe dehydration, which can be diagnosed clinically, and will require rapid intravenous rehydration with Ringers Lactate or other appropriate fluid before being managed with oral rehydration solution.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the systemic impact of cholera, including dehydration, which can lead to severe complications and death.", "reference": "PMID:33252133", "snippet": "The morbidity and mortality of cholera is resultant from large-volume diarrhea, hypovolemia, and electrolyte derangement.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Dehydration", "notes": "Can lead to death within hours if untreated", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Dehydration", "term": {"id": "HP:0001944", "label": "Dehydration"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Sunken Eyes"}, {"target": "Low Blood Pressure"}, {"target": "Tachycardia"}, {"target": "Acute Kidney Injury"}]}

name: Hypovolemic Shock
notes: Caused by severe dehydration due to fluid loss
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Hypovolemic Shock", "notes": "Caused by severe dehydration due to fluid loss"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference states that cholera leads to severe dehydration and shock, which aligns with the statement indicating that cholera can occasionally cause hypovolemic shock due to severe dehydration.", "reference": "PMID:14738797", "snippet": "Intestinal infection with Vibrio cholerae results in the loss of large volumes of watery stool, leading to severe and rapidly progressing dehydration and shock.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The title of the reference suggests that hypovolemia, which can lead to hypovolemic shock, is a significant effect of cholera.", "reference": "PMID:4869291", "snippet": "Hemodynamic studies on cholera. Effects of hypovolemia and acidosis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference confirms that cholera causes hypovolemia, which can lead to hypovolemic shock, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:33252133", "snippet": "The morbidity and mortality of cholera is resultant from large-volume diarrhea, hypovolemia, and electrolyte derangement.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Hypovolemic Shock", "notes": "Caused by severe dehydration due to fluid loss", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypovolemic Shock", "term": {"id": "HP:0031274", "label": "Hypovolemic shock"}}}

name: Hypokalemia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Electrolyte/Metabolic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hypokalemia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Electrolyte/Metabolic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates that hypokalemia is a frequent occurrence in cholera patients, particularly during the acute stage and rehydration process.", "reference": "PMID:5300879", "snippet": "Hypokalaemic patterns were seen in 40% of the cases in the acute stage (during rehydration). This pattern became more marked after rehydration and disappeared gradually within 3-7 days.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This case report mentions hyperkalemia in a cholera patient, not hypokalemia. Therefore, it does not support the statement about frequent hypokalemia in cholera.", "reference": "PMID:33252133", "snippet": "On presentation, he was hyperkalemic with ECG changes and soon went into a hypovolemic shock.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference mentions potassium losses as part of the treatment for severe cholera, which indirectly suggests hypokalemia might occur, but it does not provide direct evidence of its frequency.", "reference": "PMID:28957470", "snippet": "Severe cholera is a life-threatening illness of hypovolemic shock and metabolic acidosis due to rapid and profuse diarrheal fluid loss. Emergency life-saving therapy is i.v. saline, optionally supplemented with potassium and alkali to correct the fluid deficit, potassium losses and acidosis.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hypokalemia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypokalemia", "term": {"id": "HP:0002900", "label": "Hypokalemia"}}}

name: Metabolic Acidosis
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Electrolyte/Metabolic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Metabolic Acidosis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Electrolyte/Metabolic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study discusses the presence of metabolic acidosis in a cholera patient, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:15367740", "snippet": "A patient presented with cholera and a severe degree of ECF volume contraction. Despite large losses of bicarbonate (HCO3-)-containing diarrhoeal fluid, laboratory acid-base values were remarkably close to normal. A detailed analysis emphasizing principles of physiology and a quantitative approach provided new insights and eventually better definitions of metabolic and respiratory acidosis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Electrolyte derangement in cholera can lead to conditions like metabolic acidosis, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:33252133", "snippet": "The morbidity and mortality of cholera is resultant from large-volume diarrhea, hypovolemia, and electrolyte derangement.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The mention of acid-base balance in cholera suggests a frequent occurrence of metabolic acidosis, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:5697815", "snippet": "Oral maintenance of water-electrolyte and acid-base balance in cholera: a preliminary report.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Metabolic Acidosis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Metabolic Acidosis", "term": {"id": "HP:0001942", "label": "Metabolic acidosis"}}}

name: Dyspnea
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Dyspnea"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature supports that dyspnea is a common symptom in COPD and is frequently observed in patients, confirming its categorization as a respiratory phenotype with diagnostic importance.", "reference": "PMID:28277858", "snippet": "Indeed, it is an important symptom in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), where it is associated with limited physical activity, increased anxiety and depression, decreased health-related quality of life (HRQoL), and reduced survival.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study highlights the high prevalence of dyspnea in patients with COPD, further supporting its status as a very frequent respiratory phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:35698999", "snippet": "Dyspnoea and pain are symptoms of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)... The pooled prevalence of pain and dyspnoea was 44% (95% confidence interval (CI) 35%-52%) and 91% (95% CI 87%-94%) respectively.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The correlation between dyspnea and COPD is reinforced by the positive association found with certain markers in exhaled breath condensate.", "reference": "PMID:34972922", "snippet": "Up to date research has shown a positive correlation between the elevated levels of some markers of EBC such as H2O2 and 8-isoprostane and dyspnea, while others present ambiguous results", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Dyspnea", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Dyspnea", "term": {"id": "HP:0002094", "label": "Dyspnea"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Exercise Intolerance"}]}

name: Chronic Cough
notes: Often productive of mucus
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic Cough", "notes": "Often productive of mucus"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study identifies chronic cough as a common and significant phenotype in COPD patients, indicating its very frequent occurrence and diagnostic importance.", "reference": "PMID:29881269", "snippet": "Compared with patients without chronic cough, those with chronic cough exhibited a lower forced expiratory volume in 1 second (% predicted) and diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (% predicted), more frequent AECOPD, more severe dyspnea, and worse QoL.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The statement mentions the heterogeneity of COPD with multiple phenotypes, which could include phenotypes like chronic cough.", "reference": "PMID:31740261", "snippet": "COPD is now widely accepted as a heterogeneous condition with multiple phenotypes and endotypes. This review will discuss the old and new concepts for the different types of COPD phenotypes.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic Cough", "notes": "Often productive of mucus", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Chronic Cough", "term": {"id": "HP:0034315", "label": "Chronic cough"}}}

name: Sputum Production
notes: Mucus is often difficult to expectorate
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Sputum Production", "notes": "Mucus is often difficult to expectorate"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The title of the article itself suggests that sputum production is recognized as a phenotype of COPD.", "reference": "PMID:22753831", "snippet": "Chronic cough and sputum production: a clinical COPD phenotype?", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Chronic bronchitis, which involves overproduction and hypersecretion of mucus, is described as a common phenomenon in COPD, indicating sputum production is a frequent COPD phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:23204254", "snippet": "Chronic bronchitis (CB) is a common but variable phenomenon in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Sputum Production", "notes": "Mucus is often difficult to expectorate", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Sputum Production", "term": {"id": "HP:0033709", "label": "Increased sputum production"}}}

name: Wheezing
notes: Due to airflow obstruction
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Wheezing", "notes": "Due to airflow obstruction"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract mentions wheezing as one of the clinical symptoms of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD).", "reference": "PMID:33302722", "snippet": "The clinical symptoms of this disease include progressive dyspnea, cough, expectoration, and wheezing, among others.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract indicates that wheezing can be a symptom of various conditions, including COPD-related bronchospasm.", "reference": "PMID:11963614", "snippet": "Remember, all that wheezes is not asthma; therefore, providers in this case had to determine if the patient was suffering something such as anaphylaxis, asthma, bronchitis, pneumonia or even congestive heart failure (CHF).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract discusses increased airway reactivity, which is related to wheezing, in patients with chronic airflow obstruction, including COPD.", "reference": "PMID:2404712", "snippet": "Increased airways reactivity is present in 15 to 70 percent of patients with chronic airflow obstruction.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Wheezing", "notes": "Due to airflow obstruction", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Wheezing", "term": {"id": "HP:0030828", "label": "Wheezing"}}}

name: Barrel Chest
notes: Due to hyperinflation of the lungs
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Barrel Chest", "notes": "Due to hyperinflation of the lungs"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference supports the association of lung hyperinflation with COPD but does not specifically mention 'Barrel Chest' or its frequency.", "reference": "PMID:25159007", "snippet": "Lung hyperinflation is highly prevalent in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and occurs across the continuum of the disease.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference discusses the clinical manifestations of COPD but does not specifically mention 'Barrel Chest' or its frequency.", "reference": "PMID:34972922", "snippet": "Attempts to connect the products of the analysis of the EBC with the clinical manifestations of COPD such as dyspnea are scarce.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference discusses chronic bronchitis in COPD but does not mention 'Barrel Chest' or its frequency.", "reference": "PMID:23204254", "snippet": "Chronic bronchitis (CB) is a common but variable phenomenon in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Barrel Chest", "notes": "Due to hyperinflation of the lungs"}

name: Respiratory Failure
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Respiratory Failure"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference indicates that respiratory failure is an important and common complication of COPD, not an occasional one.", "reference": "PMID:14621114", "snippet": "Respiratory failure is still an important complication of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and hospitalisation with an acute episode being a poor prognostic marker.", "supports": "REFUTE"}, {"explanation": "The reference suggests that hypoventilation, which can lead to respiratory failure, is not uncommon in COPD.", "reference": "PMID:38692758", "snippet": "Hypoventilation is a complication that is not uncommon in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and calls for both medical treatment of the underlying disease and, frequently, noninvasive ventilation either during exacerbations requiring hospitalization or in a chronic state in the patient at home.", "supports": "REFUTE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Respiratory Failure", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Respiratory Failure", "term": {"id": "HP:0002878", "label": "Respiratory failure"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Hypoxemia"}, {"target": "Hypercapnia"}]}

name: Fatigue
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The title itself indicates that fatigue is a recognized symptom of COPD.", "reference": "PMID:33998496", "snippet": "Fatigue: A neglected symptom of COPD.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference acknowledges fatigue as an important symptom of COPD, supporting its frequent occurrence.", "reference": "PMID:31729154", "snippet": "Fatigue is an important yet ignored symptom of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While this reference does not mention fatigue explicitly, it discusses systemic manifestations of COPD, implying the systemic nature of the disease.", "reference": "PMID:24874124", "snippet": "Symptoms in COPD do not solely arise from the degree of airflow obstruction as exercise limitation is compounded by the specific secondary manifestations of the disease including skeletal muscle impairment, osteoporosis, mood disturbance, anemia, and hormonal imbalance.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fatigue", "term": {"id": "HP:0012378", "label": "Fatigue"}}}

name: Weight Loss
notes: More common in advanced disease
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Weight Loss", "notes": "More common in advanced disease"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature states that weight loss is a common phenomenon in COPD patients, which supports the statement that weight loss is a systemic issue in COPD, more common in advanced disease.", "reference": "PMID:12406664", "snippet": "Weight loss occurs frequently in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference mentions unintentional weight loss as one of the systemic effects of COPD, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:18415812", "snippet": "These include unintentional weight loss, skeletal muscle dysfunction, an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, and depression, among others.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The mention of cachexia (underweight) as a comorbidity in COPD patients aligns with the statement about weight loss being more common in advanced disease.", "reference": "PMID:36922031", "snippet": "COPD patients with psychological (high anxiety and depression) and cachectic (underweight and osteoporotic) comorbidity have higher mortality and exacerbate more.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Weight Loss", "notes": "More common in advanced disease", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Weight loss", "term": {"id": "HP:0001824", "label": "Weight loss"}}}

name: Chronic Abdominal Pain

Many patients suffer from inadequate pain relief, completely incapacitating them in their daily activities.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic Abdominal Pain", "notes": "Epigastric, radiating to back", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Chronic Abdominal Pain", "term": {"id": "HP:0002027", "label": "Abdominal pain"}}}

name: Steatorrhea

raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Steatorrhea (excess faecal fat excretion) is a key manifestation of exocrine insufficiency in chronic pancreatitis, as demonstrated by its improvement with enzyme replacement therapy.", "reference": "PMID:27941156", "snippet": "PERT improved coefficient of nitrogen absorption, reduced faecal fat excretion, faecal nitrogen excretion, faecal weight and abdominal pain, without significant adverse events.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Steatorrhea", "notes": "Fat malabsorption", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Steatorrhea", "term": {"id": "HP:0002570", "label": "Steatorrhea"}}}

name: Weight Loss

raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Prospective study demonstrates that over half of CP patients experience weight loss, with significantly higher malnutrition rates than controls.", "reference": "PMID:18554234", "snippet": "After the onset of chronic pancreatitis, 56.5% of patients lost weight and significantly more patients became malnourished compared with controls (45.8% vs 22.5%; P < 0.001).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Weight Loss", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Weight Loss", "term": {"id": "HP:0001824", "label": "Weight loss"}}}

name: Chronic watery diarrhea
description: Persistent diarrhea is the primary clinical manifestation, resulting from impaired nutrient and fluid absorption due to altered intestinal architecture, epithelial barrier dysfunction, and villous atrophy.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Persistent diarrhea is the primary clinical manifestation, resulting from impaired nutrient and fluid absorption due to altered intestinal architecture, epithelial barrier dysfunction, and villous atrophy.\n", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic watery diarrhea"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Persistent diarrhea is the primary clinical manifestation, resulting from impaired nutrient and fluid absorption due to altered intestinal architecture, epithelial barrier dysfunction, and villous atrophy.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Literature documents watery diarrhea as the primary clinical manifestation in collagenous enteropathy", "reference": "DOI:10.1093/ecco-jcc/jjab123", "snippet": "MC is a multifactorial disease believed to involve innate and adaptive immune responses to luminal factors, genetic risk, autoimmunity, and extracellular matrix alterations, all contributing by varied mechanisms to watery diarrhoea", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic watery diarrhea", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Chronic diarrhea", "term": {"id": "HP:0002028", "label": "Chronic diarrhea"}}}

name: Malabsorption

It often presents with more severe symptoms and a worse prognosis compared to celiac disease, including significant malabsorption, weight loss, and nutrient deficiencies", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Protein-losing enteropathy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Protein-losing enteropathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0002243", "label": "Protein-losing enteropathy"}}}

Lifetime cancer risk estimated at 15-17%.\n", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "Establishes the approximately 17% lifetime malignancy risk in Costello syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:16443854", "snippet": "Individuals with CS have an increased risk of malignancy, suggested to be about 17%.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Predisposition to Malignancy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Neoplasm", "term": {"id": "HP:0002664", "label": "Neoplasm"}}}

name: Abdominal Pain
notes: Often occurs in the right lower quadrant
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Abdominal Pain", "notes": "Often occurs in the right lower quadrant"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"reference": "PMID:29246562", "snippet": "The most frequent symptoms are abdominal pain and diarrhoea, which can seriously affect patients' quality of life.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"reference": "PMID:33946069", "snippet": "In Crohn's disease, inflammation causes pain.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"reference": "PMID:35380673", "snippet": "The prevalence of pain was high in IBD patients ... and higher in CD patients.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While this reference focuses on identifying subpopulations with varying disease severity, it underscores the heterogeneity of Crohns disease symptoms, indirectly supporting that abdominal pain is a frequent symptom.", "reference": "PMID:33836648", "snippet": "Using the patients'' self-reported information, we identified two subpopulations of Crohn's disease; these subpopulations differ in disease severity, associations with smoking, and genetic transmission patterns.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Abdominal Pain", "notes": "Often occurs in the right lower quadrant", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abdominal pain", "term": {"id": "HP:0002027", "label": "Abdominal pain"}}}

name: Diarrhea
notes: Can be bloody or non-bloody
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Diarrhea", "notes": "Can be bloody or non-bloody"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference supports the presence of diarrhea and weight loss as frequent symptoms of Crohn's disease. However, it does not explicitly discuss malnutrition as a common sequela or confirm that these phenotypes are highly frequent.", "reference": "PMID:22230271", "snippet": "Patients may experience diarrhea, abdominal pain, fever, weight loss, abdominal masses, and anemia.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference mentions weight loss and suggests a role for malnutrition in Crohn's disease prognosis, but does not confirm high frequency of gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea.", "reference": "PMID:38036713", "snippet": "Malnutrition might play a key role in the prognosis of patients with Crohn's disease (CD) ... Forty-one patients (24.8%) had body weight loss whereas 124 patients (75.2%) had no body weight loss.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Diarrhea", "notes": "Can be bloody or non-bloody", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Diarrhea", "term": {"id": "HP:0002014", "label": "Diarrhea"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Weight Loss"}, {"target": "Malnutrition"}, {"target": "Dehydration"}]}

name: Fatigue
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference confirms that fatigue is a common symptom among Crohn's disease patients.", "reference": "PMID:23111414", "snippet": "A high percentage of CD patients suffer from fatigue.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference articulates the high prevalence of fatigue in inflammatory diseases, supporting the statement that fatigue is common among Crohn's disease patients.", "reference": "PMID:37569413", "snippet": "Despite high prevalence and importance, the symptom is often underestimated in clinical practice.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fatigue", "term": {"id": "HP:0012378", "label": "Fatigue"}}}

name: Perianal Disease
notes: Fistulas, abscesses, skin tags
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Perianal Disease", "notes": "Fistulas, abscesses, skin tags"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature supports that perianal disease is a manifestation of Crohn's disease and lists fistulas, abscesses, and skin tags as possible manifestations. However, it does not specifically address the frequency as 'occasional'.", "reference": "PMID:15227686", "snippet": "Perianal Crohn's disease can manifest as skin tags, ulcers, fissures, abscesses, fistulas or stenoses.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The literature indicates that perianal fistulas are common in Crohn's disease, which suggests a higher frequency than 'occasional'.", "reference": "PMID:15711045", "snippet": "Fistulas are common in Crohn's disease. A population-based study has shown a cumulative risk of 33% after 10 years and 50% after 20 years. Perianal fistulas were the most common (54%).", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The literature supports that perianal symptoms can be an initial presentation of Crohn's disease in children, but it does not specify the frequency as 'occasional'.", "reference": "PMID:33280851", "snippet": "Of children presenting with a perianal symptom, three percent will eventually be diagnosed with CD. At highest risk (35%) were males aged 10 years or older with a perianal fistula.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Perianal Disease", "notes": "Fistulas, abscesses, skin tags"}

name: Intestinal Obstruction
notes: Due to stricturing disease
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Intestinal Obstruction", "notes": "Due to stricturing disease"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference states that stricturing disease, a common phenotype of Crohn's disease, can lead to obstructive-like symptoms, supporting the statement that intestinal obstruction due to stricturing disease occurs occasionally in Crohn's disease.", "reference": "PMID:29043578", "snippet": "The most common phenotype is stricturing disease which can lead to obstructive-like symptoms.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference indicates that a significant proportion of Crohn's disease patients develop intestinal strictures, which can lead to obstruction, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:34014617", "snippet": "Approximately 70% of patients inevitably develop fibrosis-associated intestinal stricture after 10 years of CD diagnosis, which seriously affects their quality of life.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference confirms that inflammatory processes like Crohn's disease can lead to colonic obstructions, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:37973225", "snippet": "Benign etiologies of colonic obstructions include...inflammatory processes such as Crohn's disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Intestinal Obstruction", "notes": "Due to stricturing disease", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Intestinal Obstruction", "term": {"id": "HP:0004796", "label": "Gastrointestinal obstruction"}}}

name: Arthritis
notes: Can affect both large and small joints
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Arthritis", "notes": "Can affect both large and small joints"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that arthritis is a common extraintestinal manifestation of Crohn's disease, affecting both large and small joints.", "reference": "PMID:21122514", "snippet": "The most common extraintestinal manifestation, articular involvement, occurs in 16% to 33% of inflammatory bowel disease patients. These arthropathies may increase morbidity, resulting in a worse quality of life compared with inflammatory bowel disease patients without arthropathies.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study supports the occurrence of arthritis in Crohn's disease patients, particularly noting a higher prevalence in patients with coexisting FMF.", "reference": "PMID:36730654", "snippet": "The prevalence of peripheral arthritis was significantly higher in CD-FMF group (37.5% vs. 10.4%, respectively, P =0.04).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Arthritis", "notes": "Can affect both large and small joints", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Arthritis", "term": {"id": "HP:0001369", "label": "Arthritis"}}}

name: Erythema Nodosum
notes: Painful nodules on shins
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Erythema Nodosum", "notes": "Painful nodules on shins"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference confirms that erythema nodosum, characterized by tender red nodules on the shins, is associated with inflammatory bowel disease, which includes Crohn's disease.", "reference": "PMID:16143688", "snippet": "Erythema nodosum is a common cause of tender red nodules of the shins. Management includes leg elevation, NSAIDs, and potassium iodide.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the statement by mentioning that erythema nodosum is commonly triggered by systemic illnesses, including inflammatory bowel disease, which encompasses Crohn's disease.", "reference": "PMID:24746312", "snippet": "Erythema nodosum (EN) is clinically the most frequent form of panniculitis and is considered a reactive process that may be triggered by a wide variety of stimuli. Whilst up to 55% of EN is considered idiopathic, the most common causes include infections, drugs, systemic illnesses such as sarcoidosis and inflammatory bowel disease, pregnancy, and malignancy.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Erythema Nodosum", "notes": "Painful nodules on shins", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Erythema Nodosum", "term": {"id": "HP:0012219", "label": "Erythema nodosum"}}}

name: Fatigue
notes: Often worsened during disease flares

raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature explicitly states that fatigue is common in IBD, which includes Crohn's Disease.", "reference": "PMID:20456309", "snippet": "Fatigue is common, disabling yet underappreciated, in patients with chronic diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference mentions pain and depression as associated with IBD but does not specifically mention fatigue. However, the association with other systemic symptoms suggests a partial support.", "reference": "PMID:17560419", "snippet": "Pain and depression are associated with inflammatory bowel disease, and their control benefits patients.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue", "notes": "Often worsened during disease flares", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fatigue", "term": {"id": "HP:0012378", "label": "Fatigue"}}}

name: Fever
notes: More common during acute flares

raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference confirms that fever is a symptom associated with acute exacerbations of Crohn's disease.", "reference": "PMID:30244270", "snippet": "Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease. The disease is characterized by acute exacerbations with diarrhea, abdominal pain, fever, anorexia, intestinal bleeding, and weight loss.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by indicating that fever is a prominent symptom in patients with Crohn's disease.", "reference": "PMID:921308", "snippet": "In 32 patients with Crohn's disease which started in childhood, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and weight loss were the common presenting symptoms, but unexplained fever and failure to grow were also prominent.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by highlighting that fever is a frequent issue in Crohn's disease, especially during exacerbations.", "reference": "PMID:27743896", "snippet": "A frequent problem in CD is the discrimination of fever caused by exacerbated bowel inflammation or IAA.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by providing a case where a patient with Crohn's disease experienced persistent fever.", "reference": "PMID:31347993", "snippet": "A 23-year-old man with a known history of Crohn's disease (CD), who underwent an ileocaecal resection for localized disease activity three months ago, suffered from persistent fever with chills since 10 days.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Fever", "notes": "More common during acute flares", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fever", "term": {"id": "HP:0001945", "label": "Fever"}}}

name: Gastrointestinal polyposis
description: Extensive hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract, particularly in the stomach, duodenum, jejunum, ileum, and colon. Polyps may cause obstruction, bleeding, or protein loss.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Extensive hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract, particularly in the stomach, duodenum, jejunum, ileum, and colon. Polyps may cause obstruction, bleeding, or protein loss.\n", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Gastrointestinal polyposis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Extensive hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract, particularly in the stomach, duodenum, jejunum, ileum, and colon. Polyps may cause obstruction, bleeding, or protein loss.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Defines CCS as characterized by diffuse gastrointestinal polyposis, establishing this as a cardinal defining feature", "reference": "PMID:38297356", "snippet": "Cronkhite-Canada syndrome (CCS) is a rare, nonhereditary disease characterized by diffuse gastrointestinal polyposis and ectodermal abnormalities.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Recent case demonstrates diffuse polyposis throughout entire GI tract as diagnostic hallmark of CCS", "reference": "PMID:40709433", "snippet": "Endoscopic and histopathological examinations revealed diffuse polyposis throughout the gastrointestinal tract, consistent with CCS findings.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Gastrointestinal polyposis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hamartomatous polyposis", "term": {"id": "HP:0004390", "label": "Hamartomatous polyposis"}}}

name: Alopecia
description: Hair loss affecting the scalp and sometimes eyebrows and body hair. Typically reversible with disease remission. Pathophysiology may involve lymphocytic infiltration around hair bulbs and follicle atrophy, though malnutrition also contributes.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cutaneous", "description": "Hair loss affecting the scalp and sometimes eyebrows and body hair. Typically reversible with disease remission. Pathophysiology may involve lymphocytic infiltration around hair bulbs and follicle atrophy, though malnutrition also contributes.\n", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Alopecia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cutaneous", "description": "Hair loss affecting the scalp and sometimes eyebrows and body hair. Typically reversible with disease remission. Pathophysiology may involve lymphocytic infiltration around hair bulbs and follicle atrophy, though malnutrition also contributes.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Describes the cutaneous manifestation of alopecia as a characteristic feature of Cronkhite-Canada syndrome", "reference": "PMID:33163187", "snippet": "Typical alopecia involves hair loss, but it is not limited to hair; eyebrows and eyelashes can also fall out", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Recent case report confirms hair loss as a primary clinical manifestation of CCS in a 72-year-old female", "reference": "PMID:39470508", "snippet": "The primary clinical manifestations of CCS include hair loss, excessive pigmentation of the skin, and malnourishment of fingernails or toenails.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Alopecia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Alopecia", "term": {"id": "HP:0001596", "label": "Alopecia"}}}

name: Nail changes
description: Onychodystrophy characterized by nail ridging, discoloration, thickening, and separation. Often reversible with disease remission. Typical nail changes include thin, soft, triangular nail plates.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cutaneous", "description": "Onychodystrophy characterized by nail ridging, discoloration, thickening, and separation. Often reversible with disease remission. Typical nail changes include thin, soft, triangular nail plates.\n", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Nail changes"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cutaneous", "description": "Onychodystrophy characterized by nail ridging, discoloration, thickening, and separation. Often reversible with disease remission. Typical nail changes include thin, soft, triangular nail plates.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Characterizes the distinctive nail changes seen in Cronkhite-Canada syndrome", "reference": "PMID:33163187", "snippet": "Typical nail changes include thin, soft, triangular nail plates", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Recent comprehensive case report documents nail malnourishment as a primary clinical manifestation", "reference": "PMID:39470508", "snippet": "The primary clinical manifestations of CCS include hair loss, excessive pigmentation of the skin, and malnourishment of fingernails or toenails.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Nail changes", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Onychodystrophy", "term": {"id": "HP:0008394", "label": "Congenital onychodystrophy"}}}

name: Hyperpigmentation
description: Increased skin pigmentation, typically affecting the palms, soles, and dorsal surfaces of hands and feet. Pigmentation appears as brown macules or red nonpruritic nodular papules and can also involve the oral mucosa.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cutaneous", "description": "Increased skin pigmentation, typically affecting the palms, soles, and dorsal surfaces of hands and feet. Pigmentation appears as brown macules or red nonpruritic nodular papules and can also involve the oral mucosa.\n", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hyperpigmentation"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cutaneous", "description": "Increased skin pigmentation, typically affecting the palms, soles, and dorsal surfaces of hands and feet. Pigmentation appears as brown macules or red nonpruritic nodular papules and can also involve the oral mucosa.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Describes the characteristic pattern and appearance of skin hyperpigmentation in Cronkhite-Canada syndrome", "reference": "PMID:33163187", "snippet": "With regard to skin changes, pigmentation of the skin is a vital sign, such as brown macula or red nonpruritic nodular papules, which can be seen on the scalp, wrist, palms, soles, limbs, face, and chest", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hyperpigmentation", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hyperpigmentation", "term": {"id": "HP:0000953", "label": "Hyperpigmentation of the skin"}}}

name: Chronic diarrhea
description: Persistent diarrhea caused by malabsorption from the polyp-affected intestinal tract. Often described as watery diarrhea occurring multiple times daily, sometimes with occult or overt GI bleeding.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Persistent diarrhea caused by malabsorption from the polyp-affected intestinal tract. Often described as watery diarrhea occurring multiple times daily, sometimes with occult or overt GI bleeding.\n", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic diarrhea"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Persistent diarrhea caused by malabsorption from the polyp-affected intestinal tract. Often described as watery diarrhea occurring multiple times daily, sometimes with occult or overt GI bleeding.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Establishes diarrhea as a typical feature of Cronkhite-Canada syndrome presentation", "reference": "PMID:33163187", "snippet": "Typical symptoms of CCS include hypogeusia, diarrhea, abdominal pain, alopecia, skin pigmentation, onychodystrophy, and even onychomadesis", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Recent comprehensive review confirms diarrhea as a notable feature of CCS presentation alongside weight loss and protein-losing enteropathy", "reference": "PMID:39470508", "snippet": "Other notable symptoms include weight loss, protein-losing enteropathy, diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, taste abnormalities, and atrophic glossitis", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic diarrhea", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Diarrhea", "term": {"id": "HP:0002014", "label": "Diarrhea"}}}

name: Protein-losing enteropathy
description: Loss of plasma proteins into the gastrointestinal lumen, resulting in hypoalbuminemia, edema, and immune dysfunction. Mucosal inflammation with epithelial damage and villous atrophy leads to significant protein loss and nutritional compromise.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Loss of plasma proteins into the gastrointestinal lumen, resulting in hypoalbuminemia, edema, and immune dysfunction. Mucosal inflammation with epithelial damage and villous atrophy leads to significant protein loss and nutritional compromise.\n", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Protein-losing enteropathy"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Loss of plasma proteins into the gastrointestinal lumen, resulting in hypoalbuminemia, edema, and immune dysfunction. Mucosal inflammation with epithelial damage and villous atrophy leads to significant protein loss and nutritional compromise.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Indicates severe complications from protein-losing enteropathy and malnutrition are major causes of morbidity and mortality", "reference": "PMID:33163187", "snippet": "The prognosis of CCS is poor, with a 5-year mortality rate of 55%", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Confirms protein-losing enteropathy as a notable and frequently occurring symptom in CCS, particularly in middle-aged and older patients", "reference": "PMID:39470508", "snippet": "Other notable symptoms include weight loss, protein-losing enteropathy, diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, taste abnormalities, and atrophic glossitis, which predominantly occur in middle-aged and older males.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Protein-losing enteropathy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Protein-losing enteropathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0002243", "label": "Protein-losing enteropathy"}}}

name: Multiple Suture Craniosynostosis
description: Premature fusion of multiple sutures including coronal, sagittal, and lambdoid, causing variable skull shape abnormalities.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Premature fusion of multiple sutures including coronal, sagittal, and lambdoid, causing variable skull shape abnormalities.\n", "name": "Multiple Suture Craniosynostosis"}
raw_json: {"description": "Premature fusion of multiple sutures including coronal, sagittal, and lambdoid, causing variable skull shape abnormalities.\n", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "Confirms craniosynostosis as a defining characteristic of Crouzon syndrome, occurring without the limb anomalies seen in related FGFR2 syndromes like Apert or Pfeiffer.", "reference": "PMID:7493034", "snippet": "Crouzon syndrome, an autosomal dominant condition characterized by craniosynostosis, ocular proptosis and midface hypoplasia", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Multiple Suture Craniosynostosis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Multiple suture craniosynostosis", "term": {"id": "HP:0011324", "label": "Multiple suture craniosynostosis"}}}

name: Craniosynostosis

name: Acanthosis Nigricans
description: Hyperpigmented, velvety thickening of the skin, typically in flexural areas (neck, axillae, groin). This distinguishes CAN from classic Crouzon syndrome and reflects the broader tissue effects of the specific FGFR3 mutation.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Hyperpigmented, velvety thickening of the skin, typically in flexural areas (neck, axillae, groin). This distinguishes CAN from classic Crouzon syndrome and reflects the broader tissue effects of the specific FGFR3 mutation.\n", "name": "Acanthosis Nigricans"}
raw_json: {"description": "Hyperpigmented, velvety thickening of the skin, typically in flexural areas (neck, axillae, groin). This distinguishes CAN from classic Crouzon syndrome and reflects the broader tissue effects of the specific FGFR3 mutation.\n", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "Acanthosis nigricans is a defining feature that distinguishes this syndrome from classic FGFR2-related Crouzon syndrome.\n", "reference": "PMID:7493034", "snippet": "We now report the unexpected observation of a FGFR3 transmembrane domain mutation, Ala391Glu, in three unrelated families with Crouzon syndrome and acanthosis nigricans, a specific skin disorder of hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Acanthosis Nigricans", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Acanthosis nigricans", "term": {"id": "HP:0000956", "label": "Acanthosis nigricans"}}}

name: Central Obesity
description: Preferential fat deposition in the trunk, face (moon facies), and dorsocervical area (buffalo hump) with relative sparing of the extremities, characteristic of hypercortisolism.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Preferential fat deposition in the trunk, face (moon facies), and dorsocervical area (buffalo hump) with relative sparing of the extremities, characteristic of hypercortisolism.\n", "name": "Central Obesity"}
raw_json: {"description": "Preferential fat deposition in the trunk, face (moon facies), and dorsocervical area (buffalo hump) with relative sparing of the extremities, characteristic of hypercortisolism.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This confirms central obesity with excess fat in the face, back of neck (buffalo hump), and visceral organs.", "reference": "PMID:37432427", "snippet": "Cushing syndrome characteristically presents with skin changes such as facial plethora, easy bruising, and purple striae and with metabolic manifestations such as hyperglycemia, hypertension, and excess fat deposition in the face, back of the neck, and visceral organs.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Central Obesity", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "truncal obesity", "term": {"id": "HP:0001956", "label": "Truncal obesity"}}}

name: Purple Striae
description: Wide (greater than 1 cm), violaceous stretch marks, typically on the abdomen, thighs, and upper arms, resulting from cortisol-induced collagen breakdown and skin thinning.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Wide (greater than 1 cm), violaceous stretch marks, typically on the abdomen, thighs, and upper arms, resulting from cortisol-induced collagen breakdown and skin thinning.\n", "name": "Purple Striae"}

name: Proximal Muscle Weakness
description: Progressive weakness and wasting of proximal muscles, particularly of the lower extremities and pelvic girdle, due to cortisol-induced protein catabolism and myopathy.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Progressive weakness and wasting of proximal muscles, particularly of the lower extremities and pelvic girdle, due to cortisol-induced protein catabolism and myopathy.\n", "name": "Proximal Muscle Weakness"}
raw_json: {"description": "Progressive weakness and wasting of proximal muscles, particularly of the lower extremities and pelvic girdle, due to cortisol-induced protein catabolism and myopathy.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Protein catabolism from cortisol excess causes proximal muscle weakness and myopathy.", "reference": "PMID:37432427", "snippet": "Cushing syndrome is associated with hyperglycemia, protein catabolism, immunosuppression, hypertension, weight gain, neurocognitive changes, and mood disorders.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Proximal Muscle Weakness", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "proximal muscle weakness", "term": {"id": "HP:0003701", "label": "Proximal muscle weakness"}}}

name: Hypertension
description: Elevated blood pressure occurring in the majority of patients, resulting from cortisol's mineralocorticoid effects on sodium retention and vascular reactivity.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Elevated blood pressure occurring in the majority of patients, resulting from cortisol's mineralocorticoid effects on sodium retention and vascular reactivity.\n", "name": "Hypertension"}

name: Glucose Intolerance
description: Impaired glucose tolerance or overt diabetes mellitus due to cortisol-induced insulin resistance and increased hepatic gluconeogenesis.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Impaired glucose tolerance or overt diabetes mellitus due to cortisol-induced insulin resistance and increased hepatic gluconeogenesis.\n", "name": "Glucose Intolerance"}

name: Osteoporosis
description: Decreased bone mineral density and increased fracture risk due to cortisol's inhibitory effects on osteoblast function, calcium absorption, and increased bone resorption.

name: Easy Bruising
description: Increased skin fragility and easy bruising resulting from cortisol-induced loss of subcutaneous connective tissue and capillary fragility.

name: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
description: Progressive thickening of the heart muscle, particularly the left ventricle, is the most common and severe manifestation of Danon disease. This typically presents in childhood or adolescence in males and can lead to heart failure and arrhythmias. Cardiomyopathy is the leading cause of death and the main prognostic factor.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Progressive thickening of the heart muscle, particularly the left ventricle, is the most common and severe manifestation of Danon disease. This typically presents in childhood or adolescence in males and can lead to heart failure and arrhythmias. Cardiomyopathy is the leading cause of death and the main prognostic factor.\n", "name": "Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy"}
raw_json: {"description": "Progressive thickening of the heart muscle, particularly the left ventricle, is the most common and severe manifestation of Danon disease. This typically presents in childhood or adolescence in males and can lead to heart failure and arrhythmias. Cardiomyopathy is the leading cause of death and the main prognostic factor.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Confirms hypertrophic cardiomyopathy as a primary clinical feature of Danon disease.", "reference": "DOI:10.1111/nan.12587", "snippet": "Danon disease is a severe multisystem disorder clinically characterized by hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, skeletal myopathy and mental retardation in male patients", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Establishes cardiomyopathy as the leading cause of death and main prognostic factor.", "reference": "DOI:10.3390/biom14101272", "snippet": "Male patients present with the triad of cardiomyopathy, myopathy, and intellectual disability, while female patients present with cardiomyopathy. The disease's leading cause of death is heart failure, and its prognostic factor is cardiomyopathy.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0001639", "label": "Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy"}}}

name: Skeletal myopathy
description: Weakness of skeletal muscles, particularly proximal muscles, is common in Danon disease. Muscle biopsy shows autophagic vacuoles with sarcolemmal features. This can cause difficulty with physical activities and may be progressive.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Weakness of skeletal muscles, particularly proximal muscles, is common in Danon disease. Muscle biopsy shows autophagic vacuoles with sarcolemmal features. This can cause difficulty with physical activities and may be progressive.\n", "name": "Skeletal myopathy"}
raw_json: {"description": "Weakness of skeletal muscles, particularly proximal muscles, is common in Danon disease. Muscle biopsy shows autophagic vacuoles with sarcolemmal features. This can cause difficulty with physical activities and may be progressive.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Confirms skeletal myopathy as part of the clinical triad in affected males.", "reference": "DOI:10.1111/nan.12587", "snippet": "Danon disease is a severe multisystem disorder clinically characterized by hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, skeletal myopathy and mental retardation in male patients", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Supports the role of autophagy dysfunction in skeletal myopathy pathogenesis.", "reference": "DOI:10.1146/annurev-pathmechdis-012419-032618", "snippet": "Through impairment of muscle homeostasis, autophagy dysfunction contributes to the pathogenesis of many different skeletal myopathies", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Skeletal myopathy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Myopathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0003198", "label": "Myopathy"}}}

name: Intellectual disability
description: Cognitive impairment of variable severity is frequently observed in affected males, ranging from mild learning difficulties to more significant intellectual disability. This is part of the classic clinical triad in male patients.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Cognitive impairment of variable severity is frequently observed in affected males, ranging from mild learning difficulties to more significant intellectual disability. This is part of the classic clinical triad in male patients.\n", "name": "Intellectual disability"}

name: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
description: Ventricular pre-excitation due to accessory atrioventricular electrical conduction pathways is frequently observed in Danon disease patients. This cardiac conduction abnormality may precede overt cardiomyopathy.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Ventricular pre-excitation due to accessory atrioventricular electrical conduction pathways is frequently observed in Danon disease patients. This cardiac conduction abnormality may precede overt cardiomyopathy.\n", "name": "Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome"}
raw_json: {"description": "Ventricular pre-excitation due to accessory atrioventricular electrical conduction pathways is frequently observed in Danon disease patients. This cardiac conduction abnormality may precede overt cardiomyopathy.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Case report documenting WPW syndrome as an early manifestation in a Danon disease patient.", "reference": "DOI:10.3390/genes14081539", "snippet": "At the age of 13, he was diagnosed with mild ventricular pre-excitation known as Wolf-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPWs)", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome", "term": {"id": "HP:0001716", "label": "Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome"}}}

name: Retinal dystrophy
description: Photoreceptor and retinal pigment epithelium degeneration has been reported in some Danon disease patients, presenting as cone-rod dystrophy and progressive visual impairment.

name: Visual Hallucinations
notes: Recurrent complex visual hallucinations are a core clinical feature of DLB, occurring in 60-80% of patients. These hallucinations are typically well-formed images of people or animals and are a distinguishing feature from other dementias.

name: Parkinsonism
notes: Parkinsonian motor features including rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability. Motor symptoms may present concurrently with or after cognitive symptoms, distinguishing DLB from Parkinson's disease dementia where motor symptoms precede dementia.

raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This confirms that parkinsonism is a core feature of DLB, with the temporal relationship to cognitive symptoms distinguishing it from Parkinson's disease dementia.", "reference": "PMID:29222591", "snippet": "Despite considerable clinical overlap, their diagnosis is based on an arbitrary distinction between the time of onset of motor and cognitive symptoms: dementia often preceding parkinsonism in DLB.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Parkinsonism", "notes": "Parkinsonian motor features including rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability. notes: Progressive cognitive impairment affecting attention, executive function, and visuospatial abilities. Cognitive fluctuations are characteristic, with marked variations in attention and alertness.

name: REM Sleep Behavior Disorder
notes: REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) is a chronic sleep condition characterized by dream enactment and loss of REM atonia. Isolated RBD is a powerful early predictor of DLB, with cognitive decline beginning up to 10 years prior to phenoconversion. Attention and executive dysfunction in RBD patients strongly predict development of dementia.

name: Seizures
description: Treatment-resistant seizures beginning in the first year of life, often triggered by fever, with progression to multiple seizure types.
notes: Include prolonged febrile seizures and various types of epilepsy as the condition progresses.

name: Respiratory Failure
description: Postictal respiratory compromise and sleep-associated breathing abnormalities contributing to SUDEP risk.
notes: Postictal ventilatory dysfunction can occur, particularly during sleep.

name: Sudden Unexpected Death in Epilepsy
description: Markedly elevated risk of sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP), accounting for up to 50% of deaths in Dravet syndrome. Linked to seizure burden, postictal cardiorespiratory dysfunction, and potential cardiac susceptibility.
notes: High premature mortality with SUDEP as leading cause. Risk peaks at ages 1-3 years and around 18 years.
