complex_fields_json: {"sequelae": [{"target": "Hypovolemic Shock"}, {"target": "Multiorgan Failure"}, {"description": "Ebola virus causes aggressive inflammatory response and impaired coagulation systems leading to hemorrhage and often death.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This paper establishes that Ebola virus causes systemic inflammatory response and coagulation impairment leading to hemorrhage and death.", "reference": "PMID:35446128", "snippet": "Ebola virus (EBV) disease (EVD) is a highly virulent systemic disease characterized by an aggressive systemic inflammatory response and impaired vascular and coagulation systems, often leading to uncontrolled hemorrhaging and death.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "target": "Vascular Dysfunction and Death"}]}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature confirms that hemorrhagic symptoms are a key diagnostic feature of EVD.", "reference": "PMID:32487785", "snippet": "It is usually diagnosed based on several clinical symptoms such as the sudden onset of illness, high fevers for less than three weeks, and at least two hemorrhagic symptoms despite no predisposing factors.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature confirms severe hemorrhagic fever as a phenotype of EVD.", "reference": "PMID:28484180", "snippet": "Ebolaviruses, members of the family Filoviridae, cause severe hemorrhagic fever in humans and nonhuman primates, with human case fatality rates of up to 90%.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature supports that EVD is a severe systemic disease with high fatality, implying high frequency and severity of symptoms like hemorrhage.", "reference": "PMID:30893774", "snippet": "Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) is one of the most lethal transmissible infections, characterized by a high fatality rate, and caused by a member of the Filoviridae family.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature supports that EVD is characterized by severe systemic symptoms, including severe hemorrhagic manifestations.", "reference": "PMID:35657325", "snippet": "A group of viruses within the genus Ebolavirus causes this severe hemorrhagic disease in humans: Ebola virus (EBOV; species Zaire ebolavirus), Sudan virus (SUDV; species Sudan ebolavirus), Bundibugyo virus, and Ta Forest virus", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hemorrhage", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hemorrhage", "term": {"id": "HP:0001892", "label": "Abnormal bleeding"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Hypovolemic Shock"}, {"target": "Multiorgan Failure"}, {"description": "Ebola virus causes aggressive inflammatory response and impaired coagulation systems leading to hemorrhage and often death.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This paper establishes that Ebola virus causes systemic inflammatory response and coagulation impairment leading to hemorrhage and death.", "reference": "PMID:35446128", "snippet": "Ebola virus (EBV) disease (EVD) is a highly virulent systemic disease characterized by an aggressive systemic inflammatory response and impaired vascular and coagulation systems, often leading to uncontrolled hemorrhaging and death.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "target": "Vascular Dysfunction and Death"}], "severity": "Severe"}

name: Vomiting
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Vomiting", "severity": "Severe"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "While vomiting is a common manifestation and can lead to severe consequences like life-threatening hypovolemia, the literature does not specifically categorize vomiting itself as \"severe.\" The severity is associated with the complications resulting from vomiting and other symptoms.", "reference": "PMID:25972150", "snippet": "Common gastrointestinal manifestations include...nausea and vomiting-60%...The diarrhea and nausea and vomiting frequently produce profound, life-threatening hypovolemia.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference indicates the inclusion of gastrointestinal signs in EVD, which can imply vomiting, but does not specifically mention the frequency or severity of vomiting.", "reference": "PMID:32080199", "snippet": "EVD outbreaks typically start from a single case of probable zoonotic transmission, followed by human-to-human transmission via direct contact or contact with infected bodily fluids or contaminated fomites. EVD has a high case-fatality rate; it is characterized by fever, gastrointestinal signs and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This suggests variability in EVD presentation, acknowledging severe forms, but it does not specify the severity or frequency of vomiting in particular.", "reference": "PMID:27717513", "snippet": "The clinical spectrum of Ebola virus disease (EVD) ranges from very serious forms with organ failure and death within days to paucisymptomatic forms and perhaps even asymptomatic.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Vomiting", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Vomiting", "term": {"id": "HP:0002013", "label": "Vomiting"}}, "severity": "Severe"}

name: Diarrhea
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Diarrhea", "severity": "Severe"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference mentions that EVD is characterized by gastrointestinal signs, indicating the relevance of diarrhea as a symptom.", "reference": "PMID:32080199", "snippet": "EVD has a high case-fatality rate; it is characterized by fever, gastrointestinal signs and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This directly supports the statement by noting that diarrhea is a common (70% frequency) gastrointestinal manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:25972150", "snippet": "Common gastrointestinal manifestations include diarrhea-70 %.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference highlights that severe gastrointestinal symptoms, including diarrhea, were common and associated with poor outcomes.", "reference": "PMID:34986351", "snippet": "During the 2013-2016 West African (WA) Ebola virus (EBOV) outbreak, severe gastrointestinal symptoms were common in patients and associated with poor outcome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Diarrhea", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Diarrhea", "term": {"id": "HP:0002014", "label": "Diarrhea"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Dehydration"}, {"target": "Electrolyte Imbalances"}], "severity": "Severe"}

name: Maculopapular Rash
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Maculopapular Rash"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The statement is supported as the primary dermatologic phenotype associated with Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) is a nonspecific maculopapular rash, and it is noted as a main cutaneous finding.", "reference": "PMID:25780982", "snippet": "The main cutaneous finding of Ebola is a nonspecific maculopapular rash that appears between day four and six of disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Maculopapular Rash"}

name: Fatigue
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Fatigue is reported as a symptom in 25% of EVD survivors, which indicates it is relatively common but not 'very frequent' as the statement suggests.", "reference": "PMID:38840082", "snippet": "The pooled prevalence was... fatigue 25% (95% CI: 19%-31%)", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fatigue", "term": {"id": "HP:0012378", "label": "Fatigue"}}}

name: Myalgia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Myalgia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The meta-analysis shows that myalgia has a pooled prevalence of 32% among Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) survivors, indicating it is a frequent musculoskeletal symptom.", "reference": "PMID:38840082", "snippet": "The pooled prevalence was: arthralgia 50% (95% CI: 41%-59%); headache 44% (95% CI: 36%-52%); myalgia 32% (95% CI: 26%-38%)", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Myalgia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Myalgia", "term": {"id": "HP:0003326", "label": "Myalgia"}}}

name: Headache
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Headache"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This study lists headache as one of the main clinical signs in children with EVD, supporting the statement that headache is an occasional neurologic symptom of EVD.", "reference": "PMID:31874716", "snippet": "The main clinical signs were asthenia (78.8%), fever (75.3%), anorexia (53.4%), headache (45.9%)...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While this reference does not explicitly mention headache, it discusses a range of neurologic symptoms in EVD patients, suggesting that neurologic symptoms, including headache, can occur occasionally.", "reference": "PMID:33493959", "snippet": "In patients with EVD, neurologic manifestations range from mild symptoms such as confusion to severe neurologic diseases such as meningitis and encephalitis. Altered mental status, from mild confusion to delirium with hallucinations, may also occur.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study reports that 48% of EVD survivors experienced headaches, supporting the statement that headache is an occasional neurologic symptom of EVD.", "reference": "PMID:26983037", "snippet": "Survivors reported musculoskeletal pain (70%), headache (48%), and ocular problems (14%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Headache", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Headache", "term": {"id": "HP:0002315", "label": "Headache"}}}

name: Abdominal Pain
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Abdominal Pain"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that abdominal pain occurs in 45% of EVD cases, supporting the claim that it is a frequent gastrointestinal manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:25972150", "snippet": "Common gastrointestinal manifestations include diarrhea-70 %, nausea and vomiting-60 %, and abdominal pain-45 %.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study shows that abdominal pain was observed in 29.5% of children with EVD, supporting the statement that it is a frequent gastrointestinal symptom.", "reference": "PMID:31874716", "snippet": "The main clinical signs were asthenia (78.8%), fever (75.3%), anorexia (53.4%), headache (45.9%), vomiting (41.8%), abdominal pain (29.5%), and diarrhea (28.8%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Abdominal Pain", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abdominal pain", "term": {"id": "HP:0002027", "label": "Abdominal pain"}}}

name: Thrombocytopenia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Thrombocytopenia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature mentions hemorrhagic symptoms but does not specifically mention thrombocytopenia or its frequency.", "reference": "PMID:32487785", "snippet": "Transmission of EBoV has been reported in various ways, including human to human transmission through close contact with blood and bodily fluids... It is usually diagnosed based on several clinical symptoms such as the sudden onset of illness, high fevers for less than three weeks, and at least two hemorrhagic symptoms despite no predisposing factors.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference discusses bleeding in Ebola virus disease but does not specifically mention thrombocytopenia or its frequency.", "reference": "PMID:25679971", "snippet": "Understanding bleeding in Ebola virus disease.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The literature discusses impaired vascular and coagulation systems, which can be related to thrombocytopenia, but does not specifically mention its frequency.", "reference": "PMID:35446128", "snippet": "Ebola virus (EBV) disease (EVD) is a highly virulent systemic disease characterized by an aggressive systemic inflammatory response and impaired vascular and coagulation systems, often leading to uncontrolled hemorrhaging and death.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Thrombocytopenia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Thrombocytopenia", "term": {"id": "HP:0001873", "label": "Thrombocytopenia"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Increased Risk of Bleeding"}]}

name: Hepatitis
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hepatic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hepatitis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Hepatic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference indicates that Ebola virus can cause hepatic injury, but clinically overt hepatocellular dysfunction is rare. This partially supports the statement as it acknowledges hepatic involvement but suggests that severe liver dysfunction is not frequent.", "reference": "PMID:2822180", "snippet": "Even though HAV, HBV and HNANB viruses are responsible for most of the viral hepatitis cases, many other viruses have been reported to cause hepatic injury. These viruses may involve the liver, either as part of a systemic illness (e.g. EBV, CMV, HSV) or as the primary target organ (e.g. yellow fever virus, Lassa fever virus, Ebola virus). Clinically overt hepatocellular dysfunction is rare in such viral infections.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference indicates elevated liver enzymes (AST and ALT) in Ebola virus infection, which supports the part of the statement regarding elevated liver enzymes. However, it does not confirm frequent impaired liver function or hepatitis as a common sequela.", "reference": "PMID:25972150", "snippet": "The mean serum AST and ALT levels are each about 200/UL, with an unusual pattern for viral hepatitis of AST > ALT.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference provides evidence of liver involvement and immune response alterations in Ebola virus infection, which can be associated with hepatic dysfunction. However, it does not explicitly state that hepatitis or impaired liver function is frequent.", "reference": "PMID:37170900", "snippet": "Results illustrate that EBOV causes macrophage phenotype alterations as well as neutrophil influx and prominent activation of interferon host responses in the liver.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference suggests that acute severe liver injury is not typical in Ebola virus disease, which refutes the statement that impaired liver function is frequent.", "reference": "PMID:29020340", "snippet": "The role of the virus in liver damage remains unclear, but our evidence suggests that acute severe liver injury is not a typical feature of Ebola virus disease.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hepatitis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hepatitis", "term": {"id": "HP:0012115", "label": "Hepatitis"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Elevated Liver Enzymes"}, {"target": "Impaired Liver Function"}]}

name: Joint Hypermobility
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Joint Hypermobility"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference confirms that musculoskeletal manifestations, including joint hypermobility, are highly prevalent in individuals with Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS).", "reference": "PMID:34807421", "snippet": "Currently, musculoskeletal manifestations related to joint hypermobility are perceived as the most prevalent determinants of the quality of life of affected individuals.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by highlighting the high frequency and significant impact of joint hypermobility (JH) and associated chronic joint pain and instabilities in EDS.", "reference": "PMID:29915965", "snippet": "Increasing data demonstrate that pain is a major disability determinator in JH and EDS. Recent findings confirm a complex pathogenesis for pain in JH and EDS and suggest a potential role for joint instability, central sensitization and small fiber neuropathy.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by acknowledging hypermobility of the joints as a characteristic of EDS, along with chronic pain and other musculoskeletal features.", "reference": "PMID:37726791", "snippet": "The Ehlers-Danlos syndromes are a group of clinically and genetically heterogeneous hereditary diseases affecting the connective tissue. They are characterized by hypermobility of the joints, hyperextensible skin and friable tissue.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Joint Hypermobility", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Joint Hypermobility", "term": {"id": "HP:0001382", "label": "Joint hypermobility"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Recurrent Joint Dislocations"}, {"target": "Chronic Joint Pain"}]}

name: Skin Hyperextensibility
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Skin Hyperextensibility"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference clearly states that cutaneous (skin) hyperextensibility is one of the cardinal features of Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS). This aligns with the statement indicating a high frequency dermatologic phenotype of skin hyperextensibility in EDS.", "reference": "PMID:358109", "snippet": "The cardinal features are cutaneous hyperextensibility, joint hypermobility, bleeding diathesis, and tissue fragility...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference shows that skin hyperextensibility is a consistent clinical feature across different EDS subtypes, which supports the statement about its high prevalence as a dermatologic phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:30837697", "snippet": "All individuals with these atypical variants exhibited skin hyperextensibility as seen in individuals with classical EDS and classical-like EDS...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Although this case was localized, it still confirms the presence of skin hyperextensibility in a patient with EDS, reinforcing its association with EDS.", "reference": "PMID:434850", "snippet": "Hyperextensibility of the skin in this region developed within the subsequent five years...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The overview and symptoms of various EDS subtypes include skin manifestations such as hyperextensibility, supporting the statement about its high prevalence.", "reference": "PMID:31904772", "snippet": "Of the 13 subtypes of Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes (EDSs)...the authors provide an overview of hEDS symptoms and... current treatment options.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference details abnormal collagen fibrils and associates them with EDS, indicating that skin hyperextensibility is a frequent manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:6733946", "snippet": "Collagen fibrils showed a distorted arrangement... abnormal collagen fibrils in normal skin suggests one of eight types of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Skin Hyperextensibility"}

name: Poor Wound Healing
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Poor Wound Healing"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference directly mentions delayed wound healing as a characteristic of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:19055167", "snippet": "Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) is a heterogeneous group of connective tissue disorders characterized by hyperextensibility, delayed wound healing, joint hypermobility, thin skin, easy bruising, tissue fragility, 'cigarette-paper' scarring over bony prominences, mitral valve prolapse, and other findings.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference acknowledges delayed wound healing in humans with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, although the study was conducted on animals.", "reference": "PMID:2728341", "snippet": "Although delayed wound healing has been reported to be a complication of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome in humans, using clinical and histologic criteria, wound healing in dogs and cats with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome appears to be similar to nonaffected animals.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference lists delayed wound healing as a characteristic feature of classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:20847697", "snippet": "Classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a heritable connective tissue disorder characterized by skin hyperextensibility, fragile and soft skin, delayed wound healing with formation of atrophic scars, easy bruising, and generalized joint hypermobility.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Poor Wound Healing", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Poor Wound Healing", "term": {"id": "HP:0001058", "label": "Poor wound healing"}}}

name: Arterial Dissection and Rupture
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Arterial Dissection and Rupture", "subtype": "Vascular EDS"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature specifies that the COL3A1 mutation, causing vascular EDS, leads to early vascular events including spontaneous arterial rupture or dissection.", "reference": "PMID:19462862", "snippet": "The mutation of the COL3A1 gene which encodes type III collagen, is responsible of early vascular (spontaneous arterial rupture or dissection), digestive (perforation) and obstetrical events (uterine and arterial rupture)", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature states that vascular EDS results in exceptional arterial fragility, justifying a high frequency of arterial dissection and rupture.", "reference": "PMID:30999998", "snippet": "The only published clinical trial to date demonstrated the benefit of celiprolol on arterial morbimortality.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Arterial Dissection and Rupture", "subtype": "Vascular EDS"}

name: Keratoconus
review_notes: Added less common phenotype for better completeness.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Keratoconus", "review_notes": "Added less common phenotype for better completeness."}
raw_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature highlights that Ehlers-Danlos syndrome has variable ophthalmic features, which supports the assertion that ophthalmologic phenotypes, including keratoconus, are part of the syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:36237549", "snippet": "In addition to these commonly recognized phenotypes, recent studies have notably highlighted variable ophthalmic features in EDS.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference talks mainly about kyphoscoliotic EDS and its genetic underpinnings, without specifically mentioning ophthalmologic features or keratoconus.", "reference": "PMID:28757364", "snippet": "As the two patients reported here illustrate, patients with kEDS-PLOD1 do not always have a kyphoscoliosis present at birth or in the first year of life, neither do they necessarily develop kyphoscoliosis later in infancy.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This reference discusses keratoconus but does not specifically link it to Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:9493273", "snippet": "Keratoconus is most commonly an isolated disorder, although several reports describe an association with Down syndrome, Leber's congenital amaurosis, and mitral valve prolapse.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The brittle cornea syndrome listed here shares ophthalmologic phenotypes, including keratoconus, similar to Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:14679583", "snippet": "The brittle cornea syndrome (BCS) is a generalized connective tissue disorder characterized by corneal rupture following only minor trauma, keratoconus or keratoglobus, blue sclerae, hyperelasticity of the skin without excessive fragility, and hypermobility of the joints.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference discusses keratoconus in the context of osteogenesis imperfecta, not Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:37074408", "snippet": "A high proportion of patients had tomographically suspect corneas when using keratoconus diagnostic indices", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Keratoconus", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Keratoconus", "term": {"id": "HP:0000563", "label": "Keratoconus"}}, "review_notes": "Added less common phenotype for better completeness."}

name: Mitral Valve Prolapse
review_notes: Added this cardiovascular manifestation seen in some EDS subtypes.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Mitral Valve Prolapse", "review_notes": "Added this cardiovascular manifestation seen in some EDS subtypes."}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This study reports the presence of mitral valve prolapse in patients with hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (hEDS) or hypermobility spectrum disorder (HSD).", "reference": "PMID:35000503", "snippet": "Mitral valve prolapse was present in 7.5% and thoracic aortic dilatation in 15.2%.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference mentions the association of mitral valve prolapse with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:6993166", "snippet": "It appears to occur more frequently in females and occasionally it is familial... particularly Marfan's syndrome, rheumatic heart disease, coronary heart disease, congestive cardiomyopathy, ostium secundum atrial septal defect, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome or abnormalities of the thoracic cage.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study confirms the association of mitral valve prolapse with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:34776077", "snippet": "There is substantial symptoms overlap between the EDS subtypes, and they are associated with an increased incidence of cardiovascular abnormalities, such as mitral valve prolapse and aortic dissection.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study indicates that mitral valve prolapse occurs at the same incidence in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome patients as in the general population.", "reference": "PMID:31328377", "snippet": "Mitral valve prolapse and bicuspid aortic valve occurred at the same incidence as the general population.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Mitral Valve Prolapse", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Mitral Valve Prolapse", "term": {"id": "HP:0001634", "label": "Mitral valve prolapse"}}, "review_notes": "Added this cardiovascular manifestation seen in some EDS subtypes."}

name: Arterial Dissection and Rupture
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Arterial Dissection and Rupture", "subtype": "Vascular EDS"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract explicitly mentions that spontaneous arterial rupture or dissection is a characteristic of vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (vEDS).", "reference": "PMID:19462862", "snippet": "The mutation of the COL3A1 gene which encodes type III collagen, is responsible of early vascular (spontaneous arterial rupture or dissection)...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study evaluates the treatment of life-threatening arterial rupture in vEDS patients, indicating that arterial rupture is a significant and frequent concern in this subtype.", "reference": "PMID:23657781", "snippet": "The indication of embolization was spontaneous arterial rupture or pseudoaneurysm with acute bleeding.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference highlights that type IV Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (vascular EDS) has a substantial risk of arterial rupture.", "reference": "PMID:7455751", "snippet": "Of the six subtypes of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which can usually be clinically differentiated, only types 1 and 4 appear to be associated with a substantial risk of arterial rupture.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract indicates that vEDS leads to exceptional arterial fragility, which supports the statement that arterial dissection and rupture are very frequent in this subtype.", "reference": "PMID:30999998", "snippet": "Vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (vEDS) is a rare genetic connective tissue disorder secondary to pathogenic variants within the COL3A1 gene, resulting in exceptional arterial and organ fragility and premature death.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study shows a high prevalence of arterial complications, including dissections, in patients with vEDS, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:33641388", "snippet": "Arterial complications can affect all anatomic areas and about 25% involve supra-aortic trunks (SATs)...Cumulative incidence of a first identification of a SAT lesion was 41.7% at 40 years old.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Arterial Dissection and Rupture", "subtype": "Vascular EDS"}

name: Gastroesophageal Reflux
review_notes: Added this gastrointestinal manifestation seen in some EDS patients.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Gastroesophageal Reflux", "review_notes": "Added this gastrointestinal manifestation seen in some EDS patients."}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature mentions heartburn and various other gastrointestinal symptoms but does not specifically mention gastroesophageal reflux as an occasional manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:26376608", "snippet": "Commonest GI symptoms were: abdominal pain (56.1%), nausea (42.3%), constipation (38.6%), heartburn (37.6%), and irritable bowel syndrome-like symptoms (27.5%).", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The literature focuses on gastroparesis in EDS patients but does not provide evidence for gastroesophageal reflux as an occasional manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:36000988", "snippet": "We report a significant enrichment of EDS cases in a set of patients with gastroparesis.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The literature mentions gastro-esophageal dysmotility and reflux as contributing factors but does not specify the frequency as 'occasional.'", "reference": "PMID:34811894", "snippet": "Functional aerodigestive manifestations such as inducible laryngeal obstruction may be misdiagnosed as asthma, with gastro-esophageal dysmotility and reflux as common contributing factors.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Gastroesophageal Reflux", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Gastroesophageal Reflux", "term": {"id": "HP:0002020", "label": "Gastroesophageal reflux"}}, "review_notes": "Added this gastrointestinal manifestation seen in some EDS patients."}

name: Keratoconus
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Keratoconus"}
raw_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature mentions variable ophthalmic features in Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, which includes conditions like keratoconus.", "reference": "PMID:36237549", "snippet": "In addition to these commonly recognized phenotypes, recent studies have notably highlighted variable ophthalmic features in EDS.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature indicates that patients with Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) may have underlying keratoconus, supporting the statement that keratoconus is an occasional ophthalmologic manifestation in EDS.", "reference": "PMID:34501218", "snippet": "Because many patients with HDCTs have ocular symptoms, commonly myopia, they will often present to the clinic seeking refractive surgery. Currently, corrective measures are limited, as the FDA contraindicates laser-assisted in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK) in EDS and discourages the procedure in OI and MFS due to a theoretically increased risk of post-LASIK ectasia, poor wound healing, poor refractive predictability, underlying keratoconus, and globe rupture.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Keratoconus", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Keratoconus", "term": {"id": "HP:0000563", "label": "Keratoconus"}}}

name: Joint Hypermobility
description: Abnormally increased range of motion in multiple joints due to lax connective tissue.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "description": "Abnormally increased range of motion in multiple joints due to lax connective tissue.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Joint Hypermobility"}
complex_fields_json: {"sequelae": [{"description": "Joint hypermobility predisposes to repeated episodes of joint displacement.", "target": "Recurrent Joint Dislocations"}, {"description": "Persistent joint pain resulting from joint instability and repeated subluxations.", "target": "Chronic Joint Pain"}]}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "description": "Abnormally increased range of motion in multiple joints due to lax connective tissue.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference supports the high frequency and significant impact of joint hypermobility in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:34807421", "snippet": "Currently, musculoskeletal manifestations related to joint hypermobility are perceived as the most prevalent determinants of the quality of life of affected individuals.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the musculoskeletal phenotype involving joint hypermobility and associated symptoms like joint pain.", "reference": "PMID:19370768", "snippet": "Classical Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) is a heritable disorder characterized by joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and abnormal wound healing.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This indicates a direct relationship between COL5A1 mutations and the classical EDS phenotype, which includes musculoskeletal manifestations such as joint hypermobility.", "reference": "PMID:35964930", "snippet": "Classical (cEDS) and vascular type (vEDS) are the most prevalent subtypes and are caused by heterozygous pathogenic variants in COL5A1, COL5A2, COL1A1 or, respectively, in COL3A1.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This supports the involvement of recurrent joint dislocations and chronic joint pain in the EDS phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:10906878", "snippet": "Thirty patients with Type III Ehlers-Danlos syndrome reported joint pain more frequently than did patients with Types I, II, or IV.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Joint Hypermobility", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Joint Hypermobility", "term": {"id": "HP:0001382", "label": "Joint hypermobility"}}, "sequelae": [{"description": "Joint hypermobility predisposes to repeated episodes of joint displacement.", "target": "Recurrent Joint Dislocations"}, {"description": "Persistent joint pain resulting from joint instability and repeated subluxations.", "target": "Chronic Joint Pain"}]}

name: Skin Hyperextensibility
description: Skin that can be stretched beyond the normal range and returns to its original position when released.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Skin that can be stretched beyond the normal range and returns to its original position when released.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Skin Hyperextensibility"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Skin that can be stretched beyond the normal range and returns to its original position when released.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract clearly states that skin hyperextensibility is a primary feature of classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is often caused by COL5A1 mutations.", "reference": "PMID:20847697", "snippet": "Classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a heritable connective tissue disorder characterized by skin hyperextensibility, fragile and soft skin...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Skin hyperextensibility is identified as a common feature in Ehlers-Danlos syndromes, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:36764582", "snippet": "A high prevalence of skin hyperextensibility, bruising, and soft skin were noted.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the dermatologic phenotype of Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, including traits commonly associated with COL5A1 mutations.", "reference": "PMID:37594181", "snippet": "The classic tragic facial expression was observed as well as chronic pruritus and mild hyperesthesia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Skin Hyperextensibility"}

name: Atrophic Scarring
description: Formation of thin, widened scars with a papyraceous or cigarette-paper appearance, typically over bony prominences.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Formation of thin, widened scars with a papyraceous or cigarette-paper appearance, typically over bony prominences.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Atrophic Scarring"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Formation of thin, widened scars with a papyraceous or cigarette-paper appearance, typically over bony prominences.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature specifies that classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which includes COL5A1-related cases, involves the formation of atrophic scars as a common dermatologic phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:20847697", "snippet": "Classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a heritable connective tissue disorder characterized by skin hyperextensibility, fragile and soft skin, delayed wound healing with formation of atrophic scars.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Atrophic Scarring"}

name: Easy Bruising
description: Increased susceptibility to bruising from minor trauma due to fragile blood vessels and connective tissue.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Increased susceptibility to bruising from minor trauma due to fragile blood vessels and connective tissue.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Easy Bruising"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Increased susceptibility to bruising from minor trauma due to fragile blood vessels and connective tissue.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference confirms the presence of easy bruising as a common phenotype of classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is often related to COL5A1 mutations.", "reference": "PMID:20847697", "snippet": "Classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a heritable connective tissue disorder characterized by ... easy bruising.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This source supports that easy bruising is a common dermatologic manifestation in Ehlers-Danlos syndromes, which includes types related to COL5A1 mutations.", "reference": "PMID:36764582", "snippet": "The Ehlers-Danlos syndromes (EDSs) comprise a group of connective tissue disorders that manifest with... easy bruising...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This excerpt indicates that easy bruising is a common feature across various subtypes of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which would include the COL5A1-related types.", "reference": "PMID:15566352", "snippet": "Easy bruising is, to a variable degree, present in all subtypes of EDS...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Easy Bruising"}

name: Mitral Valve Prolapse
description: Abnormal bulging of the mitral valve leaflets into the left atrium during systole due to connective tissue laxity.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "description": "Abnormal bulging of the mitral valve leaflets into the left atrium during systole due to connective tissue laxity.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Mitral Valve Prolapse"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "description": "Abnormal bulging of the mitral valve leaflets into the left atrium during systole due to connective tissue laxity.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature shows an occasional incidence of mitral valve prolapse in Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, and while the exact subtype related to COL5A1 is not specified, it partially supports the statement.", "reference": "PMID:21193204", "snippet": "Fifteen of the 252 patients (6.0%) had mitral valve prolapse (MVP), although only one patient (0.4%) had MVP that was mild to moderate.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the association of Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (a group including COL5A1-related subtypes) with mitral valve prolapse.", "reference": "PMID:34776077", "snippet": "The EDS are currently classified into thirteen subtypes. There is substantial symptoms overlap between the EDS subtypes, and they are associated with an increased incidence of cardiovascular abnormalities, such as mitral valve prolapse and aortic dissection.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Mitral Valve Prolapse", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Mitral Valve Prolapse", "term": {"id": "HP:0001634", "label": "Mitral valve prolapse"}}}

However, it does not explicitly distinguish the frequency of this phenotype for COL5A1-related EDS specifically.", "reference": "PMID:26376608", "snippet": "Commonest GI symptoms were: abdominal pain (56.1%), nausea (42.3%), constipation (38.6%), heartburn (37.6%), and irritable bowel syndrome-like symptoms (27.5%)... Among 37.8% of the 378 patients who underwent esophagogastroduodenoscopy, the commonest abnormalities were gastritis, hiatal hernia and reflux esophagitis.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Gastroesophageal Reflux", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Gastroesophageal Reflux", "term": {"id": "HP:0002020", "label": "Gastroesophageal reflux"}}}

name: Elevated Blood Pressure

raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This establishes hypertension as the defining diagnostic feature of the condition.", "reference": "PMID:38172242", "snippet": "Hypertension is a global health problem, with >1.3 billion individuals with high blood pressure worldwide.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This confirms the clinical significance of elevated blood pressure as the primary phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:38164753", "snippet": "Hypertension is the primary modifiable risk factor for cardiovascular, renal, and cerebrovascular diseases and is considered the main contributing factor to morbidity and mortality worldwide.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Elevated Blood Pressure", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypertension", "term": {"id": "HP:0000822", "label": "Hypertension"}}}

name: Left Ventricular Hypertrophy
notes: Secondary to chronic pressure overload
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Left Ventricular Hypertrophy", "notes": "Secondary to chronic pressure overload"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This confirms cardiac hypertrophy as a consequence of chronic hypertension and immune-mediated damage.", "reference": "PMID:38172242", "snippet": "The activated immune cells migrate to target organs such as arteries (especially the perivascular fat and adventitia), kidneys, the heart and the brain, where they release effector cytokines that elevate blood pressure and cause vascular remodelling, renal damage, cardiac hypertrophy, cognitive impairment and dementia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Left Ventricular Hypertrophy", "notes": "Secondary to chronic pressure overload", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Left Ventricular Hypertrophy", "term": {"id": "HP:0001712", "label": "Left ventricular hypertrophy"}}}

name: Renal Damage
notes: Hypertensive nephropathy and chronic kidney disease
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Renal", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Renal Damage", "notes": "Hypertensive nephropathy and chronic kidney disease"}
raw_json: {"category": "Renal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This confirms renal damage as a major consequence of chronic hypertension.", "reference": "PMID:39765782", "snippet": "Hypertension (HTN) is a major contributor to kidney damage, leading to conditions such as nephrosclerosis and hypertensive nephropathy, significant causes of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and end-stage renal disease (ESRD).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This describes immune-mediated renal damage as a consequence of hypertension.", "reference": "PMID:38172242", "snippet": "The activated immune cells migrate to target organs such as arteries (especially the perivascular fat and adventitia), kidneys, the heart and the brain, where they release effector cytokines that elevate blood pressure and cause vascular remodelling, renal damage, cardiac hypertrophy, cognitive impairment and dementia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This confirms the role of immune mechanisms in causing kidney damage in hypertension.", "reference": "PMID:38164753", "snippet": "Human and animal studies demonstrate that the immune system plays an important role in the etiology and pathogenesis of salt sensitivity of blood pressure, kidney damage, and vascular diseases.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Renal Damage", "notes": "Hypertensive nephropathy and chronic kidney disease", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Renal Insufficiency", "term": {"id": "HP:0000083", "label": "Renal insufficiency"}}}

description: Profound fatigue related to anemia and hypermetabolic state from rapid leukemic cell turnover.

name: Abnormal Bleeding
description: Easy bruising, petechiae, mucosal bleeding, and prolonged bleeding from minor wounds due to thrombocytopenia.

name: Acrodystrophic neuropathic pain
description: Severe, burning pain affecting the extremities, particularly hands and feet, often the earliest clinical manifestation. Pain crises can be disabling. Pathophysiology involves neuronal sensitization from lyso-Gb3 effects and lysosomal dysfunction.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "description": "Severe, burning pain affecting the extremities, particularly hands and feet, often the earliest clinical manifestation. Pain crises can be disabling. Pathophysiology involves neuronal sensitization from lyso-Gb3 effects and lysosomal dysfunction.\n", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Acrodystrophic neuropathic pain"}

Pain crises can be disabling. name: Angiokeratomas
description: Small, dark red skin lesions that cluster in the lower trunk and genital region. These are pathognomonic cutaneous manifestations of Fabry disease resulting from vascular dilatation with epidermal hyperkeratosis.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cutaneous", "description": "Small, dark red skin lesions that cluster in the lower trunk and genital region. These are pathognomonic cutaneous manifestations of Fabry disease resulting from vascular dilatation with epidermal hyperkeratosis.\n", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Angiokeratomas"}

These are pathognomonic cutaneous manifestations of Fabry disease resulting from vascular dilatation with epidermal hyperkeratosis.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Identifies angiokeratomas as a characteristic progressive clinical manifestation of Fabry disease", "reference": "PMID:31939530", "snippet": "Subsequently, symptoms related to progressive impairment appear, such as angiokeratomas, cornea verticillata, left ventricular hypertrophy, myocardial fibrosis, proteinuria, and renal insufficiency", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Angiokeratomas", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Angiokeratoma", "term": {"id": "HP:0001014", "label": "Angiokeratoma"}}}

name: Proteinuria
description: Urinary protein excretion, often the earliest sign of Fabry nephropathy. Progresses from microalbuminuria to overt proteinuria. Results from podocyte injury due to Gb3/lyso-Gb3 accumulation, autophagy impairment, and inflammatory signaling.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Renal", "description": "Urinary protein excretion, often the earliest sign of Fabry nephropathy. Progresses from microalbuminuria to overt proteinuria. Results from podocyte injury due to Gb3/lyso-Gb3 accumulation, autophagy impairment, and inflammatory signaling.\n", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Proteinuria"}

Results from podocyte injury due to Gb3/lyso-Gb3 accumulation, autophagy impairment, and inflammatory signaling.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Demonstrates that podocyte dysfunction is a central mechanism in Fabry disease, leading to proteinuria", "reference": "PMID:39100494", "snippet": "This study focuses on genome-wide expression analysis in an FD human podocyte model to gain insights into the underlying mechanisms of podocyte dysfunction", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Proteinuria", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Proteinuria", "term": {"id": "HP:0000093", "label": "proteinuria"}}}

name: Chronic kidney disease
description: Progressive renal dysfunction leading to end-stage renal disease. Driven by podocyte loss, glomerulosclerosis, tubulointerstitial fibrosis, and persistent inflammation.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Renal", "description": "Progressive renal dysfunction leading to end-stage renal disease. Driven by podocyte loss, glomerulosclerosis, tubulointerstitial fibrosis, and persistent inflammation.\n", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic kidney disease"}
raw_json: {"category": "Renal", "description": "Progressive renal dysfunction leading to end-stage renal disease. Driven by podocyte loss, glomerulosclerosis, tubulointerstitial fibrosis, and persistent inflammation.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Identifies progressive renal failure as the primary cause of death in Fabry disease", "reference": "PMID:31939530", "snippet": "Subsequently, symptoms related to progressive impairment appear...proteinuria, and renal insufficiency. The latter being the main cause of death in FD", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic kidney disease", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Chronic kidney disease", "term": {"id": "HP:0012622", "label": "Chronic kidney disease"}}}

name: Left ventricular hypertrophy
description: Concentric hypertrophy of the left ventricle resulting from cardiomyocyte lipid accumulation, oxidative stress, inflammation, and fibrosis. Increases arrhythmia risk and may progress to heart failure.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiac", "description": "Concentric hypertrophy of the left ventricle resulting from cardiomyocyte lipid accumulation, oxidative stress, inflammation, and fibrosis. Increases arrhythmia risk and may progress to heart failure.\n", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Left ventricular hypertrophy"}

Increases arrhythmia risk and may progress to heart failure.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Confirms that left ventricular hypertrophy is a major cardiac manifestation of Fabry disease", "reference": "PMID:33602475", "snippet": "Cardiovascular involvement usually manifests as left ventricular hypertrophy, myocardial fibrosis, heart failure, and arrhythmias, which limit quality of life and represent the most common causes of death", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Left ventricular hypertrophy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Cardiomyopathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0001638", "label": "cardiomyopathy"}}}

name: Cardiac arrhythmia
description: Atrial fibrillation and ventricular arrhythmias result from cardiomyocyte hypertrophy, fibrosis, and inflammatory remodeling that create arrhythmogenic substrate.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiac", "description": "Atrial fibrillation and ventricular arrhythmias result from cardiomyocyte hypertrophy, fibrosis, and inflammatory remodeling that create arrhythmogenic substrate.\n", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Cardiac arrhythmia"}

name: Stroke
description: Increased risk of ischemic stroke and transient ischemic attacks due to cerebrovascular dysfunction from endothelial dysfunction, microvascular remodeling, and pro-thrombotic state.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "description": "Increased risk of ischemic stroke and transient ischemic attacks due to cerebrovascular dysfunction from endothelial dysfunction, microvascular remodeling, and pro-thrombotic state.\n", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Stroke"}

name: Colorectal Polyposis
description: Hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps carpet the colon and rectum. Polyps typically appear in adolescence in classic FAP. The number and density of polyps correlates with mutation location in APC.

name: Colorectal Cancer
description: Without prophylactic surgery, colorectal cancer develops in nearly 100% of patients with classic FAP, typically by age 40. The average age of cancer diagnosis is 39 years without surveillance/intervention.

name: Duodenal Adenomas
description: Duodenal adenomas, especially periampullary, occur in 80-90% of FAP patients. They carry risk of progression to duodenal/ampullary adenocarcinoma, which is a leading cause of death in post-colectomy FAP patients.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Duodenal adenomas, especially periampullary, occur in 80-90% of FAP patients. name: Desmoid Tumors
description: Desmoid tumors (aggressive fibromatoses) occur in 10-15% of FAP patients, often in the mesentery or abdominal wall. They can cause significant morbidity through local invasion and compression. More common with 3' APC mutations and after abdominal surgery.

They are rare tumors occurring with a particularly high incidence in FAP, especially after surgery.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Desmoid Tumors", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Desmoid tumor", "term": {"id": "HP:6001034", "label": "Desmoid tumor"}}}

name: Osteomas
description: Benign bony growths, particularly of the mandible and skull. Characteristic of Gardner syndrome phenotype. May be detected radiographically before polyposis becomes apparent.

name: Congenital Hypertrophy of the Retinal Pigment Epithelium (CHRPE)
description: Pigmented lesions of the retinal pigment epithelium present from birth. Multiple bilateral CHRPE lesions are highly specific for FAP and can be detected before polyp development, aiding early diagnosis.

name: Recurrent Fever
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Recurrent Fever"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature supports that recurrent fever is a common feature of Familial Mediterranean Fever type 1, but it does not fully support that FMF should be categorized solely under systemic phenotypes.", "reference": "PMID:21358337", "snippet": "Familial Mediterranean fever type 1 is characterized by recurrent short episodes of inflammation and serositis, including fever, peritonitis, synovitis, pleuritis, and, rarely, pericarditis.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The literature supports that recurrent fever is a common diagnostic feature of FMF and systemically involves fever and inflammation, but it does not confirm all specified aspects of the statement.", "reference": "PMID:25832989", "snippet": "Familial Mediterranean fever...presents with recurrent and self-limited inflammatory attacks of fever and polyserositis along with high acute-phase reactants.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "It supports the systemic nature and severity aspects but does not fully align with the complete statement's focus.", "reference": "PMID:36688581", "snippet": "Higher Pras scores, earlier age of symptoms and diagnosis, more frequent arthritis and erysipelas-like erythema, and higher colchicine dose are closely associated with M694V homozygous familial Mediterranean fever patients. These patients also have mostly moderate and severe disease severity.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "While fever is a prominent symptom, FMF is known for phenotypic heterogeneity, indicating varied systemic manifestations.", "reference": "PMID:34606655", "snippet": "Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is the most common monogenic autoinflammatory disease manifesting with phenotypic heterogeneity. It is a clinically diagnosed disease supported by Mediterranean fever gene mutation analysis.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Recurrent Fever", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Recurrent Fever", "term": {"id": "HP:0001954", "label": "Recurrent fever"}}}

name: Arthritis
notes: Transient, affecting large joints
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Arthritis", "notes": "Transient, affecting large joints"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference supports the statement that arthritis is a common phenotype in FMF, is transient, and affects large joints.", "reference": "PMID:11411958", "snippet": "The arthritis was transient, monoarticular, nonerosive, and nondeforming in the majority of cases. Four patients (5.4%) had chronic arthritis, with one requiring total hip replacement. As in previous reports on arthritis of FMF, the majority of FMF patients studied in Lebanon had a transient monoarticular nonerosive and nondeforming type of arthritis affecting predominantly the large joints of the lower extremities.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference confirms the presence of arthritis in FMF patients, especially in large joints, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:33124556", "snippet": "More patients had arthritis in the ELE group than in the other group (p=0.011). Arthritis occurred in the ankle (77.4%), knee (19.3%) and hip (3.2%) joints.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Arthritis", "notes": "Transient, affecting large joints", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Arthritis", "term": {"id": "HP:0001369", "label": "Arthritis"}}}

name: Peritonitis
notes: Recurrent abdominal pain due to inflammation of the peritoneum
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Peritonitis", "notes": "Recurrent abdominal pain due to inflammation of the peritoneum"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference supports that peritonitis, which involves abdominal pain due to inflammation of the peritoneum, is a phenotype of FMF. However, it does not explicitly indicate a high frequency of gastrointestinal phenotypes.", "reference": "PMID:36082189", "snippet": "FMF is characterised by dysregulation of the inflammatory process in the body, presenting as recurrent episodes of serositis. Patients with FMF commonly present with episodes of fever, peritonitis, synovitis, pleuritis, arthritis, and occasionally pericarditis.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports that gastrointestinal manifestations, including abdominal pain, are phenotypes of FMF. However, it does not specify the high frequency of peritonitis.", "reference": "PMID:37723615", "snippet": "Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is the most prevalent hereditary autoinflammatory disease among children. Abdominal pain and various gastrointestinal system (GIS) manifestations may arise directly from FMF or concomitantly with FMF.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports that peritonitis is a common phenotype of FMF, aligning well with the statement.", "reference": "PMID:9562837", "snippet": "When a patient complains of episodic fever accompanied by unexplained arthritis, peritonitis, pleurisy, or skin rash, this disorder should be considered.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference clearly supports that peritonitis, involving abdominal pain due to inflammation of the peritoneum, is a key feature of FMF and occurs frequently.", "reference": "PMID:35737103", "snippet": "The key feature of familial Mediterranean fever is relapsing episodes of fever and serositis including peritonitis, pleurisy, or arthritis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports that recurrent abdominal pain is a phenotype associated with FMF.", "reference": "PMID:31308342", "snippet": "Considering the history of recurrent abdominal pain, Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF) was considered.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Peritonitis", "notes": "Recurrent abdominal pain due to inflammation of the peritoneum", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Peritonitis", "term": {"id": "HP:0002586", "label": "Peritonitis"}}}

name: Pleuritis
notes: Recurrent chest pain due to inflammation of the pleura
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Thoracic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Pleuritis", "notes": "Recurrent chest pain due to inflammation of the pleura"}
raw_json: {"category": "Thoracic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study highlights chest pain as a frequent symptom in FMF patients, indicating pleuritis as a common phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:38204312", "snippet": "The most common signs and symptoms are fever, abdominal pain, chest pain, and arthritis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study specifies that pleuritis, which is inflammation of the pleura, is a frequent thoracic phenotype in FMF.", "reference": "PMID:12092043", "snippet": "Lung involvement in FMF is limited mainly to transient pleuritis during acute attacks.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study identifies pleurisy, another term for pleuritis, as a characteristic symptom in FMF patients, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:36385047", "snippet": "Pericarditis, pleurisy and the response to colchicine indicated FMF.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While the study acknowledges pleuritis as a known pulmonary involvement in FMF, it does not provide evidence on its frequency being \"FREQUENT\".", "reference": "PMID:36725780", "snippet": "Pleuritis is the only known pulmonary involvement of FMF; however, as far as we know, thoracic involvements in pleural, parenchymal, bronchial, and vascular structures have not been evaluated yet.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Pleuritis", "notes": "Recurrent chest pain due to inflammation of the pleura", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Pleuritis", "term": {"id": "HP:0002102", "label": "Pleuritis"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Renal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature confirms that amyloidosis can lead to kidney failure in patients with Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF), supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:12832747", "snippet": "Amyloidosis, causing renal failure, is one of the most severe complications of the disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The statement is supported as FMF is listed as one of the frequent causes of renal amyloidosis.", "reference": "PMID:23548761", "snippet": "Familial Mediterranean Fever and tuberculosis were the most frequent causes of amyloidosis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This confirms that FMF is a frequent cause of renal amyloidosis, thereby supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:21360109", "snippet": "The most frequent cause [of renal amyloidosis in children] is now autoinflammatory diseases. Among this group of diseases, the most frequent one throughout the world is familial Mediterranean fever (FMF).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature confirms the renal involvement in FMF-associated amyloidosis, thus supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:33052444", "snippet": "Amyloidosis [...] stands out as a major complication of familial Mediterranean fever (FMF). Splenic and renal involvement is more likely in FMF-associated systemic amyloidosis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Amyloidosis", "notes": "Can lead to kidney failure if untreated", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Amyloidosis", "term": {"id": "HP:0011034", "label": "Amyloidosis"}}}

name: Pancytopenia
description: Progressive decline in all blood cell lineages due to bone marrow failure.
notes: Decreased levels of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. Over 80% of FA patients develop bone marrow failure. Typically presents in the first decade, often initially with thrombocytopenia or leukopenia. Notably, patients with FANCD1/BRCA2 mutations may not develop BMF. FA-S (biallelic BRCA1) patients also characteristically lack bone marrow failure.

Over 80% of FA patients develop bone marrow failure. Typically presents in the first decade, often initially with thrombocytopenia or leukopenia. Notably, patients with FANCD1/BRCA2 mutations may not develop BMF. FA-S (biallelic BRCA1) patients also characteristically lack bone marrow failure."}

name: Increased Risk of Leukemia
description: Significantly elevated risk of developing leukemia, predominantly acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with an incidence of 13% by age 50. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) also reported, especially in FANCD1/BRCA2 patients.
notes: The incidence of AML is 13% by age 50 years. Patients with FANCA mutations develop cancer at a significantly older age (mean 18.5 years) compared to non-FANCA groups (mean 5.2 years, P=0.001). Patients with FANCC mutations show a trend toward more MDS. FANCG patients may have less MDS and cancer overall. All FANCA patients in the Israeli cohort developed their first cancer after age 10, while all non-FANCA patients developed cancer by age 10.

name: Aplastic Anemia
description: Bone marrow failure resulting in severely reduced production of all blood cell types.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "description": "Bone marrow failure resulting in severely reduced production of all blood cell types.", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Aplastic Anemia"}

name: Thrombocytopenia
description: Low platelet count due to progressive bone marrow failure in Fanconi anemia.
notes: Listed in FA clinical screening manifestations and commonly contributes to bleeding risk.

name: Short Stature
description: Growth deficiency present from birth, affecting approximately 60% of patients.
notes: In the Israeli cohort, 57% met criteria for short stature. Patients with downstream FA gene mutations (FANCD1, FANCJ) were significantly shorter than core complex patients (P=0.003). Patients with deletion mutations were shorter than those with nonsense mutations (P=0.018). Contributing factors include GH deficiency, hypothyroidism, and constitutional factors.

notes: Includes areas such as the radius, thumb, and hips

name: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
description: Markedly increased risk of early-onset squamous cell carcinomas, particularly of the head and neck, oral cavity, esophagus, and anogenital regions.
notes: Cancer surveillance is critical due to genomic instability and persistent epithelial cancer risk. Solid tumors in the Israeli cohort appeared at a mean age of 26.6 years, significantly later than MDS/leukemia. All solid tumors in that cohort were in patients with FANCA mutations or undiagnosed patients. HPV vaccination is recommended to reduce risk. Oral examination every 6 months from age 9-10 years and annual nasolaryngoscopy from age 10 years are recommended.

notes: Part of the congenital anomaly spectrum. Skull anomalies were significantly more common in patients with downstream FA gene mutations (FANCD1, FANCJ) compared to core complex mutations (P<0.001). FA-S (biallelic BRCA1) patients also frequently present with microcephaly.

name: Congenital Heart Defects
description: Structural heart anomalies including ventricular septal defects, atrial septal defects, patent ductus arteriosus, and other cardiac malformations.
notes: Part of the VACTERL association overlap with FA. Heart abnormalities contribute to the congenital abnormality burden score (CABS). Patients with missense mutations had significantly less congenital heart disease (P=0.022) in the Israeli cohort. Downstream FA genes (FANCD1, FANCJ) may be associated with more severe congenital anomalies.

name: Hearing Loss
description: Conductive and/or sensorineural hearing loss, often associated with external ear anomalies or middle ear malformations.
notes: In the Israeli FA cohort, 18% of patients had hearing loss, all with a conductive component. Hearing loss contributes to the congenital abnormality burden score (CABS). Hearing aids may be helpful per otolaryngology evaluation.

name: Hypothyroidism
description: Thyroid hormone deficiency requiring monitoring and potentially replacement therapy.
notes: About 80% of FA patients have at least one endocrine abnormality. Hypothyroidism is one of the most common endocrine manifestations. Annual TSH and free T4 screening is recommended.

name: Growth Hormone Deficiency
description: Insufficient growth hormone production contributing to short stature beyond what is expected from the underlying condition alone.
notes: GH deficiency affects approximately 51% of FA patients (Giri et al. 2007, NCI cohort). Patients with GH deficiency were significantly shorter than those without (P=0.01). Growth hormone therapy may be used but requires careful monitoring given cancer predisposition. Ninety-two percent of FA patients aged 18 or older had osteopenia or osteoporosis.

name: Abnormal Glucose Homeostasis

notes: Part of the metabolic/endocrine abnormalities seen in up to 80% of FA patients. Two-hour glucose tolerance testing and insulin levels are recommended as part of annual endocrine surveillance.

name: Delayed Puberty and Hypogonadism
description: Delayed onset of puberty and hypogonadism affecting both sexes, with males commonly showing cryptorchidism and females showing ovarian insufficiency.
notes: Pubertal delay and hypogonadism are among the most common endocrine abnormalities in FA (present in up to 80% of patients with at least one endocrine abnormality). Pubertal staging and hormone levels should be assessed at puberty and every two years until complete.

name: Impaired Fertility
description: Reduced fertility in both sexes, with males often showing azoospermia or oligospermia due to gonadal failure, and females showing diminished ovarian reserve and premature menopause.
notes: Male infertility is very common due to primary gonadal failure. Female fertility is reduced but pregnancies have been reported. Fertility preservation counseling should be offered early.

name: Cryptorchidism
description: Undescended testes, a common genitourinary malformation in male FA patients.
notes: Part of the genitourinary anomaly spectrum. Genital anomalies were significantly more common in patients with downstream FA gene mutations (FANCD1, FANCJ) compared to core complex mutations in the Israeli cohort.

name: Testicular Aplasia or Hypoplasia

name: Renal Anomalies
description: Congenital kidney malformations including ectopic kidneys, horseshoe kidneys, renal agenesis, or hypoplastic kidneys.
notes: In the Israeli FA cohort, 39.6% of patients had renal anomalies, making it the second most common congenital anomaly after skin pigmentation changes. Renal anomalies contribute to the congenital abnormality burden score.

name: Developmental Delay
description: Cognitive and/or motor developmental delays present in a subset of FA patients.
notes: Developmental delay contributes to the congenital abnormality burden score. Patients with splice site mutations had significantly more CNS anomalies and developmental delay (P=0.038) compared with other mutation types. Patients with downstream FA gene mutations (FANCD1, FANCJ) had significantly more CNS abnormalities (P=0.005). FA-S (biallelic BRCA1) patients frequently present with intellectual disability.

name: Hypopigmentation
description: Areas of decreased skin pigmentation, often in combination with hyperpigmented lesions such as caf-au-lait spots.
notes: The combination of hypo- and hyperpigmented skin lesions is characteristic of FA. In the Israeli cohort, skin pigmentation changes (caf-au-lait spots) were the most common congenital anomaly (52.3%).

name: Hyperpigmentation
description: Generalized or patchy increased skin pigmentation in the Fanconi anemia congenital anomaly spectrum.
notes: Included in FA guideline skin findings and commonly co-occurs with hypopigmented lesions.

name: Osteopenia and Osteoporosis
description: Reduced bone mineral density affecting the majority of adult FA patients, likely related to endocrine dysfunction, chronic illness, and potentially direct effects of FA pathway deficiency on osteoblast function.
notes: 92% of FA patients aged 18 or older had osteopenia or osteoporosis in the NCI cohort (Giri et al. 2007). May be compounded by GH deficiency, hypogonadism, and post-HSCT conditioning effects.

May be compounded by GH deficiency, hypogonadism, and post-HSCT conditioning effects."}

name: Dental and Craniofacial Anomalies
description: Dental anomalies including tooth agenesis, root abnormalities, tooth rotation, enamel defects, and craniofacial dysmorphisms.
notes: In a systematic review with 46 additional Brazilian cases, 93.5% of FA patients exhibited dental/craniofacial anomalies. Root abnormalities (69.6%), tooth rotation (54.3%), and tooth agenesis (26%) were most common. Anomalies in tooth size and shape were more prevalent in patients who underwent HSCT at age 14 or older.

name: Myelodysplastic Syndrome
description: Clonal hematopoietic disorder with dysplastic bone marrow and cytopenias, frequently preceding progression to acute myeloid leukemia.
notes: In the Israeli cohort, 30% of patients developed MDS, leukemia, and/or solid tumors. Patients with non-FANCA mutations (FANCC, FANCD1, FANCG, FANCJ) developed first cancer (including MDS) significantly earlier than FANCA patients (mean 5.2 vs 18.5 years, P=0.001). There was a trend toward more MDS in FANCC patients.

name: Early-Onset Solid Tumors in FANCD1/BRCA2
description: Patients with biallelic FANCD1/BRCA2 mutations have a uniquely severe cancer predisposition with early-onset solid tumors in childhood, including medulloblastoma, Wilms tumor, and neuroblastoma, distinct from the typical FA tumor spectrum.
notes: FANCD1/BRCA2 and FANCN/PALB2 patients have the most severe cancer phenotype with near-invariable early-onset malignancy. In the Israeli cohort, one FANCD1 patient developed medulloblastoma at age 3. These patients require cancer screening from a very young age. Neither FANCD1 patient in the Israeli cohort developed BMF, distinguishing this subtype. FA-S (biallelic BRCA1) patients also lack bone marrow failure but have cancer predisposition.

Neither FANCD1 patient in the Israeli cohort developed BMF, distinguishing this subtype. FA-S (biallelic BRCA1) patients also lack bone marrow failure but have cancer predisposition.", "subtype": "FANCD1/BRCA2"}

name: Congenital Great Toe Malformation
notes: Bilateral hallux valgus with short first metatarsals and monophalangic great toes. Present at birth and pathognomonic for FOP.

name: Heterotopic Ossification
notes: Progressive formation of ectopic bone in muscles, tendons, and ligaments. Typically begins in childhood and progresses cranially to caudally and axially to appendicularly.

raw_json: {"category": "Skeletal", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The development of a second skeleton is the defining feature of the disease.", "reference": "PMID:17572636", "snippet": "Individuals with fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva are born with malformations of the great toes and develop a heterotopic skeleton during childhood", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Heterotopic Ossification", "notes": "Progressive formation of ectopic bone in muscles, tendons, and ligaments. name: Progressive Joint Immobility
notes: Ankylosis of joints due to heterotopic bone formation crossing joint spaces. Leads to progressive loss of mobility.

name: Restrictive Ventilatory Defect
notes: Thoracic insufficiency syndrome develops as heterotopic ossification involves the thoracic spine, ribs, and thoracic musculature, severely restricting chest expansion and ventilatory capacity. This is a major cause of mortality with median life expectancy of approximately 40 years.

This is a major cause of mortality with median life expectancy of approximately 40 years."}
