name: Behavioral Changes
notes: Prominent behavioral changes including disinhibition, apathy, loss of empathy, compulsive behaviors, and dietary changes. Particularly characteristic of behavioral variant FTD.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Behavioral Changes", "notes": "Prominent behavioral changes including disinhibition, apathy, loss of empathy, compulsive behaviors, and dietary changes. Particularly characteristic of behavioral variant FTD."}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This confirms that behavioral disinhibition and repetitive stereotyped behaviors are core clinical features of genetic FTD, particularly in MAPT mutations.", "reference": "PMID:26473392", "snippet": "MAPT patients were younger than other groups, and showed more frequent behavioural disinhibition, repetitive and stereotyped behaviours, semantic impairment and temporal predominance of atrophy.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Behavioral Changes", "notes": "Prominent behavioral changes including disinhibition, apathy, loss of empathy, compulsive behaviors, and dietary changes. Particularly characteristic of behavioral variant FTD."}

name: Aphasia
notes: Progressive language impairment, particularly non-fluent aphasia in GRN mutations and semantic variant primary progressive aphasia. Language deficits may be the presenting feature.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Aphasia", "notes": "Progressive language impairment, particularly non-fluent aphasia in GRN mutations and semantic variant primary progressive aphasia. Language deficits may be the presenting feature."}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This demonstrates that non-fluent aphasia is a characteristic presenting feature in patients with GRN mutations causing frontotemporal dementia.", "reference": "PMID:26473392", "snippet": "GRN patients were older at death and more likely to present with non-fluent aphasia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Aphasia", "notes": "Progressive language impairment, particularly non-fluent aphasia in GRN mutations and semantic variant primary progressive aphasia. Language deficits may be the presenting feature.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Aphasia", "term": {"id": "HP:0002381", "label": "Aphasia"}}}

name: Personality Changes
notes: Progressive changes in personality including social inappropriateness, loss of emotional warmth, and altered social cognition. C9orf72 patients may paradoxically appear socially warm despite other behavioral changes.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Personality Changes", "notes": "Progressive changes in personality including social inappropriateness, loss of emotional warmth, and altered social cognition. C9orf72 patients may paradoxically appear socially warm despite other behavioral changes."}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This highlights the complex and sometimes paradoxical personality changes in C9orf72-related FTD, where patients may retain apparent social warmth despite significant behavioral dysfunction.", "reference": "PMID:26473392", "snippet": "They showed more psychotic symptoms and irrational behaviour, yet were more often reported clinically as socially appropriate and warm.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Personality Changes", "notes": "Progressive changes in personality including social inappropriateness, loss of emotional warmth, and altered social cognition. name: Hemolytic Anemia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hemolytic Anemia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The text supports that G6PD deficiency is associated with hemolytic anemia, jaundice, and other hematologic phenotypes.", "reference": "PMID:17611006", "snippet": "People, usually males, with deficient alleles are susceptible to neonatal jaundice, and acute hemolytic anemia, usually during infection, after treatment with certain drugs or after eating fava beans.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The mention of hemolytic anemia as a potential trigger due to G6PD deficiency supports the statement.", "reference": "PMID:32600868", "snippet": "Although most individuals are asymptomatic, exposure to certain food, drugs, or infections can trigger acute hemolytic anemia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This supports the hematologic nature of the phenotypes associated with G6PD deficiency.", "reference": "PMID:35465846", "snippet": "The characteristic of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is red blood cell (RBC) destruction in response to oxidative stress.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference highlights the role of G6PD deficiency in neonatal sepsis, supporting the association with hematologic issues.", "reference": "PMID:27974910", "snippet": "G6PD deficiency is a risk factor of neonatal sepsis and also a justification for more male involvement in this disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study confirms that hemolytic anemia is a common phenotype in G6PD deficiency.", "reference": "PMID:28982343", "snippet": "The highest prevalence of hemolytic crisis in G6PD deficiency patients was found within the age group of 1-3 years.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the hematologic impact of G6PD deficiency.", "reference": "PMID:30161219", "snippet": "A moderate decrease in G6PD activity is associated with PAH.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hemolytic Anemia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hemolytic Anemia", "term": {"id": "HP:0001878", "label": "Hemolytic anemia"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Jaundice"}, {"target": "Fatigue"}, {"target": "Shortness of Breath"}]}

name: Dark Urine
notes: Occurs during acute hemolytic episodes
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Genitourinary", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Dark Urine", "notes": "Occurs during acute hemolytic episodes"}
raw_json: {"category": "Genitourinary", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Blackwater fever syndrome (BWF) characterized by dark urine is associated with G6PD deficiency, supporting the statement that dark urine occurs during acute hemolytic episodes, which fits the genitourinary category.", "reference": "PMID:19589177", "snippet": "In Vietnam the blackwater fever syndrome (BWF) has been associated with malaria infection, quinine ingestion and G6PD deficiency.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Although the reference does not explicitly mention dark urine, it implies hemolysis during acute episodes which is known to cause dark urine as a result of hemoglobinuria, indirectly supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:4556779", "snippet": "Hemolysis in glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Dark Urine", "notes": "Occurs during acute hemolytic episodes", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Dark Urine", "term": {"id": "HP:0040319", "label": "Dark urine"}}}

name: Neonatal Jaundice
notes: May be severe in G6PD-deficient newborns
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Neonatal Jaundice", "notes": "May be severe in G6PD-deficient newborns"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This study shows a high incidence of moderate or severe jaundice in G6PD-deficient neonates, supporting the claim that neonatal jaundice is a common systemic phenotype in these individuals and may be severe.", "reference": "PMID:508636", "snippet": "Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency was detected in 16 (69.6%) of a group of 23 neonates who had unexplained moderate or severe jaundice.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature states that severe neonatal jaundice is associated with G6PD deficiency, supporting the statement's note about the potential severity.", "reference": "PMID:27040960", "snippet": "G6PD-deficient persons are mostly asymptomatic, but they can develop severe jaundice during the neonatal period.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study confirms that G6PD deficiency causes neonatal hyperbilirubinemia (jaundice), reinforcing the statement.", "reference": "PMID:19233695", "snippet": "This inherited deficiency causes neonatal hyperbilirubinemia and chronic hemolytic anemia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by confirming susceptibility to neonatal jaundice in G6PD-deficient individuals.", "reference": "PMID:17611006", "snippet": "People, usually males, with deficient alleles are susceptible to neonatal jaundice, and acute hemolytic anemia, usually during infection, after treatment with certain drugs or after eating fava beans.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Neonatal Jaundice", "notes": "May be severe in G6PD-deficient newborns", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Neonatal Jaundice", "term": {"id": "HP:0003265", "label": "Neonatal hyperbilirubinemia"}}}

name: Favism
notes: Acute hemolytic anemia triggered by ingestion of fava beans
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Favism", "notes": "Acute hemolytic anemia triggered by ingestion of fava beans"}
raw_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The article supports the statement that G6PD deficiency can result in acute hemolytic anemia triggered by the ingestion of fava beans, termed as favism.", "reference": "PMID:32702756", "snippet": "any of them may develop acute and sometimes very severe hemolytic anemia when triggered by ingestion of fava beans", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The article explicitly describes favism as a hemolytic disease caused by the ingestion of fava beans in individuals with G6PD deficiency.", "reference": "PMID:36678214", "snippet": "Favism is a hemolytic disease due to the ingestion of fava beans in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While the article acknowledges the occurrence of favism in certain populations, it also highlights that significant hemolysis due to fava bean consumption is not well documented among the Thais or Southeast Asians, suggesting geographic variability in the phenotype's frequency.", "reference": "PMID:1948276", "snippet": "Favism, a hemolytic condition associated with fava bean consumption among the glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficient persons, is well described in the Middle East and Mediterranean areas.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The article confirms the occurrence of favism in a subset of G6PD-deficient children, supporting the notion of occasional frequency.", "reference": "PMID:16513531", "snippet": "Favism was found in 3.6% of the G6PD-deficient children.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The article supports the association between G6PD deficiency and hemolytic anemia triggered by fava bean consumption (favism).", "reference": "PMID:30380124", "snippet": "In this review, fava beans were found to be the only food for which there is conclusive clinical evidence linking the risk of hemolytic anemia to individuals with G6PD deficiency.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Favism", "notes": "Acute hemolytic anemia triggered by ingestion of fava beans"}

name: Leukocyte Dysfunction
notes: Impaired phagocytosis and bactericidal activity, leading to increased susceptibility to certain infections
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Leukocyte Dysfunction", "notes": "Impaired phagocytosis and bactericidal activity, leading to increased susceptibility to certain infections"}
raw_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates that despite reduced G6PD activity, the functional assays of neutrophils in G6PD-deficient individuals were comparable to those in normal individuals, suggesting that leukocyte dysfunction is not a common occurrence in G6PD deficiency.", "reference": "PMID:9158663", "snippet": "Our results show that the G6PD activity of neutrophils from 48 individuals, identified as severely erythrocyte (RBC) G6PD deficient (< 2 U/10(12) RBC) was 23% of the enzyme activity of neutrophils from 53 individuals with normal RBC G6PD levels (98.8 U/10(12) RBC). However, the results of functional assays of neutrophils as measured by hexose monophosphate shunt and the NBT test were comparable in G6PD-deficient and normal individuals, suggesting that a reduced activity of G6PD to as low as 23% of normal does not affect neutrophil function.", "supports": "REFUTE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Leukocyte Dysfunction", "notes": "Impaired phagocytosis and bactericidal activity, leading to increased susceptibility to certain infections"}

name: Pallor
notes: Due to anemia, most noticeable during acute hemolytic episodes

raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Hemolysis from G6PD deficiency leads to anemia, which manifests as pallor due to decreased red blood cell count.", "reference": "PMID:31235029", "snippet": "Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is an erythrocyte enzyme defect that amplifies the susceptibility of erythrocytes to oxidative stress due to excessive levels of reactive oxygen species. Consequently, erythrocyte destruction and hemolysis occur.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Pallor", "notes": "Due to anemia, most noticeable during acute hemolytic episodes", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Pallor", "term": {"id": "HP:0000980", "label": "Pallor"}}}

name: Medulloblastoma
description: Increased risk of medulloblastoma, particularly the desmoplastic/nodular subtype. Risk is estimated at 1-5% for PTCH1 carriers but up to 20-fold higher in SUFU mutation carriers. Tumors typically occur in the first few years of life.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Oncologic", "description": "Increased risk of medulloblastoma, particularly the desmoplastic/nodular subtype. Risk is estimated at 1-5% for PTCH1 carriers but up to 20-fold higher in SUFU mutation carriers. Tumors typically occur in the first few years of life.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Medulloblastoma"}

Tumors typically occur in the first few years of life.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Quantifies medulloblastoma risk by genotype, showing much higher risk in SUFU carriers.", "reference": "PMID:25403219", "snippet": "Each SUFU-positive family included a single case of medulloblastoma, whereas only two (1.7%) of 115 individuals with Gorlin syndrome and a PTCH1 mutation developed medulloblastoma.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Documents early onset of medulloblastoma in SUFU mutation carriers.", "reference": "PMID:29186568", "snippet": "Twenty-two patients from 17 families were identified with medulloblastoma and a germline SUFU mutation (median age at diagnosis: 16.5 mo).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "iPSC model demonstrates that Gorlin patient-derived neural stem cells can form medulloblastoma-like tumors.", "reference": "PMID:32747535", "snippet": "We found that Gorlin NES cells formed tumors in mouse cerebellum mimicking human medulloblastoma.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Medulloblastoma", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Medulloblastoma", "term": {"id": "HP:0002885", "label": "Medulloblastoma"}}}

name: Intellectual disability
description: Moderate to severe intellectual disability with delayed developmental milestones. Variable severity ranging from learning disabilities to developmental delay, with some cases showing normal or above-average cognitive function.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "description": "Moderate to severe intellectual disability with delayed developmental milestones. Variable severity ranging from learning disabilities to developmental delay, with some cases showing normal or above-average cognitive function.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "OBLIGATE", "name": "Intellectual disability"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "description": "Moderate to severe intellectual disability with delayed developmental milestones. Variable severity ranging from learning disabilities to developmental delay, with some cases showing normal or above-average cognitive function.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Raggio et al. 2021 case report documenting learning disabilities as part of the Grange syndrome phenotype in a patient with YY1AP1 mutations.", "reference": "PMID:33971976", "snippet": "whose symptoms include stenosis or occlusion of multiple arteries, congenital heart defects, brachydactyly, syndactyly, bone fragility, and learning disabilities.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Viora-Dupont et al. 2023 case report documents variable developmental delay as a feature, supporting variable penetrance but not obligate frequency of intellectual disability in Grange syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:37698238", "snippet": "Grange syndrome (GRNG-MIM#135580) is a rare recessive disorder associating variable features including diffuse vascular stenosis, brachysyndactyly, osteopenia with increased bone fragility, cardiac malformations, and variable developmental delay.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "Rath et al. 2019 family study documents phenotypic variability in intellectual/developmental features, with one sibling demonstrating above-average cognitive abilities while another showed normal development, indicating incomplete penetrance or variable expressivity of cognitive involvement in Grange syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:30556293", "snippet": "Learning disabilities, brachysyndactyly, bone fragility, and congenital heart defects seem to be the most variable features of Grange syndrome... Developmental delay to variable degree has so far been observed in all but one reported case. Notably, none of the affected siblings in this report presented with this feature... Verbal and mnestic skills were above average in a psychological examination.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OBLIGATE", "name": "Intellectual disability", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Intellectual disability", "term": {"id": "HP:0001249", "label": "Intellectual disability"}}}

name: Micrognathia
description: Underdevelopment of the mandible, a characteristic craniofacial feature.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "description": "Underdevelopment of the mandible, a characteristic craniofacial feature.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Micrognathia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "description": "Underdevelopment of the mandible, a characteristic craniofacial feature.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Volonghi et al. 2012 documents facial dysmorphisms (including micrognathia) as part of the distinctive craniofacial phenotype in Grange syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:22987684", "snippet": "We report on the case of an 18-year-old female presenting with subarachnoid hemorrhage due to the rupture of a basilar artery aneurysm, and with distinctive systemic features including extensive vasculopathy, facial dysmorphisms and brachysyndactyly, consistent with the diagnosis of Grange syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Micrognathia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Micrognathia", "term": {"id": "HP:0000347", "label": "Micrognathia"}}}

name: Hypertelorism
description: Increased distance between the inner canthi of the eyes, documented in some Grange syndrome cases but not uniformly present.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "description": "Increased distance between the inner canthi of the eyes, documented in some Grange syndrome cases but not uniformly present.", "diagnostic": false, "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hypertelorism"}
raw_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "description": "Increased distance between the inner canthi of the eyes, documented in some Grange syndrome cases but not uniformly present.", "diagnostic": false, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Guo et al. 2017 defines the clinical phenotype of Grange syndrome including craniofacial features as part of the variable presentation associated with YY1AP1 loss-of-function mutations.", "reference": "PMID:27939641", "snippet": "Grange syndrome is an autosomal-recessive condition characterized by severe and early-onset vascular disease similar to FMD and variable penetrance of brachydactyly, syndactyly, bone fragility, and learning disabilities.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hypertelorism", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypertelorism", "term": {"id": "HP:0000316", "label": "Hypertelorism"}}}

name: Brachydactyly
description: Shortened fingers and toes due to reduced length of metacarpals and metatarsals.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Limb", "description": "Shortened fingers and toes due to reduced length of metacarpals and metatarsals.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Brachydactyly"}
raw_json: {"category": "Limb", "description": "Shortened fingers and toes due to reduced length of metacarpals and metatarsals.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Guo et al. 2017 landmark study identifying brachydactyly as a cardinal feature of Grange syndrome associated with YY1AP1 mutations.", "reference": "PMID:27939641", "snippet": "variable penetrance of brachydactyly, syndactyly, bone fragility, and learning disabilities.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Wallerstein et al. 2006 early case report documenting brachysyndactyly (including brachydactyly component) as a consistent feature in Grange syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:16691574", "snippet": "a 3-year-old girl with brachysyndactyly, renal artery stenosis with hypertension, and bone fragility.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Brachydactyly", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Brachydactyly", "term": {"id": "HP:0001156", "label": "Brachydactyly"}}}

name: Syndactyly
description: Webbing or fusion between digits, often requiring surgical correction in childhood.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Limb", "description": "Webbing or fusion between digits, often requiring surgical correction in childhood.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Syndactyly"}
raw_json: {"category": "Limb", "description": "Webbing or fusion between digits, often requiring surgical correction in childhood.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Guo et al. 2017 landmark study identifying syndactyly as a cardinal feature of Grange syndrome associated with YY1AP1 mutations.", "reference": "PMID:27939641", "snippet": "variable penetrance of brachydactyly, syndactyly, bone fragility, and learning disabilities.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Rath et al. 2019 family study documents variable syndactyly presentation requiring surgical correction in childhood, highlighting the consistent acral involvement in Grange syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:30556293", "snippet": "she still has bilateral cutaneous syndactyly of her second and third toes... Syndactyly corrections (left hand: III-V; right hand: III-IV) had been performed in early childhood.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Syndactyly", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Syndactyly", "term": {"id": "HP:0001159", "label": "Syndactyly"}}}

name: Hypertension
description: Elevated blood pressure resulting from vascular stenosis and renal artery involvement, often presenting in childhood and contributing to serious vascular complications including hemorrhagic stroke.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "description": "Elevated blood pressure resulting from vascular stenosis and renal artery involvement, often presenting in childhood and contributing to serious vascular complications including hemorrhagic stroke.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hypertension"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "description": "Elevated blood pressure resulting from vascular stenosis and renal artery involvement, often presenting in childhood and contributing to serious vascular complications including hemorrhagic stroke.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Viora-Dupont et al. 2023 documents hypertension and vascular stenosis as hallmark features of Grange syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:37698238", "snippet": "Grange syndrome (GRNG-MIM#135580) is a rare recessive disorder associating variable features including diffuse vascular stenosis, brachysyndactyly, osteopenia with increased bone fragility, cardiac malformations, and variable developmental delay.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Wallerstein et al. 2006 documents renal artery stenosis with hypertension as a key feature in Grange syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:16691574", "snippet": "a 3-year-old girl with brachysyndactyly, renal artery stenosis with hypertension, and bone fragility.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Volonghi et al. 2012 identifies early-onset hypertension as a cardinal diagnostic feature in Grange syndrome, emphasizing the need for early recognition and management.", "reference": "PMID:22987684", "snippet": "Grange syndrome is a disorder characterized by arterial occlusive disease, hypertension, congenital cardiac defects, bone fragility, brachysyndactyly, and learning disabilities.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Saida et al. 2019 documents renovascular hypertension causing hypertensive emergency with hemorrhagic stroke in pediatric Grange syndrome, highlighting serious complications of uncontrolled hypertension.", "reference": "PMID:31270375", "snippet": "Pediatric hypertension can cause hypertensive emergencies, including hemorrhagic stroke... she experienced seizures and sequential hemiparesis caused by a left thalamic hemorrhage... Chronic hypertension was observed.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hypertension", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypertension", "term": {"id": "HP:0000822", "label": "Hypertension"}}}

name: Hyperthyroidism
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Endocrine", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hyperthyroidism"}
raw_json: {"category": "Endocrine", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature supports that Graves' Disease is an endocrine disorder that frequently causes hyperthyroidism and has sequelae such as weight loss and heat intolerance.", "reference": "PMID:2451239", "snippet": "Graves' disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. Clinical features include thyroid enlargement, eye signs, tachycardia, heat intolerance, emotional lability, weight loss, and hyperkinesis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This statement corroborates that Graves' Disease frequently causes hyperthyroidism.", "reference": "PMID:37725590", "snippet": "Graves' disease (GD) is an autoimmune disease, and it is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hyperthyroidism", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hyperthyroidism", "term": {"id": "HP:0000836", "label": "Hyperthyroidism"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Weight Loss"}, {"target": "Increased Appetite"}, {"target": "Heat Intolerance"}, {"target": "Sweating"}]}

name: Exophthalmos (Proptosis)
notes: Bulging of the eyes due to inflammation and tissue buildup behind the eyes.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ocular", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Exophthalmos (Proptosis)", "notes": "Bulging of the eyes due to inflammation and tissue buildup behind the eyes."}
raw_json: {"category": "Ocular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that proptosis occurs in a subset of patients with Graves' disease, but it does not support that it is a frequent occurrence for all patients.", "reference": "PMID:34243871", "snippet": "In approximately 25% of patients, an inflammatory condition, Graves eye disease (GED), affects the orbital soft tissues. About 60% of patients develop mild symptoms including fat expansion and inflammation of the levator muscle complex with resultant proptosis, eyelid retraction, and exposure of the globe.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by indicating that proptosis is a frequent finding in about half of Graves' disease patients.", "reference": "PMID:35315985", "snippet": "Graves' ophthalmopathy (GO) is a vision-threatening finding observed in approximately half of Graves' disease patients. The pathophysiology of GO is unclear, and one of the suspected factors is oxidative stress.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by indicating a high frequency (84.3%) of proptosis in pediatric Graves' orbitopathy, which aligns with the frequency aspect of the statement.", "reference": "PMID:34951116", "snippet": "Clinical findings included proptosis (n = 97; 84.3%), eyelid retraction (n = 77; 67%) and diplopia (n = 13; 11.3%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference mentions proptosis in the context of a rare form of orbital inflammation associated with Graves' disease, but does not provide enough information to support the frequency aspect of the statement.", "reference": "PMID:32976333", "snippet": "Superior ophthalmic vein periphlebitis is a rare form of orbital inflammation presenting with proptosis and motility restriction yet few inflammatory signs.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by indicating that ocular manifestations, including proptosis, are common in Graves' disease.", "reference": "PMID:20181974", "snippet": "Graves' ophthalmopathy, also called Graves' orbitopathy, is a potentially sight-threatening ocular disease... Generally occurring in patients with hyperthyroidism or a history of hyperthyroidism due to Graves' disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Exophthalmos (Proptosis)", "notes": "Bulging of the eyes due to inflammation and tissue buildup behind the eyes."}

name: Goiter
notes: Enlargement of the thyroid gland, often visible as a swelling in the neck.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Endocrine", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Goiter", "notes": "Enlargement of the thyroid gland, often visible as a swelling in the neck."}
raw_json: {"category": "Endocrine", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that Graves' disease frequently results in thyroid enlargement, which aligns with the statement that goiter is a frequent manifestation of Graves' disease.", "reference": "PMID:2451239", "snippet": "Graves' disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. Clinical features include thyroid enlargement...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference is titled 'Goiter' but does not provide specific information about its frequency in Graves' disease.", "reference": "PMID:4886698", "snippet": "Goiter.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "Although this reference primarily discusses Graves' Orbitopathy, it supports the context that Graves' disease involves immune-mediated disorders affecting the thyroid, which can lead to goiter.", "reference": "PMID:22632361", "snippet": "Graves' Orbitopathy (GO) is an immune-mediated disorder causing inflammation and expansion of orbital fat and muscle...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature mentions the significant prevalence of Graves' disease, which often includes thyroid enlargement as a symptom, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:22112923", "snippet": "Among them, subacute thyroiditis and Graves' disease accounted for 918 patients (3.6%) and 4,617 patients (18.2%), respectively.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference directly supports the statement by mentioning that Graves' disease is characterized by diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, which is synonymous with goiter.", "reference": "PMID:37152963", "snippet": "Graves' disease (GD) is characterized by diffuse enlargement and overactivity of the thyroid gland...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference indicates that thyroid enlargement (goiter) is a frequent occurrence in Graves' disease, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:14605602", "snippet": "Several studies have demonstrated both an increased incidence of nodules and of thyroid cancer in patients with Graves' disease...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Goiter", "notes": "Enlargement of the thyroid gland, often visible as a swelling in the neck.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Goiter", "term": {"id": "HP:0000853", "label": "Goiter"}}}

name: Tachycardia
notes: Increased heart rate, commonly experienced as palpitations.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Tachycardia", "notes": "Increased heart rate, commonly experienced as palpitations."}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study shows that tachyarrhythmias, which include tachycardia, are common in patients with Graves' disease and improve with treatment.", "reference": "PMID:32402541", "snippet": "Tachyarrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation and tachycardia, improved in 85.9% of patients in the surgical group vs 66% in the medical group (P = .01).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The case report mentions a patient with Graves' disease experiencing tachycardia, supporting the statement that tachycardia is a frequent cardiovascular manifestation of Graves' disease.", "reference": "PMID:33749695", "snippet": "She was hypoxic and tachycardic and was extensively investigated as well as aggressively treated.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Tachycardia", "notes": "Increased heart rate, commonly experienced as palpitations.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Tachycardia", "term": {"id": "HP:0001649", "label": "Tachycardia"}}}

scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Tremor", "notes": "Fine shaking, particularly in the hands."}

name: Anxiety
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Psychiatric", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Anxiety"}
raw_json: {"category": "Psychiatric", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates that anxiety scores are significantly higher in patients with Graves' disease compared to controls, both during hyperthyroidism and after treatment, supporting the statement that anxiety is a frequent psychiatric complication of Graves' disease.", "reference": "PMID:38215285", "snippet": "Depression scores and anxiety scores were higher in patients compared to controls both during hyperthyroidism (depression (median (IQR): 7.5 (5.0-9.5) vs 1.0 (0.5-2.5) P < 0.001), anxiety: 7.7 (5.0-11) vs 2.5 (1.0-4.0) P < 0.001) and after treatment (depression: 2.5 (1.5-5.0) vs 1.5 (0.5-3.5) P < 0.05), anxiety: 4.0 (2.5-7.5) vs 3.0 (1.5-5.0) P < 0.05).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Anxiety", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Anxiety", "term": {"id": "HP:0000739", "label": "Anxiety"}}}

name: Irritability
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Psychiatric", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Irritability"}
raw_json: {"category": "Psychiatric", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study found that children with Graves' Disease exhibited symptoms of irritability, supporting the statement that irritability is a frequent psychiatric symptom in GD.", "reference": "PMID:38644701", "snippet": "In children with GD, irritability, oppositional defiant, and conduct disorder symptoms have been detected.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature supports the association of hyperthyroidism, which is a characteristic of Graves' Disease, with psychiatric symptoms including irritability.", "reference": "PMID:36853810", "snippet": "The common view is that clinical hypothyroidism is associated with depressive symptoms, whereas the psychiatric manifestations of hyperthyroidism are agitation, emotional lability, hyperexcitability, occasionally accompanied by angry outbursts, and euphoria.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the presence of psychiatric symptoms in GD, including emotional distress which can encompass irritability.", "reference": "PMID:37224080", "snippet": "Mental fatigue, depression, anxiety, and cognitive complaints are common in Graves' disease (GD).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Irritability", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Irritability", "term": {"id": "HP:0000737", "label": "Irritability"}}}

name: Pretibial Myxedema
notes: Swelling and thickening of the skin, usually on the shins.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Pretibial Myxedema", "notes": "Swelling and thickening of the skin, usually on the shins."}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature states that pretibial myxedema is an uncommon manifestation of Graves disease, aligning with the statement that it occurs occasionally.", "reference": "PMID:8309359", "snippet": "Pretibial myxedema is an uncommon manifestation of Graves disease...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature confirms the association of pretibial myxedema with Graves' disease, supporting its classification as an occasional dermatologic manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:34047397", "snippet": "Pretibial myxedema (PTM)... is almost always associated with Graves' disease (GD).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the occurrence of pretibial myxedema in the context of Graves' disease.", "reference": "PMID:37193106", "snippet": "Worsening of pretibial myxedema following radioiodine treatment for hyperthyroid Graves' disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Pretibial Myxedema", "notes": "Swelling and thickening of the skin, usually on the shins.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Pretibial Myxedema", "term": {"id": "HP:0200028", "label": "Pretibial myxedema"}}}

name: Abnormal Eye Movements

scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "description": "Eye movement abnormalities including rotary nystagmus, exotropia, and strabismus.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Abnormal Eye Movements"}
raw_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "description": "Eye movement abnormalities including rotary nystagmus, exotropia, and strabismus.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Strabismus is a common feature of HIDEA syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:30940925", "snippet": "the common presenting features include strabismus (N = 11/13, 85%), epilepsy (N = 10/13, 77%)", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Abnormal Eye Movements", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Strabismus", "term": {"id": "HP:0000486", "label": "Strabismus"}}}

name: Visual Impairment
description: Visual problems including myopia, hyperopia, astigmatism, optic atrophy, cortical blindness, or achromic fundi.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "description": "Visual problems including myopia, hyperopia, astigmatism, optic atrophy, cortical blindness, or achromic fundi.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Visual Impairment"}
raw_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "description": "Visual problems including myopia, hyperopia, astigmatism, optic atrophy, cortical blindness, or achromic fundi.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Visual abnormalities are part of the eye phenotype in HIDEA.", "reference": "PMID:30940925", "snippet": "All the patients with P4HTM gene variants have developmental delay or intellectual disability and visual abnormalitiessuch as strabismus, rotating eye movements, nystagmus, or cortical blindness", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Visual Impairment", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Visual impairment", "term": {"id": "HP:0000505", "label": "Visual impairment"}}}

name: Gait Disturbance
description: Delayed walking or inability to walk, with unsteady wide-based gait in those who achieve ambulation.

name: Recurrent Respiratory Infections

raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Fatigue is a common systemic symptom resulting from hypothyroidism caused by progressive thyroid destruction.", "reference": "PMID:38731922", "snippet": "Due to the progressive destruction of cells, AITD can lead to subclinical or overt hypothyroidism.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fatigue", "term": {"id": "HP:0012378", "label": "Fatigue"}}}

name: Goiter
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Endocrine", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Goiter"}
raw_json: {"category": "Endocrine", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Goiter develops due to lymphocytic infiltration and inflammatory enlargement of the thyroid gland.", "reference": "PMID:38731922", "snippet": "Hashimoto's thyroiditis (HT) is generally characterized by the presence of thyroid peroxidase and thyroglobulin antibodies, with a concomitant infiltration of lymphocytes in the thyroid.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Vascular remodeling and increased blood flow contribute to thyroid gland enlargement in autoimmune thyroid disease.", "reference": "PMID:39003267", "snippet": "We also demonstrate an increase of fenestrated PLVAP+ vessels in AITD, especially in GD.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Goiter", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Goiter", "term": {"id": "HP:0000853", "label": "Goiter"}}}

scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Psychiatric", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Depression"}

name: Dyspnea
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Dyspnea"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Dyspnea results from elevated filling pressures and reduced exercise tolerance caused by diastolic dysfunction and myocardial fibrosis in heart failure.", "reference": "PMID:40892534", "snippet": "Myocardial fibrosis and its surrogate changes in LV structure and geometry lead to functional impairments such as increased diastolic stiffness and elevated filling pressures and are associated with reduced exercise tolerance and poor prognosis in patients with HFpEF.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Dyspnea", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Dyspnea", "term": {"id": "HP:0002094", "label": "Dyspnea"}}}

name: Peripheral Edema
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Peripheral Edema"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Peripheral edema results from the cardiorenal interaction where reduced cardiac output leads to renal dysfunction, sodium retention, and fluid accumulation in peripheral tissues.", "reference": "PMID:36769308", "snippet": "The pathophysiology between the heart and the kidneys is bidirectional. Common mechanisms leading to the dysfunction of these organs result in a vicious cycle of cardiorenal deterioration.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Peripheral Edema", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Peripheral Edema", "term": {"id": "HP:0012398", "label": "Peripheral edema"}}}

scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue"}

name: Orthopnea
notes: Dyspnea when lying flat
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Orthopnea", "notes": "Dyspnea when lying flat"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Orthopnea", "notes": "Dyspnea when lying flat", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Orthopnea", "term": {"id": "HP:0012764", "label": "Orthopnea"}}}

name: Exercise Intolerance
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Exercise Intolerance"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Exercise intolerance in heart failure is directly caused by increased diastolic stiffness and elevated filling pressures from myocardial fibrosis and structural remodeling.", "reference": "PMID:40892534", "snippet": "Myocardial fibrosis and its surrogate changes in LV structure and geometry lead to functional impairments such as increased diastolic stiffness and elevated filling pressures and are associated with reduced exercise tolerance and poor prognosis in patients with HFpEF.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Exercise Intolerance", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Exercise Intolerance", "term": {"id": "HP:0003546", "label": "Exercise intolerance"}}}

name: Cardiomegaly
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Cardiomegaly"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Cardiomegaly in heart failure results from myocardial hypertrophy, which is a structural adaptation to increased workload and sympathetic activation.", "reference": "PMID:38636927", "snippet": "In the isoproterenol (ISO)-induced animal model, it is often accompanied by myocardial hypertrophy, fibrosis, and inflammation.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Cardiomegaly", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Cardiomegaly", "term": {"id": "HP:0001640", "label": "Cardiomegaly"}}}

name: Hepatomegaly
description: Enlarged liver due to iron accumulation in hepatocytes, often the earliest detectable physical finding.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Enlarged liver due to iron accumulation in hepatocytes, often the earliest detectable physical finding.\n", "name": "Hepatomegaly"}
raw_json: {"description": "Enlarged liver due to iron accumulation in hepatocytes, often the earliest detectable physical finding.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Liver involvement early in disease course leads to enlargement and progression to cirrhosis.", "reference": "PMID:37168645", "snippet": "One of the most serious clinical characteristics associated with early-onset iron overload is liver disease with eventual cirrhosis", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Hepatomegaly", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "hepatomegaly", "term": {"id": "HP:0002240", "label": "Hepatomegaly"}}}

name: Skin Hyperpigmentation
description: Bronze or grayish skin discoloration due to increased melanin and iron deposition in the dermis, a classic feature of hemochromatosis.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Bronze or grayish skin discoloration due to increased melanin and iron deposition in the dermis, a classic feature of hemochromatosis.\n", "name": "Skin Hyperpigmentation"}
raw_json: {"description": "Bronze or grayish skin discoloration due to increased melanin and iron deposition in the dermis, a classic feature of hemochromatosis.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Case report documents skin pigmentation in ferroportin-related hemochromatosis.", "reference": "PMID:38886778", "snippet": "The proband is a 64-year-old man complaining of persistent abnormality of liver enzyme levels for 1 year, with a history of knee joint pain, diabetes and skin pigmentation.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Skin Hyperpigmentation", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "generalized bronze hyperpigmentation", "term": {"id": "HP:0007574", "label": "Generalized bronze hyperpigmentation"}}}

name: Diabetes Mellitus
description: Development of diabetes due to pancreatic beta cell destruction from iron toxicity, historically called "bronze diabetes."
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Development of diabetes due to pancreatic beta cell destruction from iron toxicity, historically called \"bronze diabetes.\"\n", "name": "Diabetes Mellitus"}
raw_json: {"description": "Development of diabetes due to pancreatic beta cell destruction from iron toxicity, historically called \"bronze diabetes.\"\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Diabetes reported as part of the hemochromatosis presentation.", "reference": "PMID:38886778", "snippet": "The proband is a 64-year-old man complaining of persistent abnormality of liver enzyme levels for 1 year, with a history of knee joint pain, diabetes and skin pigmentation.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Diabetes Mellitus", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "diabetes mellitus", "term": {"id": "HP:0000819", "label": "Diabetes mellitus"}}}

name: Arthropathy
description: Joint pain and swelling, particularly affecting the second and third metacarpophalangeal joints, due to iron and calcium pyrophosphate deposition.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Joint pain and swelling, particularly affecting the second and third metacarpophalangeal joints, due to iron and calcium pyrophosphate deposition.\n", "name": "Arthropathy"}
raw_json: {"description": "Joint pain and swelling, particularly affecting the second and third metacarpophalangeal joints, due to iron and calcium pyrophosphate deposition.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Knee joint pain in hemochromatosis supports arthropathy association.", "reference": "PMID:38886778", "snippet": "The proband is a 64-year-old man complaining of persistent abnormality of liver enzyme levels for 1 year, with a history of knee joint pain, diabetes and skin pigmentation.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Arthropathy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "arthropathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0003040", "label": "Arthropathy"}}}

name: Cardiomyopathy
description: Heart muscle disease due to iron deposition in cardiomyocytes, which can lead to heart failure and arrhythmias.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Heart muscle disease due to iron deposition in cardiomyocytes, which can lead to heart failure and arrhythmias.\n", "name": "Cardiomyopathy"}
raw_json: {"description": "Heart muscle disease due to iron deposition in cardiomyocytes, which can lead to heart failure and arrhythmias.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Juvenile hemochromatosis case describes cardiomyopathy among manifestations.", "reference": "PMID:35449524", "snippet": "Hemochromatosis type 2 or juvenile hemochromatosis has an early onset of severe iron overload resulting in organ manifestation such as liver fibrosis, cirrhosis, cardiomyopathy, arthropathy, hypogonadism, diabetes", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Cardiomyopathy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "cardiomyopathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0001638", "label": "Cardiomyopathy"}}}

name: Hypogonadism
description: Decreased gonadal function due to iron deposition in the pituitary gland, leading to reduced libido, erectile dysfunction, and testicular atrophy.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Decreased gonadal function due to iron deposition in the pituitary gland, leading to reduced libido, erectile dysfunction, and testicular atrophy.\n", "name": "Hypogonadism"}
raw_json: {"description": "Decreased gonadal function due to iron deposition in the pituitary gland, leading to reduced libido, erectile dysfunction, and testicular atrophy.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Pituitary iron deposition disrupts gonadotropin signaling leading to hypogonadism.", "reference": "PMID:36644615", "snippet": "Pituitary haemochromatosis is an endocrine disorder caused by the accumulation of iron due to a lack of absorption during haemochromatosis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Hypogonadism", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "hypogonadotropic hypogonadism", "term": {"id": "HP:0000044", "label": "Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism"}}}

name: Fatigue
description: Chronic tiredness and weakness, one of the most common and earliest symptoms of hemochromatosis.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Chronic tiredness and weakness, one of the most common and earliest symptoms of hemochromatosis.\n", "name": "Fatigue"}
raw_json: {"description": "Chronic tiredness and weakness, one of the most common and earliest symptoms of hemochromatosis.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Fatigue questionnaires show higher fatigue burden in HH compared with controls.", "reference": "PMID:39337031", "snippet": "The HH patients exhibited significantly worse fatigue across all the scales.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Long-term cohort notes chronic fatigue as a characteristic manifestation of genetic hemochromatosis.", "reference": "PMID:30244162", "snippet": "It results in chronic fatigue and in potential liver (cirrhosis), pancreas (diabetes) and joint (arthritis) damage in adulthood.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Fatigue", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "fatigue", "term": {"id": "HP:0012378", "label": "Fatigue"}}}

name: Hemarthrosis
notes: Recurrent joint bleeds leading to arthropathy
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hemarthrosis", "notes": "Recurrent joint bleeds leading to arthropathy"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Review confirms hemarthrosis as the primary clinical feature of severe hemophilia.", "reference": "PMID:34197690", "snippet": "Recurrent joint bleeding (hemarthrosis) is the most frequent clinical manifestation of severe hemophilia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hemarthrosis", "notes": "Recurrent joint bleeds leading to arthropathy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hemarthrosis", "term": {"id": "HP:0005261", "label": "Joint hemorrhage"}}}

name: Prolonged Bleeding
notes: After trauma or surgery

name: Jaundice
description: Yellowing of the skin and eyes due to elevated bilirubin levels from impaired liver function.
notes: Due to liver dysfunction causing elevated bilirubin levels
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Yellowing of the skin and eyes due to elevated bilirubin levels from impaired liver function.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Jaundice", "notes": "Due to liver dysfunction causing elevated bilirubin levels"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Yellowing of the skin and eyes due to elevated bilirubin levels from impaired liver function.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature mentions the management of chronic Hepatitis B and its effects on liver function, which can lead to jaundice.", "reference": "PMID:24266913", "snippet": "Chronically infected patients should be followed on a regular basis, preferably every 6 months, with liver function tests, and when appropriate, HBV DNA levels. Those who meet the criteria for high risk for HCC should undergo liver ultrasound every 6 months. Powerful antiviral medications are available that can suppress but not cure HBV and result in resolution of liver inflammation and fibrosis, even cirrhosis, as well as decrease the risk of developing HCC.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature explicitly lists jaundice as a classic presenting symptom of viral hepatitis, including Hepatitis B.", "reference": "PMID:3050928", "snippet": "The classic presenting symptoms of viral hepatitis are jaundice, nausea, vomiting, malaise, anorexia, and dull right upper quadrant pain.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature discusses the severe liver diseases caused by Hepatitis B, which can lead to jaundice due to liver dysfunction.", "reference": "PMID:34835022", "snippet": "Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is one of the serious health problems in the world as HBV causes severe liver diseases.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The case report describes a patient with Hepatitis B presenting with jaundice, supporting the statement that jaundice is a frequent symptom due to liver dysfunction.", "reference": "PMID:35395817", "snippet": "This case report describes a 57-year-old Iranian woman admitted to the hospital with jaundice, fever, body itching, abdominal pain, progressive muscle weakness, icteric sclera, right upper quadrant pain, and decreased muscle force.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Jaundice", "notes": "Due to liver dysfunction causing elevated bilirubin levels", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Jaundice", "term": {"id": "HP:0000952", "label": "Jaundice"}}}

name: Fatigue
description: Persistent tiredness and weakness commonly experienced by patients with chronic hepatitis B infection.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "Persistent tiredness and weakness commonly experienced by patients with chronic hepatitis B infection.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "Persistent tiredness and weakness commonly experienced by patients with chronic hepatitis B infection.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates that fatigue is more common after recovery in patients hospitalized for hepatitis B up to 30 months post-infection compared with matched controls hospitalized for other infectious diseases.", "reference": "PMID:7493307", "snippet": "Hepatitis cases scored significantly higher fatigue scores, GHQ-12 scores and muscle pain scores.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fatigue", "term": {"id": "HP:0012378", "label": "Fatigue"}}}

name: Abdominal Pain

notes: May be related to liver inflammation

raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Right upper quadrant pain or discomfort related to hepatic inflammation and liver capsule distension.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature mentions liver damage and clinical outcomes related to Hepatitis B, which can include gastrointestinal symptoms like abdominal pain due to liver inflammation.", "reference": "PMID:24954675", "snippet": "Hepatitis B virus is not cytopathic; both liver damage and viral control--and therefore clinical outcome--depend on the complex interplay between virus replication and host immune response.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature lists dull right upper quadrant pain as a classic symptom of viral hepatitis, which includes Hepatitis B, supporting the statement that abdominal pain is an occasional gastrointestinal symptom related to liver inflammation.", "reference": "PMID:3050928", "snippet": "The classic presenting symptoms of viral hepatitis are jaundice, nausea, vomiting, malaise, anorexia, and dull right upper quadrant pain.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Abdominal Pain", "notes": "May be related to liver inflammation", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abdominal pain", "term": {"id": "HP:0002027", "label": "Abdominal pain"}}}

name: Elevated Liver Enzymes
description: Increased serum levels of ALT and AST indicating hepatocyte injury and ongoing liver inflammation.
notes: Reflects liver cell damage and is a key diagnostic feature
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hepatic", "description": "Increased serum levels of ALT and AST indicating hepatocyte injury and ongoing liver inflammation.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Elevated Liver Enzymes", "notes": "Reflects liver cell damage and is a key diagnostic feature"}
raw_json: {"category": "Hepatic", "description": "Increased serum levels of ALT and AST indicating hepatocyte injury and ongoing liver inflammation.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates that elevated liver enzymes, which reflect liver cell damage, are more frequently observed in patients with Hepatitis B virus infection.", "reference": "PMID:34835022", "snippet": "The HBV surface antigen (HBsAg)-positive group had a more frequent prevalence of patients with higher transaminase elevations than the HBsAg-negative group.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Elevated liver enzymes are a common diagnostic feature in various liver diseases, including Hepatitis B.", "reference": "PMID:30418344", "snippet": "Abnormal liver enzymes are frequently encountered in primary care offices and hospitals and may be caused by a wide variety of conditions, from mild and nonspecific to well-defined and life-threatening.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The presence of elevated liver enzymes is associated with Hepatitis B infection, as indicated by the prevalence of HBsAg in patients.", "reference": "PMID:29551632", "snippet": "The prevalence of hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) was 18.5% (126/680) and of liver cirrhosis was 9.4% (64/680).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Although the focus is on hepatocellular carcinoma, the study implies the role of Hepatitis B in causing severe liver conditions, which include elevated liver enzymes as a diagnostic feature.", "reference": "PMID:33418899", "snippet": "Globally, hepatitis B virus (HBV) related hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is one of the major causes of cancer-related mortality.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Elevated transaminase levels are characteristic of hepatitis infections, including Hepatitis B.", "reference": "PMID:3050928", "snippet": "Studies are done for the elevated transaminase levels that are characteristic of hepatitis infection.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Elevated Liver Enzymes", "notes": "Reflects liver cell damage and is a key diagnostic feature"}

name: Fever

scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "Elevated body temperature that may occur during acute HBV infection or flares of chronic disease.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Fever"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "Elevated body temperature that may occur during acute HBV infection or flares of chronic disease.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates that fever can be associated with acute hepatitis B, particularly in severe cases, but it does not explicitly categorize fever as an occasional systemic manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:28223176", "snippet": "Prodromal fever indicated more severe liver injury and was independently associated with hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) negativity.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "While the reference mentions systemic manifestations of hepatitis B, it does not specifically mention fever as one of them.", "reference": "PMID:34913875", "snippet": "Several of these extrahepatic syndromes have been well described, including systemic vasculitides, glomerulonephritis, and cutaneous manifestations.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The study mentions the prevalence of hepatitis B among febrile patients but does not specifically categorize fever as an occasional systemic manifestation of hepatitis B.", "reference": "PMID:35499229", "snippet": "The study confirms the endemicity of hepatitis B and enteric fever in the area.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Fever", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fever", "term": {"id": "HP:0001945", "label": "Fever"}}}

notes: Liver enlargement

raw_json: {"category": "Hepatic", "description": "Enlargement of the liver detectable on physical examination or imaging, indicating hepatic inflammation.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "While the abstract does not specifically mention hepatomegaly as a frequent symptom, it implies that various liver-related conditions are associated with hepatitis B, supporting the occasional occurrence of hepatomegaly.", "reference": "PMID:12150847", "snippet": "Occult hepatitis B occurs in a number of clinical settings.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The text describes severe liver conditions related to chronic hepatitis B, but does not directly mention hepatomegaly. It suggests severe liver involvement, which could include hepatomegaly.", "reference": "PMID:19682192", "snippet": "Severe acute exacerbation is a unique presentation of chronic hepatitis B characterized by very high alanine aminotransferase level accompanied by jaundice and hepatic decompensation.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Hepatomegaly", "notes": "Liver enlargement", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hepatomegaly", "term": {"id": "HP:0002240", "label": "Hepatomegaly"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "Joint pain without joint swelling, an extrahepatic manifestation of HBV infection.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference confirms that arthralgia (joint pain) is a commonly described extrahepatic manifestation of Hepatitis B.", "reference": "PMID:18760074", "snippet": "The most commonly described include skin rash, arthritis, arthralgia, glomerulonephritis, polyarteritis nodosa, and papular acrodermatitis etc.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Arthralgias", "notes": "Joint pain", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Arthralgias", "term": {"id": "HP:0002829", "label": "Arthralgia"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Skin eruptions that may occur as an extrahepatic manifestation of HBV infection.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The title of the reference directly indicates the presence of dermatologic manifestations, supporting the statement that hepatitis B can cause occasional dermatologic conditions like rash.", "reference": "PMID:6133886", "snippet": "Dermatologic manifestations of hepatitis B virus infection.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference mentions that skin rashes are recognized as prodromal manifestations of viral hepatitis, including hepatitis B, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:1185334", "snippet": "The association of arthritis, arthralgia, and various types of skin rashes, as a prodrome to viral hepatitis, although well recognized in adults, has not been well described in children.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference notes that skin rashes were among the most frequent adverse reactions to the hepatitis B vaccine, indicating that hepatitis B can be associated with dermatologic manifestations like rash.", "reference": "PMID:1532114", "snippet": "The most frequent adverse reactions were myalgia/arthralgia lasting longer than 3 days (14), followed by skin rashes (eight) and dizziness (seven).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Rash", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Skin rash", "term": {"id": "HP:0000988", "label": "Skin rash"}}}

name: Breast Cancer
description: Breast cancer risk is 70-80% for BRCA1 and 60-70% for BRCA2 mutation carriers. BRCA1-associated breast cancers are often triple-negative (ER-/PR-/HER2-) and high grade. BRCA2-associated breast cancers more often express hormone receptors. Risk of contralateral breast cancer is significantly elevated.

description: Ovarian cancer risk is 40-50% for BRCA1 and 15-30% for BRCA2 mutation carriers. Most are high-grade serous carcinomas. Typically presents at earlier ages than sporadic ovarian cancer. Risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy is often recommended.

disorder_name: Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syndrome
name: Pancreatic Cancer
description: Lifetime risk of pancreatic cancer is increased to approximately 2-7%, particularly with BRCA2 mutations. BRCA2 is a recognized pancreatic cancer susceptibility gene. Surveillance may be considered in families with pancreatic cancer history.

disorder_name: Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syndrome
name: Prostate Cancer
description: BRCA2 mutations confer a 5-8 fold increased risk of prostate cancer, with earlier onset and more aggressive disease. BRCA1 mutations also increase risk but to a lesser degree. PARP inhibitors are effective in BRCA-mutated prostate cancer.

disorder_name: Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syndrome
name: Male Breast Cancer
description: Male breast cancer risk is elevated, particularly with BRCA2 mutations (6-8% lifetime risk). BRCA2 is the most common hereditary cause of male breast cancer.
notes: Uses same HP term as female breast cancer. Male breast cancer is specifically associated with BRCA2 more than BRCA1.

name: Chronic Constipation

name: Upper limb abnormality
description: Characteristic skeletal abnormalities of the upper limbs, ranging from thumb anomalies (thumb hypoplasia or aplasia) to severe bilateral upper limb malformations including radial ray defects, carpal abnormalities, and forearm hypoplasia.
notes: Upper limb abnormalities are a cardinal feature of Holt-Oram syndrome, occurring in nearly 100% of affected individuals.

raw_json: {"category": "Cardiac", "description": "Defects in the interatrial septum are the most common cardiac manifestation, typically ostium secundum type but can include other types of ASDs.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Establishes that septal defects are cardinal features of congenital heart disease associated with genetic factors including TBX5", "reference": "PMID:39596866", "snippet": "Within these malformations, septal defects such as ventricular (VSD) and atrial septal defects (ASD) are the most common forms of CHDs", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Clinical epidemiology showing atrial septal defect is the most common cardiac manifestation of HOS", "reference": "PMID:39156428", "snippet": "Seventy-five percent of those with Holt-Oram syndrome have a congenital cardiac defect, which most frequently affects the septum", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Atrial septal defect", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Atrial septal defect", "term": {"id": "HP:0001631", "label": "atrial septal defect"}}}

raw_json: {"evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference clearly states that chorea is a characteristic abnormal movement in Huntington's Disease.", "reference": "PMID:24176425", "snippet": "Huntington disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant, adult-onset, progressive neurodegenerative disease characterized by the triad of abnormal movements (typically chorea), cognitive impairment, and psychiatric problems.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference confirms that chorea is a major manifestation of Huntington's Disease.", "reference": "PMID:36049455", "snippet": "Chorea is one of the major manifestations of Huntington's disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference mentions chorea in the context of Huntington's Disease, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:31707371", "snippet": "BACKGROUND: Anosognosia, or unawareness of illness of deficits, has been observed in Huntington's disease (HD) in relation to motor and cognitive signs and symptoms. Most studies of awareness in HD have used self-report questionnaire methodology rather than asking patients to report on their symptoms in real-time. The two studies in which patients were asked about their chorea in real-time had small sample sizes and only examined patients early in disease progression.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference directly associates Huntington's Disease with chorea.", "reference": "PMID:6446233", "snippet": "Huntington's disease (chorea) is characterized by abnormal movements and dementia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference states that chorea is the most common associated movement disorder in Huntington's Disease.", "reference": "PMID:32699773", "snippet": "Huntington's Disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder with a progressive decline in cognitive, motor, and psychological function. The development of heart failure can occur because of complications of ischemic heart disease or from progression of diastolic dysfunction to heart failure with preserved ejection fraction degenerating to a dilated heart with systolic dysfunction or heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "While the reference discusses dyspnea as a symptom that limits exercise tolerance, it is not specific to hypertensive heart disease.", "reference": "PMID:15950133", "snippet": "Dyspnea and leg effort are the major symptoms limiting exercise in healthy subjects and in patients with a variety of respiratory disorders.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference implies that dyspnea could be an issue in hypertensive patients, which could lead to reduced exercise tolerance.", "reference": "PMID:37345800", "snippet": "Ventilatory efficiency is impaired people with hypertension without a diagnosis of heart failure versus normotensive individuals.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "It mentions heart failure and its link to dyspnea indirectly through pulmonary hypertension but does not focus on hypertensive heart disease specifically.", "reference": "PMID:26569571", "snippet": "Pulmonary hypertension (PH) due to left-sided heart disease (LSHD) is a common and disconcerting occurrence. For example, both heart failure (HF) with preserved and reduced ejection fraction (HFpEF and HFrEF) often lead to PH as a consequence of a chronic elevation in left atrial filling pressure.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Dyspnea", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Dyspnea", "term": {"id": "HP:0002094", "label": "Dyspnea"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Reduced Exercise Tolerance"}, {"target": "Heart Failure Exacerbations"}]}

raw_json: {"category": "Renal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that hypertension is associated with proteinuria and the progression of renal disease, supporting the statement that hypertension can cause and worsen kidney damage.", "reference": "PMID:18677585", "snippet": "Hypertension and proteinuria are common risk factors for cardiovascular morbidity and mortality, as well as for the progression of renal disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While the literature suggests a link between hypertension and end-stage renal disease, it also notes that the diagnosis is often one of exclusion and lacks definitive pathologic data.", "reference": "PMID:1614065", "snippet": "The number of patients developing end-stage renal disease (ESRD) as a consequence of hypertension is increasing and accounts for 25% of new cases of ESRD in the United States. However, the diagnosis of hypertensive ESRD is one of exclusion and no pathologic data corroborate this classification.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by indicating that hypertension can lead to renal damage, including proteinuria and nephrosclerosis.", "reference": "PMID:7606639", "snippet": "The kidney can be considered as both culprit and victim in the hypertensive process. Deranged renal function contributes to the development of arterial hypertension and of secondary vascular damage at the glomerular and arteriolar level and accounts for the development of progressive nephrosclerosis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature supports the statement by discussing how glomerular injury, often exacerbated by conditions like hypertension, leads to further renal damage and proteinuria.", "reference": "PMID:20400279", "snippet": "With ongoing progression and glomerular extracapillary proliferation, tubulointerstitial damage occurs with consequent nephron loss and development of fibrotic lesions, finally resulting in terminal renal failure.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Proteinuria", "notes": "Hypertension can cause and worsen kidney damage", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Proteinuria", "term": {"id": "HP:0000093", "label": "Proteinuria"}}}
