raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates a relationship between hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) and arrhythmias, supporting the statement that arrhythmias are a common cardiovascular phenotype of HCM.", "reference": "PMID:34969871", "snippet": "Study aims were to estimate the population-diagnosed prevalence of cardiomyopathies and describe the temporal relationship between a diagnosis of cardiomyopathy with HF and arrhythmia... Between 2010 and 2018, prevalence increased for ARVC by 180% and HCM by 9%.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study directly assesses the prevalence and types of arrhythmias in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, confirming that arrhythmias are a common phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:7201843", "snippet": "The patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy showed a significant increase in supraventricular extrasystoles/24 hours, supraventricular arrhythmias, high grade ventricular arrhythmia, and the number of patients with more than 10 ventricular extrasystoles every 24 hours when compared with the other groups.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference mentions common arrhythmic events in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, supporting the idea that arrhythmias are a common cardiovascular phenotype in HCM.", "reference": "PMID:3158692", "snippet": "Frequent ventricular premature complexes, complex ventricular ectopic activity and asymptomatic ventricular tachycardia are common to both hypertrophic and dilated cardiomyopathy; in both conditions, sudden death is a common occurrence.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Arrhythmias", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Arrhythmias", "term": {"id": "HP:0011675", "label": "Arrhythmia"}}}

name: Arrhythmias
notes: Abnormal heart rhythms are common. Can include atrial fibrillation and ventricular arrhythmias.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Arrhythmias", "notes": "Abnormal heart rhythms are common. Can include atrial fibrillation and ventricular arrhythmias."}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference confirms that hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is associated with ventricular arrhythmias and is a leading cause of sudden cardiac death.", "reference": "PMID:23124402", "snippet": "Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is the most common genetic cardiovascular disorder and the leading cause of sudden cardiac death in the young. This article reviews the ventricular arrhythmias associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference confirms that atrial fibrillation is common in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.", "reference": "PMID:28602671", "snippet": "Patients with HCM are predisposed to developing atrial fibrillation (AF) due primarily to advanced diastolic dysfunction and left atrial (LA) dilatation and remodelling.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference discusses the role of arrhythmias in structural heart disease, including hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and their association with significant cardiovascular complications and sudden cardiac death.", "reference": "PMID:29203161", "snippet": "Cardiac arrhythmias refer to any abnormality or disturbance in the normal activation sequence of the myocardium and may be indicative of structural heart disease and the cause of significant cardiovascular complications and sudden cardiac death.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference confirms that ventricular arrhythmias are common in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, particularly in athletes.", "reference": "PMID:11174912", "snippet": "Ventricular arrhythmias in the athlete generally occur in the setting of structural heart disease that is genetically determined (hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia, anomalous coronary arteries) or acquired (coronary artery disease, myocarditis, idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathies).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Arrhythmias", "notes": "Abnormal heart rhythms are common. Can include atrial fibrillation and ventricular arrhythmias.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Arrhythmias", "term": {"id": "HP:0011675", "label": "Arrhythmia"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Palpitations"}, {"target": "Sudden Cardiac Death"}]}

name: Mitral Valve Regurgitation
notes: Thickened heart muscle can affect mitral valve function, causing leakage.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Mitral Valve Regurgitation", "notes": "Thickened heart muscle can affect mitral valve function, causing leakage."}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference discusses the common occurrence of mitral valve elongation and thickening in HCM, which can lead to mitral regurgitation.", "reference": "PMID:21909825", "snippet": "Elongation and pathological thickening of the mitral valve (MV) is commonly seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM)... failure of either to optimally adapt in this setting can result in mitral regurgitation.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study shows that mitral regurgitation (MR) is a significant factor in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), supporting the statement that thickened heart muscle can affect mitral valve function, causing leakage.", "reference": "PMID:35644869", "snippet": "RESULTS: Significant (more than mild) MR was a significant univariate predictor of all the three LA strain values", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference indicates that hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is often complicated by mitral regurgitation, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:37563454", "snippet": "However, the interplay between these conditions is increasingly being recognized and they frequently coexist, as in the paradigmatic examples of dilated cardiomyopathy and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which are often complicated by the occurrence of mitral regurgitation.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study indicates that mitral valve regurgitation is a complication in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (OHCM), supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:37574021", "snippet": "OHCM patients with MAC had a worse prognosis and more recurrent mitral valve regurgitation than those without MAC after septal myectomy.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Mitral Valve Regurgitation", "notes": "Thickened heart muscle can affect mitral valve function, causing leakage."}

raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference mentions fatigue as a common symptom of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, supporting the statement that fatigue occurs occasionally in this condition.", "reference": "PMID:34533409", "snippet": "Common symptoms include chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, fatigue and syncope (fainting)...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference describes a patient with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy experiencing muscle fatigue, aligning with the statement that fatigue is occasionally observed due to reduced cardiac output and efficiency.", "reference": "PMID:37715354", "snippet": "A 59-year-old man was referred for SSM as dyspnoea and low threshold muscle fatigue associated to severe left ventricular outflow obstruction...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Fatigue", "notes": "Due to reduced cardiac output and efficiency.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fatigue", "term": {"id": "HP:0012378", "label": "Fatigue"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Hematological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This review highlights that thrombocytopenia is the cardinal feature of ITP, with up to 75% of adult patients developing chronic thrombocytopenia, and bleeding risk correlates with platelet count severity.", "reference": "PMID:38396839", "snippet": "Although the pathogenesis of ITP is currently better known and its etiology has been extensively studied, up to 75% of adult patients with ITP may develop chronicity, which represents a significant burden on patients' quality of life. name: Abdominal Pain
notes: Related to defecation

raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "TRPV1-expressing nerve fibers are increased in IBS and directly linked to abdominal pain severity.", "reference": "PMID:18252749", "snippet": "Increased TRPV1 nerve fibres are observed in IBS, together with a low-grade inflammatory response. The increased TRPV1 nerve fibres may contribute to visceral hypersensitivity and pain in IBS, and provide a novel therapeutic target.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Mast cell mediators, particularly histamine and proteases, directly excite nociceptive neurons to produce abdominal pain in IBS.", "reference": "PMID:17241857", "snippet": "IBS-dependent excitation of dorsal root ganglia was inhibited by histamine H(1) receptor blockade and serine protease inactivation (inhibition of 51.7%; P < .05 and 74.5%; P < .05; respectively).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Abdominal Pain", "notes": "Related to defecation", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abdominal Pain", "term": {"id": "HP:0002027", "label": "Abdominal pain"}}}

name: Absence of Hand Abnormalities

name: Eyelid Myoclonia
description: Rapid, rhythmic jerking of the eyelids often accompanied by upward eye deviation and brief impairment of consciousness.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "description": "Rapid, rhythmic jerking of the eyelids often accompanied by upward eye deviation and brief impairment of consciousness.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Eyelid Myoclonia"}
complex_fields_json: {"sequelae": [{"description": "Transient visual impairment during myoclonic episodes due to involuntary eyelid movement.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "While this reference describes the eyelid movements and consciousness impairment during episodes, it indirectly supports that rapid eyelid closure would impair visual function.", "reference": "PMID:8270934", "snippet": "Brief, typical absences occur with rapid eyelid myoclonia associated with retropulsive movements of the eyeballs and occasionally of the head. The seizures are of shorter duration than in childhood absence epilepsy, and are accompanied by less profound impairment of consciousness.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "target": "Impaired Visual Functioning During Episodes"}]}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "description": "Rapid, rhythmic jerking of the eyelids often accompanied by upward eye deviation and brief impairment of consciousness.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature supports the neurologic diagnostic of eyelid myoclonia as a high frequency phenotype of Jeavons Syndrome (JS).", "reference": "PMID:32554361", "snippet": "Jeavons syndrome (JS) is mainly characterized by eyelid myoclonia with or without absences.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study confirms that eyelid myoclonia is a common and significant phenotype of JS, reinforcing the diagnostic.", "reference": "PMID:30685520", "snippet": "Eyelid myoclonia, the most common seizure type in all 8 patients, were typically initiated by eating or other simple orofacial stimuli.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "It confirms the diagnostic frequency of eyelid myoclonia as a defining characteristic of JS.", "reference": "PMID:36216271", "snippet": "To the best of our knowledge, this is the first case of STAG2 encephalopathy fulfilling all electroclinical criteria for epilepsy with eyelid myoclonia and absences (EMA), formally named Jeavons syndrome (JS).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While photosensitivity is discussed, the specific association with eyelid myoclonia and its sequelae in JS is not the main focus.", "reference": "PMID:14706039", "snippet": "Seizures induced by photic (or visual) stimuli or photosensitive seizures can be observed in generalized or focal, idiopathic, or symptomatic epilepsies...", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Eyelid Myoclonia", "phenotype_term": {"description": "Rapid, rhythmic jerking of the eyelids often associated with brief impairment of consciousness.", "preferred_term": "Eyelid Myoclonia", "term": {"id": "HP:0011149", "label": "Absence seizure with eyelid myoclonia"}}, "sequelae": [{"description": "Transient visual impairment during myoclonic episodes due to involuntary eyelid movement.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "While this reference describes the eyelid movements and consciousness impairment during episodes, it indirectly supports that rapid eyelid closure would impair visual function.", "reference": "PMID:8270934", "snippet": "Brief, typical absences occur with rapid eyelid myoclonia associated with retropulsive movements of the eyeballs and occasionally of the head. The seizures are of shorter duration than in childhood absence epilepsy, and are accompanied by less profound impairment of consciousness.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "target": "Impaired Visual Functioning During Episodes"}]}

name: Absences
description: Brief episodes of impaired awareness typically lasting seconds, often accompanying eyelid myoclonia.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "description": "Brief episodes of impaired awareness typically lasting seconds, often accompanying eyelid myoclonia.", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Absences"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "description": "Brief episodes of impaired awareness typically lasting seconds, often accompanying eyelid myoclonia.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature provides a title indicating a connection between eyelid myoclonia (a feature of Jeavons Syndrome) and absences, further supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:15508923", "snippet": "Eyelid myoclonia and absence.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Absences", "phenotype_term": {"description": "Brief impaired awareness seizures accompanied by eyelid jerking movements.", "preferred_term": "Absence seizure with eyelid myoclonia", "term": {"id": "HP:0011149", "label": "Absence seizure with eyelid myoclonia"}}}

name: Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizures
description: Convulsive seizures involving bilateral stiffening and rhythmic jerking, occurring in a subset of patients.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "description": "Convulsive seizures involving bilateral stiffening and rhythmic jerking, occurring in a subset of patients.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizures"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "description": "Convulsive seizures involving bilateral stiffening and rhythmic jerking, occurring in a subset of patients.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The statement is partially supported because generalized tonic-clonic seizures occur in 70% of patients, which suggests a high frequency rather than 'occasional'.", "reference": "PMID:30082241", "snippet": "After a median follow-up of two years, 80% of patients had drug-resistant epilepsy and 70% experienced generalized tonic-clonic seizures.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizures", "phenotype_term": {"description": "Convulsive seizures with bilateral motor manifestations and generalized onset.", "preferred_term": "Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure with generalized onset", "term": {"id": "HP:0025190", "label": "Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure with generalized onset"}}}

name: Mild Cognitive Impairment
description: Subtle deficits in processing speed, verbal learning, and attention observed in some patients.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cognitive", "description": "Subtle deficits in processing speed, verbal learning, and attention observed in some patients.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Mild Cognitive Impairment"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cognitive", "description": "Subtle deficits in processing speed, verbal learning, and attention observed in some patients.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature supports that there are cognitive impairments in Jeavons syndrome, but it does not explicitly classify these impairments as 'mild cognitive impairment' (MCI) nor does it mention the frequency as 'occasional'. The impairments are more specific and varied, making the statement partially correct but not completely accurate.", "reference": "PMID:26492104", "snippet": "All participants completed neuropsychological evaluations. Statistical analyses revealed performance that was below average on measures of global IQ, processing speed and rote, verbal learning coupled with average nonverbal reasoning, and sustained attention. There was also evidence of impaired higher-level verbal reasoning. While global IQ ranged from low average to borderline impaired, no participant could be accurately described as impaired or having intellectual disability (ID) given the consistently average performance noted on some higher-order tasks including nonverbal reasoning.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Mild Cognitive Impairment"}

name: Photosensitivity
description: Abnormal brain response to flickering light or visual patterns that triggers seizures or EEG abnormalities.
notes: Increased sensitivity to light stimulation, which can provoke seizures or eyelid myoclonia. A common finding in Jeavons syndrome.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "description": "Abnormal brain response to flickering light or visual patterns that triggers seizures or EEG abnormalities.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Photosensitivity", "notes": "Increased sensitivity to light stimulation, which can provoke seizures or eyelid myoclonia. A common finding in Jeavons syndrome."}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "description": "Abnormal brain response to flickering light or visual patterns that triggers seizures or EEG abnormalities.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract clearly states that photosensitivity is a characteristic feature of Jeavons syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:30082241", "snippet": "Jeavons syndrome is an underreported epileptic syndrome characterized by eyelid myoclonia, eyelid closure-induced seizures or electroencephalography paroxysms, and photosensitivity.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Photosensitivity", "notes": "Increased sensitivity to light stimulation, which can provoke seizures or eyelid myoclonia. A common finding in Jeavons syndrome."}

name: Pulmonary Involvement

name: Fever
description: High fever lasting at least 5 days, a mandatory criterion for diagnosis of Kawasaki disease.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "High fever lasting at least 5 days, a mandatory criterion for diagnosis of Kawasaki disease.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Fever"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "High fever lasting at least 5 days, a mandatory criterion for diagnosis of Kawasaki disease.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature mentions fever as one of the most frequent symptoms observed in Kawasaki disease, supporting the statement that fever is a very frequent systemic diagnostic symptom of Kawasaki disease.", "reference": "PMID:30029859", "snippet": "Fever, abdominal pain, and vomiting were the most frequent symptoms observed and typical Kawasaki disease signs and symptoms appeared after intestinal complaints in all cases.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature highlights the challenge of distinguishing Kawasaki disease from other febrile illnesses, indicating that fever is a very frequent systemic diagnostic symptom in Kawasaki disease.", "reference": "PMID:31900257", "snippet": "The conundrum for acute paediatricians is which clinical features best distinguish the febrile child with possible KD, needing intravenous immunoglobulin, from the many other children with febrile illnesses.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature states that fever is present in 100% of the cases, supporting the statement that fever is a very frequent systemic diagnostic symptom of Kawasaki disease.", "reference": "PMID:26631821", "snippet": "The main symptoms were fever (100%), exanthema (98%), changes in the extremities (91%), conjunctivitis (77%), oral cavity changes (89%), cervical adenitis (55%) and cardiac abnormalities (45%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Fever", "phenotype_term": {"description": "Elevated body temperature above the normal range, typically above 38C (100.4F).", "preferred_term": "Fever", "term": {"id": "HP:0001945", "label": "Fever"}}}

name: Rash
description: Polymorphous exanthem typically affecting the trunk and extremities, without vesicles or crusting.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Polymorphous exanthem typically affecting the trunk and extremities, without vesicles or crusting.", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Rash"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Polymorphous exanthem typically affecting the trunk and extremities, without vesicles or crusting.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Exanthema, which refers to a widespread rash, was present in 98% of the adult patients with Kawasaki Disease.", "reference": "PMID:26631821", "snippet": "The main symptoms were fever (100%), exanthema (98%)...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The case description includes a diffuse erythematous maculopapular rash as one of the clinical features.", "reference": "PMID:1440951", "snippet": "We describe a four-year-old girl who presented with fever, a diffuse erythematous maculopapular rash...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract emphasizes the mucocutaneous manifestations, which include skin rashes, as critical for diagnosing Kawasaki Disease.", "reference": "PMID:33453126", "snippet": "All children with KD have fever accompanied by clinical signs, with four of the five classic criteria for complete KD being mucocutaneous...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The case report mentions a generalized rash as one of the symptoms of Kawasaki Disease.", "reference": "PMID:23481152", "snippet": "This is a report of a 4-year-old Hispanic boy who presented with skin changes to the lips and oral cavity, a generalized rash...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The patients with COVID-19 inflammatory syndrome had clinical features resembling Kawasaki Disease, including a rash.", "reference": "PMID:32843441", "snippet": "Both patients presented with fever lasting >5 days and were found to have rash, conjunctival injection, and swollen lips.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Rash", "phenotype_term": {"description": "Visible change in skin color or texture, typically involving erythema or papules.", "preferred_term": "Skin rash", "term": {"id": "HP:0000988", "label": "Skin rash"}}}

name: Conjunctivitis
description: Bilateral bulbar conjunctival injection without exudate, typically limbal sparing.
notes: Non-purulent (no pus)
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ocular", "description": "Bilateral bulbar conjunctival injection without exudate, typically limbal sparing.", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Conjunctivitis", "notes": "Non-purulent (no pus)"}
raw_json: {"category": "Ocular", "description": "Bilateral bulbar conjunctival injection without exudate, typically limbal sparing.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study shows that Kawasaki Disease is associated with allergic conjunctivitis, supporting the statement that conjunctivitis is very frequent in Kawasaki Disease.", "reference": "PMID:34814144", "snippet": "In cross-sectional studies, KD was associated with allergic rhinitis (n = 6; OR, 1.69; 95% CI, 1.52-1.87), asthma (n = 3; OR, 1.72; 95% CI, 1.38-2.14), allergic conjunctivitis (n = 2; OR, 1.95; 95% CI, 1.68-2.27), and atopic dermatitis (n = 3; OR, 1.35; 95% CI, 1.22-1.49).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The description of conjunctival injection in patients with Kawasaki Disease supports the statement.", "reference": "PMID:32843441", "snippet": "Both patients presented with fever lasting >5 days and were found to have rash, conjunctival injection, and swollen lips.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Although the study focuses on anterior uveitis, it indicates significant ocular involvement in Kawasaki Disease, supporting the statement indirectly.", "reference": "PMID:7299613", "snippet": "In a prospective series, ophthalmologic examinations on 10 children with Kawasaki disease showed that eight had anterior uveitis during the acute phase of the illness.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Conjunctivitis", "notes": "Non-purulent (no pus)", "phenotype_term": {"description": "Inflammation of the conjunctiva resulting in redness and irritation of the eye.", "preferred_term": "Conjunctivitis", "term": {"id": "HP:0000509", "label": "Conjunctivitis"}}}

name: Swelling of Hands and Feet
description: Acute erythema and induration of the hands and feet with subsequent periungual desquamation.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "description": "Acute erythema and induration of the hands and feet with subsequent periungual desquamation.", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Swelling of Hands and Feet"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "description": "Acute erythema and induration of the hands and feet with subsequent periungual desquamation.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature explicitly mentions that swelling of the hands and feet is one of the six main clinical presentations of Kawasaki disease.", "reference": "PMID:1704148", "snippet": "The six main clinical presentations of Kawasaki disease are: prolonged fever, conjunctivitis, lesions of the oral and pharyngeal mucosa, inflammatory reddening and swelling of the hands and feet, skin rash and cervical lymph node enlargement.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature lists swelling and redness of hands and feet as early clinical features of Kawasaki disease.", "reference": "PMID:3333141", "snippet": "Early clinical features include fever, rash, conjunctival injection, dry reddened lips, oropharyngeal reddening, enlarged cervical nodes, and swelling and redness of hands and feet.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Swelling of Hands and Feet"}

name: Peeling Skin
description: Desquamation beginning at the tips of fingers and toes, spreading to palms and soles during recovery phase.
notes: Particularly on the fingers and toes, often during the subacute phase
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Desquamation beginning at the tips of fingers and toes, spreading to palms and soles during recovery phase.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Peeling Skin", "notes": "Particularly on the fingers and toes, often during the subacute phase"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Desquamation beginning at the tips of fingers and toes, spreading to palms and soles during recovery phase.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The term 'desquamation' refers to peeling of the skin, which supports the statement that peeling skin is a frequent dermatologic manifestation of Kawasaki Disease, particularly during the subacute phase.", "reference": "PMID:6833960", "snippet": "The second, subacute, phase begins with a decline of the acute findings and proceeds with desquamation of rash...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference explicitly mentions that peeling of the skin on the fingers and toes is a frequent occurrence 1-2 weeks after the onset of Kawasaki Disease.", "reference": "PMID:3333141", "snippet": "Peeling of skin of fingers and toes, arthralgia, and marked thrombocytosis are frequent 1-2 weeks after onset.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The term 'desquamative rash' indicates peeling skin, supporting the statement that this is a frequent dermatologic manifestation of Kawasaki Disease.", "reference": "PMID:37065507", "snippet": "Kawasaki disease's clinical manifestations range from oral skin disease to the blistering of the mucosa, symptoms involving the hands and the feet, skin disease of the palms and soles, a desquamative rash...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Peeling Skin", "notes": "Particularly on the fingers and toes, often during the subacute phase"}

name: Red, Cracked Lips
description: Erythema, dryness, and fissuring of the lips with strawberry tongue and diffuse oropharyngeal erythema.
notes: Includes "strawberry tongue" and inflammation in the mouth and throat
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Oropharyngeal", "description": "Erythema, dryness, and fissuring of the lips with strawberry tongue and diffuse oropharyngeal erythema.", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Red, Cracked Lips", "notes": "Includes \"strawberry tongue\" and inflammation in the mouth and throat"}
raw_json: {"category": "Oropharyngeal", "description": "Erythema, dryness, and fissuring of the lips with strawberry tongue and diffuse oropharyngeal erythema.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract mentions redness of the lips and a typical strawberry tongue as clinical manifestations of Kawasaki disease.", "reference": "PMID:15835487", "snippet": "The disease can present with protean clinical manifestations which include high grade fever (for at least 5 days), rash, redness of the lips and a typical strawberry tongue, cervical lymph node enlargement (often unilateral), swelling over the hands/feet and, later a characteristic peripheral desquamation over the fingers and toes.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study indicates that ENT (ear, nose, and throat) manifestations, which include oropharyngeal symptoms, are frequently at the forefront of KD.", "reference": "PMID:30903929", "snippet": "Kawasaki disease (KD) is a febrile multisystemic vasculitis of unknown etiology whose coronary prognosis is improved by early diagnosis and management. ... ENT manifestations are frequently at the forefront of KD and constitute a misleading clinical picture responsible for delayed diagnosis and potentially inappropriate medico-surgical management.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The case description includes dry, red, fissured lips and a tongue with a strawberry 'appearance', supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:1440951", "snippet": "We describe a four-year-old girl who presented with fever, a diffuse erythematous maculopapular rash, bilateral nonpurulent bulbar conjunctivitis, dry, red, fissured lips, a tongue with a strawberry 'appearance', an erythematous pharynx, indurative erythema, and edema and desquamation of the face, hands and feet.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The report includes skin changes to the lips and oral cavity, which supports the statement.", "reference": "PMID:23481152", "snippet": "This is a report of a 4-year-old Hispanic boy who presented with skin changes to the lips and oral cavity, a generalized rash, edema of hands and feet, and peeling of the periungual areas of the fingers as well as to the groin and perianal areas.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Red, Cracked Lips", "notes": "Includes \"strawberry tongue\" and inflammation in the mouth and throat"}

name: Coronary Artery Aneurysms
description: Abnormal dilation of coronary arteries that can lead to thrombosis, stenosis, and myocardial infarction.
notes: Can lead to serious heart complications
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "description": "Abnormal dilation of coronary arteries that can lead to thrombosis, stenosis, and myocardial infarction.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Coronary Artery Aneurysms", "notes": "Can lead to serious heart complications"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "description": "Abnormal dilation of coronary arteries that can lead to thrombosis, stenosis, and myocardial infarction.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that coronary artery aneurysms are a common complication of Kawasaki disease, occurring in 15-25% of cases, which is more frequent than 'occasional'.", "reference": "PMID:10512599", "snippet": "Coronary artery aneurysms or ectasia develop in approximately 15-25% of children with the disease.", "supports": "REFUTE"}, {"explanation": "The incidence of coronary artery aneurysms (CAAs) in Kawasaki disease is significant, with a notable percentage of patients developing CAAs, indicating that the frequency is more than 'occasional'.", "reference": "PMID:31732547", "snippet": "Twenty-three patients had SAAs, demonstrating an incidence of 14.2% (23 of 162) in patients who were screened at 1 month after onset. The proportion of patients with SAAs was estimated to be 2% (23 of 1148) of all patients with KD.", "supports": "REFUTE"}, {"explanation": "The study shows a high incidence of cardiovascular complications in children with Kawasaki disease, indicating that coronary artery aneurysms and other heart complications are not just occasional.", "reference": "PMID:34651205", "snippet": "Among the 640 KD children, most were 1-5 years old (415/640, 64.8%). Children < 1 year old (31.6%) and > 5 years old (28.3%) were more likely to have cardiovascular complications.", "supports": "REFUTE"}, {"explanation": "The literature indicates a high rate of complications from coronary artery aneurysms in Kawasaki disease, suggesting that these complications are not occasional but rather significant.", "reference": "PMID:23075819", "snippet": "Patients with persistent or remodeled coronary aneurysms after Kawasaki disease have a high rate of complications including thrombosis or stenosis leading to myocardial infarction.", "supports": "REFUTE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Coronary Artery Aneurysms", "notes": "Can lead to serious heart complications"}

name: Thrombocytosis
description: Elevated platelet count commonly found in the subacute phase of Kawasaki disease.
notes: Often appears 1-2 weeks after onset
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "description": "Elevated platelet count commonly found in the subacute phase of Kawasaki disease.", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Thrombocytosis", "notes": "Often appears 1-2 weeks after onset"}
raw_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "description": "Elevated platelet count commonly found in the subacute phase of Kawasaki disease.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Thrombocytosis is a common finding during the subacute phase of KD.", "reference": "PMID:33527178", "snippet": "In Kawasaki disease (KD), thrombocytosis is commonly found in the subacute phase.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Thrombocytosis occurs during the subacute phase of KD.", "reference": "PMID:6833960", "snippet": "The second, subacute, phase begins with a decline of the acute findings and proceeds with desquamation of rash, joint manifestations, thrombocytosis, and cardiac disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Thrombocytosis", "notes": "Often appears 1-2 weeks after onset", "phenotype_term": {"description": "Abnormally increased platelet count in the blood.", "preferred_term": "Thrombocytosis", "term": {"id": "HP:0001894", "label": "Thrombocytosis"}}}

name: Aneurysm Formation
description: Vascular dilation resulting from inflammatory weakening of vessel walls, affecting coronary and other medium-sized arteries.

raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "description": "Vascular dilation resulting from inflammatory weakening of vessel walls, affecting coronary and other medium-sized arteries.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference directly states that coronary artery aneurysm development is a major complication of Kawasaki disease.", "reference": "PMID:31599798", "snippet": "Kawasaki disease is a childhood vasculitis of unknown origin, whose major complication is the development of coronary artery aneurysms (CAA).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference describes the mechanism by which arterial inflammation leads to dilation and aneurysm formation in Kawasaki disease.", "reference": "PMID:21447126", "snippet": "Histologically, coronary arteritis begins 6-8 days after the onset of KD, and leads immediately to inflammation of all layers of the artery. The inflammation spreads completely around the artery; as a result, structural components of the artery undergo intense damage; the artery then begins to dilate.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Aneurysm Formation", "phenotype_term": {"description": "Abnormal focal dilation of a blood vessel due to weakening of the vessel wall.", "preferred_term": "Aneurysm Formation", "term": {"id": "HP:0002617", "label": "Vascular dilatation"}}}

name: Palmoplantar Keratoderma

{"description": "Generalized scaling of the skin, characteristic of the loricrin-associated (Camisa) variant but absent in classic GJB2-associated form.
", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Ichthyosis is present in the loricrin variant but not classic form.", "reference": "PMID:9326398", "snippet": "Our first family (VK1) also had ichthyosis but not deafness.
", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "MODEL_ORGANISM", "explanation": "Transgenic mice with mutant loricrin develop ichthyosis-like scaling.", "reference": "PMID:11038186", "snippet": "At birth, transgenic mice (ML.VS) exhibited erythrokeratoderma with an epidermal barrier dysfunction. 4 d after birth, high-expressing transgenic animals showed a generalized scaling of the skin
", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Ichthyosis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Ichthyosis", "term": {"id": "HP:0008064", "label": "Ichthyosis"}}, "subtype": "Loricrin Keratoderma (Variant Vohwinkel Syndrome)"}

name: Alopecia
description: Sparse hair or patchy hair loss, particularly affecting eyebrows and eyelashes in some patients.

raw_json: {"description": "Sparse hair or patchy hair loss, particularly affecting eyebrows and eyelashes in some patients.\n", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Alopecia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Alopecia", "term": {"id": "HP:0001596", "label": "Alopecia"}}}

name: Hypogonadism
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Reproductive", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hypogonadism"}
raw_json: {"category": "Reproductive", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference indicates that hypogonadism, a reproductive phenotype, is commonly associated with Klinefelter Syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:29382506", "snippet": "Hypogonadism is usually not evident until early adulthood and progresses with ageing.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The text mentions that hypogonadism is among the numerous clinical features of Klinefelter Syndrome, supporting its high frequency and inclusion in reproductive diagnostics.", "reference": "PMID:26823086", "snippet": "Klinefelter's syndrome, the most common sex disorder associated with chromosomal aberrations, is characterized by a plethora of clinical features.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference specifically mentions hypogonadism in the context of a Klinefelter Syndrome diagnosis, supporting the reproductive diagnostic frequency.", "reference": "PMID:33107323", "snippet": "presented with hypoglycemia due to isolated secondary adrenal insufficiency, who further had a decrease in testicular size with increased follicle-stimulating hormone level (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism) and diagnosed with Klinefelter syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hypogonadism", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypogonadism", "term": {"id": "HP:0000135", "label": "Hypogonadism"}}}

name: Delayed Speech and Language Development
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Developmental", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Delayed Speech and Language Development"}
raw_json: {"category": "Developmental", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that around two-thirds of individuals with KS require speech and language therapy or developmental support, suggesting that delayed speech and language development is relatively common but not universally present.", "reference": "PMID:35948402", "snippet": "Although Klinefelter syndrome (KS) is common, it is rarely recognised in childhood, sometimes being identified with speech or developmental delay or incidental antenatal diagnosis... Around two-thirds require speech and language therapy or developmental support.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement that delayed speech and language development is a common phenotype among individuals with Klinefelter Syndrome, as part of broader developmental delays.", "reference": "PMID:21217607", "snippet": "The behavioral phenotype of 47,XXY (Klinefelter syndrome) includes increased risks for developmental delays, language-based learning disabilities...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Delayed Speech and Language Development", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Delayed Speech and Language Development", "term": {"id": "HP:0000750", "label": "Delayed speech and language development"}}}

name: Learning Disabilities
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cognitive", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Learning Disabilities"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cognitive", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract indicates an increased risk of language disorders and reading disabilities, which fits under learning disabilities.", "reference": "PMID:20014369", "snippet": "Most studies support that males with KS have an increased risk of language disorders and reading disabilities.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract directly mentions the increased risk of language-based learning disabilities in individuals with Klinefelter syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:21217607", "snippet": "The behavioral phenotype of 47,XXY (Klinefelter syndrome) includes increased risks for developmental delays, language-based learning disabilities, executive dysfunction/ADHD, and socialemotional difficulties.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Learning Disabilities"}

name: Reduced Muscle Tone

scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Reduced Muscle Tone", "notes": "Manifests in infancy and childhood"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The provided literature does not mention reduced muscle tone as a feature of Klinefelter Syndrome, whether in infancy, childhood, or adulthood.", "reference": "PMID:20843200", "snippet": "The most specific clinical features which can be observed at adult age are small testes, gynecomastia, female distribution of fat and body hair, slightly increased body length due to an increased leg length and azoospermia.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Reduced Muscle Tone", "notes": "Manifests in infancy and childhood"}

name: Micropenis
notes: Noted at birth in some cases
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Reproductive", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Micropenis", "notes": "Noted at birth in some cases"}
raw_json: {"category": "Reproductive", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The provided literature does not mention micropenis as a characteristic feature of Klinefelter syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:20843200", "snippet": "The most specific clinical features which can be observed at adult age are small testes, gynecomastia, female distribution of fat and body hair, slightly increased body length due to an increased leg length and azoospermia.", "supports": "REFUTE"}, {"explanation": "This reference discusses micropenis in the context of Bardet-Biedl syndrome, not Klinefelter syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:32835378", "snippet": "BBS patients frequently presented with genitourinary malformations, such as cryptorchidism (5/11), short scrotum (5/8), and micropenis (5/8), but unexpectedly, with normal testis size (7/8).", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "While this case mentions micropenis, it is associated with the 49,XXXYY karyotype, not the typical 47,XXY Klinefelter syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:38684424", "snippet": "Subsequent examinations were conducted due to various symptoms, including delayed motor development, intellectual disability, facial dysmorphisms, forearm deformities, hip dysplasia, cryptorchidism, micropenis, primary hypogonadism, and essential tremor", "supports": "REFUTE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Micropenis", "notes": "Noted at birth in some cases", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Micropenis", "term": {"id": "HP:0000054", "label": "Micropenis"}}}

name: Psychosocial Difficulties
notes: May include shyness, low self-esteem, reduced assertiveness
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Behavioral", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Psychosocial Difficulties", "notes": "May include shyness, low self-esteem, reduced assertiveness"}
raw_json: {"category": "Behavioral", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference mentions psychosocial features including autistiform behavior, which aligns with the statement about occasional psychosocial difficulties.", "reference": "PMID:20843200", "snippet": "Cognition is characterized by verbal deficits and psychosocial features include autistiform behavior.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference highlights social-emotional difficulties, which supports the statement about occasional psychosocial difficulties.", "reference": "PMID:21217607", "snippet": "Tartaglia.nicole@tchden.org The behavioral phenotype of 47,XXY (Klinefelter syndrome) includes increased risks for developmental delays, language-based learning disabilities, executive dysfunction/ADHD, and socialemotional difficulties", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference discusses social cognition disorders, which can be related to psychosocial difficulties as mentioned in the statement.", "reference": "PMID:27743676", "snippet": "Social cognition disorders, predominantly on emotional recognition processes, have also been documented", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Psychosocial Difficulties", "notes": "May include shyness, low self-esteem, reduced assertiveness"}

name: Attention Deficit
notes: ADD/ADHD is more common than general population
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cognitive", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Attention Deficit", "notes": "ADD/ADHD is more common than general population"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cognitive", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that ADHD-like characteristics are indeed more common in individuals with Klinefelter Syndrome, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:20573461", "snippet": "A high rate of Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)-like characteristics has been reported in a wide variety of disorders including syndromes with known genetic causes... and Klinefelter Syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study found an association between X chromosome excess (as seen in Klinefelter Syndrome) and attention problems, supporting the statement that ADD/ADHD is more common in this population.", "reference": "PMID:34431088", "snippet": "X chromosome excess was associated with weakness in working memory (p=0.018) and approached significance for attention problems (p=0.071)...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Attention Deficit", "notes": "ADD/ADHD is more common than general population", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder", "term": {"id": "HP:0007018", "label": "Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder"}}}

name: Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
description: Core pulmonary manifestation of Lane Hamilton Syndrome, characterized by bleeding into the alveolar spaces of the lungs with radiologic ground-glass opacities and hemosiderin-laden macrophages on histology.

name: Iron-deficiency anemia

scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Near-universal finding in Lane Hamilton Syndrome adults, resulting from chronic blood loss into the alveoli with hemoglobin and iron depletion.\n", "name": "Iron-deficiency anemia"}

name: Malabsorption

name: Soft Tissue Sarcoma
description: Soft tissue sarcomas, particularly rhabdomyosarcoma in children and undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma in adults, are core tumors of LFS. Often present at young ages.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neoplastic", "description": "Soft tissue sarcomas, particularly rhabdomyosarcoma in children and undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma in adults, are core tumors of LFS. Often present at young ages.", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Soft Tissue Sarcoma"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neoplastic", "description": "Soft tissue sarcomas, particularly rhabdomyosarcoma in children and undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma in adults, are core tumors of LFS. Often present at young ages.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "French cohort study of 415 TP53 mutation carriers demonstrates soft tissue sarcomas are a core tumor type in LFS, occurring in 23% of children and 27% of adults.", "reference": "PMID:26014290", "snippet": "In childhood, the LFS tumor spectrum was characterized by osteosarcomas, adrenocortical carcinomas (ACC), CNS tumors, and soft tissue sarcomas (STS) observed in 30%, 27%, 26%, and 23% of the patients, respectively. In adults, the tumor distribution was characterized by the predominance of breast carcinomas observed in 79% of the females, and STS observed in 27% of the patients.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Soft Tissue Sarcoma", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Soft tissue sarcoma", "term": {"id": "HP:0030448", "label": "Soft tissue sarcoma"}}}

name: Osteosarcoma

name: Breast Cancer
description: Premenopausal breast cancer is a hallmark of female LFS patients. Lifetime risk approaches 85-90% in women. Often HER2-positive. Occurs at much younger ages than sporadic breast cancer.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neoplastic", "description": "Premenopausal breast cancer is a hallmark of female LFS patients. Lifetime risk approaches 85-90% in women. Often HER2-positive. name: Adrenocortical Carcinoma

name: Multiple Primary Cancers
description: Many LFS patients develop multiple independent primary cancers during their lifetime. This is a characteristic feature distinguishing LFS from sporadic cancer cases.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neoplastic", "description": "Many LFS patients develop multiple independent primary cancers during their lifetime. This is a characteristic feature distinguishing LFS from sporadic cancer cases.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Multiple Primary Cancers"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neoplastic", "description": "Many LFS patients develop multiple independent primary cancers during their lifetime. This is a characteristic feature distinguishing LFS from sporadic cancer cases.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Large French cohort demonstrates that 43% of LFS patients develop multiple malignancies, with average 1.7 tumors per affected carrier.", "reference": "PMID:26014290", "snippet": "The 322 affected carriers developed 552 tumors, and 43% had developed multiple malignancies. The mean age of first tumor onset was 24.9 years, 41% having developed a tumor by age 18.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Multiple Primary Cancers", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Neoplasm", "term": {"id": "HP:0002664", "label": "Neoplasm"}}}

raw_json: {"description": "Persistent, debilitating fatigue that is not relieved by rest.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Documents fatigue as a prominent symptom that interferes with function in Long COVID.", "reference": "PMID:37342500", "snippet": "They develop persistent fatigue, cognitive problems, headaches, disrupted sleep, myalgias and arthralgias, post-exertional malaise, orthostatic intolerance and other symptoms that greatly interfere with their ability to function", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Fatigue", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fatigue", "term": {"id": "HP:0012378", "label": "Fatigue"}}}

Often referred to as cognitive dysfunction.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Documents cognitive problems as a core symptom of Long COVID.", "reference": "PMID:37342500", "snippet": "They develop persistent fatigue, cognitive problems, headaches, disrupted sleep", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Provides mechanistic explanation for memory impairment in Long COVID.", "reference": "PMID:37848036", "snippet": "Peripheral serotonin reduction, in turn, impedes the activity of the vagus nerve and thereby impairs hippocampal responses and memory.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Cognitive Impairment", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Memory impairment", "term": {"id": "HP:0002354", "label": "Memory impairment"}}}

At two years' follow-up, 53% still experienced smell impairment", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Demonstrates long-term persistence of olfactory dysfunction in Long COVID.", "reference": "PMID:38976065", "snippet": "Most patients who initially suffered from smell and/or taste disturbance did not reach full recovery after 2 years follow-up.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Anosmia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Anosmia", "term": {"id": "HP:0000458", "label": "Anosmia"}}}

name: Erythema Migrans
description: Characteristic expanding circular rash at the site of tick bite, often with central clearing (bull's-eye appearance). Present in 70-80% of cases.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Characteristic expanding circular rash at the site of tick bite, often with central clearing (bull's-eye appearance). Present in 70-80% of cases.", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Erythema Migrans"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Characteristic expanding circular rash at the site of tick bite, often with central clearing (bull's-eye appearance). Present in 70-80% of cases.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Large Lithuanian cohort confirms erythema migrans as the dominant presentation.", "reference": "PMID:33669940", "snippet": "Results: In total, 1005 patients were enrolled with the following prevalence of clinical syndromes: erythema migrans (EM), 945 (94.02%); Lyme arthritis, 32 (3.18%); neuroborreliosis, 23 (2.28%); Lyme carditis, 4 (0.39%); and acrodermatitis, 1 (0.09%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Erythema Migrans", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Erythema migrans", "term": {"id": "HP:0031180", "label": "Erythema migrans"}}}

name: Fatigue
description: Profound fatigue is common in all stages of Lyme disease and may persist in post-treatment Lyme disease syndrome.

name: Arthralgia

raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "description": "Joint pain, particularly affecting large joints such as the knee, commonly precedes frank arthritis.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Arthralgia was reported in one-third of patients in a large endemic cohort.", "reference": "PMID:33669940", "snippet": "Clinical symptoms were as follows: arthralgia (33.2%), general weakness (19%), head pain (13.1%), myalgia (11.2%), fever (6.2%), joint swelling (5.9%), head dizziness (5.1%), nervus facialis neuropathy (2.4%), and radiculitis (2.0%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Arthralgia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Arthralgia", "term": {"id": "HP:0002829", "label": "Arthralgia"}}}

scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "description": "Unilateral or bilateral facial nerve palsy (Bell's palsy) in early disseminated disease, occurring in approximately 5% of untreated patients.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Facial Palsy"}

Occurs in approximately 60% of untreated patients.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Cohort study documents oligoarticular knee-predominant Lyme arthritis.", "reference": "PMID:33669940", "snippet": "Lyme arthritis mainly manifested among middle-aged women as an oligoarthritis, mostly affecting the knee joint.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Arthritis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Arthritis", "term": {"id": "HP:0001369", "label": "Arthritis"}}}

scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiac", "description": "Cardiac involvement including AV block (first, second, or third degree) and myocarditis. Lyme carditis occurs in 1-5% of untreated patients.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Atrioventricular Block"}

Lyme carditis occurs in 1-5% of untreated patients.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Case report and review emphasize AV block as the hallmark of Lyme carditis.", "reference": "PMID:37234726", "snippet": "the most common clinical manifestation is AV block, which can be acute in onset and can rapidly progress to complete heart block.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Atrioventricular Block", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Atrioventricular block", "term": {"id": "HP:0001678", "label": "Atrioventricular block"}}}

name: Endometrial Cancer
description: Uterine cancer developing at younger ages than sporadic cases, often the sentinel cancer in female Lynch syndrome carriers.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gynecologic", "description": "Uterine cancer developing at younger ages than sporadic cases, often the sentinel cancer in female Lynch syndrome carriers.", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Endometrial Cancer"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gynecologic", "description": "Uterine cancer developing at younger ages than sporadic cases, often the sentinel cancer in female Lynch syndrome carriers.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The article discusses Lynch syndrome and its association with endometrial cancer, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:28376523", "snippet": "The clinical characteristics of Lynch-associated endometrial cancer and screening and risk-reducing strategies also are described.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The article states that Lynch syndrome carriers have a strongly increased risk of developing endometrial cancer.", "reference": "PMID:23681793", "snippet": "Carriers of MMR defects have a strongly increased risk of developing CRC and endometrial cancer.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The review confirms that Lynch syndrome prominently predisposes individuals to endometrial cancer.", "reference": "PMID:29071502", "snippet": "Lynch syndrome is the hereditary disorder that most frequently predisposes to colorectal cancer as well as predisposing to a number of extracolonic cancers, most prominently endometrial cancer.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference further supports the statement that Lynch syndrome is strongly associated with endometrial cancer.", "reference": "PMID:37728516", "snippet": "Lynch syndrome (LS) markedly increases risks of colorectal and endometrial cancers.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Endometrial Cancer", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "endometrial cancer", "term": {"id": "MONDO:0011962", "label": "endometrial cancer"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Gastric adenocarcinoma occurring at elevated rates in Lynch syndrome, particularly with certain MMR gene mutations.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference supports the increased frequency of stomach (gastric) cancer as a phenotype of Lynch Syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:31319185", "snippet": "Lynch syndrome is the most common inherited cause of gastrointestinal cancer and increases risk for a variety of malignancies, including gastric cancer.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While this provides general context about hereditary gastrointestinal cancers, it does not specify Lynch Syndrome or stomach cancer.", "reference": "PMID:27546846", "snippet": "Approximately 5% arise from germline mutations in genes associated with cancer predisposition.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Stomach Cancer", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Stomach Cancer", "term": {"id": "HP:0012126", "label": "Stomach cancer"}}}

name: Urinary Tract Cancer
description: Upper urinary tract urothelial carcinoma affecting the ureter or renal pelvis.
notes: Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter or renal pelvis
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Genitourinary", "description": "Upper urinary tract urothelial carcinoma affecting the ureter or renal pelvis.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Urinary Tract Cancer", "notes": "Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter or renal pelvis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Genitourinary", "description": "Upper urinary tract urothelial carcinoma affecting the ureter or renal pelvis.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This large cohort supports urinary tract cancer as a recognized Lynch-associated malignancy and informs clinical risk stratification.", "reference": "PMID:31615790", "snippet": "Lynch syndrome confers markedly increased risks of various malignancies, including urinary tract cancers (UTC; renal pelvis, ureter, bladder, and possibly kidney cancers).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature supports the occurrence of upper urinary tract cancer (urothelial carcinoma) in patients with Lynch syndrome, which includes transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter or renal pelvis.", "reference": "PMID:21419447", "snippet": "Patients with Lynch syndrome are much more likely to have generally rare upper urinary tract urothelial carcinoma but not bladder urothelial carcinoma.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature confirms that Lynch syndrome is associated with cancers of the genitourinary tract, which includes urinary tract cancer.", "reference": "PMID:34798988", "snippet": "Lynch syndrome (LS) is a common form of inherited cancer susceptibility, which predisposes to colorectal cancer (CRC) along with a wide array of other extracolonic malignancies, including other gastrointestinal cancers, cancers of the gynecologic and genitourinary tracts, and other organ sites.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This review supports the elevated UTC burden and the relevance of LS-specific surveillance.", "reference": "PMID:23700068", "snippet": "Urinary tract cancers (UTC) have in many studies been reported increased in LS and it has been discussed among researchers and clinicians whether or not screening for urological tumours should be included in the surveillance programme.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature indicates that transitional cell carcinomas of the upper urinary tract are rare but occur in patients with Lynch syndrome (HNPCC), supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:15962502", "snippet": "Transitional cell carcinomas of the upper urinary tract (UUT-TCCs) are rare: they account for approximately 5% of all urothelial carcinomas. ... UUT-TCC occurs in 5% of patients with HNPCC.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Urinary Tract Cancer", "notes": "Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter or renal pelvis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "renal pelvis/ureter urothelial carcinoma", "term": {"id": "MONDO:0020654", "label": "renal pelvis/ureter urothelial carcinoma"}}}

name: Sebaceous Adenomas

notes: Muir-Torre variant of Lynch syndrome
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Sebaceous gland tumors associated with Muir-Torre syndrome, a phenotypic variant of Lynch syndrome.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Sebaceous Adenomas", "notes": "Muir-Torre variant of Lynch syndrome"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Sebaceous gland tumors associated with Muir-Torre syndrome, a phenotypic variant of Lynch syndrome.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference confirms that sebaceous adenomas are a part of the dermatologic manifestations in the Muir-Torre variant of Lynch syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:25427047", "snippet": "Muir-Torre syndrome (MTS) is a rare autosomal-dominant genodermatosis characterized by sebaceous neoplasms and one or more visceral malignancies. Sebaceous tumors include sebaceous adenoma and carcinoma, which may be solitary or multiple.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the association of sebaceous adenomas with Lynch syndrome, particularly in the context of Muir-Torre syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:34023105", "snippet": "Sebaceous adenoma, sebaceoma, and a subset of cutaneous SC are frequently associated with defective DNA mismatch repair resulting from mutations in MLH1, MSH2, or MSH6. These tumors can be sporadic or associated with Muir-Torre syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This systematic review confirms sebaceous adenoma as a common cutaneous Lynch-associated manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:36418753", "snippet": "The main skin lesions were: Sebaceous adenomas (43%), sebaceous carcinomas (27%), keratoacanthomas (16%), sebaceomas (13%), squamous cell carcinomas (23%), and basal cell carcinomas (10%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Sebaceous Adenomas", "notes": "Muir-Torre variant of Lynch syndrome", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "sebaceous adenoma", "term": {"id": "MONDO:0002375", "label": "sebaceous adenoma"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Confirms intellectual impairment occurs in MSUD and is not reversed by liver transplantation.", "reference": "PMID:21839471", "snippet": "One-third of our patients were mentally impaired (IQ  70) before transplantation, with no statistically significant change 1 year later.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Demonstrates cognitive impairment in MSUD patients compared to controls.", "reference": "PMID:23478409", "snippet": "Compared with 26 age-matched controls, MSUD patients were at higher risk for disorders of cognition, attention, and mood.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Intellectual Disability", "notes": "If treatment delayed or metabolic control poor; liver transplantation may arrest but not reverse brain damage", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Intellectual disability", "term": {"id": "HP:0001249", "label": "Intellectual disability"}}}

name: Aortic Aneurysm
description: Progressive dilation of the aortic root beginning in childhood, with risk of life-threatening aortic dissection.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "description": "Progressive dilation of the aortic root beginning in childhood, with risk of life-threatening aortic dissection.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Aortic Aneurysm"}
complex_fields_json: {"sequelae": [{"description": "Progressive dilation weakens the aortic wall, predisposing to acute dissection.", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This study demonstrates that rapid aortic root dilation significantly increases dissection risk, with 47% dissection rate in rapidly progressing patients.", "reference": "PMID:16321689", "snippet": "Aortic dissection occurred more frequently in group R (7 patients, 47%) than in group S (0%, P < 0.001).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "target": "Aortic Dissection"}]}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "description": "Progressive dilation of the aortic root beginning in childhood, with risk of life-threatening aortic dissection.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This reference confirms that aortic aneurysm and aortic dissection are frequent cardiovascular manifestations in Marfan Syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:21797750", "snippet": "MFS is one of the most common inherited connective tissue disorders affecting 1 in 5000 individuals. Although the phenotype of MFS can be quite variable, aneurysmal dilation of the aortic root and consecutive acute aortic dissection is the leading cause of death in this patient population.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "The literature discusses the severe cardiovascular manifestations of Marfan Syndrome, supporting the frequent occurrence of aortic aneurysm and dissection.", "reference": "PMID:36058493", "snippet": "Early Onset Marfan Syndrome is at the severe end of the Marfan syndrome spectrum and is frequently associated with variants in exons 24-32 of the FBN1 gene.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This study indicates a high frequency of aortic dilation, a precursor to aortic aneurysm, among Marfan Syndrome patients.", "reference": "PMID:20364556", "snippet": "The majority of those individuals had significant organ involvement including dilatation of ascending aorta (78%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "The study highlights the cardiovascular system as a primary area affected in Marfan Syndrome, supporting the frequent occurrence of aortic aneurysms and dissection.", "reference": "PMID:32290873", "snippet": "Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of the connective tissue, whose cardinal features raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This describes the age-specific manifestations of Meckel diverticulum complications.", "reference": "PMID:8506491", "snippet": "Meckel's diverticula are most commonly manifested in children by painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding and in adults, as an inflammatory process or obstruction.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This systematic review identifies hemorrhage as a major complication of Meckel diverticulum.", "reference": "PMID:17021300", "snippet": "It can cause complications in the form of ulceration, haemorrhage, intussusception, intestinal obstruction, perforation and, very rarely, vesicodiverticular fistulae and tumours.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This identifies hemorrhage from peptic ulceration as the most common complication.", "reference": "PMID:15026601", "snippet": "The most common complications are hemorrhage from peptic ulceration, small intestinal obstruction, and diverticulitis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This documents rare neonatal presentation with massive rectal bleeding in the first week of life.", "reference": "PMID:19444035", "snippet": "Our first patient presented with massive bleeding per rectum in the first week of life, which is the only case reported so far.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Gastrointestinal Bleeding", "notes": "Painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding is the most common presentation in children, often due to peptic ulceration from ectopic gastric mucosa.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Gastrointestinal hemorrhage", "term": {"id": "HP:0002239", "label": "Gastrointestinal hemorrhage"}}}

name: Pigmented Lesion
notes: Changes in size, shape, or color of the nevus
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Pigmented Lesion", "notes": "Changes in size, shape, or color of the nevus"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference supports the connection between congenital melanocytic nevi and melanoma but does not specify that it is very frequent.", "reference": "PMID:20888464", "snippet": "The relative risk for melanoma arising within a congenital nevus is related to the size of the lesion.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference confirms that melanoma in congenital melanocytic nevi is associated with pigmented lesions and involves clinical, histopathologic evaluation which can count as dermatologic diagnostic, but does not claim it to be very frequent.", "reference": "PMID:34799033", "snippet": "This article provides an update on the clinical, histopathologic, and ancillary testing for 3 categories of particularly challenging pigmented lesions: congenital melanocytic nevi, spitzoid neoplasms, and pediatric melanoma.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference suggests that proliferative nodules in congenital melanocytic nevi may have malignant potential, so it acknowledges the risk of melanoma but does not indicate that it is very frequent.", "reference": "PMID:32392930", "snippet": "Although most of the PN manifest as a benign lesion clinically, it may have certain malignant potential at the genetic level, and warrant long-term monitoring and follow-up.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The study indicates that giant CMN has a higher potential to develop melanoma, recognizing the risk but not specifying the frequency for all CMNs.", "reference": "PMID:34887981", "snippet": "Giant CMN also known as 'bathing trunk nevus,' 'giant hairy nevus', and 'nevus pigmentosus et pilosus' has highest potential to turn into malignant melanoma.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Pigmented Lesion", "notes": "Changes in size, shape, or color of the nevus"}

name: Nodules
notes: Raised, firm lesions that can be a sign of melanoma
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Nodules", "notes": "Raised, firm lesions that can be a sign of melanoma"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study discusses the presence of proliferative nodules and melanoma in congenital melanocytic nevi, noting that nodules can be mistaken for melanoma. This partially supports that nodules are a frequent phenotype but doesn't provide a clear frequency or definitively state they are always indicative of melanoma.", "reference": "PMID:27486690", "snippet": "The differential diagnosis between proliferative nodules (PNs) and melanoma arising in congenital melanocytic nevi (CMN) is crucial, as patients with PNs most often experience no increased risk of melanoma with metastases and death.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The presence of a pigmented nodule on congenital melanocytic nevi is noted, suggesting it can be a feature but does not elaborate on its frequent occurrence in melanoma specifically.", "reference": "PMID:36122342", "snippet": "A Pigmented Nodule on Congenital Melanocytic Nevus: Challenge.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "While it outlines that melanocytic nevi, including nodules, can be misdiagnosed as melanoma, it stops short of stating the frequency with which nodules are a phenotype of melanoma.", "reference": "PMID:17653760", "snippet": "A group of melanocytic benign nevi are prone to be misdiagnosed as nodular or superficial spreading melanoma. This review illustrates the most frequent forms of these nevi in direct comparison with their malignant morphologic counterparts.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference mentions the risk of congenital melanocytic nevi transforming into melanoma but does not specifically discuss nodules as a frequent phenotype or their dermatologic characteristics.", "reference": "PMID:10591787", "snippet": "They run an increased life-time risk of transformation into malignant melanoma.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Nodules", "notes": "Raised, firm lesions that can be a sign of melanoma"}

name: Lymphadenopathy
notes: Swollen lymph nodes may indicate metastasis

raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The swollen lymph nodes indicating metastasis, with the subject having melanoma, supports the statement of lymphadenopathy as an occasional systemic phenotype of melanoma-in-congenital-melanocytic-nevus.", "reference": "PMID:38779794", "snippet": "A 30-year-old female patient presented with a swelling of a cervical left lymph node measuring 1x3 cm, which had been presenting for three weeks. Lymph node excision revealed a metastasis of a malignant melanoma.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While this source discusses lymph nodes in relation to melanoma, the focus is more on diagnostic difficulty rather than a clear statement of lymphadenopathy as a phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:14750241", "snippet": "Melanocytic nevi occurring in lymph nodes create diagnostic difficulty by mimicking metastases. Few studies describe nodal nevi in sentinel lymph nodes (SLNs) excised for melanoma.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "Lymph-node metastasis being a poor prognosis indicator supports the link between swollen lymph nodes and metastasis in melanoma patients, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:11902552", "snippet": "Lymph-node metastasis is an indicator of poor prognosis for patients with melanoma.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This source confirms the occurrence of lymph node metastasization in melanoma but does not specifically address it in the context of congenital melanocytic nevus.", "reference": "PMID:18481261", "snippet": "Malignant melanomas of the skin primarily metastasize to lymph nodes, and the detection of sentinel lymph node metastases serves as an important prognostic parameter.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Lymphadenopathy", "notes": "Swollen lymph nodes may indicate metastasis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Lymphadenopathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0002716", "label": "Lymphadenopathy"}}}

name: Migraine
description: Recurrent migraines with or without aura have been described in rare cases of Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome, particularly in patients with concurrent SCN1A variants. This represents a rare neurological phenotype suggesting potential overlap between MRS and channelopathy-related disorders.

This represents a rare neurological phenotype suggesting potential overlap between MRS and channelopathy-related disorders.\n", "frequency": "RARE", "name": "Migraine"}
