This represents a rare neurological phenotype suggesting potential overlap between MRS and channelopathy-related disorders.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Documents rare association of migraine with MRS in a family with SCN1A variants, suggesting potential genetic overlap", "reference": "PMID:37510386", "snippet": "Migraine is a common neurological disorder... A family in which two sisters displayed recurrent migraines, one of which presented recurrent facial palsy and had clinical diagnosis of MRS.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "RARE", "name": "Migraine", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Migraine", "term": {"id": "HP:0002076", "label": "Migraine"}}}

name: Episodic Vertigo
description: Recurrent attacks of spinning vertigo lasting 20 minutes to several hours, often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Episodes are unpredictable and can be severely debilitating.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Recurrent attacks of spinning vertigo lasting 20 minutes to several hours, often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Episodes are unpredictable and can be severely debilitating.\n", "name": "Episodic Vertigo"}
raw_json: {"description": "Recurrent attacks of spinning vertigo lasting 20 minutes to several hours, often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Episodes are unpredictable and can be severely debilitating.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Confirms vertigo as cardinal episodic manifestation of MD", "reference": "PMID:27083887", "snippet": "episodic attacks of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, aural pressure", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Large epidemiological study documents episodes of vertigo as defining MD feature", "reference": "PMID:22053211", "snippet": "episodes of vertigo associated with hearing loss and tinnitus", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Episodic Vertigo", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "paroxysmal vertigo", "term": {"id": "HP:0010532", "label": "Paroxysmal vertigo"}}}

name: Sensorineural Hearing Loss
description: Fluctuating, progressive hearing loss initially affecting low frequencies, eventually becoming permanent and affecting all frequencies as the disease progresses.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Fluctuating, progressive hearing loss initially affecting low frequencies, eventually becoming permanent and affecting all frequencies as the disease progresses.\n", "name": "Sensorineural Hearing Loss"}
raw_json: {"description": "Fluctuating, progressive hearing loss initially affecting low frequencies, eventually becoming permanent and affecting all frequencies as the disease progresses.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Establishes fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss as core MD feature", "reference": "PMID:27083887", "snippet": "episodic attacks of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, aural pressure", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Confirms hearing loss as cardinal MD manifestation in large epidemiological study", "reference": "PMID:22053211", "snippet": "MD, an inner ear disorder characterized by episodes of vertigo associated with hearing loss and tinnitus", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Sensorineural Hearing Loss", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "low-frequency sensorineural hearing impairment", "term": {"id": "HP:0008573", "label": "Low-frequency sensorineural hearing impairment"}}}

name: Tinnitus
description: Ringing, buzzing, or roaring sounds in the affected ear, often low-pitched and fluctuating. May become constant with disease progression.

May become constant with disease progression.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Confirms tinnitus as defining component of MD clinical tetrad", "reference": "PMID:27083887", "snippet": "episodic attacks of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, aural pressure", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Epidemiological evidence reaffirms tinnitus as hallmark MD symptom", "reference": "PMID:22053211", "snippet": "episodes of vertigo associated with hearing loss and tinnitus", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Tinnitus", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "tinnitus", "term": {"id": "HP:0000360", "label": "Tinnitus"}}}

name: Aural Fullness
description: Sensation of pressure or fullness in the affected ear, often preceding or accompanying vertiginous episodes.

name: Neuroendocrine Neoplasm
description: Merkel cell carcinoma is a high-grade neuroendocrine carcinoma with characteristic small round blue cell histology and neuroendocrine marker expression (synaptophysin, chromogranin, CD56).

name: Cutaneous Nodule
description: Rapidly growing, firm, painless, dome-shaped nodule typically red or violaceous in color. Often described by AEIOU criteria: Asymptomatic, Expanding rapidly, Immunosuppression, Older age, UV-exposed site.

name: Headache
notes: Unilateral, pulsating, moderate-severe
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Headache", "notes": "Unilateral, pulsating, moderate-severe"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Demonstrates that cortical spreading depression directly induces headache-related behaviors in animal models.", "reference": "PMID:37495957", "snippet": "In both WT and FHM1 mutant mice, CSDs induced headache-related behaviour, as evidenced by increased MGS scores and the occurrence of oculotemporal strokes, at 30 min.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Explains the mechanistic pathway from neuronal stress to the characteristic lasting headaches of migraine.", "reference": "PMID:39080518", "snippet": "We propose that neuronal stress induced by CSD or synaptic activity-energy mismatch may initiate a parenchymal inflammatory signaling cascade, transmitted to the meninges, thereby triggering lasting headaches characteristic of migraine, with or without aura.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Headache", "notes": "Unilateral, pulsating, moderate-severe", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Headache", "term": {"id": "HP:0002315", "label": "Headache"}}}

name: Photophobia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Photophobia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Describes the neuroanatomical basis for photophobia in migraine through visual-pain pathway interactions.", "reference": "PMID:35322292", "snippet": "The coexistence of photophobia and headache is associated with the interactions between visual and pain pathway at retina, midbrain, thalamus, hypothalamus and visual cortex.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Photophobia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Photophobia", "term": {"id": "HP:0000613", "label": "Photophobia"}}}

name: Phonophobia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Phonophobia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Demonstrates that phonophobia in migraine is associated with sensitization of brainstem auditory neurons, as evidenced by higher brainstem auditory evoked potential amplitudes.", "reference": "PMID:33305448", "snippet": "Higher amplitudes of BAEP waves in migraineurs and their relationship with the frequency of headache and HT suggest the sensitization of brainstem auditory neurons.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Phonophobia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Phonophobia", "term": {"id": "HP:0002183", "label": "Phonophobia"}}}

name: Nausea
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Nausea"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Neuroinflammatory responses to CSD contribute to the full range of migraine symptoms including autonomic features like nausea through central nervous system activation.", "reference": "PMID:39080518", "snippet": "After a single CSD, astrocytes respond by upregulating the transcription of proinflammatory enzymes and mediators, while microglia are involved in restoring neuronal structural integrity; however, repeated CSDs may prompt microglia to adopt a pro-inflammatory state.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Nausea", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Nausea", "term": {"id": "HP:0002018", "label": "Nausea"}}}

name: Visual Aura
notes: Scintillating scotoma, fortification spectra
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Visual Aura", "notes": "Scintillating scotoma, fortification spectra"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Demonstrates that visual auras in migraine are associated with inflammatory activity localized to the occipital cortex, the brain region responsible for visual processing.", "reference": "PMID:39080518", "snippet": "PET studies utilizing inflammation markers have revealed meningeal inflammatory activity in patients experiencing migraine with aura, particularly over the occipital cortex generating visual auras.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Visual Aura", "notes": "Scintillating scotoma, fortification spectra", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Visual Disturbance", "term": {"id": "HP:0000505", "label": "Visual impairment"}}}

name: Vertigo
notes: Vestibular migraine
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Vertigo", "notes": "Vestibular migraine"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Establishes vestibular migraine as a recognized migraine phenotype where vertigo is a prominent symptom.", "reference": "PMID:38619053", "snippet": "Vestibular migraine is an underdiagnosed migraine phenotype that shares the pathophysiological mechanisms of migraine, with growing interest in recent years.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Links vestibular symptoms to abnormal sensory processing and CGRP signaling in vestibular pathways.", "reference": "PMID:37889468", "snippet": "There is evidence of abnormal sensory processing and integration in VM patients. Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) has also been found to play a role in trigeminal and vestibular nucleus pathways.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Vertigo", "notes": "Vestibular migraine", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Vertigo", "term": {"id": "HP:0002321", "label": "Vertigo"}}}

name: Raynaud Phenomenon
notes: Present in most patients
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Vascular", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Raynaud Phenomenon", "notes": "Present in most patients"}
raw_json: {"category": "Vascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Raynaud phenomenon is nearly universal in MCTD and often the presenting symptom, reflecting the underlying systemic vasculopathy characterized by intimal fibrosis and vascular obliteration that links this cutaneous manifestation to visceral complications including pulmonary hypertension.", "reference": "PMID:16084319", "snippet": "Raynaud's phenomenon affects most patients who have mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) and frequently represents the initial manifestation of the disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Raynaud Phenomenon", "notes": "Present in most patients", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Raynaud Phenomenon", "term": {"id": "HP:0030880", "label": "Raynaud phenomenon"}}}

name: Arthritis
notes: Polyarthritis common
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Arthritis", "notes": "Polyarthritis common"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This landmark 5-year longitudinal study demonstrated that arthritis is universal in MCTD, often as the presenting manifestation, with symmetric involvement of PIP, MCP, wrists, MTP joints and knees mimicking rheumatoid arthritis but with predominantly lymphocytic non-inflammatory effusions and good response to low-dose corticosteroids.", "reference": "PMID:718271", "snippet": "Arthritis occurred in all 20 patients, being the presenting complaint in 11 patients.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Arthritis", "notes": "Polyarthritis common", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Arthritis", "term": {"id": "HP:0001369", "label": "Arthritis"}}}

name: Myopathy
notes: Inflammatory myositis
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Myopathy", "notes": "Inflammatory myositis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "MCTD-associated myositis presents with both typical proximal muscle weakness and atypical distributions affecting axial and distal muscles, with muscle biopsy showing perivascular inflammatory infiltrates and muscle fiber necrosis, reflecting the heterogeneous nature of MCTD myopathy that may require intensive immunosuppressive therapy.", "reference": "PMID:39876825", "snippet": "Eight patients had muscle weakness in the proximal extremities, and overall, six patients had atypical weakness in the face, neck, wrist, or fingers.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Myopathy", "notes": "Inflammatory myositis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Myopathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0003198", "label": "Myopathy"}}}

name: Rash
notes: Rash typically starts on the face and spreads to other parts of the body

raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference confirms that rash is a common dermatologic manifestation of monkeypox.", "reference": "PMID:36396927", "snippet": "Initially, there is a prodrome phase of a few days, which is followed by the appearance of rashes. The dermatological manifestations are in the form of an exanthematous rash, which transforms through a macular, papular, and vesicular phase and disappears after crusting in approximately 3 weeks.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference further mentions the potential for secondary infections.", "reference": "PMID:36396927", "snippet": "Respiratory manifestations include nasal congestion and shortness of breath that may result in secondary bacterial infections.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the frequent occurrence of various types of rashes in monkeypox.", "reference": "PMID:35904894", "snippet": "Pleomorphic skin lesions appear ranging from macules, papules, vesicles, pustules, some of which may appear umbilicated before crusting over.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference mentions that skin lesions (including rashes) are significant for diagnosis.", "reference": "PMID:36223653", "snippet": "Our clinical evaluation identified skin lesions as the optimal diagnostic specimen source.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference describes mucocutaneous lesions, which also support dermatologic manifestations.", "reference": "PMID:36729940", "snippet": "Primarily affecting the sexually active population, these cases present with mucocutaneous lesions mainly localized in perioral, genital, and anal areas.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference clearly states that a vesiculopustular rash is characteristic of monkeypox.", "reference": "PMID:37403493", "snippet": "Monkeypox (MPX) characteristically presents as a fever with a vesiculopustular rash.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference confirms the typical progression of skin lesions, including rashes, in monkeypox.", "reference": "PMID:15660652", "snippet": "Initially, it presents with skin eruptions and fevers with diaphoresis and rigors. Clinically, the skin lesions progress from papules to vesiculopustules to resolving eschars.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Rash", "notes": "Rash typically starts on the face and spreads to other parts of the body", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Skin rash", "term": {"id": "HP:0000988", "label": "Skin rash"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Scarring"}, {"target": "Secondary Infections"}]}

name: Coronal Craniosynostosis
description: Uni- or bilateral coronal suture fusion is the most common feature. Bilateral involvement causes brachycephaly; unilateral causes plagiocephaly.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Uni- or bilateral coronal suture fusion is the most common feature. Bilateral involvement causes brachycephaly; unilateral causes plagiocephaly.\n", "name": "Coronal Craniosynostosis"}
raw_json: {"description": "Uni- or bilateral coronal suture fusion is the most common feature. Bilateral involvement causes brachycephaly; unilateral causes plagiocephaly.\n", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "The largest natural history study of Muenke syndrome confirmed that craniosynostosis is the predominant feature, present in 85% of affected individuals.", "reference": "PMID:26740388", "snippet": "Eighty-five percent of the participants had craniosynostosis (16 of 103 did not have craniosynostosis)", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "The original paper defining the syndrome identified coronal synostosis as the primary cranial manifestation caused by the FGFR3 P250R mutation.", "reference": "PMID:9042914", "snippet": "coronal synostosis is due to an amino acid substitution (Pro250Arg) that results from a single point mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 gene", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Coronal Craniosynostosis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Coronal craniosynostosis", "term": {"id": "HP:0004440", "label": "Coronal craniosynostosis"}}}

name: Midface Retrusion
description: Midface hypoplasia may be present but is typically milder than in Crouzon or Apert syndromes.

name: Sensorineural Hearing Loss
description: Sensorineural hearing loss is common and may be progressive. It is an important feature distinguishing Muenke from other craniosynostosis syndromes.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Sensorineural hearing loss is common and may be progressive. It is an important feature distinguishing Muenke from other craniosynostosis syndromes.\n", "name": "Sensorineural Hearing Loss"}
raw_json: {"description": "Sensorineural hearing loss is common and may be progressive. It is an important feature distinguishing Muenke from other craniosynostosis syndromes.\n", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "The international multicenter study documented hearing loss in over 70% of individuals with Muenke syndrome, confirming it as a major clinical feature.", "reference": "PMID:26740388", "snippet": "Hearing loss was identified in 70.8%", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This study characterized the hearing loss in Muenke syndrome as predominantly low-frequency sensorineural in nature, with incomplete penetrance in the human cohort.", "reference": "PMID:18818193", "snippet": "The Muenke syndrome cohort showed significant, but incompletely penetrant, predominantly low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This study established low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss as a characteristic and previously underrecognized feature of Muenke syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:18000976", "snippet": "a majority of the patients (95%) demonstrated a mild-to-moderate, low frequency sensorineural hearing loss", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Sensorineural Hearing Loss", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Sensorineural hearing impairment", "term": {"id": "HP:0000407", "label": "Sensorineural hearing impairment"}}}

name: Brachydactyly
description: Short hands with brachydactyly may occur, though limb involvement is generally mild.

name: Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma
description: MTC occurs in virtually all MEN2 patients and is the primary cause of morbidity and mortality. Develops from thyroid C-cells that produce calcitonin. Age of onset depends on RET mutation: MEN2B patients may develop MTC in infancy while some FMTC mutations cause later onset. Prophylactic thyroidectomy timing is based on mutation risk category.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neoplastic", "description": "MTC occurs in virtually all MEN2 patients and is the primary cause of morbidity and mortality. Develops from thyroid C-cells that produce calcitonin. Age of onset depends on RET mutation: MEN2B patients may develop MTC in infancy while some FMTC mutations cause later onset. Prophylactic thyroidectomy timing is based on mutation risk category.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "OBLIGATE", "name": "Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neoplastic", "description": "MTC occurs in virtually all MEN2 patients and is the primary cause of morbidity and mortality. Prophylactic thyroidectomy timing is based on mutation risk category.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Review confirms MTC is the hallmark of MEN2 with genotype-phenotype correlations determining clinical presentation and aggressiveness.", "reference": "PMID:21862994", "snippet": "MEN2A accounts for 90-95% of childhood MTC cases and is most commonly due to mutations in codon 634 of RET. MEN2B is associated with the most aggressive clinical presentation of MTC and is almost always due to the Met918Thr mutation of RET.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OBLIGATE", "name": "Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Medullary thyroid carcinoma", "term": {"id": "HP:0002865", "label": "Medullary thyroid carcinoma"}}}

name: Pheochromocytoma
description: Pheochromocytomas occur in approximately 50% of MEN2A and MEN2B patients. Often bilateral (50-80%) and may be diagnosed before, concurrent with, or after MTC. Screening with plasma metanephrines is essential before any surgery. Generally benign but can cause hypertensive crises if undiagnosed.

name: Primary Hyperparathyroidism
description: Primary hyperparathyroidism occurs in 20-30% of MEN2A patients but not in MEN2B. Usually multigland disease. May be asymptomatic or cause hypercalcemia symptoms. Often milder than MEN1-associated hyperparathyroidism.

name: Mucosal Neuromas
description: Mucosal neuromas of the lips, tongue, and eyelids are characteristic of MEN2B and may be present from early childhood. They produce a distinctive bumpy, nodular appearance of the lips and thickened appearance of the eyelids.
notes: Mucosal neuromas represent ganglioneuromas of mucosal surfaces. The term ganglioneuroma is used as there is no specific HP term for mucosal neuromas.

name: Intestinal Ganglioneuromatosis
description: Diffuse ganglioneuromatosis of the gastrointestinal tract occurs in MEN2B, causing constipation, megacolon, and feeding difficulties from infancy.

name: Marfanoid Habitus
description: MEN2B patients often have a marfanoid body habitus with tall stature, long limbs, arachnodactyly, pectus excavatum, and high-arched palate. Unlike true Marfan syndrome, they do not have lens dislocation or aortic root dilation.

raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Dysesthesia", "notes": "Abnormal unpleasant sensations such as burning or prickling", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Dysesthesia", "term": {"id": "HP:0012534", "label": "Dysesthesia"}}}

name: Fever
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Fever"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study describes fever as a common symptom in all six pediatric patients diagnosed with MIS-C.", "reference": "PMID:35442269", "snippet": "Six pediatric patients with mean age of 126 months were admitted with fever associated with multisystem involvement.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Although this reference discusses fever in the context of various illnesses in children, it supports the statement that fever is a frequent symptom in systemic conditions like MIS-C.", "reference": "PMID:29025800", "snippet": "Fever is a common sign of illness in children and is most frequently due to infection.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference title directly indicates a focus on MIS-C, supporting the systemic nature and frequent occurrence of fever in this condition.", "reference": "PMID:34210761", "snippet": "Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract supports the systemic nature of MIS-C and its association with hyperinflammatory responses, indirectly supporting the frequent occurrence of fever.", "reference": "PMID:37651206", "snippet": "Multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C) is a rare but life-threatening hyperinflammatory condition induced by infection with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) that causes pediatric COVID-19 (pCOVID-19).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Fever", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fever", "term": {"id": "HP:0001945", "label": "Fever"}}}

name: Hypotension
notes: May lead to shock and require intensive care.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hypotension", "notes": "May lead to shock and require intensive care."}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference indicates that cardiac dysfunction, which includes hypotension and can lead to shock, is common in MIS-C patients.", "reference": "PMID:35183528", "snippet": "Cardiac involvement is found in 80-85% patients, typically with cardiac dysfunction with or without cardiogenic shock.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The use of vasopressors indicates the presence of hypotension and the need for intensive care, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:37309831", "snippet": "Pearson's chi-squared analysis showed an erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) greater than 30 mm/h and 50 mm/h were disproportionately associated with pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) admission (2 = 4.44, P = .04) and use of vasopressors (2 = 6.06, P = .01), respectively", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While this reference discusses vascular complications, it implies that MIS-C affects the cardiovascular system, which can include hypotension and shock.", "reference": "PMID:37142896", "snippet": "Children may develop a specific complication of COVID-19 called multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C) which could influence the vascular system of children and cause multiple coagulopathies in the body.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hypotension", "notes": "May lead to shock and require intensive care.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypotension", "term": {"id": "HP:0002615", "label": "Hypotension"}}}

name: Abdominal Pain
notes: Often similar to appendicitis
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Abdominal Pain", "notes": "Often similar to appendicitis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This study shows that a significant proportion of children with MIS-C present with abdominal pain, supporting the statement that abdominal pain is a very frequent symptom in MIS-C.", "reference": "PMID:36511208", "snippet": "A total of 28 out of 83 children with probable MIS-C had acute abdominal symptoms and signs. Fifteen children had mild features like diffuse abdominal pain or non-bilious vomiting, and the remaining 13 (46.2%) had severe abdominal signs or bilious vomiting.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While this reference indicates that abdominal pain is a common concern and can be confused with appendicitis, it does not specifically mention MIS-C.", "reference": "PMID:34507344", "snippet": "Children with abdominal pain are frequently seen in emergency departments. Physicians and parents worry about appendicitis; physicians are also concerned about intussusception and bowel obstruction in patients with previous surgical procedures.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference discusses the frequency of abdominal pain in children and its differential diagnosis, including appendicitis, but does not specifically address MIS-C.", "reference": "PMID:8820774", "snippet": "For every 15 school-age children with abdominal pain, 1, at most, will have a serious condition such as appendicitis.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Abdominal Pain", "notes": "Often similar to appendicitis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abdominal pain", "term": {"id": "HP:0002027", "label": "Abdominal pain"}}}

name: Rash
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Rash"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates that 72% of children with MIS-C presented with mucocutaneous symptoms, including rash, supporting the statement that rash is a frequent dermatologic manifestation in MIS-C.", "reference": "PMID:35290661", "snippet": "Twenty-four children presented with mucocutaneous symptoms (72%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference confirms that skin involvement, including rash, is commonly seen in MIS-C, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:36881797", "snippet": "Skin and mucosal involvement, gastrointestinal symptoms, and neurologic manifestations are also commonly seen.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The case report mentions a broad range of skin manifestations, including rash, in MIS-C, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:36375463", "snippet": "A wide spectrum of cutaneous manifestations are reported in multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This review highlights that mucocutaneous symptoms, including rash, are common in MIS-C, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:38957128", "snippet": "Most cases of MIS-C show low mortality and suggest mucocutaneous symptoms do not correlate with COVID-19 disease severity.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Rash", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Skin rash", "term": {"id": "HP:0000988", "label": "Skin rash"}}}

name: Coagulopathy
notes: May involve thrombocytopenia or elevated D-dimer levels.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Coagulopathy", "notes": "May involve thrombocytopenia or elevated D-dimer levels."}
raw_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study shows that D-dimer levels increase in MIS-C patients, supporting the statement that coagulopathy, characterized by elevated D-dimer levels, is an occasional hematologic manifestation of MIS-C.", "reference": "PMID:33305475", "snippet": "In both cohorts, D-dimer and C-reactive protein levels increased upon clinical worsening but were not accompanied by decreased fibrinogen or platelet values, with all parameters returning to normal upon disease resolution.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study confirms that coagulation abnormalities, including thromboelastography (TEG) and platelet count changes, are common in children with MIS-C.", "reference": "PMID:34941014", "snippet": "Coagulation abnormalities are frequent in children with MIS-C.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study reports thromboembolism as a significant complication of MIS-C, indicating that coagulopathy, a hematologic issue, occurs occasionally in MIS-C cases.", "reference": "PMID:35031708", "snippet": "On review of all published cases of thromboembolism (TE) as a complication of MIS-C, 33 cases of TE were found with incidence ranging from 1.4 to 6.5%.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Coagulopathy", "notes": "May involve thrombocytopenia or elevated D-dimer levels.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Coagulopathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0003256", "label": "Abnormality of the coagulation cascade"}}}

name: Headache
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Headache"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study mentions neurological manifestations in children with COVID-19, including those with MIS-C, but does not specify headache as a frequent symptom.", "reference": "PMID:36976476", "snippet": "Out of the 3021 patients evaluated, 232 were confirmed to have COVID-19 and 21 of these patients (9%) showed neurological manifestations associated with the virus.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The study discusses neurological complications including encephalopathy and seizures but does not specifically mention headache.", "reference": "PMID:37866138", "snippet": "Patients with acute encephalopathy tend to have EEG showing diffusely slow background, often in the delta range; however, the pattern of slowing is sometimes anterior or posterior predominant and may evolve over the course of illness.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The study focuses on mucocutaneous symptoms and does not mention headache as a frequent symptom of MIS-C.", "reference": "PMID:35290661", "snippet": "Twenty-four children presented with mucocutaneous symptoms (72%). Age, male gender, PICU length of stay, presenting symptoms, inotrope requirement, the existence of myocarditis or respiratory failure were higher but not significantly different in patients with rash compared to those without rash (P > 0.05).", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This study differentiates MIS-C from acute appendicitis based on abdominal pain and other markers, without mention of headache.", "reference": "PMID:34298578", "snippet": "The duration of abdominal pain, presence of high-grade and prolonged fever, and evaluation of hemogram in terms of high neutrophil count and low LC exhibit high sensitivity and negative predictive value for MIS-C presenting with AAP.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The study compares MIS-C with dengue and highlights various symptoms but does not specifically mention headache as a frequent symptom.", "reference": "PMID:35511400", "snippet": "Rash (72.5% vs. 22.7%), conjunctival injection (60% vs. 2.3%), oral mucocutaneous changes (27.5% vs. 0) and gallop rhythm (15% vs. 0) were seen more frequently with MIS-C.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Headache", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Headache", "term": {"id": "HP:0002315", "label": "Headache"}}}

"snippet": "Multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C) is a syndrome of abnormal immune response after severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 infection that can result in organ dysfunction including severe cardiovascular compromise in children.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference focuses on skin manifestations and does not mention respiratory symptoms or cough.", "reference": "PMID:36271769", "snippet": "Malar rash in multisystemic inflammatory syndrome in children.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference discusses abdominal pain and other symptoms but does not mention respiratory symptoms or cough.", "reference": "PMID:34298578", "snippet": "The duration of abdominal pain, presence of high-grade and prolonged fever, and evaluation of hemogram in terms of high neutrophil count and low LC exhibit high sensitivity and negative predictive value for MIS-C presenting with AAP.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference highlights the severity of MIS-C but does not provide information on respiratory symptoms or cough.", "reference": "PMID:33938473", "snippet": "MIS-C is a novel and life-threatening manifestation of exposure to the virus.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference mentions chest tightness but does not specifically address cough or categorize MIS-C as a respiratory condition.", "reference": "PMID:33023287", "snippet": "These symptoms include malaise, myalgias, chest tightness, brain fog and other neuropsychiatric symptoms that were originally reported in children and named Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome (MIS-C).", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference focuses on the incidence of MIS-C following Omicron variant infection and does not mention respiratory symptoms or cough.", "reference": "PMID:37054392", "snippet": "This study, utilizing national data sources, describes the NZ incidence of multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C) following infection with the Omicron variant.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference discusses a case with abdominal pain and heart failure but does not mention respiratory symptoms or cough.", "reference": "PMID:36375463", "snippet": "A wide spectrum of cutaneous manifestations are reported in multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C). However, gangrenous changes are less frequently reported.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference mentions the timing of MIS-C appearance but does not provide information on respiratory symptoms or cough.", "reference": "PMID:35709786", "snippet": "This multisystem disease typically appears several weeks after infection with COVID-19 in children and young adults.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference title indicates an association with COVID-19 but does not provide details on respiratory symptoms or cough.", "reference": "PMID:32525700", "snippet": "Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children in Association With COVID-19.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference focuses on critical illness and outcomes but does not mention respiratory symptoms or cough.", "reference": "PMID:35994614", "snippet": "To characterize the prevalence of pediatric critical illness from multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C) and to assess the influence of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) strain on outcomes.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Cough", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Cough", "term": {"id": "HP:0012735", "label": "Cough"}}}

name: Post-Exertional Malaise
description: Worsening of symptoms following physical or mental exertion, often delayed by 24-72 hours and lasting days to weeks.
notes: Cardinal feature required for diagnosis
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "description": "Worsening of symptoms following physical or mental exertion, often delayed by 24-72 hours and lasting days to weeks.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "OBLIGATE", "name": "Post-Exertional Malaise", "notes": "Cardinal feature required for diagnosis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "description": "Worsening of symptoms following physical or mental exertion, often delayed by 24-72 hours and lasting days to weeks.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "PEM is universally recognized as the cardinal feature of ME/CFS.", "reference": "PMID:25584525", "snippet": "Post-exertional malaise (PEM) is a cardinal symptom of the illnesses referred to as Myalgic Encephalomyelitis (ME), Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS), and chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS)", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OBLIGATE", "name": "Post-Exertional Malaise", "notes": "Cardinal feature required for diagnosis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Post-Exertional Malaise", "term": {"id": "HP:0030973", "label": "Postexertional symptom exacerbation"}}}

name: Fatigue

name: Cognitive Impairment

raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "description": "Difficulties with concentration, short-term memory, and information processing, commonly described as brain fog.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Meta-analysis demonstrates specific cognitive deficits in ME/CFS patients.", "reference": "PMID:35140252", "snippet": "The clinical picture typically affects visuo-spatial immediate memory (g = - 0.55, p = 0.007), reading speed (g = - 0.82, p = 0.0001) and graphics gesture (g = - 0.59, p = 0.0001)", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Cognitive Impairment", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Cognitive Impairment", "term": {"id": "HP:0100543", "label": "Cognitive impairment"}}}

name: Orthostatic Intolerance
description: Worsening of symptoms upon assuming and maintaining upright posture, including lightheadedness, dizziness, and presyncope.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "description": "Worsening of symptoms upon assuming and maintaining upright posture, including lightheadedness, dizziness, and presyncope.", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Orthostatic Intolerance"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "description": "Worsening of symptoms upon assuming and maintaining upright posture, including lightheadedness, dizziness, and presyncope.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Orthostatic symptoms are highly prevalent in ME/CFS patients.", "reference": "PMID:31159884", "snippet": "Dizziness and lightheadedness were found in 41% of recumbent CFS subjects and in 72% of standing CFS subjects", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Orthostatic Intolerance", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Orthostatic Intolerance", "term": {"id": "HP:0001278", "label": "Orthostatic hypotension"}}}

name: Sleep Disturbance

name: Progressive Renal Failure
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Renal", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Progressive Renal Failure"}
raw_json: {"category": "Renal", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This abstract describes nephronophthisis as a progressive renal disease leading to end-stage renal failure, supporting the idea that progressive renal failure is a frequent and diagnostic feature.", "reference": "PMID:16966065", "snippet": "Nephronophthisis is a chronic tubulo-interstitial nephritis which progress to terminal renal failure.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference states that nephronophthisis-related ciliopathies are a common cause of end-stage renal disease in children, confirming that progressive renal failure and progression to ESRD is common.", "reference": "PMID:33323469", "snippet": "Nephronophthisis-related ciliopathies (NPHP-RC) account for the majority of cases of monogenetically caused end-stage renal disease (ESRD) in children.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While the abstract primarily discusses hereditary kidney diseases in general, it emphasizes the importance of kidney function maintenance in genetic diseases, indirectly supporting the frequency and importance of progressive renal failure in conditions like nephronophthisis.", "reference": "PMID:20969579", "snippet": "A Mendelian inheritance underlies a nonnegligible proportion of hereditary kidney diseases, suggesting that the encoded proteins are essential for maintenance of the renal function.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Progressive Renal Failure", "sequelae": [{"target": "End-Stage Renal Disease"}]}

name: Hypertension
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hypertension"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "While this reference mentions Mendelian forms of hypertension, there is no specific mention of Nephronophthisis resulting in hypertension or cardiovascular phenotypes generally.", "reference": "PMID:17647025", "snippet": "Among the causes of secondary hypertension are a group of disorders with a Mendelian inheritance pattern. Recent advances in molecular biology have unveiled the pathogenesis of hypertension in many of these conditions.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This reference discusses hereditary kidney diseases and the genetic mutations involved but does not mention Nephronophthisis or its cardiovascular phenotypes including hypertension.", "reference": "PMID:20969579", "snippet": "A Mendelian inheritance underlies a nonnegligible proportion of hereditary kidney diseases, suggesting that the encoded proteins are essential for maintenance of the renal function.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The article discusses the role of dopamine in the kidney and its involvement in hypertension, but it does not address Nephronophthisis or whether hypertension is a common cardiovascular phenotype in this condition.", "reference": "PMID:12589180", "snippet": "Defective transduction of the dopamine receptor signal in the kidney...", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This article offers a general overview of hypertension and its management but does not specifically mention Nephronophthisis or any associated cardiovascular phenotypes.", "reference": "PMID:23402468", "snippet": "Hypertension is the most common modifiable risk factor for cardiovascular disease. Antihypertensive treatment substantially reduces the risk of heart failure, stroke, and myocardial infarction.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "While the article discusses hypertension in the context of renal diseases, it does not specify an association between Nephronophthisis and hypertension as a cardiovascular phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:16336577", "snippet": "Nephrosclerosis, benign nephrosclerosis, and hypertensive kidney disease are terms that clinicians use when renal damage is thought to be secondary to essential hypertension.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This study focuses on congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract (CAKUT) and their association with hypertension, but it does not discuss Nephronophthisis.", "reference": "PMID:37910243", "snippet": "Hypertension is common in children with CAKUT and increases the risk of CKD.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hypertension", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypertension", "term": {"id": "HP:0000822", "label": "Hypertension"}}}

name: Fibrosis
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hepatic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Fibrosis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Hepatic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature mentions liver fibrosis as an extrarenal manifestation of nephronophthisis, supporting the statement that hepatic fibrosis is an occasional phenotype category of nephronophthisis.", "reference": "PMID:35533128", "snippet": "Nephronophthisis is an autosomal recessive cystic kidney disease caused by mutations in genes that encode proteins involved in the primary cilia function, resulting in kidney disease and extrarenal manifestations such as retinal degeneration and liver fibrosis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Fibrosis"}

name: Retinitis Pigmentosa
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Retinitis Pigmentosa"}
raw_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference indicates that tapetoretinal degeneration, synonymous with retinitis pigmentosa in the context of this disease, is an occasional extrarenal symptom of nephronophthisis.", "reference": "PMID:16966065", "snippet": "Some children present with extrarenal symptoms: tapetoretinal degeneration (Senior-Loken syndrome)...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference directly confirms the association between nephronophthisis and retinitis pigmentosa as occasional ophthalmologic phenotypes.", "reference": "PMID:25161209", "snippet": "The renal lesions were characterized by diffuse renal cyst development with tubulointerstitial nephropathy...These renal and retinal lesions are most similar to those associated with nephronophthisis (NPHP) and retinitis pigmentosa in humans.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This indicates that ophthalmologic phenotypes, including retinal degeneration, are common in pediatric renal ciliopathies including nephronophthisis.", "reference": "PMID:37644229", "snippet": "Eighty-two of the 86 pediatric-onset renal ciliopathies (95%) have an ocular phenotype, including inherited retinal degeneration, oculomotor disorders, and coloboma.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Retinitis Pigmentosa", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Retinitis Pigmentosa", "term": {"id": "HP:0000510", "label": "Rod-cone dystrophy"}}}

However, growth retardation could be inferred as a potential consequence of chronic kidney disease.", "reference": "PMID:16966065", "snippet": "Some children present with extrarenal symptoms: tapetoretinal degeneration (Senior-Loken syndrome), mental retardation, cerebellar ataxia, bone anomalies or liver involvement.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement that growth retardation is associated with chronic kidney disease, which can be a consequence of nephronophthisis.", "reference": "PMID:30552565", "snippet": "Growth retardation is a major feature of chronic kidney disease (CKD) of onset in infants or children and is associated with increased morbidity and mortality.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Growth Retardation", "notes": "May be seen due to chronic kidney disease", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Growth Retardation", "term": {"id": "HP:0001510", "label": "Growth delay"}}}

name: Abdominal Mass
description: An abdominal mass is the most common presentation, typically arising from the adrenal gland or paraspinal sympathetic ganglia. The mass may be incidentally discovered or cause abdominal distension.

name: Hypertension
description: Hypertension may occur due to catecholamine secretion by tumor cells or renal artery compression by the tumor mass.

name: Proptosis
description: Periorbital metastases causing proptosis and periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes) are characteristic of metastatic neuroblastoma.

name: Bone Pain
description: Bone pain from skeletal metastases is common in high-risk neuroblastoma. Metastatic bone disease may cause limping or irritability in young children.

name: Diarrhea
description: Secretory diarrhea can occur as a paraneoplastic syndrome due to tumor secretion of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP).

name: Cafe-au-lait Macules
description: Flat, hyperpigmented skin lesions present in >99% of NF1 patients. Six or more cafe-au-lait macules >5mm (prepubertal) or >15mm (postpubertal) meet one of the NIH diagnostic criteria. Usually present at birth or develop in first years of life.

name: Cutaneous Neurofibromas
description: Benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors arising from Schwann cells. Typically appear around puberty and increase in number with age. May cause cosmetic concerns but rarely become malignant.

name: Plexiform Neurofibromas
description: Diffuse neurofibromas involving multiple nerve fascicles, often present at birth. Can cause significant morbidity through mass effect, disfigurement, and pain. Approximately 8-13% lifetime risk of malignant transformation to MPNST.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neoplastic", "description": "Diffuse neurofibromas involving multiple nerve fascicles, often present at birth. Can cause significant morbidity through mass effect, disfigurement, and pain. Approximately 8-13% lifetime risk of malignant transformation to MPNST.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Plexiform Neurofibromas"}

name: Lisch Nodules
description: Melanocytic hamartomas of the iris, appearing as tan-brown dome-shaped elevations. Present in >90% of adults with NF1. Best visualized by slit-lamp examination. Pathognomonic for NF1 and do not affect vision.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "description": "Melanocytic hamartomas of the iris, appearing as tan-brown dome-shaped elevations. Present in >90% of adults with NF1. name: Optic Pathway Glioma
description: Low-grade gliomas of the optic nerve, chiasm, or tract occur in 15-20% of NF1 patients. Usually pilocytic astrocytomas. Most are asymptomatic and nonprogressive, but can cause vision loss. Peak incidence in first 6 years of life.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neoplastic", "description": "Low-grade gliomas of the optic nerve, chiasm, or tract occur in 15-20% of NF1 patients. Usually pilocytic astrocytomas. name: Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumor
description: Aggressive sarcoma arising from peripheral nerves, often from transformation of plexiform neurofibromas. Lifetime risk 8-13% in NF1. Leading cause of NF1-related mortality. Presents with rapid growth, pain, or new neurologic deficits.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neoplastic", "description": "Aggressive sarcoma arising from peripheral nerves, often from transformation of plexiform neurofibromas. Lifetime risk 8-13% in NF1. Leading cause of NF1-related mortality. Presents with rapid growth, pain, or new neurologic deficits.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumor"}

name: Scoliosis
description: Spinal curvature occurs in 10-30% of NF1 patients. Can be idiopathic-type or dystrophic (sharply angulated, short segment) forms. Dystrophic scoliosis may progress rapidly and require surgical intervention.

name: Learning Difficulties
description: Learning disabilities and attention deficits occur in 50-75% of children with NF1. Intelligence is usually normal but specific learning disabilities, ADHD, and executive function problems are common. Motor coordination difficulties may occur.
notes: Most NF1 patients have normal IQ but specific learning disabilities. HP term for learning disability is used as closest match.

name: Optic Neuritis
description: Inflammation of the optic nerve causing acute vision loss, eye pain, and color vision impairment. Often bilateral and severe in NMOSD compared to MS-associated optic neuritis.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Inflammation of the optic nerve causing acute vision loss, eye pain, and color vision impairment. Often bilateral and severe in NMOSD compared to MS-associated optic neuritis.\n", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Optic Neuritis"}

name: Longitudinally Extensive Transverse Myelitis
description: Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM) affecting three or more vertebral segments is characteristic of NMOSD, distinguishing it from the shorter lesions typical of multiple sclerosis. Causes paraplegia, sensory loss, and bladder/bowel dysfunction. LETM is a core diagnostic criterion for NMOSD.
notes: Annotated with general HP:0012486 (Myelitis) as HPO lacks a specific term for longitudinally extensive myelitis. The spatial extent qualifier "longitudinally extensive" (3 vertebral segments) is documented in the description and name fields. See issue #222 for schema enhancement to support spatial extent qualifiers.

name: Area Postrema Syndrome
description: Intractable nausea, vomiting, and hiccups due to inflammation of the area postrema (UBERON:0002162) in the dorsal medulla. A characteristic early manifestation that may precede other symptoms. This is a syndrome involving a specific anatomical location rather than a simple phenotype.
notes: Area postrema location: UBERON:0002162. This syndrome manifests clinically as the phenotype of nausea and vomiting due to inflammation of this specific brainstem structure.

name: Persistent Cough
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Persistent Cough"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This study supports that persistent cough is common in NSCLC patients.", "reference": "PMID:35224703", "snippet": "A total of 219 NSCLC patients completed the sCSS, Leicester Cough Questionnaire in Mandarin-Chinese (LCQ-MC) and cough Visual Analog Scale (VAS)... The sCSS is a reliable, valid instrument for assessing postoperative cough in NSCLC patients.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study confirms the high frequency of persistent cough in patients after lung cancer surgery, aligning with the statement that persistent cough is a common phenotype in NSCLC.", "reference": "PMID:37920959", "snippet": "Persistent cough is one of the most frequent complications following lung cancer surgery. ... Multivariable regression analysis revealed that a duration of anesthesia exceeding 156 min ... and gastroesophageal acid reflux (GER) ... were independent risk factors of persistent CAP.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While this study shows that cough is one of the symptoms among lung cancer patients, it does not explicitly address the commonality of persistent cough in NSCLC phenotypes.", "reference": "PMID:29666219", "snippet": "Compared with the cough-alone symptom group, the risks of dying or HRs were significantly higher for the groups presenting with breathlessness ..., systemic symptoms ..., weight loss ..., chest pain ..., cough with breathlessness ..., neurological symptoms ... and other symptom combinations ...", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Persistent Cough"}

raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study confirms that hemoptysis is a recognized condition associated with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).", "reference": "PMID:25359349", "snippet": "Severe haemoptysis due to nonsmall cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is considered a grim condition...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The case report does not support the presence of hemoptysis in the specific instance of NSCLC described.", "reference": "PMID:33563454", "snippet": "There was no associated hemoptysis, hoarseness, epistaxis, or fever on systemic review.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The study does not specifically focus on hemoptysis as a symptom of NSCLC.", "reference": "PMID:34807953", "snippet": "A positive association was observed between scores of respiratory symptoms and deaths due to COPD and lung cancer.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Hemoptysis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hemoptysis", "term": {"id": "HP:0002105", "label": "Hemoptysis"}}}

name: Weight Loss
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Weight Loss"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that weight loss is a common symptom in Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer patients due to cancer cachexia.", "reference": "PMID:35468688", "snippet": "One of the reasons patients with Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer are not fit for treatment is cancer cachexia, which is common (upto 75% of patients) in this group. This metabolic syndrome presents clinically as weight loss (muscle +/- fat), decreased physical function (patients less active) and anorexia on a background of systemic inflammation.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature mentions weight loss as a common systemic symptom associated with lung cancer, supporting its prevalence in Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.", "reference": "PMID:35559635", "snippet": "Associated symptoms, including hemoptysis or shortness of breath, or systemic symptoms, including anorexia or weight loss, greatly increase the likelihood of having lung cancer.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Weight Loss", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Weight loss", "term": {"id": "HP:0001824", "label": "Weight loss"}}}

Bone metastases were evident at diagnosis in 57.5% of patients.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Bone Pain", "notes": "May indicate bone metastases", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Bone Pain", "term": {"id": "HP:0002653", "label": "Bone pain"}}}

"reference": "PMID:38469616", "snippet": "Cancer-related fatigue (CRF) stands out as one of the most prevalent subjective adverse reactions experienced by patients following chemotherapy, often resulting in unfavorable symptoms for elderly non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients during chemotherapy.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Fatigue is listed as one of the most common adverse effects of treatment for NSCLC.", "reference": "PMID:33755621", "snippet": "The most common adverse effects of treatment are leukopenia, lymphopenia, thrombocytopenia, diarrhea, anemia, rash, musculoskeletal pain, nail toxicity, neutropenia, dry skin, stomatitis, fatigue, and cough.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Fatigue is mentioned as a symptom that emerges in individuals with lung cancer, including NSCLC.", "reference": "PMID:32013812", "snippet": "During the early stage, there is no perspicuous sign/symptoms but later many symptoms emerge in the infected individual such as insomnia, headache, pain, loss of appetite, fatigue, coughing etc.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Fatigue is listed as one of the common grade III/IV toxicities associated with treatment for metastatic NSCLC.", "reference": "PMID:26990789", "snippet": "Toxicities included neutropenia, febrile neutropenia, fatigue, diarrhea, nausea and vomiting, rash, bleeding, hypertension, and hair loss.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Fatigue is noted as a non-hematological toxicity in NSCLC patients beyond third-line therapy.", "reference": "PMID:30537755", "snippet": "Non-hematological toxicities of >/= grade 2 included anorexia (27.5%) and fatigue (24.6%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fatigue", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": name: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
description: Left ventricular hypertrophy occurring in approximately 20% of patients overall, but up to 70-95% in those with RAF1 or RIT1 mutations. Can be present at birth or develop during infancy.

Can be present at birth or develop during infancy.", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "RAF1 mutations are strongly associated with HCM.", "reference": "PMID:17603483", "snippet": "Of 19 subjects with a RAF1 mutation in two hotspots, 18 (or 95%) showed hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), compared with the 18% prevalence of HCM among individuals with Noonan syndrome in general.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "RIT1 mutations confer high risk of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.", "reference": "PMID:23791108", "snippet": "Seventy percent of mutation-positive individuals presented with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy; this frequency is high relative to the overall 20% incidence in individuals with Noonan syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "PTPN11 mutations are associated with lower HCM risk compared to other NS genes.", "reference": "PMID:11992261", "snippet": "hypertrophic cardiomyopathy was less prevalent among those with PTPN11 mutations (5.9% vs. 26.2%; P<.005)", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0001639", "label": "Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy"}}}

Also known as fifth disease or slapped cheek syndrome, EI presents as an erythematous exanthem limited to the malar eminences that follows a mild prodromal illness.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)", "sequelae": [{"description": "Bright red facial erythema confined to the cheeks, giving the appearance of having been slapped.", "target": "Slapped Cheek Rash"}]}

name: Arthropathy
description: Symmetric polyarthritis affecting small joints of hands, wrists, and knees, more common in adult women.
notes: Particularly in adults.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "description": "Symmetric polyarthritis affecting small joints of hands, wrists, and knees, more common in adult women.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Arthropathy", "notes": "Particularly in adults."}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "description": "Symmetric polyarthritis affecting small joints of hands, wrists, and knees, more common in adult women.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference confirms that arthropathy is a common manifestation in adults with acute parvovirus B19 infection.", "reference": "PMID:9595838", "snippet": "Arthropathy is known to occur in children and adults with acute parvovirus B19 infection. In adults, the arthropathy is common and is usually brief and self-limited, although a chronic arthropathy due to HPV B19 infections can occur rarely.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference title suggests it is about Parvovirus B19 infection in adults, but no specific excerpt or abstract is provided to confirm or refute the statement.", "reference": "PMID:11993780", "snippet": "", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference indicates a high prevalence of parvovirus B19 antibodies in musculoskeletal diseases, but does not specifically mention arthropathy.", "reference": "PMID:27511498", "snippet": "The highest positivity for IgG alone was found in musculoskeletal system and connective tissue diseases (55.9%)... The highest positivity for IgG was seen in rheumatoid arthritis (72.2%) and pregnancy (52.6%).", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports that arthritis and arthralgia, which can be associated with parvovirus B19, are common.", "reference": "PMID:29512949", "snippet": "Arthritis and arthralgia during a viral infection are often polyarticular and symmetric and can mimic rheumatoid arthritis. ... Worldwide most common germs are Parvovirus B19, hepatitis B and C, HIV and alphavirus.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference discusses parvovirus B19 infection and kidney injury but does not mention arthropathy.", "reference": "PMID:32646497", "snippet": "", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the statement by reporting a case of B19V arthropathy in adults.", "reference": "PMID:32510300", "snippet": "We report here a small outbreak of B19V infection among physicians and family members in an adult rheumatology practice that occurred after providing care for a patient with B19V arthropathy.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports that symmetrical acute polyarthritis, a form of arthropathy, is a typical manifestation of parvovirus B19.", "reference": "PMID:33944819", "snippet": "Typical clinical manifestations are: short lived fever accompanied by asthenia, myalgias and pharyngodynia; symmetrical acute polyarthritis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the statement by indicating that joint symptoms, including arthropathy, are frequent in adults with B19 infection.", "reference": "PMID:19480999", "snippet": "B19 infection-associated joint symptoms occur most frequently in adults, usually presenting as a self-limited, acute symmetric polyarthritis affecting the small joints of the hands, wrists, and knees.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference discusses parvovirus B19 infection and pregnancy but does not mention arthropathy.", "reference": "PMID:26044725", "snippet": "", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the statement by indicating that arthritis and arthralgias are common in adults with B19 infection.", "reference": "PMID:25965702", "snippet": "Arthralgias and arthritis, with or without rash, are common manifestations of B19V infection in adults.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Arthropathy", "notes": "Particularly in adults.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Arthropathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0003040", "label": "Arthropathy"}}}

name: Hydrops Fetalis
description: Severe fetal condition with fluid accumulation in body cavities due to profound anemia from viral destruction of fetal erythroid precursors.
notes: Due to severe fetal anemia resulting from maternal infection.

name: Hypotonia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hypotonia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference mentions hypotonia as a significant clinical feature in peroxisomal disorders.", "reference": "PMID:7685145", "snippet": "These disorders should be considered in the differential diagnosis of the infant with hypotonia and psychomotor delay...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While the reference primarily discusses cerebellar involvement, it indirectly supports the statement by implicating neurological systems in PEX10-related peroxisome biogenesis disorders.", "reference": "PMID:28320181", "snippet": "...suggest that these PEX10 mutations involve not only cerebellar but also more multiple nervous systems...", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference directly supports the very frequent occurrence of hypotonia in infants with peroxisomal disorders.", "reference": "PMID:13129589", "snippet": "The floppy infant syndrome is a well-recognized entity for pediatricians and neonatologists. The condition refers to an infant with generalized hypotonia...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Hypotonia is listed as one of the common clinical presentations in Zellweger syndrome, a type of peroxisome biogenesis disorder.", "reference": "PMID:38409970", "snippet": "Common clinical presentations include hypotonia, seizure, hepatomegaly, craniofacial dysmorphism and early death.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hypotonia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypotonia", "term": {"id": "HP:0001252", "label": "Hypotonia"}}}

name: Developmental Delay
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Developmental Delay"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that peroxisomal disorders, which include Peroxisome Biogenesis Disorders (PBDs), frequently present with progressive psychomotor dysfunction, supporting the statement that developmental delay is a very frequent neurologic phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:7685145", "snippet": "Because peroxisomes are involved in the metabolism of lipids critical to the functioning of the nervous system, many of the peroxisomal disorders manifest with significant degrees of progressive psychomotor dysfunction.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Although this does not explicitly mention developmental delay, the overall description implies a frequent occurrence of neurologic dysfunction, which is often tied to developmental delays.", "reference": "PMID:36293220", "snippet": "The clinical presentation of PBDs may range from severe, lethal multisystemic disorders to milder, late-onset disease. The vast majority of PBDs belong to Zellweger Spectrum Disordes (ZSDs) and represents a continuum of overlapping clinical symptoms.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The article describes neurologic deficits appearing early in life, which aligns with developmental delays being a very frequent phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:11769739", "snippet": "Distinctive external features are variable among these three disorders, and neurologic deficit has its onset at birth or in infancy.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The mention of the neonatal onset of CNS dysfunction supports the frequent presence of developmental delays.", "reference": "PMID:38409970", "snippet": "Zellweger syndrome is an autosomal recessive disease within the spectrum of peroxisome biogenesis disorder manifesting in the neonatal period with profound dysfunction of the central nervous system, liver and kidney.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "RCDP is a type of peroxisomal disorder, and its characteristic neurodevelopmental deficits support the statement about developmental delay being a common phenotype in PBDs.", "reference": "PMID:24172221", "snippet": "Neurodevelopmental deficits and age-related occurrence of seizures are characteristic of RCDP and are related to the rest-activity in plasmalogen biosynthesis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Developmental Delay", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Developmental Delay", "term": {"id": "HP:0001263", "label": "Global developmental delay"}}}

name: Seizures

raw_json: {"category": "Hepatobiliary", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference states that inherited metabolic diseases, which include peroxisome biogenesis disorders, account for a substantial portion of pediatric hepatomegaly cases but does not specify the frequency as 'frequent.'", "reference": "PMID:31005404", "snippet": "Inherited metabolic diseases account for about one third of pediatric patients with hepatomegaly, acute liver failure, cirrhosis or cholestasis.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference mentions liver pathology as frequent but does not specifically state hepatomegaly.", "reference": "PMID:22978395", "snippet": "Liver pathology is a frequent finding in patients affected by a peroxisomal disorder.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference discusses organ involvement including hepatic involvement but does not specify hepatomegaly as frequent.", "reference": "PMID:26615381", "snippet": "ZS is a peroxisomal disorder with a multiple congenital anomalies, characterized by stereotypical facies, profound hypotonia, organ involvement including cerebral, retinal, hepatic, and renal.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hepatomegaly", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hepatomegaly", "term": {"id": "HP:0002240", "label": "Hepatomegaly"}}}
