name: Retinopathy
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Visual", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Retinopathy"}
raw_json: {"category": "Visual", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study states that retinopathy is a recurrent feature in patients with peroxisomal disorders, supporting the statement that visual phenotypes, specifically retinopathy, are frequent.", "reference": "PMID:31884631", "snippet": "Retinopathy is a recurrent feature in both the severely and mildly affected patients, which can be accompanied with other ophthalmological pathologies.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study indicates that retinopathy is common in peroxisome biogenesis disorders like Zellweger syndrome, neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy, and infantile Refsum disease, supporting the frequent occurrence of retinopathy as a visual phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:12473763", "snippet": "Common to these three disorders are liver disease, variable neurodevelopmental delay, retinopathy, and perceptive deafness.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study states that retinal degeneration is the most frequent ocular phenotype observed in inherited metabolic disorders, which includes peroxisome biogenesis disorders, thereby supporting the frequent occurrence of retinopathy.", "reference": "PMID:35227579", "snippet": "Retinal degeneration with or without optic atrophy is the most frequent phenotype, followed by oculomotor problems, involvement of the cornea and lens, and refractive errors.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study highlights that retinopathy leading to blindness is a significant issue in patients with Zellweger Spectrum Disorder, a type of peroxisome biogenesis disorder, supporting the frequency of retinopathy as a visual phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:31254513", "snippet": "Retinopathy leading to blindness is one of the major untreatable handicaps faced by patients with ZSD but is not well characterized.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Retinopathy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Retinopathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0000488", "label": "Retinopathy"}}}

name: Hearing Loss
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Auditory", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hearing Loss"}
raw_json: {"category": "Auditory", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This study characterizes hearing loss as a common phenotype in patients with Peroxisome Biogenesis Disorder within the Zellweger Spectrum.", "reference": "PMID:34534157", "snippet": "The majority of PBD-ZSD patients in this study presented with moderately-severe to severe hearing loss.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study also confirms hearing impairment as a frequent phenotype in Peroxisome Biogenesis Disorders, further supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:36291074", "snippet": "Peroxisome biogenesis disorders (due to PEX gene mutations) are associated with symptoms that range in severity and can lead to early childhood death, but a common feature is hearing impairment.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Heimler syndrome, a less severe form of peroxisome biogenesis disorders, frequently presents with sensorineural hearing loss, further supporting the frequent association of hearing loss with these disorders.", "reference": "PMID:33417209", "snippet": "Heimler syndrome is a rare syndrome associating sensorineural hearing loss with retinal dystrophy and amelogenesis imperfecta due to PEX1 or PEX6 biallelic pathogenic variations. This syndrome is one of the less severe forms of peroxisome biogenesis disorders.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hearing Loss", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hearing Loss", "term": {"id": "HP:0000365", "label": "Hearing impairment"}}}

name: Craniofacial Dysmorphism
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Craniofacial Dysmorphism"}
raw_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Distinctive facial stigmata can be considered a form of craniofacial dysmorphism, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:23671347", "snippet": "Patients with ZS present in the neonatal period with a characteristic phenotype of distinctive facial stigmata.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While the text does not explicitly mention craniofacial dysmorphism, the severity of symptoms and multisystem involvement suggest potential craniofacial manifestations.", "reference": "PMID:1710072", "snippet": "Zellweger syndrome, the most lethal of the three peroxisomal biogenesis disorders, causes infantile hypotonia, seizures, and death within the first year.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Craniofacial Dysmorphism"}

name: Adrenal Insufficiency
notes: Due to adrenal gland dysfunction
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Endocrine", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Adrenal Insufficiency", "notes": "Due to adrenal gland dysfunction"}
raw_json: {"category": "Endocrine", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates that primary adrenal insufficiency is frequent in patients with peroxisomal disorders, specifically those with PEX1 pathogenic variants.", "reference": "PMID:36649687", "snippet": "Primary adrenal insufficiency is common in patients with PD. Based on our data, patients with the compound heterozygous PEX1 pathogenic variants of exon 13 (c.2097dupT and c.2528G>A) tend to have adrenal insufficiency.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study highlights a high prevalence of primary adrenal insufficiency in patients with Zellweger spectrum disorders, which are a type of peroxisome biogenesis disorder.", "reference": "PMID:25179809", "snippet": "Primary adrenal insufficiency was found in 7/24 patients examined, with 4/7 being asymptomatic. Systematic evaluation of adrenal function, through a Synacthen test, should be included in the clinical management of these patients.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Adrenal Insufficiency", "notes": "Due to adrenal gland dysfunction", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Adrenal Insufficiency", "term": {"id": "HP:0000846", "label": "Adrenal insufficiency"}}}

name: Chondrodysplasia Punctata
notes: Stippling of epiphyses on X-rays
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Chondrodysplasia Punctata", "notes": "Stippling of epiphyses on X-rays"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata is a type of peroxisome biogenesis disorder, supporting the statement that chondrodysplasia punctata falls under the category of musculoskeletal issues associated with peroxisome biogenesis disorders.", "reference": "PMID:10904262", "snippet": "Zellweger syndrome, neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy, infantile Refsum disease and rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata are progressive disorders characterized by loss of multiple peroxisomal metabolic functions.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study supports the statement by indicating that epiphyseal stippling (chondrodysplasia punctata) is a characteristic feature in Zellweger syndrome, a type of peroxisome biogenesis disorder.", "reference": "PMID:24030027", "snippet": "We present a 2-month-old male affected by Zellweger syndrome, a rare peroxisomal disorder. The diagnosis was supported by clinical and radiological findings and established by biochemical tests. The characteristic radiological features included anomalous ossification (epiphyseal stippling).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata is characterized by punctuate calcifications of the epiphyses, supporting the statement that this condition is associated with peroxisome biogenesis disorders and involves stippling of epiphyses.", "reference": "PMID:17671048", "snippet": "Classic rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata is a rare, autosomal, recessively inherited disorder that is characterized by proximal shortening of the limbs, punctuate calcifications of the epiphyses, cataracts, developmental delay, and early lethality.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Chondrodysplasia Punctata", "notes": "Stippling of epiphyses on X-rays"}

notes: Low platelet count

Retinopathy is a recurrent feature in both the severely and mildly affected patients, which can be accompanied with other ophthalmological pathologies.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Thrombocytopenia", "notes": "Low platelet count", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Thrombocytopenia", "term": {"id": "HP:0001873", "label": "Thrombocytopenia"}}}

However, it does not specifically mention peroxisome biogenesis disorders (PBDs) in this context.", "reference": "PMID:25465824", "snippet": "CI in MIDs includes cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias, heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, dilation of the aortic root, pericardial effusion, coronary heart disease, autonomous nervous system dysfunction, congenital heart defects, or sudden cardiac death.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference provides an overview of pediatric cardiomyopathies but does not specifically mention peroxisome biogenesis disorders (PBDs) as a cause.", "reference": "PMID:36870438", "snippet": "Paediatric cardiomyopathies form a heterogeneous group of disorders characterized by structural and electrical abnormalities of the heart muscle, commonly due to a gene variant of the myocardial cell structure.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Cardiomyopathy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Cardiomyopathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0001638", "label": "Cardiomyopathy"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Heart Failure"}]}

name: Small intestinal polyposis
description: Multiple hamartomatous polyps predominantly in the small intestine. These polyps are benign but can grow large and cause complications.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Multiple hamartomatous polyps predominantly in the small intestine. These polyps are benign but can grow large and cause complications.\n", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Small intestinal polyposis"}

These polyps are benign but can grow large and cause complications.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Confirms small intestinal polyposis as a hallmark manifestation of PJS", "reference": "PMID:37892343", "snippet": "The management of pediatric Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome (PJS) focuses on the prevention of intussusception complicating small intestinal (SI) polyposis", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Small intestinal polyposis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Small intestinal polyposis", "term": {"id": "HP:0030256", "label": "Small intestinal polyposis"}}}

name: Gastrointestinal hemorrhage
description: Bleeding from polyps can occur, presenting as hematemesis, melena, or positive fecal occult blood. Chronic blood loss may lead to iron deficiency anemia.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Bleeding from polyps can occur, presenting as hematemesis, melena, or positive fecal occult blood. Chronic blood loss may lead to iron deficiency anemia.\n", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Gastrointestinal hemorrhage"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Bleeding from polyps can occur, presenting as hematemesis, melena, or positive fecal occult blood. Chronic blood loss may lead to iron deficiency anemia.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Establishes chronic gastrointestinal bleeding from polyps as a major complication of PJS", "reference": "PMID:20301443", "snippet": "GI polyps can result in chronic bleeding, anemia, and recurrent obstruction and intussusception requiring repeated laparotomy and bowel resection", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Gastrointestinal hemorrhage", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Gastrointestinal hemorrhage", "term": {"id": "HP:0002239", "label": "Gastrointestinal hemorrhage"}}}

name: Abnormal pigmentation of oral mucosa

raw_json: {"category": "Dermatologic", "description": "Characteristic dark brown macules on the lips and intraoral mucosa, often present before gastrointestinal manifestations appear.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Oral and mucocutaneous pigmentation is a characteristic diagnostic feature of PJS, often appearing before GI polyps", "reference": "PMID:20301443", "snippet": "Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation presents in childhood as dark blue to dark brown macules around the mouth, eyes, and nostrils, in the perianal area, and on the buccal mucosa", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Abnormal pigmentation of oral mucosa", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abnormal pigmentation of oral mucosa", "term": {"id": "HP:0100669", "label": "Abnormal pigmentation of the oral mucosa"}}}

description: Significantly elevated lifetime risk of gastrointestinal cancers (stomach, duodenal, colorectal, pancreatic) and non-GI cancers (breast, lung, ovarian).

name: Progressive Dementia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Progressive Dementia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature describes Pick's disease as a type of frontotemporal dementia with behavior and executive function impacts, supporting progressive dementia and associated sequelae like loss of social awareness and executive dysfunction.", "reference": "PMID:16736722", "snippet": "Frontotemporal dementia (clinical Pick's disease) is a relatively common, but underdiagnosed degenerative disease in the presenium. ... The behavioural, aphasic and extrapyramidal presentations are labeled FTD-behavioural variant, Primary Progressive Aphasia (PPA) and Corticobasal Degeneration/Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (CBD/PSP).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The snippet indicates that loss of social awareness is frequently observed in frontotemporal dementia, aligning with the sequelae specified in the query.", "reference": "PMID:28689508", "snippet": "Socially inappropriate behaviors, such as loss of empathy, inappropriateness of affect, and disinhibition are frequently reported in prodromal bvFTD and in prodromal AD.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This supports the statement as it mentions social cognition deficits, which align with executive dysfunction and loss of social awareness in progressive dementia.", "reference": "PMID:30876954", "snippet": "Although primary progressive aphasia (PPA) is clinically typified by linguistic impairments, emerging evidence highlights the presence of early deficits in social cognition.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While this indicates behavioral symptoms appear, it specifies they are less prominent early on, suggesting partial support for the statement regarding the phenotypes and sequelae.", "reference": "PMID:32507758", "snippet": "Behavioral symptoms are less prominent in the early stages...", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Progressive Dementia", "sequelae": [{"target": "Loss of Social Awareness"}, {"target": "Executive Dysfunction"}]}

name: Behavioral Changes
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Psychiatric", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Behavioral Changes"}
raw_json: {"category": "Psychiatric", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference supports that behavioral changes, which can be considered psychiatric phenotypes, are common in Pick's disease.", "reference": "PMID:26583316", "snippet": "Behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia was the predominant clinical phenotype (18 of 21), but all patients eventually developed a social comportment disorder.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While this study indicates that social behavior changes (which can include behavioral changes) are common, it does not specifically state the frequency in Pick's disease.", "reference": "PMID:35584922", "snippet": "Changes in social behavior are common symptoms of frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) and Alzheimer disease syndromes.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "MND (Motor Neuron Disease) does overlap with frontotemporal dementia and associated behavioral changes, but this is not directly related to Pick's disease and does not provide evidence for high-frequency psychiatric phenotypes in Pick's disease.", "reference": "PMID:31871139", "snippet": "Neuropsychiatric disorders in patients and their families are associated with cognitive and behavioural changes post-MND diagnosis, with many occurring independently of MND-FTD and C9orf72 status.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Behavioral Changes"}

raw_json: {"category": "Psychiatric", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference discusses the presence of repetitive behaviors in frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD), which includes Pick's disease. However, the emphasis is more on impulsive behaviors rather than strictly compulsive behaviors as seen in OCD.", "reference": "PMID:30537913", "snippet": "Patients with bvFTD often have perseverative, stereotyped, or compulsive-ritualistic behavior as an early aspect of their disorder.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Compulsive Behaviors", "notes": "Repetitive, ritualistic behaviors such as hand-wringing, pacing, or collecting objects.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Compulsive Behaviors", "term": {"id": "HP:0000722", "label": "Compulsive behaviors"}}}

name: Aphasia
notes: Language difficulties, particularly with word-finding and naming. May progress to mutism in advanced stages.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Aphasia", "notes": "Language difficulties, particularly with word-finding and naming. May progress to mutism in advanced stages."}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference states that primary progressive aphasia is a common early manifestation of Pick's disease, supporting the claim that aphasia is a frequent neurological symptom of Pick's disease.", "reference": "PMID:9059759", "snippet": "Primary progressive aphasia is an important recently emphasized clinical syndrome that is a common early manifestation of Pick's disease and Pick complex pathology.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference confirms the association of Pick's disease with frontotemporal dementia, which includes language difficulties such as aphasia.", "reference": "PMID:36925418", "snippet": "Frontotemporal Dementia, also known by the name Pick's disease, is a rare form of dementia that can run for several generations. The two key characteristics are argyrophilic, spherical intraneuronal inclusions, which most frequently impact the frontal and temporal poles, and localized cortical atrophy (Pick bodies).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the statement by indicating that aphasic symptoms are associated with Pick's disease, particularly its frontal and temporal forms.", "reference": "PMID:37276800", "snippet": "His frontal and temporal forms of aphasia foreshadowed what are now called the nonfluent/agrammatic and semantic variants of primary progressive aphasia. Moreover, aphasic symptoms may occur with frontal degeneration (what used to be called 'Pick's disease') that yields personality changes and behavioral disturbances, now called the behavioral variant of frontotemporal dementia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Aphasia", "notes": "Language difficulties, particularly with word-finding and naming. May progress to mutism in advanced stages.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Aphasia", "term": {"id": "HP:0002381", "label": "Aphasia"}}}

name: Parkinsonism
notes: Extrapyramidal signs such as rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability. More common as disease progresses.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Parkinsonism", "notes": "Extrapyramidal signs such as rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability. More common as disease progresses."}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The provided literature does not mention parkinsonism or extrapyramidal signs such as rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability in the context of Pick's disease (Frontotemporal dementia).", "reference": "PMID:11402143", "snippet": "The clinical presentation in frontotemporal dementia (FTD) reflects the distribution of the pathologic changes rather than the exact histologic subtype of the disease. Three major clinical syndromes can be identified: 1) frontal variant FTD (dementia of frontal type) in which changes in social behavior and personality predominate, reflecting the orbitobasal frontal lobe focus of the pathology. Traditional cognitive tests are insensitive, but more specific measures are under development; 2) semantic dementia (progressive fluent aphasia) in which there is a breakdown in the conceptual database which underlies language production and comprehension, although deficits in nonverbal semantic knowledge can also be shown on neuropsychologic testing. Patients with semantic dementia have asymmetric anterolateral temporal atrophy with relative sparing of the hippocampal formation, which is typically worse on the left side. A variant of this syndrome affecting the right temporal lobe presents with progressive prosopagnosia; 3) progressive nonfluent aphasia in which the phonologic and syntactic components of language are affected in association with left peri-Sylvian atrophy. The assessment of patients with potential FTD involves a multidisciplinary approach. The development of comprehensive caregiver-based neuropsychiatric instruments, neuropsychologic tasks sensitive to semantic memory and other key cognitive impairments, and functional (hexamethyly-propyleneamine-SPECT) and structural (MRI) brain imaging represent significant advances in the field.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Parkinsonism", "notes": "Extrapyramidal signs such as rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability. More common as disease progresses.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Parkinsonism", "term": {"id": "HP:0001300", "label": "Parkinsonism"}}}

name: Primitive Reflexes
notes: Reemergence of reflexes normally suppressed in adulthood, such as the grasp reflex or rooting reflex.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Primitive Reflexes", "notes": "Reemergence of reflexes normally suppressed in adulthood, such as the grasp reflex or rooting reflex."}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reemergence of primitive reflexes, such as the grasp reflex, is associated with diseases affecting the frontal lobes, which includes Pick's disease.", "reference": "PMID:12700289", "snippet": "Primitive reflexes are typically present in childhood, suppressed during normal development, and may reappear with diseases of the brain, particularly those affecting the frontal lobes.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Pick's disease affects the frontal lobes, which can lead to the reemergence of primitive reflexes.", "reference": "PMID:22411252", "snippet": "Picks disease is a major clinicopathological disease having circumscribed atrophy in the frontotemporal lobe.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Primitive Reflexes", "notes": "Reemergence of reflexes normally suppressed in adulthood, such as the grasp reflex or rooting reflex."}

name: Executive Dysfunction
notes: Impairment in planning, problem-solving, and abstract thinking. One of the earliest cognitive changes.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cognitive", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Executive Dysfunction", "notes": "Impairment in planning, problem-solving, and abstract thinking. One of the earliest cognitive changes."}
raw_json: {"category": "Cognitive", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract mentions that the clinical picture of Pick's disease (frontotemporal dementia) mainly involves behavioral and language impairment. While it does not explicitly mention executive dysfunction, the broader category of cognitive impairments and the association with other syndromes that involve executive dysfunction support the statement.", "reference": "PMID:20420119", "snippet": "This condition, formerly known as Pick's disease and considered rare, is estimated to be 12-15% of all dementias and 30-50% early onset ones. The clinical picture is protean, mainly a behavioural and language impairment, but the extrapyramidal syndromes of CBD and PSP also belong.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The title of the study directly links Pick's disease with corticobasal syndrome, which is known to involve executive dysfunction. This supports the statement that executive dysfunction is frequent in Pick's disease.", "reference": "PMID:32145523", "snippet": "Corticobasal syndrome-Pick's disease: A clinicopathological study.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract mentions that social cognitive dysfunctions, including executive dysfunction, are core diagnostic criteria for behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD), which is closely related to Pick's disease.", "reference": "PMID:29854017", "snippet": "Specifically, in some NDs these deficits may represent core diagnostic criteria, such as for behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD)...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Executive Dysfunction", "notes": "Impairment in planning, problem-solving, and abstract thinking. One of the earliest cognitive changes."}

name: Seizures
notes: Can occur in advanced stages, but are not a typical feature.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "RARE", "name": "Seizures", "notes": "Can occur in advanced stages, but are not a typical feature."}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference discusses the clinical features of Pick's disease (now considered a type of frontotemporal dementia) but does not specifically mention seizures as a typical feature. However, it does not refute the possibility of seizures occurring in advanced stages.", "reference": "PMID:16317256", "snippet": "What was once called Pick's disease has three major anatomic variants. With all three, frontotemporal brain is selectively injured whereas posterior cortical regions are spared.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference only provides the title \"Pick's disease\" and does not contain any information about seizures or their frequency in Pick's disease.", "reference": "PMID:17076146", "snippet": "Pick's disease.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "RARE", "name": "Seizures", "notes": "Can occur in advanced stages, but are not a typical feature.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Seizures", "term": {"id": "HP:0001250", "label": "Seizure"}}}

name: Polycystic hepatic lesion
description: Large multilocular hydatid cysts occupying the liver.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Large multilocular hydatid cysts occupying the liver.", "name": "Polycystic hepatic lesion"}
raw_json: {"description": "Large multilocular hydatid cysts occupying the liver.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The CT finding documents a large hepatic polycystic hydatid lesion consistent with the phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:33553405", "snippet": "Computed tomography of the abdomen revealed a huge polycystic lesion in left liver lobe, without reinforcement after enhanced scanning and sized about 16.9 cm  12.2 cm, which was considered a type II hydatid cyst.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Polycystic hepatic lesion", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hepatic cysts", "term": {"id": "HP:0001407", "label": "Hepatic cysts"}}}

name: Hepatic abscess complication
description: Secondary infection of hepatic hydatid lesions leading to abscess formation.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Secondary infection of hepatic hydatid lesions leading to abscess formation.", "name": "Hepatic abscess complication"}
raw_json: {"description": "Secondary infection of hepatic hydatid lesions leading to abscess formation.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The report documents hepatic abscess formation as a complication of neotropical echinococcosis.", "reference": "PMID:41431593", "snippet": "We describe a rural patient with hepatitis B virus (HBV)-related cirrhosis and neotropical echinococcosis who developed a hepatic abscess that fistulized into the right hemithorax.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Hepatic abscess complication", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Liver abscess", "term": {"id": "HP:0100523", "label": "Liver abscess"}}}

name: Thoracic abscess from hepatic fistula
description: Extension of the hepatic abscess through the diaphragm into the thoracic cavity, resulting in a secondary thoracic abscess.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Extension of the hepatic abscess through the diaphragm into the thoracic cavity, resulting in a secondary thoracic abscess.", "name": "Thoracic abscess from hepatic fistula"}
raw_json: {"description": "Extension of the hepatic abscess through the diaphragm into the thoracic cavity, resulting in a secondary thoracic abscess.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The case describes a transdiaphragmatic fistula leading to a thoracic abscess, aligning with a lung abscess complication.", "reference": "PMID:41431593", "snippet": "We describe a rural patient with hepatitis B virus (HBV)-related cirrhosis and neotropical echinococcosis who developed a hepatic abscess that fistulized into the right hemithorax.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Thoracic abscess from hepatic fistula", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Lung abscess", "term": {"id": "HP:0025044", "label": "Lung abscess"}}}

name: Multiple Renal Cysts
description: Multiple fluid-filled cysts in both kidneys, progressively enlarging over time.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Renal", "description": "Multiple fluid-filled cysts in both kidneys, progressively enlarging over time.", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Multiple Renal Cysts"}
raw_json: {"category": "Renal", "description": "Multiple fluid-filled cysts in both kidneys, progressively enlarging over time.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "REPRISE trial confirms PKD as a cystic kidney disease defined by progressive kidney volume increase.", "reference": "PMID:29105594", "snippet": "the vasopressin V2-receptor antagonist tolvaptan slowed the growth in total kidney volume", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "JAMA review describes ADPKD as a progressive cystic kidney disease.", "reference": "PMID:40126492", "snippet": "Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is characterized by progressive development of kidney cysts", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Multiple Renal Cysts", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Multiple renal cysts", "term": {"id": "HP:0005562", "label": "Multiple renal cysts"}}}

name: Hypertension
description: High blood pressure, often preceding decline in renal function.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "description": "High blood pressure, often preceding decline in renal function.", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hypertension"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "description": "High blood pressure, often preceding decline in renal function.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "JAMA review confirms very high prevalence of hypertension in ADPKD patients.", "reference": "PMID:40126492", "snippet": "Hypertension affects 70% to 80% of patients with ADPKD", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Tight blood pressure targets underscore hypertension as a central clinical issue in ADPKD.", "reference": "PMID:40126492", "snippet": "Optimal management of ADPKD includes systolic blood pressure lower than 120 mm Hg for most patients", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Proteomic study lists hypertension as a common comorbidity in ADPKD cohorts.", "reference": "PMID:40371605", "snippet": "Comorbidities include hypertension, flank pain, and bacterial infections.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hypertension", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypertension", "term": {"id": "HP:0000822", "label": "Hypertension"}}}

name: Chronic Kidney Disease
description: Progressive decline in kidney function, with approximately 50% reaching end-stage renal disease by age 60.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Renal", "description": "Progressive decline in kidney function, with approximately 50% reaching end-stage renal disease by age 60.", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic Kidney Disease"}
raw_json: {"category": "Renal", "description": "Progressive decline in kidney function, with approximately 50% reaching end-stage renal disease by age 60.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Trial demonstrates progressive GFR decline in PKD patients.", "reference": "PMID:29105594", "snippet": "The change from baseline in the estimated GFR was -2.34 ml per minute per 1.73 m2", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "High rate of kidney replacement therapy highlights progression to advanced CKD in ADPKD.", "reference": "PMID:40126492", "snippet": "Approximately 50% of individuals with ADPKD require kidney replacement therapy by 62 years of age", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic Kidney Disease", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Chronic kidney disease", "term": {"id": "HP:0012622", "label": "Chronic kidney disease"}}}

name: Hepatic Cysts

raw_json: {"category": "Hepatic", "description": "Liver cysts are common extrarenal manifestation, more prevalent in women.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "JAMA review confirms hepatic cysts as a very common manifestation in ADPKD.", "reference": "PMID:40126492", "snippet": "More than 90% of patients older than 35 years have hepatic cysts", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Describes prevalence plus symptomatic burden and intervention needs from hepatic cysts in ADPKD.", "reference": "PMID:40126492", "snippet": "More than 90% of patients older than 35 years have hepatic cysts, which may cause abdominal discomfort and occasionally require medical or surgical intervention", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hepatic Cysts", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hepatic cysts", "term": {"id": "HP:0001407", "label": "Hepatic cysts"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Vascular", "description": "Cerebral berry aneurysms occur in 5-10% of ADPKD patients, with risk of rupture.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "JAMA review confirms intracranial aneurysms occur in 9-14% of ADPKD patients.", "reference": "PMID:40126492", "snippet": "approximately 9% to 14% develop intracranial aneurysms", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Intracranial Aneurysm", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Cerebral berry aneurysm", "term": {"id": "HP:0007029", "label": "Cerebral berry aneurysm"}}}

", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Establishes pouchitis as an inflammatory condition of the ileal pouch, which manifests clinically with diarrhea as a cardinal symptom of inflammation.
", "reference": "PMID:40240062", "snippet": "Pouchitis, defined as inflammation of the ileal pouch, is the most common complication following restorative proctocolectomy for refractory ulcerative colitis.

name: Pruritus
notes: Often the presenting symptom
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatological", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Pruritus", "notes": "Often the presenting symptom"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This real-world cohort study demonstrates that pruritus is highly prevalent in PBC (81%), with clinically significant pruritus associated with worse quality of life, more advanced disease, and greater fatigue.", "reference": "PMID:35704252", "snippet": "Pruritus was reported in 170 patients (81%), with those reporting clinically significant pruritus (30%) scoring worse across each domain of the PBC-40 and 5-D itch, more frequently having cirrhosis, and having significantly greater levels of fatigue.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Pruritus", "notes": "Often the presenting symptom", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Pruritus", "term": {"id": "HP:0000989", "label": "Pruritus"}}}

name: Chronic Cough
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic Cough"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The statement is supported because PCD leads to chronic respiratory symptoms, including chronic cough.", "reference": "PMID:27258773", "snippet": "Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a rare, heterogeneous, recessive, genetic disorder of motile cilia, leading to chronic upper and lower respiratory symptoms.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The statement is supported because PCD causes progressive involvement of the respiratory tract, which includes chronic cough.", "reference": "PMID:17142159", "snippet": "Primary ciliary dyskinesia is an autosomal recessive genetic disease that results in impaired mucociliary clearance causing progressive involvement of the upper and lower respiratory tract, characterized by airway obstruction and recurrent infections of the lungs, middle ear and paranasal sinuses.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic Cough", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Chronic Cough", "term": {"id": "HP:0034315", "label": "Chronic cough"}}}

name: Recurrent Respiratory Infections
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Recurrent Respiratory Infections"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The article discusses recurrent respiratory diseases as a significant aspect of PCD, supporting the statement that recurrent respiratory infections are very frequent in PCD.", "reference": "PMID:39069333", "snippet": "This review article explores the respiratory aspects of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), a rare, heterogenous, genetic disorder characterized by impaired motile ciliary function. It discusses the clinical diagnosis and management strategies for PCD-related respiratory disease, including chronic sinusitis, otitis media with effusion, recurrent pneumonia, and bronchiectasis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study highlights recurrent respiratory tract infections in children with chronic respiratory symptoms, supporting the statement that recurrent respiratory infections are very frequent in PCD.", "reference": "PMID:36214320", "snippet": "Ninety-two children with chronic respiratory symptoms were divided into 4 groups: 18 children with refractory asthma, 10 with bronchiectasis without dextrocardia, 18 with dextrocardia and 46 with recurrent respiratory tract infections.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study mentions chronic rhinosinusitis and bronchiectasis in patients suspected of ciliary dyskinesia, indicating frequent respiratory issues.", "reference": "PMID:31430425", "snippet": "The objective of this study was to evaluate the prevalence of chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) and its characteristics in bronchiectasis patients suspected of harboring ciliary dyskinesia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study discusses sinus infections as a common issue in PCD, supporting the statement about frequent respiratory infections.", "reference": "PMID:25370419", "snippet": "The sinuses should be considered as a bacterial reservoir and a target for surgery and antibiotic treatment in patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Recurrent Respiratory Infections", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Recurrent Respiratory Infections", "term": {"id": "HP:0002205", "label": "Recurrent respiratory infections"}}}

name: Bronchiectasis
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Bronchiectasis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The article mentions bronchiectasis as one of the potential conditions that patients with PCD could develop.", "reference": "PMID:10894096", "snippet": "Patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia could potentially develop recurrent sinotrachrobronchitis, bronchiectasis, serous otitis media, hydrocephalus, and male infertility.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The article lists bronchiectasis as a typical manifestation of primary ciliary dyskinesia.", "reference": "PMID:36344229", "snippet": "Typical manifestations include bronchiectasis, secretory otitis media, sinusitis, situs inversus, and infertility.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The article discusses the relationship between functional and structural abnormalities in PCD, including bronchiectasis.", "reference": "PMID:25673230", "snippet": "Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a rare disease, characterised by chronic airway infection.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The article discusses primary ciliary dyskinesia and non-CF bronchiectasis, implying a connection between PCD and bronchiectasis.", "reference": "PMID:21680564", "snippet": "A review is presented of key clinical papers published in Thorax and elsewhere between 2008 and April 2011 which have advanced our understanding of cystic fibrosis (CF), primary ciliary dyskinesia and non-CF bronchiectasis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study evaluates bronchiectasis in patients suspected of having ciliary dyskinesia, indicating a frequent association.", "reference": "PMID:31430425", "snippet": "The objective of this study was to evaluate the prevalence of chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) and its characteristics in bronchiectasis patients suspected of harboring ciliary dyskinesia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The article explicitly states that PCD is a common cause of bronchiectasis in a specific population.", "reference": "PMID:37278553", "snippet": "Primary ciliary dyskinesia as a common cause of bronchiectasis in the Canadian Inuit population.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The article discusses the need for diagnostic workup for PCD in patients with bronchiectasis, indicating a frequent association.", "reference": "PMID:33895745", "snippet": "Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a rare genetic disorder which requires a complex diagnostic workup. Thus, an easy and widely available screening method would be helpful to identify patients who need a further diagnostic workup for PCD.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The article focuses on primary ciliary dyskinesia and its impact on mucociliary clearance, which is related to bronchiectasis.", "reference": "PMID:23181248", "snippet": "Mucociliary clearance is a primary defence mechanism of the airway that can be altered in congenital diseases such as primary ciliary dyskinesia and cystic fibrosis, as well as acquired conditions.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The article discusses Bardet-Biedl Syndrome as a cause of bronchiectasis, not primary ciliary dyskinesia.", "reference": "PMID:37852905", "snippet": "Bardet-Biedl Syndrome: An Uncommon Cause of Bronchiectasis.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Bronchiectasis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Bronchiectasis", "term": {"id": "HP:0002110", "label": "Bronchiectasis"}}}

name: Chronic Otitis Media
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Otologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic Otitis Media"}
raw_json: {"category": "Otologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study found that patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) frequently exhibited otologic issues, including chronic otitis media.", "reference": "PMID:29135867", "snippet": "All 15 patients showed ciliary ultrastructural abnormalities on electron microscopy and/or biallelic mutations in genes associated with ciliary function or structure. All 30 eardrums examined showed certain abnormalities. Fourteen patients had otitis media with effusion or its sequelae. The remaining patient had chronic otitis media.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports that chronic otitis media and other otologic issues are common in patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia.", "reference": "PMID:19796826", "snippet": "Primary ciliary dyskinesia is an autosomal recessively inherited group of disorders of ciliary ultrastructure. Otolaryngologists are frequently involved in the management of some of the most common symptoms of primary ciliary dyskinesia including chronic rhinitis, sinusitis and otitis media with effusion.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic Otitis Media", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Chronic Otitis Media", "term": {"id": "HP:0000389", "label": "Chronic otitis media"}}}

name: Hearing Loss
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Otologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Hearing Loss"}
raw_json: {"category": "Otologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates that hearing loss is a prevalent condition among patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), not occasional.", "reference": "PMID:29287859", "snippet": "Slight to mild CHL and all types of otitis media are prevalent among patients with PCD, and some of these children have sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL).", "supports": "REFUTE"}, {"explanation": "The study describes otological manifestations including hearing loss as a prominent feature in patients with PCD, suggesting it is not occasional but rather common.", "reference": "PMID:9222635", "snippet": "All children (11 patients) had bilateral otitis media with effusion. Of the five adults, three had tympanosclerosis; one had bilateral cholesteatoma; and one patient had bilateral keratosis obturans in combination with tympanosclerosis.", "supports": "REFUTE"}, {"explanation": "This study discusses hearing loss in osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), not primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD).", "reference": "PMID:33844744", "snippet": "In this group of patients with OI, 30% had hearing loss and among those ears with normal hearing, 13% did not have an acoustic stapedial reflex.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Hearing Loss", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hearing Loss", "term": {"id": "HP:0000365", "label": "Hearing impairment"}}}

name: Nasal Polyps
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Nasal Polyps"}
raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract discusses histopathology and neutrophil count in PCD-CRS, but does not provide evidence on the frequency of nasal polyps in PCD.", "reference": "PMID:37997295", "snippet": "Despite endoscopic differences, PCD-CRS and cystic fibrosis-related chronic rhinosinusitis (CF-CRS) had similar structured histopathology reports. Compared to healthy patients and those with idiopathic chronic rhinosinusitis without nasal polyps, patients with PCD-CRS had an increased neutrophil count.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The review focuses on respiratory aspects of PCD and does not mention nasal polyps as a frequent gastrointestinal manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:39069333", "snippet": "This review article explores the respiratory aspects of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), a rare, heterogenous, genetic disorder characterized by impaired motile ciliary function. It discusses the clinical diagnosis and management strategies for PCD-related respiratory disease, including chronic sinusitis, otitis media with effusion, recurrent pneumonia, and bronchiectasis.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Nasal Polyps"}

name: Situs Inversus Totalis
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiac", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Situs Inversus Totalis"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiac", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that situs inversus, including situs inversus totalis, occurs in approximately 50% of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) cases. This suggests that it is not merely 'occasional' but rather relatively common in PCD patients.", "reference": "PMID:16036877", "snippet": "Total immotility of the cilia should therefore result in random asymmetry of the body that is situs inversus in 50% of the cases. It has also been claimed that 50% of cases with PCD have situs inversus.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The data indicates that situs inversus totalis occurs in 38.5% of PCD cases, which is more frequent than 'occasional.'", "reference": "PMID:36342963", "snippet": "Results: Of 559 participants, 286 (51.2%), 215 (38.5%), and 58 (10.4%) were identified as having situs solitus, situs inversustotalis, and situs ambiguus, respectively; heterotaxy, defined as situs ambiguus with complex cardiovascular defects, was present in 14 (2.5%)", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "Situs inversus totalis (SIT) is present in a significant portion of PCD cases, indicating it is more common than 'occasional.'", "reference": "PMID:38072392", "snippet": "The remaining 355 participants did not have SA, including 152 with SIT and 203 with SS.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Situs Inversus Totalis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Situs Inversus Totalis", "term": {"id": "HP:0001696", "label": "Situs inversus totalis"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "ENT", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference supports that tonsillar enlargement can be a diagnostic sign for malignancies, including lymphoma, but it does not specifically state that primary tonsillar lymphoma is very frequent.", "reference": "PMID:19558906", "snippet": "Histopathologic study revealed 80 % to be benign and 20 % malignant. The risk factors with the strongest association were enlargement of cervical lymphatic nodes and suspicious appearance of the tonsil.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference indicates that lymphoma, including primary tonsillar lymphoma, is common in the head and neck region but does not specify it as very frequent.", "reference": "PMID:2190267", "snippet": "Lymphoma is the second most common neoplasm of the head and neck region and should be considered in the differential diagnosis of any lesion in this region, especially if the typical factors for squamous cell carcinoma are not present.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports that primary tonsillar lymphoma is common in the head and neck region but does not specify it as very frequent.", "reference": "PMID:34754855", "snippet": "Lymphomas are the second most common malignancy of the head and neck. In this region, the vast majority of extranodal lymphomas are located in the palatine tonsil, accounting for about 51%.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference indicates the occurrence of tonsillar lymphoma but does not provide information on its frequency.", "reference": "PMID:38044117", "snippet": "Tonsillar Peripheral T-cell Lymphoma Detected by Esophagogastroduodenoscopy.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Enlarged Tonsil", "notes": "Often unilateral and can cause difficulty swallowing or a sensation of a lump in the throat.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Enlarged Tonsil", "term": {"id": "HP:0030812", "label": "Enlarged tonsils"}}}

name: Fever
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fever"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The case report of primary CLL/SLL of the palatine tonsil mentioned does not include fever as a symptom.", "reference": "PMID:37997620", "snippet": "We report a case of primary CLL/SLL of the palatine tonsil in a 51-year-old gentleman who presented with tonsillar asymmetry and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) but lacked signs and symptoms suspicious for malignancy, including lymphadenopathy and 'B-symptoms.'", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "Fever is not mentioned as a symptom in this case of palatine tonsillar follicular lymphoma.", "reference": "PMID:35314548", "snippet": "A 52-year-old man presented with palatine tonsillar swelling caused by follicular lymphoma. His tumor burden was low, but exacerbation of snoring and dysphagia was observed.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The study does not mention fever as a common symptom in cases of tonsillar hematolymphoid malignancy.", "reference": "PMID:28351195", "snippet": "Hematolymphoid malignancy was diagnosed in 6 adults by histology/immunohistochemistry: diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (2), small B-cell lymphoma (2), concomitant follicular lymphoma and histiocytic sarcoma (1), and extraosseous plasmacytoma (1).", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The study on pediatric tonsillar malignancies does not mention fever as a frequent symptom.", "reference": "PMID:30639969", "snippet": "Burkitt lymphoma (32.6%) followed by diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) (27.0%) were the two most common histological types of tonsillar cancers.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This study discusses fever in the context of infections and autoinflammatory diseases, not specifically in primary tonsillar lymphoma.", "reference": "PMID:29025800", "snippet": "Fever is a common sign of illness in children and is most frequently due to infection. However, when acute and chronic infections have been excluded and when the fever pattern becomes recurrent or periodic, the expanding spectrum of autoinflammatory diseases, including periodic fever syndromes, should be considered.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fever", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fever", "term": {"id": "HP:0001945", "label": "Fever"}}}

name: Night Sweats
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Night Sweats"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "While lymphoma can cause night sweats, they are not frequently found to be the cause in modern practice, suggesting that night sweats are not a frequent systemic symptom of primary tonsillar lymphoma.", "reference": "PMID:12643362", "snippet": "Tuberculosis and lymphoma are diseases in which night sweats are a dominant symptom, but these are infrequently found to be the cause of night sweats in modern practice.", "supports": "REFUTE"}, {"explanation": "Night sweats are considered a B symptom, and they were present in only 16% of pediatric tonsillar lymphoma cases, indicating that they are not a frequent symptom.", "reference": "PMID:24387945", "snippet": "The presence of B symptoms occurred in only 16% of the patients.", "supports": "REFUTE"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Night Sweats", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Night sweats", "term": {"id": "HP:0030166", "label": "Night sweats"}}}

name: Weight Loss
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Weight Loss"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature does not mention weight loss as a frequent systemic symptom in primary tonsillar lymphoma.", "reference": "PMID:10592134", "snippet": "We report six cases of primary tonsillar lymphoma with a median patient age of 42 years... All patients achieved durable complete remission.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The study focuses on the ultrasonic characteristics of tonsillar lymphoma and does not mention systemic symptoms such as weight loss.", "reference": "PMID:38742359", "snippet": "Objective: To analyze the ultrasonic features of tonsillar lymphoma to improve the diagnostic accuracy... Conclusions: The ultrasonic features of tonsillar lymphoma include hypoechoic area, clear boundary, full shape, irregular and uniform internal echo, no or low linear signal of internal blood flow.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Weight Loss", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Weight loss", "term": {"id": "HP:0001824", "label": "Weight loss"}}}

name: Lymphadenopathy
notes: Swelling of lymph nodes, typically in the neck but can be in other regions as well.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Lymphadenopathy", "notes": "Swelling of lymph nodes, typically in the neck but can be in other regions as well."}
raw_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference supports the statement that primary tonsillar lymphoma is frequently associated with lymphadenopathy, particularly in the neck.", "reference": "PMID:24387945", "snippet": "The most common clinical manifestations found in children with lymphoma in palatine tonsils were unilateral tonsillar enlargement (72.7%), alteration in appearance of the tonsil (45.4%) and cervical lymphadenopathy (30.3%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference indicates that lymphoma can frequently involve the head and neck region, which includes the tonsils, but does not specifically mention lymphadenopathy.", "reference": "PMID:2190267", "snippet": "The head and neck is the second most common site for extranodal lymphoma. It can involve virtually any region, including the orbit, paranasal sinuses, Waldeyer's ring, salivary glands, or thyroid.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference discusses lymphadenopathy in the context of metastatic melanoma, not primary tonsillar lymphoma.", "reference": "PMID:38779794", "snippet": "A 30-year-old female patient presented with a swelling of a cervical left lymph node measuring 1x3 cm, which had been presenting for three weeks. Lymph node excision revealed a metastasis of a malignant melanoma, but the primary tumor was not found.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This reference is about histiocytic sarcoma, not primary tonsillar lymphoma.", "reference": "PMID:32719287", "snippet": "Histiocytic sarcoma (HS) is an extremely rare and aggressive hematopoietic tumor.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Lymphadenopathy", "notes": "Swelling of lymph nodes, typically in the neck but can be in other regions as well.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Lymphadenopathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0002716", "label": "Lymphadenopathy"}}}

name: Sore Throat
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "ENT", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Sore Throat"}
raw_json: {"category": "ENT", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference discusses the rarity of primary tongue lymphoma, implying that similar conditions like primary tonsillar lymphoma are also rare, but does not provide evidence regarding the frequency of sore throat as a symptom.", "reference": "PMID:35373599", "snippet": "Primary tongue lymphoma is exceedingly rare, with only case reports or small case series in the literature.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This reference discusses the ultrasonic features of tonsillar lymphoma but does not provide information on the frequency of sore throat as a symptom.", "reference": "PMID:38742359", "snippet": "The ultrasonic features of tonsillar lymphoma include hypoechoic area, clear boundary, full shape, irregular and uniform internal echo, no or low linear signal of internal blood flow.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "While this case report mentions sore throat as a symptom in a child with extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma involving the tonsil, it does not provide sufficient evidence to categorize sore throat as a frequent symptom of primary tonsillar lymphoma.", "reference": "PMID:39080655", "snippet": "A 13-year-old girl presented with an unexplained sore throat for more than 2 months, together with intermittent fever and suppurative tonsilitis.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Sore Throat"}

name: Dysphagia
notes: Difficulty swallowing.

raw_json: {"category": "ENT", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates that dysphagia is a common presenting symptom in tonsillar lymphoma.", "reference": "PMID:3891063", "snippet": "Tonsillar and base of tongue lesions presented with sore throat and dysphagia, whereas nasopharyngeal lymphomas most commonly presented with nasal, auditory, and cranial nerve sympatomatology.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Although the specific symptoms are not detailed, the detection of tonsillar lymphoma via esophagogastroduodenoscopy suggests an association with dysphagia.", "reference": "PMID:38044117", "snippet": "Tonsillar Peripheral T-cell Lymphoma Detected by Esophagogastroduodenoscopy.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Dysphagia", "notes": "Difficulty swallowing.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Dysphagia", "term": {"id": "HP:0002015", "label": "Dysphagia"}}}

name: Overgrowth
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Overgrowth"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This highlights skin and bony overgrowth as common manifestations.", "reference": "DOI:10.1093/hmg/ddz116", "snippet": "Common manifestations include skin and bony overgrowth, vascular malformations (VMs), cysts and benign tumors.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This describes the characteristic disproportionate overgrowth in Proteus syndrome.", "reference": "DOI:10.1055/a-2300-7002", "snippet": "It is characterized by a disproportionate, asymmetric overgrowth of all types of tissues, provoked by a somatic activating mutation in serine/threonine protein kinase 1.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "GeneReviews describes the hallmark progressive segmental overgrowth in Proteus syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:22876373", "snippet": "Proteus syndrome (PS) is characterized by progressive segmental or patchy overgrowth most commonly affecting the skeleton, skin, adipose, and central nervous systems.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This case report emphasizes disproportionate connective tissue overgrowth.", "reference": "PMID:33987133", "snippet": "Proteus syndrome is an extremely rare disorder that manifests as an asymmetric, disproportionate overgrowth of any connective tissue, such as bone, fat or epidermal nevi, in a mosaic or patchy pattern.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Overgrowth", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Overgrowth", "term": {"id": "HP:0001548", "label": "Overgrowth"}}}

name: Inability to Belch
description: Complete or near-complete inability to belch (eructate), which is the cardinal feature of R-CPD. Patients cannot voluntarily or reflexively release gas from the esophagus through the pharynx.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Complete or near-complete inability to belch (eructate), which is the cardinal feature of R-CPD. Patients cannot voluntarily or reflexively release gas from the esophagus through the pharynx.", "frequency": "Common", "name": "Inability to Belch"}
raw_json: {"description": "Complete or near-complete inability to belch (eructate), which is the cardinal feature of R-CPD. Patients cannot voluntarily or reflexively release gas from the esophagus through the pharynx.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This landmark paper defined R-CPD and established inability to belch as the cardinal feature.", "reference": "PMID:31236539", "snippet": "To propose and test the validity of a new syndrome called retrograde cricopharyngeus dysfunction (R-CPD) that explains inability to belch and the associated symptoms of loud gurgling noises, chest and abdominal pain/distention, and excessive flatulence", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The Pavesi 2023 case report reiterates inability to burp as the defining symptom of R-CPD.", "reference": "PMID:37621856", "snippet": "A large constellation of hitherto unexplained symptoms including inability to burp, gurgling noises from the chest and lower neck, abdominal bloating, flatulence, painful hiccups and emetophobia was defined as Retrograde Cricopharyngeus Dysfunction (R-CPD) in 2019.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The Jimnez-Castillo 2025 series states the hallmark symptom is inability to belch.", "reference": "PMID:38767031", "snippet": "The incapacity to belch is the hallmark of the disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The Jefferson case series quantifies inability to burp as the dominant presenting symptom.", "reference": "PMID:36054518", "snippet": "The inability to burp (98.8%), bloating (92.9%), gurgling noises (31.8%), and excessive flatulence (21.2%) were the most common symptoms.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Survey data reinforce inability to burp as near-universal among affected patients.", "reference": "PMID:38115814", "snippet": "99% reported inability to burp, 98% reported abdominal bloating, 93% reported socially awkward gurgling noises, 89% reported excessive flatulence.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "Common", "name": "Inability to Belch", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abnormality of the digestive system", "term": {"id": "HP:0025031", "label": "Abnormality of the digestive system"}}}

raw_json: {"description": "Abdominal bloating and distension due to trapped air that cannot be expelled through belching.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Bloating (abdominal distention) is described as part of the core symptom complex of R-CPD.", "reference": "PMID:35122356", "snippet": "The associated symptom complex includes some combination of chest pain, gurgling noises in the chest, bloating, nausea, hiccups, and flatulence.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The Pavesi 2023 case report lists abdominal bloating as a key symptom.", "reference": "PMID:37621856", "snippet": "A large constellation of hitherto unexplained symptoms including inability to burp, gurgling noises from the chest and lower neck, abdominal bloating, flatulence, painful hiccups and emetophobia was defined as Retrograde Cricopharyngeus Dysfunction (R-CPD) in 2019.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Community survey data show abdominal bloating affects nearly all respondents with R-CPD.", "reference": "PMID:38115814", "snippet": "99% reported inability to burp, 98% reported abdominal bloating, 93% reported socially awkward gurgling noises, 89% reported excessive flatulence.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "Common", "name": "Abdominal Distention", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abdominal distention", "term": {"id": "HP:0003270", "label": "Abdominal distention"}}}

Joint deformities are more likely to be seen in children with long-standing disease, those with polyarthritis JIA and seropositive patients.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This literature clearly supports that RA often presents as symmetric arthritis, aligning with the statement.", "reference": "PMID:37410796", "snippet": "Incident RA presents mainly as symmetric arthritis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference reinforces that symmetric polyarthritis is characteristic of RA, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:37158761", "snippet": "Symmetrical involvement of the hand joints is described as characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While this reference mentions systemic and joint involvement, it does not specifically address symmetric polyarthritis or its frequency.", "reference": "PMID:22035393", "snippet": "Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic, systemic inflammatory disorder affecting multiple organ systems, joints, ligaments, and bones and commonly involves the cervical spine.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This suggests a genetic predisposition to more severe and chronic forms of RA, which could include symmetric polyarthritis, thus supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:11358413", "snippet": "RA is now thought to be associated with a conserved sequence of amino acids in a number of HLA-DRB1 alleles, called the RA shared epitope", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Symmetric Polyarthritis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Symmetric Polyarthritis", "term": {"id": "HP:0040311", "label": "Symmetric polyarthritis"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Joint Deformity"}, {"target": "Reduced Mobility"}]}

ExRA manifestations are not uncommon, explain excess mortality in RA and are predicted by smoking and autoantibodies.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference confirms RA-ILD as a significant extra-articular manifestation, but it does not detail its specific frequency.", "reference": "PMID:38411210", "snippet": "RA-associated interstitial lung disease (RA-ILD) is a major contributor to mortality, with no decline in incidence and scant therapeutic options.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference indicates that interstitial lung disease is a common pulmonary manifestation of RA, but does not quantify how often it occurs.", "reference": "PMID:31376890", "snippet": "The most common intrathoracic manifestations of RA include interstitial lung disease, airway disease, pleural disease, rheumatoid nodules, and drug-induced toxicity.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Interstitial Lung Disease"}

name: Boutonniere Deformity

raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference describes the occurrence of boutonniere deformity in the context of rheumatoid arthritis, supporting the statement that it is a frequent musculoskeletal issue associated with this condition.", "reference": "PMID:2661577", "snippet": "The pathology of the boutonniere begins with a synovitis of the joint, followed by elongation al the central slip, subluxation of the later bands, and contracture of the retinacular ligaments.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study indicates that bone erosions, including those leading to deformities like boutonniere, are common in rheumatoid arthritis patients.", "reference": "PMID:34628456", "snippet": "Bone erosion can be observed at the DIP joint in patients with RA, and these cases frequently shows bone erosions of other finger joints, such as PIP joint.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference discusses the prevalence of hand deformities in rheumatoid arthritis, indicating that such deformities, including boutonniere, significantly impact the working space of the hand.", "reference": "PMID:19474183", "snippet": "The average working space volume was 4921 cc in rheumatoid patients with no visible hand deformity and 1154 cc in the presence of combined finger deformities (P < 0.005).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Boutonniere Deformity", "notes": "Flexion contracture of PIP joint with hyperextension of DIP joint"}

However, the literature indicates that it occurs in almost 10% of RA patients, suggesting it is not merely occasional but more common.", "reference": "PMID:33346115", "snippet": "Secondary Sjgren's syndrome and pulmonary manifestations are observed in almost 10% of patients, also in the early disease", "supports": "REFUTE"}, {"explanation": "The study found that secondary Sjogren's syndrome (sSS) has a prevalence of 5.9% among RA patients, and 27.7% of RA patients reported sicca symptoms. This indicates that sSS is not just an occasional manifestation but occurs with a higher frequency.", "reference": "PMID:27424016", "snippet": "Our results demonstrated that the prevalence of sSS was 5.9% (CI:0.6%-10.5%). Number of 27.7% of RA patients positively responded to at least one question about sicca symptoms.", "supports": "REFUTE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Sicca Syndrome", "notes": "Dry eyes and mouth due to secondary Sjogren's syndrome"}

name: Scleritis
notes: Inflammation of the sclera of the eye
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Extra-articular", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Scleritis", "notes": "Inflammation of the sclera of the eye"}
raw_json: {"category": "Extra-articular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference indicates that scleritis is part of the spectrum of eye involvement in rheumatoid arthritis, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:20559644", "snippet": "The main spectrum of eye involvement comprises keratoconjunctivitis sicca, episcleritis and scleritis as well as ulcerative keratitis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports that scleritis is associated with rheumatoid arthritis.", "reference": "PMID:37344292", "snippet": "Rheumatoid arthritis and systemic vasculitides, particularly antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA)-associated vasculitides, are the main autoimmune causes of scleritis and episcleritis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference confirms that rheumatoid arthritis is a common systemic association with scleritis.", "reference": "PMID:30412434", "snippet": "Rheumatoid arthritis and Wegener granulomatosis were the 2 most common systemic associations among our cohort.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the association between rheumatoid arthritis and scleritis.", "reference": "PMID:10879785", "snippet": "Ocular manifestations commonly include episcleritis, scleritis, conjunctivitis, iridocyclitis, chorioretinitis, and proptosis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Scleritis", "notes": "Inflammation of the sclera of the eye", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Scleritis", "term": {"id": "HP:0100532", "label": "Scleritis"}}}

name: Pericarditis
notes: Inflammation of the pericardium
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Pericarditis", "notes": "Inflammation of the pericardium"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference confirms that pericarditis can be present in systemic inflammatory rheumatic diseases, including rheumatoid arthritis, indicating it can occur as a cardiovascular manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:33216192", "snippet": "Pericarditis is the term for inflammatory involvement of the pericardium, which can be associated with pericardial effusion and myocardial involvement (perimyocarditis). Pericarditis can be present in the context of systemic inflammatory rheumatic diseases but can also constitute a distinct disease entity.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference directly states that pericardial effusion, which is indicative of pericarditis, is common in rheumatoid arthritis patients, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:11055006", "snippet": "Pericardial effusion is common in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. It is essentially a sign of pericardial involvement of the rheumatoid disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Pericarditis", "notes": "Inflammation of the pericardium", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Pericarditis", "term": {"id": "HP:0001701", "label": "Pericarditis"}}}

name: Felty's Syndrome
notes: Combination of rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Felty's Syndrome", "notes": "Combination of rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature confirms that Felty's Syndrome is a hematologic condition associated with rheumatoid arthritis, occurring occasionally (approximately 1% of patients with RA).", "reference": "PMID:1862580", "snippet": "Felty's syndrome (FS) consists of the triad: rheumatoid arthritis (RA), leukopenia and splenomegaly. FS occurs in approximately 1% of patients with RA.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature supports that Felty's Syndrome is a hematologic manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis, occurring occasionally.", "reference": "PMID:12455813", "snippet": "The hematological manifestations can be conveniently categorized into the broad areas of; anemia, particularly NSAID induced iron deficiency anemia and the anemia of chronic disease, neutropenia, particularly Felty's syndrome and the large granular lymphocyte syndrome and drug induced neutropenia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature supports that Felty's Syndrome is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, even in the absence of splenomegaly, indicating it as a hematologic condition.", "reference": "PMID:312016", "snippet": "Thus, patients with rheumatoid arthritis without overt splenic enlargement may have pathophysiologic Felty's syndrome, and in vitro studies such as these may be used to define this process.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Felty's Syndrome", "notes": "Combination of rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia"}
