name: Recurrent Infections
notes: Frequent and severe bacterial infections due to immunodeficiency.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Immunologic", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Recurrent Infections", "notes": "Frequent and severe bacterial infections due to immunodeficiency."}
raw_json: {"category": "Immunologic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference confirms that Roifman syndrome is an immunologic disorder and mentions immunodeficiency, but it does not provide explicit details about the frequency or severity of recurrent infections.", "reference": "PMID:35450878", "snippet": "Roifman syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive inherited syndromic immunodeficiency. We wish to add to the available literature by reporting two brothers with clinical, radiological and immunological features of Roifman syndrome, confirmed on whole exome sequencing.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference describes Roifman syndrome as having immunodeficiency complications, but does not specifically mention the frequency or severity of recurrent infections.", "reference": "PMID:33059947", "snippet": "Roifman syndrome is an allelic disorder of MOPD I that is characterized by immunodeficiency complications.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Recurrent Infections", "notes": "Frequent and severe bacterial infections due to immunodeficiency.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Recurrent Infections", "term": {"id": "HP:0002719", "label": "Recurrent infections"}}}

name: Growth Retardation
notes: Short stature and skeletal abnormalities, such as shortened limbs.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Skeletal", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Growth Retardation", "notes": "Short stature and skeletal abnormalities, such as shortened limbs."}
raw_json: {"category": "Skeletal", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference mentions new radiological features but does not explicitly confirm that growth retardation and skeletal abnormalities are very frequent in Roifman syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:35450878", "snippet": "Roifman syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive inherited syndromic immunodeficiency... New radiological features are also described here which may assist in the diagnosis of other patients.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The reference mentions Roifman syndrome as a skeletal dysplasia with developmental delay and microcephaly, but does not explicitly confirm short stature and skeletal abnormalities as very frequent.", "reference": "PMID:29265708", "snippet": "RNU4ATAC pathogenic variants to date have been associated with microcephalic osteodysplastic primordial dwarfism, type 1 and Roifman syndrome. Both conditions are clinically distinct skeletal dysplasias... Some of the overlapping features of the two conditions include developmental delay, microcephaly, and immune deficiency.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Growth Retardation", "notes": "Short stature and skeletal abnormalities, such as shortened limbs.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Growth Retardation", "term": {"id": "HP:0001510", "label": "Growth delay"}}}

name: Acanthosis nigricans
description: Hyperpigmented, velvety, thickened skin typically in flexural areas (neck, axillae, groin). This distinctive skin finding is not seen in achondroplasia or thanatophoric dysplasia and is part of the defining features of SADDAN.

name: Prenatal Hydrops Fetalis
description: Excessive accumulation of serous fluid in the fetus (nonimmune hydrops fetalis), which can be a presenting feature of infantile-onset FSASD. Detectable on prenatal ultrasound at 24 weeks gestation or earlier.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Excessive accumulation of serous fluid in the fetus (nonimmune hydrops fetalis), which can be a presenting feature of infantile-onset FSASD. Detectable on prenatal ultrasound at 24 weeks gestation or earlier.", "name": "Prenatal Hydrops Fetalis"}
raw_json: {"description": "Excessive accumulation of serous fluid in the fetus (nonimmune hydrops fetalis), which can be a presenting feature of infantile-onset FSASD. Detectable on prenatal ultrasound at 24 weeks gestation or earlier.", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "Case report demonstrates prenatal hydrops as a presenting feature of infantile-onset FSASD, with fetal hydrops detected at 24 weeks gestation.", "reference": "PMID:34667062", "snippet": "Nonimmune hydrops fetalis, the excessive accumulation of serous fluid in the subcutaneous tissues and serous cavities of the fetus, has many possible etiologies, providing a diagnostic challenge for the physician. Lysosomal storage diseases have been reported in up to 5%-16% of nonimmune hydrops fetalis pregnancies. Infantile free sialic acid storage disease (ISSD) (OMIM #269920) is a severe form of autosomal recessive sialic acid storage disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Prenatal Hydrops Fetalis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Nonimmune hydrops fetalis", "term": {"id": "HP:0001790", "label": "Nonimmune hydrops fetalis"}}}

name: Hallucinations
notes: Often auditory in nature, such as hearing voices. Can also be visual, tactile, or olfactory.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Psychiatric", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hallucinations", "notes": "Often auditory in nature, such as hearing voices. Can also be visual, tactile, or olfactory."}
raw_json: {"category": "Psychiatric", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Delusions and hallucinations are recognized as common symptom clusters in schizophrenia, supporting the statement that hallucinations are frequent and a part of the psychiatric diagnostic category.", "reference": "PMID:28437056", "snippet": "Schizophrenia symptoms fall into six common symptom clusters: delusions and hallucinations, disorganization of speech, cognitive dysfunction, negative symptoms, affective symptoms, and motor system abnormalities.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This supports the note that hallucinations in schizophrenia can be auditory, visual, tactile, or olfactory in nature, indicating changes in sensory processing.", "reference": "PMID:25773224", "snippet": "Schizophrenia is a complex mental disorder associated with not only cognitive dysfunctions, such as memory and attention deficits, but also changes in basic sensory processing.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This supports the claim that olfactory hallucinations are among the types of hallucinations experienced by schizophrenic patients, although less frequent than auditory hallucinations.", "reference": "PMID:21545448", "snippet": "Prevalence of OHs and hallucinations in other modalities differed according to the WHO-10 international centre. Across centres, OHs were present in 13% of the WHO-10 dataset, similar to the 17% prevalence rate in the SAPS/SANS dataset.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This supports the auditory nature of hallucinations (hearing voices) but does not provide comprehensive support for visual, tactile, or olfactory hallucinations.", "reference": "PMID:35383683", "snippet": "We found that a substantial proportion of patients could not clearly distinguish between thinking and hallucinating. The emotional tone of the voices increased in negativity.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Hallucinations", "notes": "Often auditory in nature, such as hearing voices. Can also be visual, tactile, or olfactory.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hallucinations", "term": {"id": "HP:0000738", "label": "Hallucinations"}}}

name: Delusions
notes: False beliefs, often paranoid or grandiose in nature. Resistant to contradictory evidence.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Psychiatric", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Delusions", "notes": "False beliefs, often paranoid or grandiose in nature. Resistant to contradictory evidence."}
raw_json: {"category": "Psychiatric", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature describes delusions as false beliefs that are resistant to contradictory evidence, which aligns with the statement's note that delusions in schizophrenia are often paranoid or grandiose in nature.", "reference": "PMID:33485408", "snippet": "Delusions are commonly conceived as false beliefs that are held with certainty and which cannot be corrected. This conception of delusion has been influential throughout the history of psychiatry and continues to inform how delusions are approached in clinical practice and in contemporary schizophrenia research.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While Capgras delusion may involve delusions, the reference suggests that these delusions are not exclusively found in paranoid schizophrenia. This partially supports the statement but adds another layer of complexity.", "reference": "PMID:949230", "snippet": "The underlying diagnosis of Capgras delusion is not found to be exclusively paranoid schizophrenia, nor is the sex exclusively female, as once was believed.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The description of non-bizarre delusions aligns with the statement that delusions, which are false beliefs, are a frequent psychiatric diagnostic category in schizophrenia.", "reference": "PMID:29151090", "snippet": "Non-bizarre delusion, defined as a false belief possible although highly unlikely, is the main manifestation of delusional disorders, previously known as paranoia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement as it mentions paranoid and grandiose delusions being prevalent in patients with schizophrenia.", "reference": "PMID:24677735", "snippet": "Persecutory and/or grandiose delusions were more strongly associated with each offender group compared with non-offenders, most so with late first offenders.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Delusions", "notes": "False beliefs, often paranoid or grandiose in nature. Resistant to contradictory evidence.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Delusions", "term": {"id": "HP:0000746", "label": "Delusion"}}}

name: Disorganized Thinking
notes: Impaired logical thought process and communication. May manifest as loose associations or incoherent speech.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cognitive", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Disorganized Thinking", "notes": "Impaired logical thought process and communication. May manifest as loose associations or incoherent speech."}
raw_json: {"category": "Cognitive", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Disorganized thinking is closely related to disorganized speech, which is highlighted as a frequent impairment in schizophrenia.", "reference": "PMID:30488088", "snippet": "Disorganized speech is one of the key symptoms of schizophrenia. This article provides an overview of those areas of speech and communication impaired in patients with schizophrenia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study highlights disordered thinking (a form of cognitive impairment) as a main symptom in later stages of schizophrenia.", "reference": "PMID:2084786", "snippet": "The course of psychoses of schizophrenic type follows rules which are still not adequately understood. It is, however, clear that certain symptoms appear mostly early, others only late... we studied 44 final phase patients whose main symptom was disordered thinking of the schizophasic type.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Impaired logical thought processes and communication, which might manifest as loose associations or incoherent speech, align with the cognitive phenotype of disorganized thinking.", "reference": "PMID:37040138", "snippet": "Patients with schizophrenia were impaired in both analytic and common-sense thinking.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Linguistic disorganization and impoverishment of clause complexity are reflective of impaired logical thought process and communication, supporting the cognitive phenotype of disorganized thinking.", "reference": "PMID:35752547", "snippet": "We conclude that an early drift towards linguistic disorganization/impoverishment of clause complexity-at the granular level of nominal subject per clause-is a distinctive feature of schizophrenia that decreases longitudinally, thus differentiating schizophrenia from other psychotic illnesses with shared phenomenology.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While the study discusses delusional thinking with little evidence of cognitive impairment in paranoid patients, it does suggest that cognitive mechanisms in schizophrenia may differ, providing partial support to the cognitive phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:17477206", "snippet": "The data of interest are (a) the failure to find evidence of cognitive impairment in diagnosed paranoid patients...", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Disorganized Thinking", "notes": "Impaired logical thought process and communication. May manifest as loose associations or incoherent speech."}

name: Social Withdrawal
notes: Reduction in social interactions and engagement. Can lead to isolation and difficulty maintaining relationships.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Occupational", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Social Withdrawal", "notes": "Reduction in social interactions and engagement. Can lead to isolation and difficulty maintaining relationships."}
raw_json: {"category": "Occupational", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates that social withdrawal is a significant aspect of schizophrenia and is frequently observed among patients.", "reference": "PMID:31390645", "snippet": "A 'positively withdrawn' position characterizes a wider group of patients than originally reported. Further, we identified a preference for partaking in social activities in particular circumstances with clearly circumscribed goals or social roles and rules.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study confirms the association between social withdrawal and various neurocognitive deficits in schizophrenia, supporting its frequent occurrence.", "reference": "PMID:35102081", "snippet": "Social withdrawal was measured by a specific item of the Heinrichs-Carpenter Quality of Life Scale. Social withdrawal was associated with a lower score in the neurocognitive composite score and in 'Verbal memory,' 'Processing speed' and 'Working memory' scores.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The review details social withdrawal as a prominent negative symptom in schizophrenia, further corroborating its frequent occurrence.", "reference": "PMID:11103877", "snippet": "Negative symptoms encompass, among others, anhedonia, flat affect, avolition and social withdrawal.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The paper discusses social withdrawal as a central component of social disability in schizophrenia.", "reference": "PMID:28637195", "snippet": "Social disability is a defining characteristic of schizophrenia... One component, social disconnection, occurs extensively... Social disconnection is an objective, long-standing lack of social/family relationships and minimal participation in social activities.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Social Withdrawal", "notes": "Reduction in social interactions and engagement. Can lead to isolation and difficulty maintaining relationships."}

name: Flat Affect
notes: Reduced expression of emotions. May appear unresponsive or lacking emotional depth.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Mood", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Flat Affect", "notes": "Reduced expression of emotions. May appear unresponsive or lacking emotional depth."}
raw_json: {"category": "Mood", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study provides evidence that flat affect is a frequent and prominent clinical feature of schizophrenia, which aligns with the statement.", "reference": "PMID:16452608", "snippet": "Impaired emotional functioning in schizophrenia is a prominent clinical feature that manifests primarily as flat affect... Flat affect was more common in men and was associated with poorer premorbid adjustment, worse current quality of life, and worse outcome at 1-year follow-up.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference suggests that flat affect, which is an emotional deficit, is part of the clinical phenotype of schizophrenia.", "reference": "PMID:23846857", "snippet": "Schizophrenia probands showed more symptoms and lower psychosocial functioning than probands with psychotic bipolar disorder, but there was considerable overlap in clinical manifestations.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study mentions flat affect as one of the core negative symptoms of schizophrenia, supporting its frequent occurrence within the schizophrenia phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:31839552", "snippet": "Voice atypicalities have been a characteristic feature of schizophrenia ... They are often associated with core negative symptoms such as flat affect and alogia ... This suggests that voice atypicalities may represent a marker of clinical features and social functioning in schizophrenia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This review states that flat affect is one of the negative symptoms associated with schizophrenia, supporting the frequent occurrence.", "reference": "PMID:11103877", "snippet": "In schizophrenia, negative symptoms encompass, among others, anhedonia, flat affect, avolition, and social withdrawal.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study discusses emotional deficits in groups at risk for schizophrenia, implying the presence of flat affect as a frequent feature.", "reference": "PMID:28242515", "snippet": "Both extreme levels of social anhedonia (SocAnh) and extreme levels of perceptual aberration/magical ideation (PerMag) indicate increased risk for schizophrenia-spectrum disorders and are associated with emotional deficits.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Even though flat affect is not explicitly mentioned, the reference discusses emotional and cognitive impairments, supporting the statement indirectly.", "reference": "PMID:11122987", "snippet": "The schizophrenia phenotype has been traditionally defined by chronic psychosis and functional deterioration ... Subtle clinical signs and symptoms, cognitive impairment particularly in attention and memory, and neurophysiologic deficits such as in sensory gating and smooth-pursuit eye movements all define aspects of the schizophrenia phenotype.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Flat Affect", "notes": "Reduced expression of emotions. May appear unresponsive or lacking emotional depth."}

name: Working Memory Deficits
notes: Difficulties in short-term information storage and manipulation.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cognitive", "frequency": "COMMON", "name": "Working Memory Deficits", "notes": "Difficulties in short-term information storage and manipulation."}
raw_json: {"category": "Cognitive", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Evidence suggests there is a working memory deficit phenotype within schizophrenia.", "reference": "PMID:36252418", "snippet": "Our data gives preliminary support to the hypotheses that there is a working memory deficit phenotype within the syndrome of schizophrenia with has a biological underpinning.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature highlights WM deficits as a central part of cognitive impairment in schizophrenia.", "reference": "PMID:30104335", "snippet": "PFC dysfunction is widely believed to underlie working memory (WM) deficits in people with schizophrenia (PSZ)...These results indicate that PPC dysfunction is central to WM storage deficits in PSZ and may play a key role in the broad cognitive deficits associated with schizophrenia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study directly supports the existence of working memory deficits as a core phenotype in schizophrenia.", "reference": "PMID:20053864", "snippet": "Working memory impairment is considered a core deficit in schizophrenia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Although the snippet is general, cognitive deficits typically encompass working memory as part of the broader impairment in schizophrenia.", "reference": "PMID:19328655", "snippet": "It is characterized by an admixture of positive, negative, cognitive, mood, and motor symptoms whose severity varies across patients and through the course of the illness.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "COMMON", "name": "Working Memory Deficits", "notes": "Difficulties in short-term information storage and manipulation."}

name: Catatonia
notes: Abnormal motor behavior, ranging from excessive movement to immobility.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Behavioral", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Catatonia", "notes": "Abnormal motor behavior, ranging from excessive movement to immobility."}
raw_json: {"category": "Behavioral", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference suggests catatonia is associated with schizophrenia but does not specify the frequency of this phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:11478416", "snippet": "Catatonia is a parallel behavior phenomenon to delusions (in thought) and delirium (in cognition).", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The study indicates catatonia is present in some patients with schizophrenia but does not specify its frequency.", "reference": "PMID:34785041", "snippet": "Lower activity levels correlated with increased age and severity of catatonia and parkinsonism. The 22 patients with catatonia had lower activity as well as higher scores on parkinsonism, involuntary movements, and negative symptoms compared to the 30 patients without catatonia.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The literature suggests catatonia, as a motor symptom, is a recognized aspect of schizophrenia.", "reference": "PMID:22814247", "snippet": "Classical schizophrenia literature reports motor symptoms as characteristic of the disorder... This review of the literature supports the idea that motor symptoms are closely related to the neurodevelopmental disturbances of schizophrenia and a distinct syndromal dimension with its own pathophysiology.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Though this reference focus on other symptoms, it indirectly supports catatonia as one of the reported motor symptoms in schizophrenia spectrum conditions.", "reference": "PMID:30177576", "snippet": "Symptoms specific to schizophrenia include self-disturbances, delusional perception and loosening of associations.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study supports the presence of catatonia in schizophrenia but does not clarify the frequency.", "reference": "PMID:37655417", "snippet": "Three forms of periodic catatonia have been identified: hypokinetic, parakinetic, multikinetic.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This case study does not provide evidence about the general frequency of catatonia in schizophrenia.", "reference": "PMID:20587767", "snippet": "Case reports in which abrupt clozapine discontinuation led to a return of psychosis, autonomic instability, or catatonia.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Catatonia", "notes": "Abnormal motor behavior, ranging from excessive movement to immobility."}

name: Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return
description: Anomalous pulmonary venous return from the right lung to the inferior vena cava, creating a left-to-right shunt. This is the defining anatomic feature of scimitar syndrome and is present in all cases.

name: Pulmonary arterial hypertension
description: Elevated pulmonary artery pressure resulting from the left-to-right shunt, anomalous systemic arterial supply, reduced pulmonary vascular bed, or pulmonary venous stenosis. More common and severe in the infantile form and a major determinant of prognosis.

More common and severe in the infantile form and a major determinant of prognosis.\n", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Pulmonary arterial hypertension"}

name: Recurrent respiratory infections
description: Recurrent pneumonia or bronchitis affecting the right lower lobe, related to anomalous arterial supply, bronchial abnormalities, or sequestration-like physiology. Reported in approximately one-sixth of patients on long-term follow-up even after surgical intervention.

name: Dextroposition of the heart
description: Rightward displacement of the heart within the thorax secondary to reduced right lung volume, rather than true dextrocardia (mirror-image reversal of cardiac structures). Reported in approximately 55% of cases.

name: Congestive heart failure
description: Right-sided heart failure from volume overload due to the left-to-right shunt. More common in the infantile form and may present with failure to thrive, tachypnea, and hepatomegaly.

raw_json: {"category": "Vestibular", "description": "Vestibular symptoms including eye movements (nystagmus) induced by loud sounds, also known as Tullio phenomenon.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The biomechanics review confirms that sound-evoked nystagmus (Tullio phenomenon) is a characteristic feature of third window syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:32982922", "snippet": "Sound-evoked vertigo or nystagmus are now termed \"Tullio phenomenon,\" often exhibited as a symptom of third window syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Sound-Induced Nystagmus", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Nystagmus", "term": {"id": "HP:0000639", "label": "Nystagmus"}}}

name: Conductive Hearing Loss
description: Low-frequency conductive hearing loss due to shunting of acoustic energy through the dehiscence rather than to the cochlea. Characterized by air-bone gap with sometimes supranormal bone conduction thresholds.

raw_json: {"category": "Auditory", "description": "Low-frequency conductive hearing loss due to shunting of acoustic energy through the dehiscence rather than to the cochlea. Characterized by air-bone gap with sometimes supranormal bone conduction thresholds.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This landmark paper explains the mechanism of pseudoconductive hearing loss in third window lesions.", "reference": "PMID:18223508", "snippet": "The CHL results by the dual mechanism of worsening of air conduction thresholds and improvement of bone conduction thresholds.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Clinical data demonstrates the characteristic low-frequency air-bone gap pattern in SCDS patients.", "reference": "PMID:16222184", "snippet": "An air-bone on audiometry in these patients with vestibular manifestations measured (mean +/- SD) 19 +/- 14 dB at 250 Hz; 15 +/- 11 dB at 500 Hz; 11 +/- 9 dB at 1,000 Hz; and 4 +/- 6 dB at 2,000 Hz.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Conductive Hearing Loss", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Conductive hearing impairment", "term": {"id": "HP:0000405", "label": "Conductive hearing impairment"}}}

scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy"}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiovascular", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This case report documents hypertrophic cardiomyopathy as a core feature of Sengers syndrome.", "reference": "DOI:10.3389/fped.2021.639687", "snippet": "Both infants had typical clinical features characterized by hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, bilateral cataracts, myopathy, and lactic acidosis, and heart failure was the most severe manifestation.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This longitudinal case report reiterates hypertrophic cardiomyopathy as a defining feature.", "reference": "DOI:10.1186/s13052-022-01370-y", "snippet": "Sengers syndrome is characterized by congenital cataract, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, mitochondrial myopathy, and lactic acidosis associated with mutations in AGK gene.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0001639", "label": "Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy"}}}

name: Diarrhea
description: Watery diarrhea due to intestinal inflammation and increased fluid secretion. Often progresses to bloody diarrhea (dysentery) as mucosal invasion and ulceration occur.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Watery diarrhea due to intestinal inflammation and increased fluid secretion. Often progresses to bloody diarrhea (dysentery) as mucosal invasion and ulceration occur.\n", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Diarrhea"}

Often progresses to bloody diarrhea (dysentery) as mucosal invasion and ulceration occur.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Establishes diarrhea as a cardinal clinical feature of shigellosis resulting from epithelial damage and inflammatory secretion", "reference": "PMID:29493962", "snippet": "The main symptom of shigellosis is bloody and often mucoid diarrhea; abdominal pain and vomiting are common", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Diarrhea", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Diarrhea", "term": {"id": "HP:0002014", "label": "Diarrhea"}}}

name: Bloody diarrhea

This is the hallmark symptom of shigellosis and bacterial dysentery.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Establishes bloody diarrhea as the defining characteristic of Shigella pathogenesis due to colonic epithelial destruction", "reference": "PMID:37952487", "snippet": "bacillary dysentery, a severe enteric disease characterized by destruction and inflammation of the colonic epithelium accompanied by acute diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Bloody diarrhea", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Bloody diarrhea", "term": {"id": "HP:0025085", "label": "Bloody diarrhea"}}}

name: Acute Chest Syndrome
notes: Leading cause of death
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Acute Chest Syndrome", "notes": "Leading cause of death"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Neutrophil activation and hemolysis contribute to vascular occlusion and acute complications like acute chest syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:24620350", "snippet": "Sickle cell disease (SCD) is characterized by recurring episodes of vascular occlusion in which neutrophil activation plays a major role. The disease is associated with chronic hemolysis with elevated cell-free hemoglobin and heme.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Heme triggers neutrophil extracellular trap formation, which contributes to acute lung injury and acute chest syndrome in sickle cell disease.", "reference": "PMID:24620350", "snippet": "we have identified a novel role for heme in the induction of neutrophil extracellular trap (NET) formation in SCD. NETs are decondensed chromatin decorated by granular enzymes and are released by activated neutrophils.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Acute Chest Syndrome", "notes": "Leading cause of death", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Respiratory Distress", "term": {"id": "HP:0002098", "label": "Respiratory distress"}}}

name: Enophthalmos
description: Posterior displacement of the globe within the orbit due to increased orbital volume from orbital floor descent. This is the hallmark presenting feature of silent sinus syndrome.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "description": "Posterior displacement of the globe within the orbit due to increased orbital volume from orbital floor descent. This is the hallmark presenting feature of silent sinus syndrome.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Enophthalmos"}
raw_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "description": "Posterior displacement of the globe within the orbit due to increased orbital volume from orbital floor descent. This is the hallmark presenting feature of silent sinus syndrome.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The original 1994 paper describes spontaneous enophthalmos as the cardinal presenting feature, unrelated to trauma.", "reference": "PMID:8152774", "snippet": "Spontaneous enophthalmos and hypoglobus, in the absence of other symptoms and unrelated to trauma or surgery", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Confirms enophthalmos as a defining feature of SSS.", "reference": "PMID:23946747", "snippet": "The silent sinus syndrome (SSS) involves painless facial asymmetry and enophthalmos, which is the result of chronic maxillary sinus atelectasis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Case series confirms enophthalmos as the presenting feature with asymptomatic sinus disease.", "reference": "PMID:11404606", "snippet": "Four patients with enophthalmos and asymptomatic maxillary sinus disease were identified.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Enophthalmos", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Deeply set eye", "term": {"id": "HP:0000490", "label": "Deeply set eye"}}}

name: Hypoglobus

name: Brain Metastases

name: Cleft Palate
description: Cleft palate, including submucous cleft palate, is a common feature in SEDC and may be associated with Pierre Robin sequence.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Cleft palate, including submucous cleft palate, is a common feature in SEDC and may be associated with Pierre Robin sequence.\n", "name": "Cleft Palate"}
raw_json: {"description": "Cleft palate, including submucous cleft palate, is a common feature in SEDC and may be associated with Pierre Robin sequence.\n", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This case series documents cleft palate as a common feature of SEDC and notes that submucous cleft palate may be more common than previously appreciated.", "reference": "PMID:11878179", "snippet": "Cleft palate is one of the common features of spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia congenita (SEDC). However, there are few clinical data about cleft palate in SEDC. We report four patients with cleft palate and SEDC including two with overt cleft palate and two with submucous cleft palate.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Cleft Palate", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Cleft palate", "term": {"id": "HP:0000175", "label": "Cleft palate"}}}

name: Membranous Vitreous
description: Characteristic membranous vitreous appearance on slit-lamp examination, pathognomonic for STL1.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Characteristic membranous vitreous appearance on slit-lamp examination, pathognomonic for STL1.\n", "name": "Membranous Vitreous"}
raw_json:
{"description": "Characteristic membranous vitreous appearance on slit-lamp examination, pathognomonic for STL1.
", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "Establishes that the membranous vitreous phenotype is characteristic of all individuals with COL2A1 haploinsufficiency mutations.
", "reference": "PMID:11007540", "snippet": "Premature termination codons in COL2A1 that result in haploinsufficiency of type II collagen are a common finding. These produce a characteristic congenital "membranous" anomaly of the vitreous of all affected individuals.
", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "Vitreous anomalies are significantly associated with confirmed COL2A1 mutations in STL1 patients.
", "reference": "PMID:20179744", "snippet": "Vitreous anomalies and retinal detachments were found more frequently in patients with a COL2A1 mutation compared with the mutation-negative group (P<0.01).
", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Membranous Vitreous", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Membranous vitreous appearance", "term": {"id": "HP:0031153", "label": "Membranous vitreous appearance"}}}

raw_json: {"description": "Congenital high myopia, often severe, is a cardinal feature.\n", "name": "High Myopia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Myopia", "term": {"id": "HP:0000545", "label": "Myopia"}}}

name: Retinal Detachment
description: Significantly increased lifetime risk of retinal detachment, often giant retinal tears. May be bilateral and recurrent.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Significantly increased lifetime risk of retinal detachment, often giant retinal tears. May be bilateral and recurrent.\n", "name": "Retinal Detachment"}
raw_json:
{"description": "Significantly increased lifetime risk of retinal detachment, often giant retinal tears. May be bilateral and recurrent.
", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "Large cohort study of 204 STL1 patients demonstrates the extremely high (73%) retinal detachment rate in untreated patients.
", "reference": "PMID:17675240", "snippet": "Of 111 patients who had no prophylactic retinopexy (group 1; mean age, 49 years), 73% (81/111) suffered RD and 48% (53/111) were bilateral.
", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "Review confirms the high retinal detachment risk in Stickler syndrome.
", "reference": "PMID:20462780", "snippet": "The ocular abnormalities include severe myopia, abnormalities of the vitreous, and a high risk of retinal detachment (60% of cases), which may cause blindness (4% of cases).
", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Retinal Detachment", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Retinal detachment", "term": {"id": "HP:0000541", "label": "Retinal detachment"}}}

name: Sensorineural Hearing Loss
description: Progressive sensorineural hearing loss, typically high-frequency, affects many individuals.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Progressive sensorineural hearing loss, typically high-frequency, affects many individuals.\n", "name": "Sensorineural Hearing Loss"}
raw_json:
{"description": "Progressive sensorineural hearing loss, typically high-frequency, affects many individuals.
", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "Systematic review of 313 Stickler syndrome patients confirms high prevalence of sensorineural hearing loss.
", "reference": "PMID:23110709", "snippet": "Hearing loss was found in 62.9%, mostly mild to moderate when reported. Hearing impairment was predominantly sensorineural (67.8%).
", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "While hearing loss is less frequent in STL1 (COL2A1) than other types, over half of STL1 patients have hearing impairment.
", "reference": "PMID:23110709", "snippet": "Overall, mutations in COL11A1 (82.5%) and COL11A2 (94.1%) seem to be more frequently associated with hearing impairment than mutations in COL2A1 (52.2%).
", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Sensorineural Hearing Loss", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Sensorineural hearing impairment", "term": {"id": "HP:0000407", "label": "Sensorineural hearing impairment"}}}

{"description": "Premature degenerative joint disease, particularly affecting weight-bearing joints.
", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "Review documents high prevalence of early-onset osteoarthritis in Stickler syndrome, with 75% of patients affected before age 30.
", "reference": "PMID:20462780", "snippet": "Osteoarthritis (75% of patients) with onset before 30 years of age is a severe manifestation that causes chronic hip and low back pain and functional impairments. Joint replacement surgery is often required.
", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Premature Osteoarthritis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Premature osteoarthritis", "term": {"id": "HP:0003088", "label": "Premature osteoarthritis"}}}

name: Muscle Rigidity
notes: Continuous stiffness affecting axial and proximal limb muscles, often with a board-like quality. Prominent in truncal muscles.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Muscle Rigidity", "notes": "Continuous stiffness affecting axial and proximal limb muscles, often with a board-like quality. Prominent in truncal muscles."}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "The randomized controlled trial establishes muscle rigidity as a defining characteristic of the syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:11756577", "snippet": "Stiff-person syndrome is a disabling central nervous system disorder with no satisfactory treatment that is characterized by muscle rigidity, episodic muscle spasms, high titers of antibodies against glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD65)", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Muscle Rigidity", "notes": "Continuous stiffness affecting axial and proximal limb muscles, often with a board-like quality. Prominent in truncal muscles.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Rigidity", "term": {"id": "HP:0002063", "label": "Rigidity"}}}

notes: Episodic, often violent, painful spasms triggered by sudden stimuli, emotional stress, or voluntary movement. Can be severe enough to cause fractures.

name: Exaggerated Startle Response

raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference explicitly states that arthritis is one of the most common disease manifestations in patients with SLE.", "reference": "PMID:19591780", "snippet": "Arthritis in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is one of the most common disease manifestations. Nearly all joints can be affected by SLE, but hand and knee involvement are the most typical.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The statement mentions joint pain, which is associated with arthritis and suggests that musculoskeletal symptoms are common in SLE.", "reference": "PMID:27742023", "snippet": "The precise nature of the disorder can be obscure and different disorders can present with similar symptoms, such as joint pain.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference elaborates on the different forms of joint involvement in SLE, including arthropathy, which reinforces the statement that arthritis is a common musculoskeletal phenotype in SLE.", "reference": "PMID:19013374", "snippet": "Systemic lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune and inflammatory disease characterized by a variety of symptoms, including arthropathy. The clinical presentation of joint involvement varies, ranging from arthralgia without erosions or deformity to an erosive arthropathy and severe functional disability.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference indicates a significant association between SLE and joint damage, further supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:32956154", "snippet": "Polyautoimmunity was recorded in 15 patients with RA (13.8%), 43 with SLE (41%), and 2 controls (2.2%). ... In SLE, joint damage (OR, 2.282; p = 0.038) and anti-RNP antibodies (OR, 5.095; p = 0.028) were risk factors for polyautoimmunity...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Arthritis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Arthritis", "term": {"id": "HP:0001369", "label": "Arthritis"}}}

name: Kidney Involvement

raw_json: {"category": "Renal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates that a significant portion of patients with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) exhibit kidney involvement in the form of lupus nephritis (LN).", "reference": "PMID:36251502", "snippet": "Among 365 patients with SLE, 36% had LN.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The classification of pathologic abnormalities in SLE patients includes various forms of lupus nephritis, which confirms kidney involvement.", "reference": "PMID:330103", "snippet": "The pathologic abnormalities present in patients with SLE have been classified as follows: minimal lupus nephritis, mild (focal) proliferative lupus nephritis, severe (diffuse) proliferative lupus nephritis, and membranous lupus nephritis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study highlights that childhood-onset SLE has a high risk of developing nephritis, underlining kidney involvement as a significant phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:30454753", "snippet": "Patients with early onset SLE tend to have a greater genetic component to their disease cause, more multisystemic involvement, and a more severe disease course, which includes greater risks for developing nephritis and end-stage kidney disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Kidney Involvement"}

raw_json: {"category": "Hematologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study reports that leukopenia is prevalent in 22-41.8% of SLE cases, indicating that leukopenia is a frequent hematologic abnormality in SLE patients.", "reference": "PMID:26170228", "snippet": "The prevalence of leukopenia is reported in 22-41.8% of cases.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Although thrombocytopenia was the most prevalent, leukopenia was still present in 14% of the cases, supporting the statement that leukopenia is a frequent hematologic abnormality in SLE patients.", "reference": "PMID:27590999", "snippet": "TCP was the most prevalent hematological abnormality evident in 15%, more than leucopenia (14%) and anemia (2%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study mentions changes in white blood cells, including leukopenia, as a common hematologic manifestation in SLE patients.", "reference": "PMID:8130682", "snippet": "The increased risk of infection in patients with SLE is due in part to changes in the white blood cells though treatments do not yet aim to modify these.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The ACR criteria include leukopenia as a significant hematologic disorder in the diagnosis of SLE, supporting its frequent occurrence.", "reference": "PMID:15580984", "snippet": "In the updated 1982 ACR criteria, the presence of one or more of the four elements: 1) hemolytic anemia (with reticulocytosis); 2) leukopenia (<4000/microL on two or more occasions)... is now considered as a single hematologic disorder.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Leukopenia", "notes": "Low white blood cell count", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Leukopenia", "term": {"id": "HP:0001882", "label": "Decreased total leukocyte count"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Neuropsychiatric", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates that psychosis is an infrequent manifestation of neuropsychiatric systemic lupus erythematosus (NPSLE), which suggests it is not common but does occur occasionally. This partially supports the statement that psychosis is an 'occasional' manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:30375754", "snippet": "Psychosis is an infrequent manifestation of NPSLE. Generally, it occurs early after SLE onset and has a significant negative impact on health status.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This case report describes psychosis as a rare manifestation of NPSLE, occurring in 21% of cases at the onset of SLE. While 'rare' and 'occasional' are not identical, they both imply infrequency, partially supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:37771217", "snippet": "Psychosis is a rare NPSLE manifestation that can occur at any phase of the illness; 21% of SLE-related psychosis cases occur at the onset of SLE.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Psychosis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Psychosis", "term": {"id": "HP:0000709", "label": "Psychosis"}}}

name: Vitelline vascular remnant
description: Remnant of the vitelline duct vasculature that can cause intestinal obstruction; rare gastrointestinal complication in TARP syndrome.

raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Remnant of the vitelline duct vasculature that can cause intestinal obstruction; rare gastrointestinal complication in TARP syndrome.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Omorodion et al. 2023 documents the first reported case of vitelline vascular remnant causing intestinal obstruction in a TARP syndrome patient, expanding the known phenotypic spectrum.", "reference": "PMID:37340830", "snippet": "Vitelline vascular remnants (VVR) are a rare vitelline duct anomaly with approximately 26 cases previously reported. There are no previously reported cases of VVRs in patients with TARP syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "RARE", "name": "Vitelline vascular remnant", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract", "term": {"id": "HP:0011024", "label": "Abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract"}}}

name: Horseshoe kidney
description: Fusion of the bilateral kidneys at the lower poles, forming a horseshoe-shaped structure; rare renal malformation reported in TARP syndrome.

raw_json: {"category": "Renal", "description": "Fusion of the bilateral kidneys at the lower poles, forming a horseshoe-shaped structure; rare renal malformation reported in TARP syndrome.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Manotas et al. 2021 documents a TARP syndrome patient with horseshoe kidney, a previously unreported renal manifestation in this syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:34031074", "snippet": "intrauterine growth restriction, with a persistent left superior vena cava, interatrial communication and a horseshoe kidney", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "RARE", "name": "Horseshoe kidney", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Horseshoe kidney", "term": {"id": "HP:0000085", "label": "Horseshoe kidney"}}}

name: Optic nerve atrophy

name: Intellectual disability

scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "description": "Severe to profound intellectual disability, a consistent feature across TARP syndrome cases affecting cognitive development and learning.", "diagnostic": false, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Intellectual disability"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "description": "Severe to profound intellectual disability, a consistent feature across TARP syndrome cases affecting cognitive development and learning.", "diagnostic": false, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Hjland et al. 2018 documents severe to profound intellectual disability in the first reported adult TARP patient, confirming this as a consistent and persistent feature.", "reference": "PMID:30462380", "snippet": "He was diagnosed with severe to profound intellectual disability in early childhood and had not developed language at age 28 years.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Intellectual disability", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Intellectual disability", "term": {"id": "HP:0001249", "label": "Intellectual disability"}}}

name: Esotropia
description: Inward deviation of the eye(s), an ophthalmic manifestation documented in adult TARP syndrome.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Ophthalmic", "description": "Inward deviation of the eye(s), an ophthalmic manifestation documented in adult TARP syndrome.", "frequency": "RARE", "name": "Esotropia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Ophthalmic", "description": "Inward deviation of the eye(s), an ophthalmic manifestation documented in adult TARP syndrome.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Hjland et al. 2018 documents esotropia as an ophthalmic finding in an adult TARP patient, expanding the known ocular manifestations of the syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:30462380", "snippet": "Clinical examination of the patient revealed sloping forehead, prominent nasal bridge and nose, high myopia, esotropia, displacement of lacrimal points in the cranial direction", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "RARE", "name": "Esotropia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Esotropia", "term": {"id": "HP:0000565", "label": "Esotropia"}}}

name: Scoliosis

raw_json: {"category": "Skeletal", "description": "Abnormal lateral curvature of the spine; rare skeletal manifestation requiring surgical intervention in some TARP patients.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Hjland et al. 2018 documents severe thoracolumbar scoliosis in an adult TARP patient, a previously unreported manifestation of TARP syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:30462380", "snippet": "Surgery for severe thoracolumbar scoliosis was performed at age 21 years.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "RARE", "name": "Scoliosis", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Scoliosis", "term": {"id": "HP:0002650", "label": "Scoliosis"}}}

name: Prominent nose

scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "description": "Abnormally prominent nasal structure, part of the expanding craniofacial phenotype in TARP syndrome.", "frequency": "RARE", "name": "Prominent nose"}
raw_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "description": "Abnormally prominent nasal structure, part of the expanding craniofacial phenotype in TARP syndrome.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Hjland et al. 2018 documents prominent nose and nasal bridge as craniofacial features in an adult TARP patient, expanding the phenotypic spectrum beyond the initially described cardinal features.", "reference": "PMID:30462380", "snippet": "Clinical examination of the patient revealed sloping forehead, prominent nasal bridge and nose, high myopia, esotropia", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "RARE", "name": "Prominent nose", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Prominent nose", "term": {"id": "HP:0000448", "label": "Prominent nose"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Neurocysticercosis is a major cause of seizures in endemic regions.", "reference": "PMID:12932389", "snippet": "This disease is one of the main causes of epileptic seizures in many less developed countries", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Seizures", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Seizure", "term": {"id": "HP:0001250", "label": "Seizure"}}}

name: Developmental Regression
notes: Loss of previously acquired milestones, typically starting at 3-6 months
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Developmental Regression", "notes": "Loss of previously acquired milestones, typically starting at 3-6 months"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Case series confirms developmental regression as a key presenting feature in GM2 gangliosidosis patients.", "reference": "PMID:25143775", "snippet": "All of them had a developmental disorder as a chief complaint. 38%of patients had a history of developmental delay or regression", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Natural history study of 97 patients confirms developmental arrest in 83% of infantile GM2 gangliosidosis cases.", "reference": "PMID:22025593", "snippet": "Common symptoms at onset were developmental arrest (83%), startling (65%), and hypotonia (60%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Review describes developmental arrest with regression of milestones as a core feature of Tay-Sachs disease.", "reference": "PMID:29618308", "snippet": "Inherited as a classical autosomal recessive disorder, this global disease of the nervous system induces developmental arrest with regression of attained milestones; neurodegeneration progresses rapidly to cause premature death in young children.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Developmental Regression", "notes": "Loss of previously acquired milestones, typically starting at 3-6 months", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Developmental Regression", "term": {"id": "HP:0002376", "label": "Developmental regression"}}}

name: Cherry-Red Spot
notes: Pathognomonic finding on fundoscopy

raw_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Case report describes cherry-red spot as the hallmark ophthalmologic finding in Tay-Sachs disease.", "reference": "PMID:19820796", "snippet": "The accumulation of lipid in retinal ganglion cells that leads to a chalk-white appearance of the fundus called 'cherry red spot' is the hallmark of Tay-Sachs disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Cherry-Red Spot", "notes": "Pathognomonic finding on fundoscopy", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Cherry-Red Spot", "term": {"id": "HP:0010729", "label": "Cherry red spot of the macula"}}}

name: Exaggerated Startle Response
notes: Hyperacusis with exaggerated startle to sound
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Exaggerated Startle Response", "notes": "Hyperacusis with exaggerated startle to sound"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Natural history study of 97 patients confirms exaggerated startle response (startling) in 65% of infantile GM2 gangliosidosis patients.", "reference": "PMID:22025593", "snippet": "Common symptoms at onset were developmental arrest (83%), startling (65%), and hypotonia (60%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Electrophysiological study documents the temporal evolution of the augmented startle reflex in Tay-Sachs disease.", "reference": "PMID:24534057", "snippet": "The augmented startle reflex appeared between the age of 3 and 17 months and disappeared between the age of 4 and 6 years.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Exaggerated Startle Response", "notes": "Hyperacusis with exaggerated startle to sound", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Exaggerated Startle Response", "term": {"id": "HP:0002267", "label": "Exaggerated startle response"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Natural history study confirms hypotonia in 60% of infantile GM2 gangliosidosis patients at disease onset.", "reference": "PMID:22025593", "snippet": "Common symptoms at onset were developmental arrest (83%), startling (65%), and hypotonia (60%).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hypotonia", "notes": "Progresses to spasticity", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypotonia", "term": {"id": "HP:0001252", "label": "Hypotonia"}}}

name: Trismus (Lockjaw)
description: Sustained contraction of the masseter muscles causing inability to open the mouth, often the first presenting symptom of tetanus.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Sustained contraction of the masseter muscles causing inability to open the mouth, often the first presenting symptom of tetanus.\n", "name": "Trismus (Lockjaw)"}
raw_json: {"description": "Sustained contraction of the masseter muscles causing inability to open the mouth, often the first presenting symptom of tetanus.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Masseter spasm (trismus) represents the cranial manifestation of the generalized muscle spasms described.", "reference": "PMID:40543524", "snippet": "C tetani releases a potent neurotoxin, causing muscle spasms, rigidity, and dysautonomia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Trismus (Lockjaw)", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "trismus", "term": {"id": "HP:0000211", "label": "Trismus"}}}

name: Generalized Muscle Rigidity
description: Sustained muscle contraction affecting the entire body, including the characteristic "risus sardonicus" (sardonic smile) from facial muscle involvement.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Sustained muscle contraction affecting the entire body, including the characteristic \"risus sardonicus\" (sardonic smile) from facial muscle involvement.\n", "name": "Generalized Muscle Rigidity"}
raw_json: {"description": "Sustained muscle contraction affecting the entire body, including the characteristic \"risus sardonicus\" (sardonic smile) from facial muscle involvement.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Highlights toxin-driven generalized rigidity.", "reference": "PMID:40543524", "snippet": "C tetani releases a potent neurotoxin, causing muscle spasms, rigidity, and dysautonomia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Generalized Muscle Rigidity", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "muscle rigidity", "term": {"id": "HP:0002063", "label": "Rigidity"}}}

name: Opisthotonus
description: Severe hyperextension of the spine with arching of the back due to sustained contraction of extensor muscles, a classic sign of generalized tetanus.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Severe hyperextension of the spine with arching of the back due to sustained contraction of extensor muscles, a classic sign of generalized tetanus.\n", "name": "Opisthotonus"}
raw_json: {"description": "Severe hyperextension of the spine with arching of the back due to sustained contraction of extensor muscles, a classic sign of generalized tetanus.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Describes the diffuse spasms that produce opisthotonic posturing.", "reference": "PMID:40543524", "snippet": "C tetani releases a potent neurotoxin, causing muscle spasms, rigidity, and dysautonomia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Opisthotonus", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "opisthotonus", "term": {"id": "HP:0002179", "label": "Opisthotonus"}}}

name: Reflex Spasms
description: Painful, generalized muscle spasms triggered by minor stimuli such as noise, light, or touch. These spasms can be severe enough to cause fractures.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Painful, generalized muscle spasms triggered by minor stimuli such as noise, light, or touch. These spasms can be severe enough to cause fractures.\n", "name": "Reflex Spasms"}
raw_json: {"description": "Painful, generalized muscle spasms triggered by minor stimuli such as noise, light, or touch. These spasms can be severe enough to cause fractures.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Confirms stimulus-sensitive spasms as a hallmark manifestation.", "reference": "PMID:40543524", "snippet": "C tetani releases a potent neurotoxin, causing muscle spasms, rigidity, and dysautonomia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Reflex Spasms", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "muscle spasms", "term": {"id": "HP:0003394", "label": "Muscle spasm"}}}

name: Dysphagia
description: Difficulty swallowing due to pharyngeal muscle spasm, which increases risk of aspiration pneumonia.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Difficulty swallowing due to pharyngeal muscle spasm, which increases risk of aspiration pneumonia.\n", "name": "Dysphagia"}
raw_json: {"description": "Difficulty swallowing due to pharyngeal muscle spasm, which increases risk of aspiration pneumonia.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Upper airway and bulbar spasms impede swallowing, leading to dysphagia.", "reference": "PMID:40543524", "snippet": "C tetani releases a potent neurotoxin, causing muscle spasms, rigidity, and dysautonomia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Dysphagia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "dysphagia", "term": {"id": "HP:0002015", "label": "Dysphagia"}}}

name: Respiratory Failure
description: Spasm of respiratory muscles and laryngospasm can cause life-threatening respiratory compromise, the leading cause of death in tetanus.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Spasm of respiratory muscles and laryngospasm can cause life-threatening respiratory compromise, the leading cause of death in tetanus.\n", "name": "Respiratory Failure"}
raw_json: {"description": "Spasm of respiratory muscles and laryngospasm can cause life-threatening respiratory compromise, the leading cause of death in tetanus.\n", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Links laryngospasm to respiratory failure.", "reference": "PMID:40543524", "snippet": "Important complications include laryngeal spasm and resultant airway obstruction and respiratory arrest.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Respiratory Failure", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "respiratory failure", "term": {"id": "HP:0002878", "label": "Respiratory failure"}}}

name: Lethal short-limbed short stature
description: Extreme micromelia (severely shortened limbs) with rhizomelic predominance. The limbs are so short that they appear flipper-like.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Extreme micromelia (severely shortened limbs) with rhizomelic predominance. The limbs are so short that they appear flipper-like.\n", "frequency": "HP_0040281", "name": "Lethal short-limbed short stature"}
raw_json: {"description": "Extreme micromelia (severely shortened limbs) with rhizomelic predominance. The limbs are so short that they appear flipper-like.\n", "frequency": "HP_0040281", "name": "Lethal short-limbed short stature", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Lethal short-limbed short stature", "term": {"id": "HP:0008909", "label": "Lethal short-limbed short stature"}}}

The most common ones are erythema toxicum neonatorum, the transient neonatal pustular melanosis and the benign cephalic pustulosis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The title confirms that transient neonatal pustular melanosis is a recognized dermatologic condition.", "reference": "PMID:511427", "snippet": "Transient neonatal pustular melanosis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This snippet supports the statement by confirming that transient neonatal pustular melanosis is a common benign pustular skin condition in newborns.", "reference": "PMID:28543629", "snippet": "Erythema toxicum neonatorum (ETN) and transient neonatal pustular melanosis (TNPM) are benign pustular skin conditions that are relatively common in newborns.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Pustules", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Pustules", "term": {"id": "HP:0200039", "label": "Pustule"}}}

name: Triple-Negative Phenotype

name: Chronic Cough
description: Persistent cough lasting more than 3 weeks, often productive with sputum, the cardinal respiratory symptom of pulmonary TB.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "description": "Persistent cough lasting more than 3 weeks, often productive with sputum, the cardinal respiratory symptom of pulmonary TB.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic Cough"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "description": "Persistent cough lasting more than 3 weeks, often productive with sputum, the cardinal respiratory symptom of pulmonary TB.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "While cough is indeed a common symptom of pulmonary TB, the statement specifically categorizes chronic cough as very frequent, which is partially supported but not explicitly confirmed by the literature.", "reference": "PMID:29196066", "snippet": "Cough is common in pulmonary TB and other chronic respiratory infections.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This strongly supports the statement as it shows a high prevalence of a persistent chronic cough in children diagnosed with tuberculosis.", "reference": "PMID:16131501", "snippet": "A persistent, non-remitting cough was reported in 15/16 (93.8%) children with tuberculosis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study identifies chronic cough as a significant symptomatic characteristic among the different TB phenotypes.", "reference": "PMID:35710915", "snippet": "Initial microbiologic burdens and radiographic features also varied, including the presence of cavities and bilateral infiltration, which reflect TB-related severity.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Chronic Cough", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Chronic Cough", "term": {"id": "HP:0034315", "label": "Chronic cough"}}}

name: Fever
description: Low-grade fever typically occurring in the afternoon and evening, often accompanied by chills.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "Low-grade fever typically occurring in the afternoon and evening, often accompanied by chills.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fever"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "Low-grade fever typically occurring in the afternoon and evening, often accompanied by chills.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that fever is a frequent symptom associated with tuberculosis.", "reference": "PMID:11120618", "snippet": "We describe three patients with recurrent fever thought to be due to tuberculosis, and review the 14 previously reported cases who fulfil the criteria of recurrent fever for at least 1 month's duration", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While this reference does affirm that tuberculosis causes systemic issues, it does not directly specify fever as a frequent phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:31641790", "snippet": "Tuberculosis is a bacterial infectious disease that is usually transmitted by inhalation of droplets containing the bacteria.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference notes the association of fever with tuberculosis but also highlights cases where fever may be absent, hence only partially supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:18173876", "snippet": "SETTING: The diagnosis of tuberculosis (TB) may be rejected in the absence of symptoms such as fever, sweats or weight loss.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Fever", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fever", "term": {"id": "HP:0001945", "label": "Fever"}}}

name: Night Sweats
description: Profuse sweating during sleep requiring change of bedclothes, a classic constitutional symptom of active TB.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "Profuse sweating during sleep requiring change of bedclothes, a classic constitutional symptom of active TB.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Night Sweats"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "Profuse sweating during sleep requiring change of bedclothes, a classic constitutional symptom of active TB.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study documents night sweats as a significant symptom in TB patients.", "reference": "PMID:31599243", "snippet": "Cough, night sweat, fever, anorexia were significant presenting features.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While night sweats are a notable symptom of TB, the reference suggests that in modern practice, they are less frequently the cause of night sweats compared to other conditions.", "reference": "PMID:12643362", "snippet": "Tuberculosis and lymphoma are diseases in which night sweats are a dominant symptom, but these are infrequently found to be the cause of night sweats in modern practice.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The data supports the presence of night sweats as a frequent symptom in TB, with sweats reducing significantly during therapy.", "reference": "PMID:21813327", "snippet": "During therapy, fever, sweats, and dyspnea decreased most rapidly, with near resolution by the end of therapy.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Night Sweats", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Night sweats", "term": {"id": "HP:0030166", "label": "Night sweats"}}}

notes: Also known as consumption historically.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "Unintentional weight loss and wasting, giving rise to the historical term \"consumption\" for TB.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Weight Loss", "notes": "Also known as consumption historically."}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "Unintentional weight loss and wasting, giving rise to the historical term \"consumption\" for TB.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This supports the statement that weight loss is a frequently observed systemic phenotype associated with tuberculosis.", "reference": "PMID:36451280", "snippet": "Tuberculosis (TB) is well-known for causing wasting. Patients on treatment gain weight and weight loss is associated with unfavorable treatment outcomes.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by indicating that weight loss is a common systemic symptom of esophageal tuberculosis.", "reference": "PMID:38736083", "snippet": "Esophageal TB most commonly presents with dysphagia, odynophagia, retrosternal pain, and systemic symptoms like decreased appetite, loss of weight, and low-grade fever as associated or other presentations.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Although the study is on mice, it draws parallels with human TB patients, reinforcing that weight loss is a frequently observed phenotype.", "reference": "PMID:23531875", "snippet": "CBA/J mice may model these events, as sick mice share features with TB patients, including weight loss...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This indicates that while weight loss is a known symptom, it is not always present in all TB cases, suggesting that it may be frequent but not ubiquitous.", "reference": "PMID:18173876", "snippet": "The diagnosis of tuberculosis (TB) may be rejected in the absence of symptoms such as fever, sweats or weight loss... In our population, TB, including pulmonary disease, frequently presented without fever, sweats or weight loss and with normal blood inflammatory markers.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference confirms that weight loss is one of the systemic symptoms that are frequently checked for in TB patients.", "reference": "PMID:8623687", "snippet": "All patients with a positive reaction to the tuberculin skin test should be evaluated for weight loss, night sweats, fever, chronic cough and other signs of active tuberculosis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Weight Loss", "notes": "Also known as consumption historically.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Weight loss", "term": {"id": "HP:0001824", "label": "Weight loss"}}}

name: Chest Pain
description: Pleuritic chest pain worsening with breathing or coughing, often indicating pleural involvement.
notes: Often described as pleuritic chest pain
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "description": "Pleuritic chest pain worsening with breathing or coughing, often indicating pleural involvement.", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Chest Pain", "notes": "Often described as pleuritic chest pain"}
raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "description": "Pleuritic chest pain worsening with breathing or coughing, often indicating pleural involvement.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference mentions pleuritic chest pain as a common symptom, but it does not specifically state that it is frequently associated with tuberculosis.", "reference": "PMID:17508531", "snippet": "Pleuritic chest pain is a common presenting symptom and has many causes, which range from life-threatening to benign, self-limited conditions.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement as it explicitly mentions that tuberculous pleural effusion (a form of extrapulmonary tuberculosis) commonly presents with pleuritic chest pain.", "reference": "PMID:27499981", "snippet": "TPE usually presents as an acute illness with fever, cough and pleuritic chest pain.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While this reference does not directly state chest pain, it supports the involvement of the chest in tuberculosis, which can be associated with pleuritic chest pain.", "reference": "PMID:30762202", "snippet": "Chest is the commonest site of involvement by tuberculosis (TB) in children; lungs being the most frequently affected region, followed by nodes, pleura and chest wall.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This case study mentions recurrent pleuritic chest pain, supporting the statement that chest pain is a frequent symptom in respiratory conditions, including tuberculosis.", "reference": "PMID:35809948", "snippet": "A 50-year-old woman with a history of permanent atrial fibrillation (AF) treated with radiofrequency catheter ablation (RFCA) 6 months ago was admitted to the respiratory department of a tertiary hospital because of recurrent episodes of pleuritic chest pain in the preceding 5 months.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Chest Pain", "notes": "Often described as pleuritic chest pain", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Chest pain", "term": {"id": "HP:0100749", "label": "Chest pain"}}}

name: Dyspnea

notes: Shortness of breath
