raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "description": "Shortness of breath due to extensive pulmonary involvement, pleural effusion, or fibrosis.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract mentions that dyspnea (shortness of breath) is a symptom of pulmonary tuberculosis, which supports the statement that dyspnea is occasionally associated with tuberculosis.", "reference": "PMID:15623010", "snippet": "Symptoms of pulmonary TB are a cough with or without sputum production lasting at least three weeks, chest pain, hemoptysis, fever, night sweats, weight loss, lack of appetite, chills and weakness.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference indicates that lung function issues, including dyspnea, can persist even after successful treatment of tuberculosis.", "reference": "PMID:29900887", "snippet": "Lung function impairment is known to occur after pulmonary TB irrespective of duration of treatment and outcome of disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Dyspnea", "notes": "Shortness of breath", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Dyspnea", "term": {"id": "HP:0002094", "label": "Dyspnea"}}}

name: Fatigue
description: Persistent tiredness and weakness associated with chronic infection and inflammatory response.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "Persistent tiredness and weakness associated with chronic infection and inflammatory response.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Fatigue"}
raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "description": "Persistent tiredness and weakness associated with chronic infection and inflammatory response.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract mentions that tuberculosis can be misdiagnosed as sarcoidosis due to similar symptoms, including fatigue, indicating that fatigue can be a systemic symptom of tuberculosis.", "reference": "PMID:33645194", "snippet": "Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disorder of unknown cause that occurs in both men and women of all races. It typically presents in patients after 20 years of age. Sarcoidosis most frequently involves the lung, but up to 30 percent of patients present with extra-thoracic manifestations. It can involve multiple organs to a variable extent and degree. In areas, where tuberculosis is endemic, the diagnosis of sarcoidosis may be overlooked and misdiagnosed because of clinical and radiographic resemblance.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study indicates that tuberculosis can lead to symptoms similar to chronic fatigue syndrome, supporting the statement that fatigue can be a systemic symptom of tuberculosis.", "reference": "PMID:35189895", "snippet": "Patients with chronic fatigue syndrome and post-tuberculosis experience similar symptoms. Furthermore, chronic fatigue syndrome and tuberculosis share similar plasma immunosignatures.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Fatigue", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Fatigue", "term": {"id": "HP:0012378", "label": "Fatigue"}}}

name: Back Pain
description: Localized spinal pain that may indicate vertebral TB (Pott's disease) with potential neurological complications.
notes: May indicate spinal tuberculosis (Pott's disease)
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "description": "Localized spinal pain that may indicate vertebral TB (Pott's disease) with potential neurological complications.", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Back Pain", "notes": "May indicate spinal tuberculosis (Pott's disease)"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "description": "Localized spinal pain that may indicate vertebral TB (Pott's disease) with potential neurological complications.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study indicates that tuberculosis is a common cause of low back pain (LBP), supporting the statement that back pain may indicate spinal tuberculosis.", "reference": "PMID:16882280", "snippet": "The findings of this study indicate that TB is a common cause of LBP that is liable to be overlooked in the differential diagnosis of LBP.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This case report supports the statement that back pain may indicate spinal tuberculosis, as it describes a patient whose neck pain was eventually diagnosed as spinal tuberculosis.", "reference": "PMID:29358061", "snippet": "We present a case report of a military veteran presenting with neck pain and initially diagnosed with cervical disc disease. The patient's pain progressed to the point of developing paresthesias in his bilateral upper extremities. Eventually, cervical spine radiographs were obtained that revealed complete cervical vertebral body destruction from spinal tuberculosis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study supports the statement by indicating that the lumbar and thoracic vertebrae are commonly involved in TB spondylitis, which can manifest as back pain.", "reference": "PMID:19845697", "snippet": "In TB spondylitis, the lumbar (22.7%) and thoracic (50%) vertebrae were the most commonly involved sites.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This case supports the statement by illustrating that tuberculosis can involve the musculoskeletal system, presenting as back pain.", "reference": "PMID:33393654", "snippet": "In this article, we present a rare case of progressed tuberculous infection involving the respiratory and musculoskeletal system in a 36-year-old patient whose main complaints were non-specific and mild, and started only two weeks before his diagnosis, despite the advanced disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Back Pain", "notes": "May indicate spinal tuberculosis (Pott's disease)", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Back Pain", "term": {"id": "HP:0003418", "label": "Back pain"}}}

name: Lymphadenopathy

notes: Swollen lymph nodes, especially in the neck

raw_json: {"category": "Lymphatic", "description": "Enlarged lymph nodes, particularly cervical, often cold and matted, indicating extrapulmonary TB.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature supports that tuberculosis can cause lymphadenopathy, specifically in the neck region, but it does not provide a clear indication of frequency.", "reference": "PMID:30513392", "snippet": "TB can affect most organs in the head and neck region, such as the lymph nodes, larynx, middle ear, oral cavity and pharynx. In particular, as for cervical tuberculosis lymphadenopathy, a predominant involvement of the posterior triangle, supraclavicular, and internal jugular group of nodes bilaterally can be observed.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The literature indicates that tuberculous lymphadenitis is one of the major causes of lymphadenopathy, but it does not specify how frequently this occurs.", "reference": "PMID:38317037", "snippet": "Other major causes of lymphadenopathy were metastatic tumor deposits, reactive lymphoid hyperplasia, and tuberculous lymphadenitis.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The study shows a significant prevalence of TB lymphadenitis among patients with enlarged lymph nodes, but it does not provide a frequency classification such as 'occasional'.", "reference": "PMID:37743370", "snippet": "Close to half of patients with enlarged lymph nodes were positive for M. tuberculosis by the GeneXpert method in the study area.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Lymphadenopathy", "notes": "Swollen lymph nodes, especially in the neck", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Lymphadenopathy", "term": {"id": "HP:0002716", "label": "Lymphadenopathy"}}}

name: Hyperglycemia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Metabolic", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hyperglycemia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Metabolic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This describes how the failure of beta cells to compensate for insulin resistance results in hyperglycemia, the hallmark of type 2 diabetes.", "reference": "PMID:29939616", "snippet": "This vicious cycle continues until pancreatic beta-cell activity can no longer adequately meet the insulin demand created by insulin resistance, resulting in hyperglycemia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This confirms that hyperglycemia in diabetes results from elevated hepatic glucose production and impaired glucose homeostasis.", "reference": "PMID:30150719", "snippet": "Diabetes is characterized by impaired glucose homeostasis partly due to abnormally elevated hepatic glucose production (HGP).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hyperglycemia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hyperglycemia", "term": {"id": "HP:0003074", "label": "Hyperglycemia"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Systemic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This establishes that polyuria results from glucose-induced osmotic diuresis in hyperglycemia, which in turn leads to polydipsia as a compensatory response to fluid loss.", "reference": "PMID:9398128", "snippet": "Polyuria due to a glucose-induced osmotic diuresis is common in patients with hyperglycemia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Polydipsia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Polydipsia", "term": {"id": "HP:0001959", "label": "Polydipsia"}}}

This diuresis usually abates when the plasma glucose level approaches its renal threshold.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Polyuria", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Polyuria", "term": {"id": "HP:0000103", "label": "Polyuria"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Endocrine", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This source supports the statement by associating Type I Diabetes with hyperglycemia and chronic complications such as retinopathy and neuropathy, as well as acute complications like diabetic ketoacidosis.", "reference": "PMID:38272591", "snippet": "Type 1 diabetes is associated with both acute and chronic complications. Acute complications include diabetic ketoacidosis and severe hypoglycemia. Chronic complications can be microvascular or macrovascular. Microvascular complications include retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This source supports the statement by confirming that Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) is a frequent acute complication in Type 1 Diabetes at the time of diagnosis.", "reference": "PMID:28544185", "snippet": "Participation in prospective follow-up studies reduces the frequency of DKA in children at diagnosis of T1D, but genetic screening alone does not decrease DKA risk.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This source supports the statement by describing stress hyperglycemia as a potential initial presentation of Type 1 Diabetes, thereby confirming hyperglycemia as a very frequent occurrence.", "reference": "PMID:34362315", "snippet": "Although SH was usually benign and long-term treatment was superfluous, it might be the first sign of insulinopenic status such as type 1 DM (T1DM)", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hyperglycemia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hyperglycemia", "term": {"id": "HP:0003074", "label": "Hyperglycemia"}}, "sequelae": [{"target": "Diabetic Ketoacidosis"}]}

raw_json: {"category": "Ophthalmologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature mentions diabetic retinopathy as a leading cause of blindness in the working-age population but does not provide specific information on its frequency in Type I Diabetes.", "reference": "PMID:24864506", "snippet": "Diabetes mellitus (DM), due to its epidemic prevalence and high occurrence of associated disability, is now one of the priority medical and social problems. Incapacitating manifestations of diabetes include visual impairment. Thus, diabetic retinopathy (DR), a late nonspecific vascular complication of DM, is the leading cause of blindness in the working-age population.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The study provides data on the prevalence of diabetic retinopathy in a diabetic population but does not specify it as occasional in Type I Diabetes.", "reference": "PMID:37469057", "snippet": "The commonest morbidity was cataract12,607(28.8%), followed by refractive errors 8,508(19.5%), vision-threatening diabetic retinopathy 2,553(5.83%) and suspected glaucoma 1,211(2.76%).", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The article mentions retinopathy as a complication of Type 1 diabetes but does not specify its frequency as occasional.", "reference": "PMID:38272591", "snippet": "Type 1 diabetes is associated with both acute and chronic complications. Acute complications include diabetic ketoacidosis and severe hypoglycemia. Chronic complications can be microvascular or macrovascular. Microvascular complications include retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The literature mentions diabetic retinopathy as a complication of Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes but does not specify its frequency as occasional.", "reference": "PMID:29682912", "snippet": "Diabetic retinopathy, a complication of both type 1 and type 2 diabetes, is a complex disease and is one of the leading causes of blindness in adults worldwide.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Diabetic Retinopathy", "notes": "Leading cause of blindness, due to chronic hyperglycemia"}

raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by indicating that aggressive glycemic control can lead to diabetic neuropathy, which is a neurologic complication of Type I Diabetes.", "reference": "PMID:28159476", "snippet": "Aggressive glucose control can result in treatment induced neuropathy of diabetes (TIND) if glycemic control is achieved too quickly.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement that diabetic neuropathy is a neurologic complication associated with glycemic variability, which can be linked to chronic hyperglycemia.", "reference": "PMID:33071962", "snippet": "Glycemic variability (GV) may attribute to the pathogenesis of diabetic neuropathy.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by highlighting the role of hyperglycemia in neurocognitive complications, which can be related to diabetic neuropathy in Type I Diabetes.", "reference": "PMID:33715053", "snippet": "Emerging evidence suggests that hyperglycemia and time in range may be more important for brain development than episodes of hypoglycemia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by describing insulin neuritis, a form of diabetic neuropathy, which is a neurologic complication associated with glycemic control.", "reference": "PMID:23506377", "snippet": "'Insulin neuritis' or 'treatment induced neuropathy' is a reversible disorder characterised by acute severe distal limb pain, peripheral nerve fibre damage and autonomic dysfunction, preceded by a period of rapid glycaemic control.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Diabetic Neuropathy", "notes": "Nerve damage from chronic hyperglycemia"}

name: Diabetic Nephropathy
notes: Kidney damage from chronic hyperglycemia

raw_json: {"category": "Renal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This study primarily discusses renal failure in type 2 diabetes, not type 1 diabetes.", "reference": "PMID:23290727", "snippet": "Renal failure in type 2 diabetes has been termed 'a medical catastrophe of worldwide dimension'.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The study mentions diabetic nephropathy as a serious complication of diabetes mellitus in general, without specifying the frequency in type 1 diabetes.", "reference": "PMID:27903991", "snippet": "Diabetic nephropathy (DN) is a serious complication of diabetes mellitus, and its prevalence has been increasing in developed countries.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The study highlights nephropathy as a serious complication of diabetes mellitus but does not specify its frequency in type 1 diabetes.", "reference": "PMID:1490695", "snippet": "The most serious complication of diabetes mellitus is clinical nephropathy.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The study identifies glycemic control as a significant factor for kidney disease in type 1 diabetes but does not specify the frequency of diabetic nephropathy.", "reference": "PMID:30833370", "snippet": "higher mean glycemic exposure was the strongest determinant of kidney disease among the modifiable risk factors.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Diabetic Nephropathy", "notes": "Kidney damage from chronic hyperglycemia"}

name: Visual Snow
notes: Dynamic, continuous tiny flickering dots in the entire visual field similar to TV static
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Visual Snow", "notes": "Dynamic, continuous tiny flickering dots in the entire visual field similar to TV static"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Foundational study defines visual snow as continuous tiny dots throughout the visual field.", "reference": "PMID:24645145", "snippet": "Patients with 'visual snow' report continuous tiny dots in the entire visual field similar to the noise of an analogue television.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Confirms visual snow as constant flickering dots resembling TV static.", "reference": "PMID:29934719", "snippet": "Visual snow is a condition where patients see constant, innumerable flickering dots throughout the visual field, similar to \"TV static.\"", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Large cohort study confirms black and white static as the most common visual snow appearance.", "reference": "PMID:31941797", "snippet": "The most commonly experienced static was black and white.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Visual Snow", "notes": "Dynamic, continuous tiny flickering dots in the entire visual field similar to TV static"}

name: Palinopsia
notes: Afterimages and trailing of moving objects
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Palinopsia", "notes": "Afterimages and trailing of moving objects"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Palinopsia including afterimages and trailing is one of the core additional symptoms in VSS.", "reference": "PMID:24645145", "snippet": "palinopsia (trailing and afterimages), entoptic phenomena (floaters, blue field entoptic phenomenon, spontaneous photopsia, self-light of the eye), photophobia, and nyctalopia (impaired night vision)", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Palinopsia symptoms including afterimages and trailing are common in VSS.", "reference": "PMID:24816400", "snippet": "Most patients describe a syndrome with additional visual symptoms of the following categories: palinopsia (\"afterimages\" and \"trailing\")", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Palinopsia", "notes": "Afterimages and trailing of moving objects"}

name: Photophobia
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Photophobia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Photophobia is one of the core additional symptoms present in VSS patients.", "reference": "PMID:24645145", "snippet": "palinopsia (trailing and afterimages), entoptic phenomena (floaters, blue field entoptic phenomenon, spontaneous photopsia, self-light of the eye), photophobia, and nyctalopia", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Large cohort study confirms photophobia as one of the most commonly reported symptoms.", "reference": "PMID:31941797", "snippet": "Floaters, afterimages, and photophobia were the most reported additional visual symptoms.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Photophobia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Photophobia", "term": {"id": "HP:0000613", "label": "Photophobia"}}}

name: Nyctalopia
notes: Impaired night vision
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Nyctalopia", "notes": "Impaired night vision"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Nyctalopia (impaired night vision) is one of the core additional symptoms in VSS.", "reference": "PMID:24645145", "snippet": "palinopsia (trailing and afterimages), entoptic phenomena (floaters, blue field entoptic phenomenon, spontaneous photopsia, self-light of the eye), photophobia, and nyctalopia (impaired night vision)", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Impaired night vision is listed as a core feature of VSS in recent review.", "reference": "PMID:38465699", "snippet": "Visual snow syndrome (VSS) is a disorder characterized by persistent visual disturbances, including the visual snow phenomenon, palinopsia, heightened perception of entoptic phenomena, impaired night vision, and photophobia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Nyctalopia", "notes": "Impaired night vision", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Nyctalopia", "term": {"id": "HP:0000662", "label": "Nyctalopia"}}}

name: Entoptic Phenomena
notes: Blue field entoptic phenomenon, floaters, spontaneous photopsia, self-light of the eye
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Entoptic Phenomena", "notes": "Blue field entoptic phenomenon, floaters, spontaneous photopsia, self-light of the eye"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Enhanced entoptic phenomena are core features of VSS.", "reference": "PMID:24645145", "snippet": "palinopsia (trailing and afterimages), entoptic phenomena (floaters, blue field entoptic phenomenon, spontaneous photopsia, self-light of the eye), photophobia, and nyctalopia", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Enhanced entoptic phenomena are part of the defining symptom complex of VSS.", "reference": "PMID:33008511", "snippet": "Visual snow syndrome is a debilitating disorder characterized by tiny flickering dots (like TV static) in the entire visual field and a set of accompanying visual (palinopsia, enhanced entoptic phenomena, photophobia, nyctalopia)", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Entoptic Phenomena", "notes": "Blue field entoptic phenomenon, floaters, spontaneous photopsia, self-light of the eye"}

name: Photopsia
notes: Spontaneous flashes of light
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Photopsia", "notes": "Spontaneous flashes of light"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Spontaneous photopsia is one of the entoptic phenomena in VSS.", "reference": "PMID:24816400", "snippet": "entopic phenomena arising from the optic apparatus itself (floaters, blue field entoptic phenomenon, photopsia, self-light of the eye)", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Photopsia is listed as one of the core associated symptoms in VSS diagnostic criteria.", "reference": "PMID:40129600", "snippet": "Visual Snow Syndrome (VSS) is characterized by the presence of dynamic, continuous, tiny dots in the entire visual field persisting for more than three months, with at least two associated symptoms- palinopsia, photopsia, photophobia, or nyctalopia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Photopsia", "notes": "Spontaneous flashes of light", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Photopsia", "term": {"id": "HP:0030786", "label": "Photopsia"}}}

name: Tinnitus
notes: Often bilateral high-pitched ringing
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurological", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Tinnitus", "notes": "Often bilateral high-pitched ringing"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurological", "evidence": [{"explanation": "About 63% of VSS patients report continuous bilateral tinnitus.", "reference": "PMID:28723606", "snippet": "While most of these symptoms appear to be visual in nature, approximately 63% of patients studied also report continuous bilateral tinnitus.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Tinnitus is highly prevalent and associated with more severe VSS presentation.", "reference": "PMID:31941797", "snippet": "Migraine and tinnitus had a very high prevalence and were independently associated with a more severe presentation of the syndrome.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Tinnitus is recognized as a common non-visual symptom in VSS.", "reference": "PMID:24816400", "snippet": "as well as the non-visual symptom tinnitus.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Tinnitus is confirmed as a common comorbid condition in VSS.", "reference": "PMID:31213497", "snippet": "Migraine, depression, anxiety, and tinnitus were common comorbid diseases.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Tinnitus", "notes": "Often bilateral high-pitched ringing", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Tinnitus", "term": {"id": "HP:0000360", "label": "Tinnitus"}}}

name: Depigmented Patches
notes: Symmetrically distributed, well-demarcated white macules or patches
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatological", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Depigmented Patches", "notes": "Symmetrically distributed, well-demarcated white macules or patches"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatological", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "The document confirms that vitiligo is characterized by depigmented patches and addresses the negative impact on quality of life, which can include social stigma.", "reference": "PMID:25572727", "snippet": "Vitiligo is an acquired cutaneous disorder of pigmentation... Recent data provide strong evidence supporting an autoimmune pathogenesis of vitiligo.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This supports the statement by confirming the presence of depigmented patches and social stigma.", "reference": "PMID:35166101", "snippet": "Vitiligo is a skin disorder characterized by selective loss of melanocytes resulting in circumscribed, depigmented macules and patches... its effects can be psychological, leading to stigmatization and suicidal ideation.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This supports the statement regarding the commonality of depigmented patches and associated social stigma.", "reference": "PMID:17250545", "snippet": "Vitiligo is the most common depigmenting disorder, which affects 0.5-1% of the worldwide population, causing disfigurement and serious disturbances in well being.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This supports the statement regarding depigmented patches and social stigma.", "reference": "PMID:23796814", "snippet": "Vitiligo is an acquired, idiopathic skin disease characterized by the mostly progressive loss of the inherited skin color leading to white patches... The disease burden includes stigmatization, depression, impaired quality of life, lack of self-confidence, embarrassment and self-consciousness.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "Supports the reduction in the risk of skin cancer but does not address increased sensitivity to sunlight.", "reference": "PMID:32462299", "snippet": "Vitiligo was causally associated with reduced risks of several cancers... melanoma (OR 0.9983; 95% CI 0.9976-0.9990; p < 0.001), non-melanoma skin cancer (OR 0.9997; 95% CI 0.9995-0.9999; p < 0.001).", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Depigmented Patches", "notes": "Symmetrically distributed, well-demarcated white macules or patches", "sequelae": [{"target": "Increased Sensitivity To Sunlight"}]}

name: Premature Hair Whitening
notes: Especially noticeable in dark-haired individuals
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Dermatological", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Premature Hair Whitening", "notes": "Especially noticeable in dark-haired individuals"}
raw_json: {"category": "Dermatological", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "The excerpt lists 'development of early or premature graying' as a characteristic feature of vitiligo in children, supporting the statement that premature hair whitening is occasionally associated with vitiligo.", "reference": "PMID:26769615", "snippet": "Vitiligo in children is a distinct subset of vitiligo and differs from adult vitiligo. Characteristic features include family history of autoimmune or endocrine disease, higher incidence of segmental vitiligo, development of early or premature graying, increased incidence of autoantibodies and poor response to topical PUVA.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Premature Hair Whitening", "notes": "Especially noticeable in dark-haired individuals"}

name: Associated Autoimmune Disorders
notes: Such as thyroid disease, type 1 diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, etc.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Autoimmune", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Associated Autoimmune Disorders", "notes": "Such as thyroid disease, type 1 diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, etc."}
raw_json: {"category": "Autoimmune", "evidence": [{"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This reference discusses the association of vitiligo with chronic autoimmune thyroiditis, supporting the statement that vitiligo is frequently associated with autoimmune disorders.", "reference": "PMID:34104234", "snippet": "The association with chronic thyroiditis is based on common autoimmune background and excessive reactive oxygen species that destroy melanocytes and thyrocytes (oxidative stress hypothesis)...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This reference indicates that vitiligo is associated with autoimmune disorders like Graves' disease and Hashimoto's disease, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:35637045", "snippet": "Vitiligo and Graves' disease were also diagnosed in this cohort but affected few patients.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This reference provides evidence that vitiligo is frequently associated with various autoimmune disorders, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:37405428", "snippet": "The most frequent autoimmune disorders in patients with vitiligo were type 1 diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), autoimmune thyroiditis, Addison's disease, and systemic sclerosis (SSc).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This reference supports the statement by listing vitiligo among other autoimmune disorders associated with Turner syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:31580326", "snippet": "The spectrum includes, Hashimoto's thyroiditis, coeliac disease (CD), type 1 diabetes (T1DM), alopecia areata, inammatory bowel disease, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis and some cutaneous disorders as vitiligo and Halo nevus", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This reference indicates that vitiligo is associated with a higher risk of other autoimmune diseases, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:16420246", "snippet": "Familial clustering of vitiligo is not uncommon, and patients and their relatives are at increased risk for a specific complex of other autoimmune diseases.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Associated Autoimmune Disorders", "notes": "Such as thyroid disease, type 1 diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, etc."}

Instead, it suggests a higher prevalence.", "reference": "PMID:32013982", "snippet": "Depression and Anxiety are common psychiatric disorders in vitiligo patients.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"evidence_source": "OTHER", "explanation": "The study acknowledges the psychosocial effects and psychiatric morbidity in vitiligo patients but does not specify the frequency as occasional.", "reference": "PMID:16405601", "snippet": "We review the psychosocial effects of vitiligo, how patients deal with them and the psychiatric morbidity in vitiligo patients.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This study indicates a susceptibility to mental disorders in vitiligo patients but does not specify the frequency as occasional.", "reference": "PMID:37975615", "snippet": "Although a large number of existing studies have confirmed that people with vitiligo are prone to mental disorders...", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"evidence_source": "HUMAN_CLINICAL", "explanation": "This study highlights the prominence of anxiety disorders and depression in children with vitiligo but does not specify the frequency as occasional.", "reference": "PMID:32064670", "snippet": "The most important finding of this study is that anxiety disorders are more prominent than depression in childhood vitiligo.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Depression/Anxiety", "notes": "Related to altered appearance and social stigma"}

name: Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma
description: Clear cell RCC occurs in approximately 70% of VHL patients. Tumors are often bilateral and multifocal. Mean age of diagnosis is 39 years, compared to 62 years for sporadic RCC. Leading cause of mortality in VHL patients.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neoplastic", "description": "Clear cell RCC occurs in approximately 70% of VHL patients. Tumors are often bilateral and multifocal. Mean age of diagnosis is 39 years, compared to 62 years for sporadic RCC. Leading cause of mortality in VHL patients.", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma"}
raw_json: {"category": "Neoplastic", "description": "Clear cell RCC occurs in approximately 70% of VHL patients. Tumors are often bilateral and multifocal. Mean age of diagnosis is 39 years, compared to 62 years for sporadic RCC. Leading cause of mortality in VHL patients.", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "Confirms high incidence of RCC in VHL disease due to VHL gene inactivation and constitutive HIF-2 activation.", "reference": "PMID:34818478", "snippet": "Patients with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease have a high incidence of renal cell carcinoma owing to VHL gene inactivation and constitutive activation of the transcription factor hypoxia-inducible factor 2 (HIF-2).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Clear cell renal cell carcinoma", "term": {"id": "HP:0006770", "label": "Clear cell renal cell carcinoma"}}}

name: Cerebellar Hemangioblastoma
description: Hemangioblastomas of the cerebellum are the most common CNS manifestation, occurring in 60-80% of VHL patients. These highly vascular tumors may cause symptoms through mass effect or associated cyst formation.

name: Retinal Hemangioblastoma
description: Retinal hemangioblastomas (also called retinal capillary hemangiomas) occur in 25-60% of VHL patients and may be the presenting manifestation. They can cause vision loss through exudation, hemorrhage, or retinal detachment.

name: Pheochromocytoma
description: Pheochromocytomas occur in 10-20% of VHL patients overall but are more common in Type 2 families (up to 60%). Often bilateral and may occur at young ages. Screening by plasma or urine metanephrines is recommended.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neoplastic", "description": "Pheochromocytomas occur in 10-20% of VHL patients overall but are more common in Type 2 families (up to 60%). name: Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumor
description: Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors occur in 5-17% of VHL patients. Most are nonfunctional. The main concern is metastatic potential, though most are indolent. Size-based surveillance guides management.

name: Renal Cysts
description: Multiple renal cysts are common in VHL patients and may precede RCC development. Some cysts contain foci of clear cell RCC. Surveillance imaging monitors for solid enhancing components.

name: Chronic diarrhea

raw_json: {"category": "Gastrointestinal", "description": "Persistent watery or steatorrheal stools reflecting malabsorption.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Review lists chronic diarrhea as hallmark of Whipple disease malabsorption.", "reference": "PMID:26288590", "snippet": "Prior to patients reporting symptoms of a malabsorption syndrome (chronic diarrhea/steatorhea, weight loss), they often suffer from non-specific symptoms.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Chronic diarrhea", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Diarrhea", "term": {"id": "HP:0002014", "label": "Diarrhea"}}}

name: Weight loss

name: Migratory polyarthralgia
description: Migratory peripheral joint pain often preceding gastrointestinal symptoms.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "description": "Migratory peripheral joint pain often preceding gastrointestinal symptoms.", "name": "Migratory polyarthralgia"}
raw_json: {"category": "Musculoskeletal", "description": "Migratory peripheral joint pain often preceding gastrointestinal symptoms.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Describes typical migratory joint involvement.", "reference": "PMID:26288590", "snippet": "Patients report a migrating polyarthritis of the peripheral joints (ankles, shoulders, knees, wrists, hands) and of the axial system.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Cohort of isolated articular Whipple disease shows stereotyped migratory arthritis pattern.", "reference": "PMID:40204565", "snippet": "Joint involvement was similar, with initial episodic migratory arthritis (91 %) predominantly affecting large joints and lasting 2-7 days.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Migratory polyarthralgia", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Arthralgia", "term": {"id": "HP:0002829", "label": "Arthralgia"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "description": "Cognitive impairment and other CNS manifestations that can occur with systemic or isolated CNS disease.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Review notes cognitive dysfunction among neurological features of Whipple disease.", "reference": "PMID:26288590", "snippet": "Patients complain of headaches, cognitive dysfunctions, and eye motility disorders.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Cognitive dysfunction", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Cognitive impairment", "term": {"id": "HP:0100543", "label": "Cognitive impairment"}}}

raw_json: {"category": "Respiratory", "description": "Pulmonary symptoms such as cough, chest pain, and dyspnea with plaques or nodules on imaging.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "Case series documents pulmonary symptoms including dyspnea and chest pain.", "reference": "PMID:38414785", "snippet": "Whipple's disease (WD) is a multiple-system chronic disease caused by Tropheryma whipplei (T. whipplei) infection. The present study describes 3 cases of WD with clinical manifestations of cough, chest pain, headache, dyspnea, sputum, joint pain, abdominal pain, diarrhea and weight loss.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Imaging and BAL sequencing confirm pulmonary involvement due to T. whipplei.", "reference": "PMID:38414785", "snippet": "Chest computed tomography (CT) showed signs of plaques, nodules and pleural thickening; and bronchoscopic alveolar lavage fluid metagenomic-sequencing indicated that it was T. whipplei.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Respiratory involvement", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Dyspnea", "term": {"id": "HP:0002094", "label": "Dyspnea"}}}

name: Characteristic Facial Features
notes: The distinctive facies includes broad nasal bridge continuing to the forehead (Greek warrior helmet appearance), microcephaly, high forehead with prominent glabella, hypertelorism, and micrognathia.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Characteristic Facial Features", "notes": "The distinctive facies includes broad nasal bridge continuing to the forehead (Greek warrior helmet appearance), microcephaly, high forehead with prominent glabella, hypertelorism, and micrognathia."}
raw_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This establishes the characteristic Greek helmet facial appearance as a major diagnostic feature.", "reference": "PMID:25137600", "snippet": "The major features of this disorder include a characteristic facial appearance known as the \"Greek helmet,\" delayed growth and development; prenatally and postnatally, intellectual disabilities, and seizures.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This identifies the typical facial gestalt as one of the core features of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:32914558", "snippet": "Its core features are typical facial gestalt, growth retardation, intellectual disability, or developmental delay and seizures.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Characteristic Facial Features", "notes": "The distinctive facies includes broad nasal bridge continuing to the forehead (Greek warrior helmet appearance), microcephaly, high forehead with prominent glabella, hypertelorism, and micrognathia.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abnormal facial shape", "term": {"id": "HP:0001999", "label": "Abnormal facial shape"}}}

name: Microcephaly
notes: Small head circumference is a consistent feature of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Microcephaly", "notes": "Small head circumference is a consistent feature of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome."}
raw_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This establishes microcephaly as a characteristic feature of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:18474167", "snippet": "It was characterized by well-described facial appearance, seizures, microcephaly and midline closure defects along with growth and mental retardation.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Microcephaly", "notes": "Small head circumference is a consistent feature of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Microcephaly", "term": {"id": "HP:0000252", "label": "Microcephaly"}}}

name: Hypertelorism
notes: Widely spaced eyes are a characteristic feature contributing to the distinctive facial appearance.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hypertelorism", "notes": "Widely spaced eyes are a characteristic feature contributing to the distinctive facial appearance."}
raw_json: {"category": "Craniofacial", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This case report confirms ocular hypertelorism as a characteristic craniofacial feature of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:9774859", "snippet": "At the autopsy, the propositus showed microcephaly, prominent glabella, broad bridge of the nose, ocular hypertelorism, poorly differentiated and low-set ears, bilateral palatoschisis, and micrognathia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This documents hypertelorism as one of the ocular findings in Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:29199884", "snippet": "Ocular findings included normal intraocular pressures and corneal diameters, large-angle exotropia, downward slanting of the palpebral fissures, absent eyelid creases, upper and lower eyelid retraction with shortage of the anterior eyelid lamellae, euryblepharon, lagophthalmos with poor Bell's reflex and exposure keratopathy, hypertelorism, Axenfeld's anomaly, megalopapillae, and cavitary optic disc anomaly.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Hypertelorism", "notes": "Widely spaced eyes are a characteristic feature contributing to the distinctive facial appearance.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Hypertelorism", "term": {"id": "HP:0000316", "label": "Hypertelorism"}}}

name: Intrauterine Growth Retardation
notes: Marked intrauterine growth retardation is a consistent prenatal finding in Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Growth", "diagnostic": true, "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Intrauterine Growth Retardation", "notes": "Marked intrauterine growth retardation is a consistent prenatal finding in Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome."}
raw_json: {"category": "Growth", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This describes delayed growth and development both prenatally and postnatally as major features.", "reference": "PMID:25137600", "snippet": "The major features of this disorder include a characteristic facial appearance known as the \"Greek helmet,\" delayed growth and development; prenatally and postnatally, intellectual disabilities, and seizures.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Intrauterine Growth Retardation", "notes": "Marked intrauterine growth retardation is a consistent prenatal finding in Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Intrauterine growth retardation", "term": {"id": "HP:0001511", "label": "Intrauterine growth retardation"}}}

name: Postnatal Growth Retardation
notes: Slow postnatal weight gain and continued growth impairment are characteristic.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Growth", "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Postnatal Growth Retardation", "notes": "Slow postnatal weight gain and continued growth impairment are characteristic."}
raw_json: {"category": "Growth", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This establishes prenatal/postnatal growth deficiency as a characteristic feature of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:30289612", "snippet": "Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome (WHS) is a rare contiguous gene deletion disorder characterized by distinctive craniofacial features, prenatal/postnatal growth deficiency, intellectual disability, and seizures.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Postnatal Growth Retardation", "notes": "Slow postnatal weight gain and continued growth impairment are characteristic.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Postnatal growth retardation", "term": {"id": "HP:0008897", "label": "Postnatal growth retardation"}}}

name: Intellectual Disability
notes: Intellectual disability is moderate to severe in most cases, rarely mild.

raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This identifies intellectual disability as one of the core features of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:32914558", "snippet": "Its core features are typical facial gestalt, growth retardation, intellectual disability, or developmental delay and seizures.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This establishes intellectual disabilities as a major feature of the disorder.", "reference": "PMID:25137600", "snippet": "The major features of this disorder include a characteristic facial appearance known as the \"Greek helmet,\" delayed growth and development; prenatally and postnatally, intellectual disabilities, and seizures.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This confirms mental retardation (intellectual disability) as a characteristic feature.", "reference": "PMID:18474167", "snippet": "It was characterized by well-described facial appearance, seizures, microcephaly and midline closure defects along with growth and mental retardation.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Intellectual Disability", "notes": "Intellectual disability is moderate to severe in most cases, rarely mild.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Intellectual disability", "term": {"id": "HP:0001249", "label": "Intellectual disability"}}}

name: Severe Delayed Psychomotor Development
notes: Severe developmental delays affecting motor skills, speech, and adaptive functioning.

raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "diagnostic": true, "evidence": [{"explanation": "This identifies developmental delay as one of the characteristic features of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:29199884", "snippet": "Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome is a rare genetic syndrome caused by a heterozygous deletion on chromosome 4p16.3 and is characterized by a \"Greek warrior helmet\" facies, hypotonia, developmental delay, seizures, structural central nervous system defects, intrauterine growth restriction, sketelal anomalies, cardiac defects, abnormal tooth development, and hearing loss.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This confirms the association of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome with intellectual disability and developmental impairment.", "reference": "PMID:40404199", "snippet": "Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome (WHS) is associated with intellectual disability and multiple congenital anomalies.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "VERY_FREQUENT", "name": "Severe Delayed Psychomotor Development", "notes": "Severe developmental delays affecting motor skills, speech, and adaptive functioning.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Global developmental delay", "term": {"id": "HP:0001263", "label": "Global developmental delay"}}}

name: Corpus Callosum Abnormalities
notes: Structural central nervous system defects including corpus callosum abnormalities may occur.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Corpus Callosum Abnormalities", "notes": "Structural central nervous system defects including corpus callosum abnormalities may occur."}
raw_json: {"category": "Neurologic", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This case report documents partial agenesis of the corpus callosum as a structural CNS abnormality in Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:29199884", "snippet": "Systemic findings included \"Greek warrior helmet\" facies, hypotonia, cleft palate, neonatal tooth eruption, talipes equinovarus, bilateral clinodactyly, clitoromegaly, partial agenesis of the corpus callosum, bilateral renal hypoplasia, and two atrial septal defects.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study identifies structural brain abnormalities as a manifestation in some cases of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:34572183", "snippet": "In some cases, we observed seizures, structural brain abnormalities, immunodeficiencies, and renal anomalies.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Corpus Callosum Abnormalities", "notes": "Structural central nervous system defects including corpus callosum abnormalities may occur.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abnormal corpus callosum morphology", "term": {"id": "HP:0001273", "label": "Abnormal corpus callosum morphology"}}}

name: Congenital Heart Defects
notes: Congenital heart defects occur in a substantial proportion of patients.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Cardiac", "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Congenital Heart Defects", "notes": "Congenital heart defects occur in a substantial proportion of patients."}
raw_json: {"category": "Cardiac", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This identifies cardiac defects as one of the characteristic features of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:29199884", "snippet": "Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome is a rare genetic syndrome caused by a heterozygous deletion on chromosome 4p16.3 and is characterized by a \"Greek warrior helmet\" facies, hypotonia, developmental delay, seizures, structural central nervous system defects, intrauterine growth restriction, sketelal anomalies, cardiac defects, abnormal tooth development, and hearing loss.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This case report documents specific cardiac defects (atrial septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus) in Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:33599186", "snippet": "The infant had multiple congenital anomalies; a cleft palate, microcephalia, micrognathia, renal pelvicalyceal ectasia, atrial septal defect, transvers arcus hypoplasia, patent ductus arteriosus, hypospadias and undescended testicle.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Congenital Heart Defects", "notes": "Congenital heart defects occur in a substantial proportion of patients.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Congenital heart defect", "term": {"id": "HP:0001627", "label": "Abnormal heart morphology"}}}

notes: Skeletal anomalies may include kyphosis, scoliosis, vertebral malformations, and limb abnormalities.

raw_json: {"category": "Skeletal", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This identifies skeletal anomalies as one of the characteristic features of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:29199884", "snippet": "Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome is a rare genetic syndrome caused by a heterozygous deletion on chromosome 4p16.3 and is characterized by a \"Greek warrior helmet\" facies, hypotonia, developmental delay, seizures, structural central nervous system defects, intrauterine growth restriction, sketelal anomalies, cardiac defects, abnormal tooth development, and hearing loss.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This case report documents specific skeletal abnormalities including cervical spine defects in Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:9774859", "snippet": "Midline closure defects of the cervical spine bodies, lower jaw, and skull base were seen at postmortem radiography.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "FREQUENT", "name": "Skeletal Anomalies", "notes": "Skeletal anomalies may include kyphosis, scoliosis, vertebral malformations, and limb abnormalities.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abnormality of the skeletal system", "term": {"id": "HP:0000924", "label": "Abnormality of the skeletal system"}}}

name: Renal Anomalies
notes: Renal anomalies including renal hypoplasia and oligomeganephronia may occur, particularly with larger 4p deletions.
scalar_fields_json: {"category": "Genitourinary", "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Renal Anomalies", "notes": "Renal anomalies including renal hypoplasia and oligomeganephronia may occur, particularly with larger 4p deletions."}
raw_json: {"category": "Genitourinary", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This study identifies renal anomalies as a manifestation in some cases of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:34572183", "snippet": "In some cases, we observed seizures, structural brain abnormalities, immunodeficiencies, and renal anomalies.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This identifies renal hypoplasia as a characteristic urinary tract anomaly in Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:41225980", "snippet": "It is characterized by intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), developmental delay, epilepsy, distinctive facial features, and urinary tract anomalies, particularly renal hypoplasia.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This case report documents bilateral renal hypoplasia as a systemic finding in Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome.", "reference": "PMID:29199884", "snippet": "Systemic findings included \"Greek warrior helmet\" facies, hypotonia, cleft palate, neonatal tooth eruption, talipes equinovarus, bilateral clinodactyly, clitoromegaly, partial agenesis of the corpus callosum, bilateral renal hypoplasia, and two atrial septal defects.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "frequency": "OCCASIONAL", "name": "Renal Anomalies", "notes": "Renal anomalies including renal hypoplasia and oligomeganephronia may occur, particularly with larger 4p deletions.", "phenotype_term": {"preferred_term": "Abnormality of the kidney", "term": {"id": "HP:0000077", "label": "Abnormality of the kidney"}}}
